Though it never espoused violence, the J.H.U. supported the Sri Lanka Freedom Party of Mr. Rajapaksa. As the government intensified its battle against the separatist Tamil Tigers, the monks\xe2\x80\x99 backing gave religious legitimacy to the state\xe2\x80\x99s claim of protecting the island for the Sinhalese Buddhist majority.'b'The defeat of the Tamil rebels in 2009 ended the country\xe2\x80\x99s nearly 30-year-long civil war. The B.B.S. emerged during this postwar high, deploying a selective reading of Sri Lanka\xe2\x80\x99s origins \xe2\x80\x94 excluding the contributions of indigenous and non-Sinhalese communities \xe2\x80\x94 to fan fears of an existential threat to Buddhism and justify its acts of violence.'b'At a rally in 2012, the B.B.S. leader Mr. Gnanasara likened the Sri Lankan military\xe2\x80\x99s victory to the ancient conquest of a Tamil chief by a beloved Sinhalese king. The spectators knew the story and cheered at the comparison. \xe2\x80\x9cTamils have been taught a lesson twice,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; so would other minorities if they tried to \xe2\x80\x9cchallenge Sri Lankan culture.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the past two years, hard-line groups have consolidated their political power. Think of the stereotypes: the free-spending, libertine liberal; the rock-ribbed, free-market conservative.'b'But there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing natural about this pairing between personality and such broad ideologies. Instead, the structure of our ideological divide is shaped by political messaging rather than psychological differences. In fact, 'b'our research'b', which we recently published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, suggests that the personality characteristics that make someone culturally conservative will often tend to promote left-wing economic views, favoring redistributive economic intervention by the government. How is this possible?'b'Start by considering the most influential scholarly view of how personality affects political ideology: the \xe2\x80\x9crigidity of the right\xe2\x80\x9d model. It holds that people differ from one another in terms of whether they are closed-minded and prefer what is familiar, or are open-minded and prefer diverse experiences.'b'According to this view, those with a conservative personality \xe2\x80\x94 which is thought to be implemented by basic neurocognitive and structural brain differences \xe2\x80\x94 are likely to gravitate toward a broad-based conservative ideology, both culturally and economically. A conservative personality, the view posits, makes you favor the stability and continuity of traditional cultural norms, and it makes you favor right-wing economic policy because that sort of policy will not disrupt the prevailing economic hierarchy.'b'Though very influential, the rigidity of the right model has incurred 'b'charges of ideological bias'b' within the scholarly community. But we think that there is something more fundamentally wrong with it: Most of the core disagreements between the left and right concern economic matters, and there are often decisive forces compelling those with a conservative personality to be economically left wing.'b'Our research, which we published along with Christopher J. Soto of Colby College and Yphtach Lelkes of the University of Amsterdam, was the 'b'largest cross-national test'b' of how a conservative personality style actually relates to cultural and economic attitudes. Analyzing responses from over 70,000 people from 51 countries, we found that people with a conservative personality did indeed tend to adopt culturally conservative attitudes on matters like abortion, homosexuality and immigration. On this count, the rigidity of the right model seems to be valid.'b'But when it came to economic matters related to social welfare policy and economic intervention \xe2\x80\x94 the central feature of the left-right divide in much of the world \xe2\x80\x94 the results were far different. People with a conservative personality tended to lean slightly to the left.'b'According to the political scientist Christopher Johnston of Duke and his colleagues Christopher M. Federico and Howard G. Lavine of the University of Minnesota, a conservative personality might actually pull people in two directions with respect to their economic attitudes. Prioritizing order and stability will lead to a yearning for the security that left-wing economic policies aim to provide \xe2\x80\x94 but having such a conservative personality will also lead to cultural conservatism, which, if a person is politically attentive, might indirectly lead to favoring economically conservative policy as well. Why? Political messaging.'b'Political messages often promote the view that right-wing economic preferences naturally fit with right-wing cultural preferences under a broad \xe2\x80\x9cconservative\xe2\x80\x9d banner. These messages define what constitutes an ideologically consistent package of preferences, and make people more likely to adopt a consistent ideological bundle. They make you say, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I am culturally conservative, I should also be economically conservative.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Our cross-national evidence was consistent with this argument: Over all, having a conservative personality made people lean to the left economically \xe2\x80\x94 with an important exception. Among people who were both highly attentive to politics and from countries in which left-right ideological conflict was prominent, like the United States, having a conservative personality was associated with holding right-wing economic views.'b'What does all of this mean for ideological conflict in the United States? For one thing, we must be cautious about accepting claims that a broad ideological conflict, pitting culturally traditional and free-market conservatives against culturally progressive and redistributive liberals, is a natural consequence of personality differences. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing natural about it: Such a conflict has more to do with the political messages that Americans receive about the nature of politicians\xe2\x80\x99 ideological conflict.'b'If there is nothing set about the combinations of political views we adopt, then there is nothing to say those combinations of attitudes can\xe2\x80\x99t change. Indeed, decades of research in political science have shown that the dominant packages of political attitudes often do change, as a result of messages from political elites. While such insight will not soften our hostile partisan climate, it might be helpful to keep in mind as we experience the highest levels of political polarization that the nation has seen in decades.'b'MY mother received the ransomnote on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving. It popped up on her computer screen soon after she\xe2\x80\x99d discovered that all of her files had been locked. \xe2\x80\x9cYour files are encrypted,\xe2\x80\x9d it announced. \xe2\x80\x9cTo get the key to decrypt files you have to pay 500 USD.\xe2\x80\x9d If my mother failed to pay within a week, the price would go up to $1,000. The virus is thought to infiltrate your computer when you click on a legitimate-looking attachment or through existing malware lurking on your hard drive, and once unleashed it instantly encrypts all your files, barring access to a single photo or tax receipt.'b'Everyone has the same questions when they first hear about CryptoWall:'b'Is there any other way to get rid of it besides paying the ransom? No \xe2\x80\x94 it appears to be technologically impossible for anyone to decrypt your files once CryptoWall 2.0 has locked them. (My mother had several I.T. professionals try.)'b'But should you really be handing money over to a bunch of criminals? According to the Internet Crime Complaint Center, a partnership between the F.B.I. and the National White Collar Crime Center, this answer is also no. \xe2\x80\x9cRansomware messages are an attempt to extort money,\xe2\x80\x9d one public service announcement helpfully explains. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you have received a ransomware message do not follow payment instructions and file a complaint.\xe2\x80\x9d Right. But that won\xe2\x80\x99t get you your files back. Which is why the Sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Dickson County, Tenn., recently paid a CryptoWall ransom to unlock 72,000 autopsy reports, witness statements, crime scene photographs and other documents.'b'Finally, can law enforcement at least do something to stop these attacks in the future? Probably not. Many ransomware viruses originate in Russia and other former Soviet bloc countries. The main difficulty in stopping cybercriminals isn\xe2\x80\x99t finding them, but getting foreign governments to cooperate and extradite them.'b'By the time my mom called to ask for my help, it was already Day 6 and the clock was ticking. (Literally \xe2\x80\x94 the virus comes with a countdown clock, ratcheting up the pressure to pay.) My father had already spent all week trying to convince her that losing six months of files wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the end of the world (she had last backed up her computer in May). It was pointless to argue with her. She had thought through all of her options; she wanted to pay.'b'Only, paying turned out not to be so easy; the CryptoWall hackers take only Bitcoins.'b'Picture the kind of early-adopting, hoodie-wearing member of the technocracy totally comfy with the idea of a cybercurrency neither backed nor issued by any central bank or government. Now picture the opposite of that. That is my mom. Having never so much as purchased an app in her life, my mom had no idea how to buy Bitcoins. Happily, her ransomers had anticipated this problem and included a link to a step-by-step guide, complete with pictures.'b'She\xe2\x80\x99d managed to make a cash deposit via Bank of America to the unique Bitcoin \xe2\x80\x9cwallet\xe2\x80\x9d provided by her ransomers, but since Bitcoin\xe2\x80\x99s price is extremely volatile, her payment had already fallen $25 short by the time it arrived. (Credit and debit payments can take up to six days to process.) The fastest way to send the extra $25 was to make a direct deposit at an A.T.M. that handled Bitcoin transactions. That\xe2\x80\x99s where I came in. Coin Cafe, the Bitcoin provider my mother had chosen, had an A.T.M. in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, not too far from where I lived.'b'The Bitcoin A.T.M. was not easy to find. It was housed in the second floor hallway of a cooperative work space, tucked inside an old Nynex phone booth. On one hand, I appreciated the winking irony of this sight gag. On the other hand, Fidelity Investments this was not.'b'Inside was a little white box with no buttons, just a screen, a camera eye and a money slot. I scanned in the QR code my mom had sent me. The machine whirred to life. \xe2\x80\x9cBalance query in progress,\xe2\x80\x9d it announced. This query remained in progress for the next 20 minutes during which I left three messages on Coin Cafe\xe2\x80\x99s voice mail before abandoning the booth to get some coffee and walk around in the rain.'b'The fourth time I called, a human being answered the phone and told me the problem had been fixed. I hurried back to the A.T.M., scanned in my QR code, sent some Voldemorts $25 in crisp bills and called my mom. The whole experience had not done much to allay my misgivings about Bitcoin; what did allay them was Mike Hoats, the nice bearded man Coin Cafe sent over to fix the A.T.M.'b'We got to talking after I made my payment, and he told me that, while no one at Coin Cafe believed people should fund criminal activity by paying the ransom, their job was to broker the purchase and sale of Bitcoins, which, like cash, could be used for any purpose. CryptoWall had thrust them into the unwitting role of ransomware advisers, coping with grandmothers crying on the phone at the thought of losing all their photos or small-business owners whose family income was on the line. Coin Cafe didn\xe2\x80\x99t like profiting from the victims (according to the company, these transactions are in the low single digits as a percentage of its total business), but they were downright mortified to learn that CryptoWall had anointed them as one of their Bitcoin providers of choice, with praise for their \xe2\x80\x9cfast, simple service.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s how my mom found out about Coin Cafe \xe2\x80\x94 from her ransom note.'b'This referral is only one of the handy services CryptoWall provides to ensure a more seamless customer experience. Others include the ability to \xe2\x80\x9cdecrypt one file for free\xe2\x80\x9d and a message interface one can use \xe2\x80\x9cin case of any problems with payment or having any other questions.\xe2\x80\x9d What next, I wondered. Twenty percent off when you refer this malware to a friend? Frequent virus cards? Black Friday ransom specials?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI THINK they like the idea they don\xe2\x80\x99t have to pretend they\xe2\x80\x99re not criminals,\xe2\x80\x9d Chester Wisniewski, a senior security adviser at the computer security firm Sophos, told me when I reached him in Vancouver by phone. \xe2\x80\x9cBy using the fact that they\xe2\x80\x99re criminals to scare you, it\xe2\x80\x99s just a lot easier on them.\xe2\x80\x9d They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to hire a professional translator to get their English perfect, Mr. Wisniewski explained, or engage in any of the baroque subterfuge required of someone pretending to be a Nigerian gentleman farmer who just needs a little help claiming his inheritance.'b'In addition to being criminals, these peddlers of ransomware are clearly businesspeople, skillfully appropriating all the tools of e-commerce. From branding (CryptoWall is a variant of a fearsome earlier virus called CryptoLocker, which was shut down last year) to determining what they can extort (ransomware hackers have tested the market with prices as low as $100 and as high as $800,000, which the city of Detroit refused to pay in order to have its database decrypted), these operators are, as Mr. Wisniewski put it, part of \xe2\x80\x9ca very mature, well-oiled capitalist machine.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s also an incredibly lucrative machine: Some experts estimate that CryptoLocker hackers cleared around $30 million in 100 days in 2013. And more than a million PCs worldwide have been hit with the CryptoWall virus.'b'Even after reading through numerous descriptions of CryptoWall 2.0 as \xe2\x80\x9cthe largest and most destructive ransomware threat on the Internet\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9can enormous danger for computer users,\xe2\x80\x9d I still couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help thinking this was mainly a problem for moms who persist in using big, boxy PC computers and small-town police departments. Mr. Wisniewski quickly disabused me of that notion. Although CryptoWall has primarily affected Windows computers and Android cellphones so far, there is no technological barrier that prevents the virus from infiltrating Macs like mine. And when it does, Mr. Wisniewski chuckled, I should expect the ransom to be a lot higher.'b'So what can we all do to protect ourselves? Keep our computers backed up on an independent drive or by using a cloud backup service like Carbonite, take those software update and \xe2\x80\x9cpatch\xe2\x80\x9d alerts seriously and, most of all, Beware the Attachment. (Remember: Brand-name businesses like J. Crew or Bank of America will rarely send you an attachment.)'b'Of course, this advice arrives too late for my mom. A shaman shook a small wooden rattle while chanting and dancing \xe2\x80\x94 final rites for yet another victim of a suicide epidemic that has plagued the Guaran\xc3\xad Indians of the western Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul.'b'The boy, Dedson Garcete, had hanged himself \xe2\x80\x94 one of 36 suicides among tribe members in 2014 through September, and one of about 500 among the tribe of 45,000 since 2004, according to Zelik Trajber, a pediatrician with the special secretariat for indigenous health within the Ministry of Health in Mato Grosso do Sul.'b'Indigenous peoples suffer the greatest suicide risk among cultural or ethnic groups worldwide. Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men ages 25 to 29 have a suicide rate four times higher than the general population in that same age group in Australia, according to the country\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Health.'b'In the United States, suicide is the second leading cause of death, behind accidents, for American Indian and Alaska Native men ages 15 to 34, and is two and a half times higher than the national average for that age group, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.'b'Among the indigenous in Brazil, the suicide rate was six times higher than the national average in 2013, according to a study released in October by Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s Ministry of Health. Many in the tribe face extreme discrimination and live in abject poverty close to the farmers and ranchers who occupy land that was once theirs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiving in this nonplace, they commit suicide,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maria de Lourdes Beldi de Alcantara, an anthropologist at the University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo who for years has studied adolescent suicides among the Guaran\xc3\xad.'b'Nearly 100 years ago, the Guaran\xc3\xad, who today live primarily in Brazil and Paraguay, were forced off their ancestral land when the Brazilian government granted farmers and ranchers the legal title to that land. That one day they can live another kind of life, a better one.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'TEL AVIV \xe2\x80\x94 Here is Amos Oz on writing a novel: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is like reconstructing the whole of Paris from Lego bricks. It\xe2\x80\x99s about three-quarters-of-a-million small decisions. It\xe2\x80\x99s not about who will live and who will die and who will go to bed with whom. Those are the easy ones. It\xe2\x80\x99s about choosing adjectives and adverbs and punctuation. These are molecular decisions that you have to take and nobody will appreciate, for the same reason that nobody ever pays attention to a single note in a symphony in a concert hall, except when the note is false. So you have to work very hard in order for your readers not to note a single false note. That is the business of three-quarters-of-a-million decisions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I found Oz at the end of his working day, around 8:30 in the morning. He\xe2\x80\x99d been up since 4, as usual, taken a brisk walk, as usual, drunk a coffee, as usual, and settled down at his desk around 5:30. His good working hours for all those decisions are between 5:30 and 8:30. With a novel called \xe2\x80\x9cJudas\xe2\x80\x9d published in Hebrew last year (but not yet out in English), he is at work on something new, but, he says, \xe2\x80\x9cin this business there are many more miscarriages and abortions than live births.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Treason and loyalty are themes of \xe2\x80\x9cJudas.\xe2\x80\x9d They have been on Oz\xe2\x80\x99s mind. \xe2\x80\x9cThe protagonist points out that almost every significant political leader in history was called a traitor by many of his own people \xe2\x80\x94 Abraham Lincoln, de Gaulle, Gorbachev, Begin, Sadat, Rabin,\xe2\x80\x9d the novelist told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThe day people in this country start calling Netanyahu a traitor I will know that something may change.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Oz, the conscience of a certain liberal and secular Israel still committed to a two-state outcome, called Benjamin Netanyahu \xe2\x80\x9ca coward, a man who prefers inaction to action.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been in power for some nine years,\xe2\x80\x9d Oz said. \xe2\x80\x9cIn those nine years he has not made one, even one, really controversial decision either way.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The result is drift, a status quo that is violent, or brewing with violence. This may be a useful lesson.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But, I asked, after almost a half-century of occupation of the West Bank, is a two-state peace not on life support? \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have sad moments, and I have encouraging moments. He sees the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative as a \xe2\x80\x9cvery reasonable starting point.\xe2\x80\x9d Perhaps, he suggested, \xe2\x80\x9cthe present day is the best chance we had in 110 years to conclude the conflict altogether because Egypt, Jordan, the Saudis, the gulf states, even Assad in Syria, all have a more immediate enemy than Israel, and they are more willing to make a historical compromise with Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But more traitors are needed. The thing about traitor-leaders is that they break the rules that seemed immutable.'b"There are none on the horizon, but you never know. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m old enough to know that when somebody says words like \xe2\x80\x98never,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98forever,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98the rest of eternity\xe2\x80\x99 in the Middle East, it usually means something like six months to 30 years. They are not born again but they change, somewhat. In fact that is how I make a living, by observing and describing the way people change.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Change and three-quarters-of-a-million decisions and before you know it, something new and original, even something unimaginable, is born.'b'LOS ANGELES \xe2\x80\x94 AS Republicans take control of Congress this month, at the top of their to-do list is changing how the government measures the impact of tax cuts on federal revenue: namely, to switch from so-called static scoring to \xe2\x80\x9cdynamic\xe2\x80\x9d scoring. While seemingly arcane, the change could have significant, negative consequences for enacting sustainable, long-term fiscal policies.'b'Whenever new tax legislation is proposed, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office \xe2\x80\x9cscores\xe2\x80\x9d it, to estimate whether the bill would raise more or less revenue than existing law would.'b'In preparing estimates, scorekeepers try to predict how people will respond to a new tax law. For example, if Congress contemplates raising the excise tax on cigarettes, scorekeepers consider existing trends in cigarette consumption, the likelihood that the higher taxes will induce some smokers to quit, and the prospect that higher prices will increase incentives for cigarette smuggling. There are no truly \xe2\x80\x9cstatic\xe2\x80\x9d revenue estimates.'b'These conventional estimates do not, however, include any indirect feedback effects that tax law changes might have on overall national income. In other words, they do not incorporate macroeconomic behavioral changes.'b'Dynamic scoring does. Proponents point out, correctly, that if a tax proposal is large enough, then those sorts of feedback effects can aim the entire economy on a slightly different path.'b'Such proponents argue that conventional projections are skewed against tax cuts, because they do not consider that cutting taxes could lead to higher economic output, which would make up at least some of the lost revenues. They maintain that dynamic scoring will, therefore, be both more neutral and more accurate than current methodologies.'b'But the reality is more complex. In order to look at the effects across the entire economy, dynamic modeling relies on many simplifying assumptions, like how well people can predict the future or how much they care about their children\xe2\x80\x99s future consumption versus their own.'b'Economists disagree on the answers, and different models\xe2\x80\x99 predicted feedback effects vary wildly, depending on the values selected for those uncertain assumptions. The resulting estimates are likely to incorporate greater uncertainty about the magnitude of any revenue-estimating errors and greater exposure to the risk of a political thumb on the scale.'b'Consider the nonpartisan scorekeepers\xe2\x80\x99 estimates of the consequences of a tax-reform bill proposed last year by Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan. Using different models and plausible inputs, the scorekeepers estimated that, under the bill, total gross domestic product might rise between 0.1 percent and 1.6 percent over the next decade \xe2\x80\x94 a 16-fold spread in projected outcomes. Which result should be the basis of congressional scorekeeping?'b'But the bigger problems lie deeper. Federal deficits are on an unsustainable path (as it happens, because of undertaxation, not excessive spending). Simply cutting taxes against the headwind of structural deficits leads to lower growth, as government borrowing soaks up an ever-increasing share of savings.'b'The most optimistic dynamic models get around this by assuming that the world today is in fiscal equilibrium, where the deficit does not grow continuously as a percentage of gross domestic product. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not true. If you add the reality of spiraling deficits into those models, they don\xe2\x80\x99t work.'b'To make these models work, scorekeepers must arbitrarily assume either that we tax more and spend less today than is really the case \xe2\x80\x94 which is what they did for the Camp bill \xe2\x80\x94 or assume that a tax cut today will be followed by a spending cut or tax increase tomorrow. Economists describe such a move as \xe2\x80\x9cmaking counterfactual assumptions\xe2\x80\x9d; the rest of us call it \xe2\x80\x9cmaking stuff up.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In practice, these models are political statements. They show the biggest economic effects by assuming that tax cuts are financed by unspecified future spending cuts. The smaller size of government, not the tax cuts by themselves, largely drives the models\xe2\x80\x99 results.'b'Further, the models are not a step toward more neutral revenue estimates, because they assume that, while individuals make productive investments, government does not. In reality, government spending contributes significantly to economic output. Truly dynamic modeling would weigh the forgone economic returns of government investments against the economic gains from lower taxes.'b'The Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 interest in dynamic scoring is not the result of a million-economist march on Washington; it comes from political factions convinced that tax cuts are the panacea for all economic ills. They will use dynamic scoring to justify a tax cut that, under conventional scorekeeping, loses revenue.'b'When revenues do in fact decline and deficits rise, those same proponents will push for steep cuts in government insurance or investment programs, because they will claim that the models demand it. That is what lies inside the Trojan horse of dynamic scoring.'b'Imagine a lender demanding that you miss a payment. That is the situation described 'b'in a recent article in The Wall Street Journal'b'. In 2013, GSO Capital Partners, the debt-investing arm of the private equity firm the Blackstone Group, refused to renew a $122.3 million loan to the Spanish gambling company Codere unless it delayed paying interest on other existing debt. Why? It turns out that GSO had placed a bet that Codere\xe2\x80\x99s existing debt would not be paid on time. When, lo and behold, the payment was late, GSO collected on its bet.'b'The bet in this scenario was a credit default swap, in which one party to the transaction \xe2\x80\x94 say, a bank, hedge fund, insurer or other institutional investor \xe2\x80\x94 agrees to pay the other party in the event of a bond default. Credit default swaps, a type of derivative, can be used to hedge against losses on bonds that investors own, or to speculate on how the underlying companies will perform.'b'If this sounds familiar, it should. In the years leading up to the financial crisis, banks and investors gorged on toxic mortgage bonds that were supposedly \xe2\x80\x9cinsured\xe2\x80\x9d against loss with credit default swaps. When the bonds went bad, many swaps turned out to be worthless as well, necessitating bailouts to cushion catastrophic losses.'b'The Dodd-Frank financial reform law was supposed to curb speculation in swaps. But as The Journal has reported, hedge funds are increasingly using swaps to wager on whether weak firms will live or die. RadioShack, the troubled consumer electronics retailer, is one of several prominent examples. In December, RadioShack\xe2\x80\x99s total debt came to about $1.4 billion, but swaps outstanding on the performance of the debt totaled $23.5 billion. Similarly, J.C. Penney, the ailing department store chain, had total debt of some $8.7 billion, but swaps outstanding on the debt totaled $19.3 billion.'b'Those gaps suggest excessive speculation, though it is hard, if not impossible, to gauge the precise exposure of funds to big losses. What is known is that a hedge fund that is betting on a company\xe2\x80\x99s default has an incentive to push it over the edge. Conversely, a fund that is betting a troubled company will not default has an incentive to keep it afloat, at least long enough to avoid a big payout. Either way, the company becomes a pawn in a financial game.'b'Speculative activity is likely to increase. Last month, Congress repealed an anti-speculation provision of Dodd-Frank that would have prevented federally insured banks from conducting several types of swap transactions. In addition, the Federal Reserve recently gave the banks two extra years to meet a Dodd-Frank provision requiring them to sell their investments in private equity funds and hedge funds.'b'The next crisis will differ from the last crisis in its origins and effects. But it is probably safe to assume that sooner or later, poorly regulated credit derivatives will again play a role in damaging the economy.'b'Mario Cuomo, the former governor of New York, came on the political scene with a surpassing idealism about the potential of government and a passion for defending its power to address the plights and hopes of ordinary citizens. Well before his three terms ended, he had become an eloquent champion of those values for the entire country.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAt the heart of the matter we are bound one to another,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cuomo declared in his keynote speech that electrified the 1984 Democratic National Convention, a speech many Americans replayed on the Internet after Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s death on Thursday.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMake this nation remember how futures are built,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'he said'b', in stirring words that resounded with New Deal liberalism and directly challenged President Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s view that \xe2\x80\x9cGovernment is not the solution to our problem, government is the problem.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s devotion to public service was a rebuke of that idea. His career may have been rich in might-have-beens \xe2\x80\x94 a presidential run? a Supreme Court seat? \xe2\x80\x94 but Mr. Cuomo was resolutely true to himself at critical moments.'b'He stoutly defended abortion rights in the face of opposition from the leaders of his Catholic faith. He repeatedly vetoed attempts to restore the death penalty in the face of legislators\xe2\x80\x99 grandstanding. As a gifted mediator, he helped settle a riot at Sing Sing prison in which 19 hostage guards were freed, in contrast to the 1971 Attica prison riot in which 10 hostages and 33 inmates died.'b'No one seemed more refreshing in the grueling politics of New York than Mr. Cuomo when he came out of Queens in the 1970s to challenge City Hall\xe2\x80\x99s condemnation of a working-class Corona neighborhood for redevelopment. The courtroom orator cited each lawn Madonna and backyard vineyard of residents he knew by name.'b'In his convention speech more than a decade later, he called for government to defend the full array of powerless Americans, from unemployed steelworkers to the homeless in Chicago. He had burnished this message as a political neophyte and incumbent, always telling of his parents\xe2\x80\x99 immigrant strivings and hopes. His death is being mourned by generations of New Yorkers, and his son, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, in his own second inaugural address on Thursday, paid homage to his father\xe2\x80\x99s beliefs.'b'Much of what Mr. Cuomo said at the 1984 convention feels prophetically relevant in today\xe2\x80\x99s debate about the wealth gap between the top 1 percenters and all the Americans below. He excoriated Republicans for a policy of \xe2\x80\x9cmake the rich richer,\xe2\x80\x9d warning that the nation was more of a \xe2\x80\x9ctale of two cities\xe2\x80\x9d than a \xe2\x80\x9cshining city on the hill.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For all his idealism, Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s years as governor were dogged by economic recession that blunted his hopes to leave great programs and innovation as his legacy. He had to cut services and scratch for scarce revenue.'b'What he certainly left, however, was a demonstration that the power to inspire citizens to demand a more humane society and better government is a vital gift.'b'It has taken far too long, but federal authorities are finally asking the right questions about how New York\xe2\x80\x99s part-time lawmakers make money apart from their legislative salaries. The Times 'b'reported'b' Tuesday that investigators are examining \xe2\x80\x9csubstantial\xe2\x80\x9d secret payments from a small law firm to one of New York\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful politicians, Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly. So far, there has been no real explanation from Mr. Silver.'b'A small band of reformers are hopeful that United States Attorney Preet Bharara and the Federal Bureau of Investigation may soon be able to shed light on how New York legislators amass income and whether it is connected to legislative payoffs that in effect amount to bribery.'b'Historically, legislators who are practicing lawyers, like Mr. Silver and Senator Dean Skelos, who will be running the State Senate, have provided only general outlines of income and its sources, partly on the specious grounds that saying more would violate attorney-client privilege.'b'Mr. Silver has for years acknowledged that he is associated with Weitz &amp; Luxenberg, a personal injury firm. His most recent financial disclosure form showed about $650,000 from legal work. Federal authorities are now asking questions not only about the money he has disclosed but about what he has done to earn the large, undisclosed sums he has received for nearly a decade from Goldberg &amp; Iryami, P.C. The Goldberg firm specializes in challenging tax assessments and seeking tax reductions, which is not known to be Mr. Silver\xe2\x80\x99s main area of expertise.'b'State ethics laws are incredibly feeble, and penalties for violations can be little more than a tap on the wrist for someone as wealthy as Mr. Silver. Gov. Andrew Cuomo proposed stricter disclosure requirements in 2014 and got almost nowhere. Mr. Bharara and his federal troops are combing through data left behind after Mr. Cuomo abruptly shut down the Moreland Commission on ethics, which was investigating the issue. They may be able to find the answers that have eluded others. In time, detailed disclosures of outside income should be required by state law.'b'When Hillary Clinton thinks about running for president, do you think she contemplates the fact that no Democrat has been elected to succeed another Democrat since James Buchanan in 1856?'b'We bring you this factoid in honor of the beginning of the 2016 election season. (Only 55 weeks until the New Hampshire primary!) We\xe2\x80\x99ve got so much time. It\xe2\x80\x99s the perfect moment for random irrelevant trivia about presidential elections of the past. Which, to be honest, is my favorite part.'b'Consider that succession information for a minute. We have had Democratic vice presidents step into office when the Democratic president died. But the voters haven\xe2\x80\x99t gone to the polls and elected one Democrat to follow another since before the Civil War.'b'What do you think this means? Actually, there weren\xe2\x80\x99t all that many Republicans who were elected to succeed Republicans either. Particularly if you acknowledge that Rutherford B. Hayes 'b'stole the election from Samuel Tilden'b'. James Garfield did it, but then he was assassinated. William Howard Taft followed Theodore Roosevelt, and then Roosevelt came to hate Taft so much that he ran as a third-party candidate in 1912, throwing the election to Woodrow Wilson. Herbert Hoover succeeded Calvin Coolidge, and we know how well that one worked out. Finally, George H.W. Bush was elected after Ronald Reagan.'b'Wow, think about that. The only president elected to follow a member of his own party without creating some sort of cosmic disaster was George H.W. Bush. No wonder he always looks so cheerful.'b'These factoids refer only to elections between Republicans and Democrats. Even with nearly two years to go (but seven months until the Iowa straw poll!), we don\xe2\x80\x99t have enough time to deal with the Whigs. Our two current parties began duking it out in \xe2\x80\x94 yes! \xe2\x80\x94 1856, when Buchanan ran against the first Republican presidential candidate, John Charles Fr\xc3\xa9mont. Fr\xc3\xa9mont was an explorer whose political enemies claimed had resorted to cannibalism during one unfortunate Western expedition. I am just telling you this to make it clear how interesting American history can be.'b'Anyhow, Buchanan won and went on triumphantly to become possibly the worst president ever. Almost every chief executive in American history has his defenders. I had a very nice time last year talking with people who feel Warren Harding hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been given his due. But you very seldom run into fans of Buchanan, the man who cozied up to slaveholders and failed to stop Southern secession.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe was terrible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jean Baker, a professor of history at Goucher College and Buchanan biographer. That\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s so ironic,\xe2\x80\x9d said Baker.'b'Did I mention that Buchanan was also the last former secretary of state elected president?'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t think Clinton-Buchanan commonalities are likely to be a big concern. (Only 58 weeks until the South Carolina primary!)'b'Still, it never hurts to push a little random presidential history into the mix, if only to liven things up for the next year or so. Any suggestions? I am in the market for some comparisons between Ted Cruz and Millard Fillmore.'b'But about James Buchanan: Professor Baker thinks his unwillingness to stand up to the South was because, at least partly, of his close friendships with Southern politicians. (He described the abolition movement as \xe2\x80\x9cweak, powerless and soon to be forgotten\xe2\x80\x9d and referred to white men from the South as \xe2\x80\x9cthe chivalrous race.\xe2\x80\x9d) Buchanan roomed with William King of Alabama during their Senate days, and the pair were so close that people referred to them as \xe2\x80\x9cSiamese twins.\xe2\x80\x9d King went on to become the only bachelor vice president, under Franklin Pierce. Buchanan, you may recall, was our only bachelor president.'b'Baker said that when she was writing her book on Buchanan, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., her editor, demanded that she \xe2\x80\x9ctake a position on whether he was gay or not.\xe2\x80\x9d She demurred. Baker wishes she could have said for sure: \xe2\x80\x9cIt would have been one of the few things I could present as positive about James Buchanan.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Well, he was kind to his nephews and nieces. He had two pet bald eagles, which sounds sort of interesting. And he was the only president who hailed from Pennsylvania. Perhaps I should point out that Joe Biden was born in Scranton.'b'Sometimes an award means more to the giver than the recipient. That is probably the case with the French government\xe2\x80\x99s decision to give the Legion of Honor to Thomas Piketty, the economist and author of the critically acclaimed book about inequality, \xe2\x80\x9cCapital in the Twenty-First Century,\xe2\x80\x9d who 'b'says'b' he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want the award.'b'While he is not the first person to refuse the honor, his decision is notable because it comes at a time when the government of President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande has been struggling to revive the slow-growing French economy. Mr. Piketty says it is not \xe2\x80\x9cthe government\xe2\x80\x99s role to decide who is honorable.\xe2\x80\x9d He went on to add insult to injury by saying the award givers \xe2\x80\x9cwould do better to concentrate on reviving growth in France and Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Legion of Honor, which was 'b'created by'b' Napoleon Bonaparte, has a history of controversy. Mr. Sartre 'b'also refused'b' the Nobel Prize for Literature. And there is a tradition of Britons like the singer David Bowie 'b'rejecting royal honors'b'.'b'It is not hard to see why the French government would want to honor Mr. Piketty. In the book, Mr. Piketty also proposes a global wealth tax to address inequality.'b'While Mr. Piketty has basked in acclaim, Mr. Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s economic policies have made him deeply unpopular. And recent 'b'polls'b' have found that Mr. Hollande would get fewer votes in a contest against the right-wing politician Marine Le Pen and his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy.'b'As much as political leaders might think that official awards are about honoring achievement, they\xe2\x80\x99re also about sharing in reflected glory. In this case, Mr. Piketty doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to want to share.'b'DAVIS, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 IT\xe2\x80\x99S been widely observed that in recent elections men have leaned Republican and women Democratic. A key element of that gender gap is often assumed to be a difference in attitudes to women\xe2\x80\x99s reproductive rights.'b'The perception that men and women have divergent views on abortion has persisted over time. The line popularized by Gloria Steinem that \xe2\x80\x9cif men could get pregnant, abortion would be a sacrament\xe2\x80\x9d proposes that a male-female divide over this social issue is more or less a biological given.'b'The polling confounds such stereotypes. 'b'The General Social Survey'b', which has been tracking American opinions for decades, includes the question of whether a woman should be allowed to get an abortion if she \xe2\x80\x9cwants it for any reason.\xe2\x80\x9d In 17 of the 23 years that this question has been asked, men have answered \xe2\x80\x9cyes\xe2\x80\x9d to a greater extent than women. The average difference was about 1.5 percentage points \xe2\x80\x94 a small but consistent gender gap, if not the one people seem to expect.'b'So what is it about women that makes them less enthusiastic than men about abortion on demand? Again, the survey offers answers. Using a common statistical method, one can determine the effect of different variables on an outcome of interest \xe2\x80\x94 in this case, the odds that someone will agree or disagree with the question. This reveals that the difference between men and women is not, in fact, likely because of their sex, but because of other factors that happen to correlate with sex.'b'As it happens, religious attendance and biblical literalism, as well as political ideology, were all highly predictive of attitudes toward abortion. Being Hispanic was also associated with being opposed to abortion on demand (even allowing for other variables, such as religiosity).'b'In contrast, sex and age were usually not independently significant. Probably the mediating factor here is that, according to most surveys, women tend to be more religious than men.'b'While, on the whole, there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a major difference in the sexes\xe2\x80\x99 attitudes toward abortion, there is one when we separate men and women by ideology. If we look at the data since 2000 (to get a more contemporary perspective), on the liberal end of the ideological spectrum men are consistently less supportive of abortion on demand than women. On the conservative end of the spectrum, it\xe2\x80\x99s women who like abortion on demand less than men do.'b'In other words, conservative women are the most anti-abortion segment of the population, and liberal women are the most in favor of abortion rights. You might say that the more significant difference here is not between men and women, but among women.'b'It may be that some have generalized this difference \xe2\x80\x94 men being less enthusiastic about abortion on demand among liberals \xe2\x80\x94 to the whole population. 'b'The critic Pauline Kael\xe2\x80\x99s 1972 assertion'b' that she personally knew only one person who voted for President Richard M. Nixon has become a favorite illustration of the cultural isolation of liberal elites. But this may simply be the reality, that Americans are 'b'ideologically polarized and inhabit different'b' and mutually exclusive social worlds.'b'Stereotypes flourish in ignorance. Liberal and conservative perceptions of one another can be ignorant and patronizing because they have so little personal experience of one another. Intriguingly, 'b'research by the social psychologists Jesse Graham, Brian A. Nozek and Jonathan Haidt'b' has shown that liberals exhibit the least accurate perception of those with opposing political views.'b'Our liking for black-and-white versions of reality is belied by their more shaded truths. Even among \xe2\x80\x9cextremely liberal\xe2\x80\x9d women in the General Social Survey, over 25 percent did not accept an unequivocal abortion-rights position. Meanwhile, among \xe2\x80\x9cextremely conservative\xe2\x80\x9d women, nearly one-fifth (18.2 percent) did.'b'So, yes, there is a large gap between these ideologically polarized positions, but we miss a substantial proportion of the electorate if all we apprehend is the stylized cartoon. Nuance goes out the window when slogans about the \xe2\x80\x9cwar on women\xe2\x80\x9d or the \xe2\x80\x9cliberal media\xe2\x80\x9d dominate public discourse.'b'All this has important consequences for a pluralistic society in which politics aspires to be the art of persuasion. Abortion is arguably the most polarizing social issue in the United States, and 'b'despite the data at our fingertips'b', many succumb to caricatures of their opponents.'b'A greater engagement with the facts would enable those who support abortion rights to consider why so many women do not, rather than dismissing their political opponents as motivated by misogyny or false consciousness. Equally, looking at the 'b'skewed racial demographics of abortion'b' might encourage conservatives to reconsider the idea that reproductive justice is purely a concern of privileged white feminists.'b'We live in a world with a surfeit of information at our service. It is our choice whether we seek out data that reinforce our biases or choose to look at the world in a critical, rational manner, and allow reality to bend our preconceptions. In the long run, the truth will work better for us than our cherished fictions.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cMario M.
