Business visas, without exception, have to be obtained in advance from an Egyptian embassy.'b'Ms. Dunne contacted the embassy on Dec. 8 and was made aware of the visa requirements. She applied on Dec. 10, but failed to provide a passport photograph or pay the required fees. Upon being notified by the consular staff that the processing time for a visa is 10 days, she asked to withdraw her application. Clearly, she decided to take her chances at the airport, hoping to get a tourist visa. She was denied entry for failing to comply with the visa requirements.'b'Ms. Dunne\xe2\x80\x99s views, research interests or scholarly distinction are irrelevant to the issue at hand. Anyone visiting Egypt on business, however distinguished he or she might be, must respect Egyptian laws and regulations if he wishes to enter Egypt. This requirement is not in any way unusual or unreasonable, nor is it something that only Egypt requires.'b'Violation of United States visa requirements, for instance, results in the immediate denial of entry, and entry upon false pretense (such as conducting business after entering on a tourist visa) makes one liable to prosecution. Egypt is entitled to the same right to respect for its sovereignty and laws.'b'MOHAMED TAWFIK'b'\nAmbassador of Egypt'b'\nWashington, Dec. 18, 2014'b''b''b'HONG KONG \xe2\x80\x94 A FEW years back I got a call from a film director based in China who had read one of my detective novels. \xe2\x80\x9cCan you help me write a screenplay for a crime story?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cThe tricky thing is that it\xe2\x80\x99s set in Beijing, so no crime can be involved.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Welcome to the world of screenwriting for China, where crime stories are crime free, ghost tales have no ghosts and crooked politicians can\xe2\x80\x99t be crooked.'b'China has a large film industry and the second-biggest box office in the world, but few people outside the country have ever watched a Chinese movie released there: Once you\xe2\x80\x99ve seen one acrobatic hero single-handedly dispatch an enemy platoon, you\xe2\x80\x99ve seen a lifetime\xe2\x80\x99s worth. For that, you can blame the rules of film censorship in China, and a Chinese government extremely sensitive about how the nation is portrayed.'b'No one can start making a film in China without submitting the plot to the State General Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (SGAPPRFT), an agency set up to administer government-owned media but best known (and feared) as a committee of censors. If any organization from outside mainland China is involved, including Hong Kong partners, a full screenplay must be submitted for review. Once approved, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be modified, meaning actors and directors must resist any urge to improvise during filming.'b'At irregular intervals the agency provides a list of unmentionables. Sex scenes or depictions of \xe2\x80\x9cexcessive drinking, smoking and other bad habits\xe2\x80\x9d are a no-go. \xe2\x80\x9cPropagating passive or negative outlook on life, worldview and value system\xe2\x80\x9d is banned; so is \xe2\x80\x9cstirring up ambivalence and conflicts between different religions or sects, and between believers and nonbelievers, causing disharmony in the community.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The vetting committee might reject a story line for being \xe2\x80\x9cunscientific,\xe2\x80\x9d because, say, it features time travel. It also bans \xe2\x80\x9chistorical untruths,\xe2\x80\x9d which, this being China, often means historical truths.'b'The ethnicity of villains is a major concern as well. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s about international crime, the bad guy must not be Chinese,\xe2\x80\x9d explained a Hong Kong screenwriter with 25 years\xe2\x80\x99 experience. (He asked not to be identified for fear of being blacklisted.) Furthermore, the crime must not be initiated within China\xe2\x80\x99s borders, as if the land itself were somehow pure. All characters in the uniformed services must be good guys. Government employees may never be corrupt. There are no prostitutes in China.'b'Getting a SGAPPRFT permit is just the first hurdle. If the hero is a monk or the setting is a temple or a church, the script will also require a permit from the State Administration for Religious Affairs. If it\xe2\x80\x99s a spy movie, national security agents will have to vet it. For cop shows, you need approval from the police\xe2\x80\x99s so-called art department.'b'Ghost stories are farcically problematic. In the spring of 2006, an online novel by Zhang Muye called \xe2\x80\x9cGui Chui Deng\xe2\x80\x9d (literally \xe2\x80\x9cGhost Blows Out the Light\xe2\x80\x9d) was enormously popular. It was read by millions. There was much excited discussion about a print version and an international movie adaptation. Then the project stalled. The government-licensed version of the book published in print was purged of any reference to the supernatural, and with that, the film project vanished, too.'b'At least half of Hong Kong movies today are co-produced with mainland organizations, and screenwriters here are also having to toe the Beijing line. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why we usually make \xe2\x80\x98ancient swordsman\xe2\x80\x99 films, or stories that happen in the period before the founding of the New China,\xe2\x80\x9d the Hong Kong screenwriter explained. He meant that you can show something negative in mainland China only so long as it happened before the Communist revolution in 1949 \xe2\x80\x94 but be careful not to portray that period as a golden era, because for that you might get censored.'b'Can a good story be written under such conditions? It\xe2\x80\x99s difficult. Some screenwriters have managed through cunning: One director squeaked a crime movie set in Hong Kong past the censors after claiming the action took place before the transfer in 1997, while the territory was still under the rule of those evil Brits.'b'More often, the rules kill creativity. The 2002 Hong Kong movie \xe2\x80\x9cInfernal Affairs,\xe2\x80\x9d a gripping tale about a triad member who infiltrates the police, was remade in Hollywood as \xe2\x80\x9cThe Departed,\xe2\x80\x9d which won four Oscars, including one for best adapted screenplay. In the original, the gangster antihero ultimately avoids being exposed by killing someone in his own gang. Is he still faking it, or has he become the top cop he was pretending to be? In the version of the film that was reshot in China, the ending is a clunker: Confronted by police officers who accuse him of being a mole, he turns in his badge without a word.'b'That crime story I co-wrote with the Chinese director had to be rejiggered multiple times. It eventually resulted in an implausible tale about an Italian businessman who flies into Beijing, steals a huge cache of art treasures, and flies out while pursued by noble detectives of Chinese origin. It was never filmed, to my relief.'b'The problem is not about to go away. According to Xinhua, the state-run news agency, China\xe2\x80\x99s uncompromising president, Xi Jinping, told a forum of writers in October, \xe2\x80\x9cThe arts must serve the people and serve socialism.\xe2\x80\x9d Anthony Lee, a Hong Kong Polytechnic University lecturer on entertainment, said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe buzz in the industry is that the toughness of China\xe2\x80\x99s new leader is making things harder, not easier.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Screenwriters may find some hope in the fact that in the long run the Chinese public, and investors, will demand global standards of story writing. On a domestic airline in China recently, I noted that a movie showing a lone Chinese hero defeating a Japanese horde was playing on drop-down screens. Not one passenger seemed to be watching it. Instead many were watching Hollywood films on portable devices.'b'THE annual ritual of the New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolution \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99ll lose 10 pounds, get my finances in order, be more patient with my family, feel more grateful \xe2\x80\x94 misses the point. We try to steel our wills to do what we already know we should be doing. Kick-in-the-pants reminders, however stern, are missed opportunities for genuine self-renewal. (Not to mention that the shelf life of any motivational juice we generate in January tends to expire in February.)'b'The turning over of a new year is an opportunity to create ourselves anew. How? The key, I suggest, is in shifting our understanding of the choices we make. For many people, the most important choices in life are sources of agony, dread, paralysis \xe2\x80\x94 even depression or suicide. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have to be like this.'b'A hypothetical example: Eve works as a textbook editor at a Boston publishing house and was approached by a small but prestigious imprint on the West Coast that was looking for a fiction editor. The job would be a big promotion, with a significant raise, and Eve had always wanted to work in fiction.'b'But Eve is in crisis. Should she move her husband and young daughter from their cozy life in Boston, her home of 15 years, to the wilds of California? If she stays, will she be forsaking the opportunity of a lifetime? If she moves, will her new boss turn out to be a jerk? Will her child be bullied at school? What if her husband can\xe2\x80\x99t find a good job? Will the family quarrel, the marriage dissolve, her boss fire her for being incompetent, and she and her child end up on food stamps in a homeless shelter?'b'Many people are like Eve and see their choices as, in essence, problems of computation. But choosing between jobs is not like computing the distance between Memphis and Mumbai. The view of choice as a matter of calculating maximal value is assumed in cost-benefit analysis, government policy making and much of economic theory. It\xe2\x80\x99s even embedded in the apps you can download that purport to help you decide whether to buy a new car, get married or change jobs.'b'At the heart of this model is a simple assumption: that what you should choose is always determined by facts in the world about which option has more value \xe2\x80\x94 facts that, if only you were smart enough to discover, would make decision-making relatively easy.'b'But the assumption is false. When we compute distances, there are only three possibilities: one distance is more than, less than or equal to another. Similarly, when we compute value, there are only three possibilities: one thing is better than, worse than or just as good as another. But we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t assume that goodness is like distance. Values don\xe2\x80\x99t have the same structure as facts.'b'Options can be \xe2\x80\x9con a par\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 different in value while being in the same overall neighborhood. If your alternatives are on a par, you can\xe2\x80\x99t make a mistake of reason in choosing one instead of the other. Since one isn\xe2\x80\x99t better than the other, you can\xe2\x80\x99t choose wrongly. But nor are they equally good. When alternatives are on a par, when the world doesn\xe2\x80\x99t determine a single right thing to do, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that value writ large has been exhausted. Instead of looking outward to find the value that determines what you should do, you can look inward to what you can stand behind, commit to, resolve to throw yourself behind. By committing to an option, you can confer value on it.'b'Of course, this isn\xe2\x80\x99t to say that you should commit to being a first-class jerk, pedophile or murderer. That\xe2\x80\x99s because being a jerk is not on a par with being a good person.'b'When we choose between options that are on a par, we make ourselves the authors of our own lives. Instead of being led by the nose by what we imagine to be facts of the world, we should instead recognize that sometimes the world is silent about what we should do. In those cases, we can create value for ourselves by committing to an option. By doing so, we not only create value for ourselves but we also (re)create ourselves. Eve might resolve to make her life in Boston. Someone else, in her shoes, might resolve to start a new life in California. There is no error here, only different resolutions that create different sorts of people.'b'So Eve, faced with her choice, should reflect on what kind of person she can be. Can she be someone who abandons a contented life for a new adventure? A choice between alternatives that are on a par is a precious opportunity to create the sort of person she can commit to being, by committing to being that sort of person.'b'Many of the choices we face in the new year will be between alternatives that are on a par. Our task then is to reflect on what kind of person we can commit to being when making those choices. Can we commit to forgoing a much-needed new car and give the money to charity instead? Can we commit to staying in a secure 9-to-5 job rather than starting the business we\xe2\x80\x99ve always dreamed of? Can we commit to having a parent with Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s move in with us, rather than paying to put her in a nursing home?'b'So in this new year, let\xe2\x80\x99s not do the same old, same old; let\xe2\x80\x99s not resolve to work harder at being the selves that we already are. Instead, let\xe2\x80\x99s resolve to make ourselves into the selves that we can commit to being.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 WHY do we have such punitive attitudes toward old people? Granted, the ancients did hideous things to elders who were unable to work but still needed food and care, but in more recent times, that had changed: In 18th-century New England, it was common for people to make themselves seem older by 'b'adding 'b'years to their real age, rather than subtracting them.'b'Once upon a time, \xe2\x80\x9csenile\xe2\x80\x9d just meant old, without being pejorative. Even \xe2\x80\x9cgeriatric\xe2\x80\x9d was originally a value-free term, rather than part of the lexicon of contempt toward old people.'b'Yet today, the language used to describe the changing age composition of the population is little short of apocalyptic. We\xe2\x80\x99re told that the \xe2\x80\x9cgraying of America\xe2\x80\x9d is an \xe2\x80\x9cagequake\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cdemographic time bomb.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Older people are likely to be seen as a burden and a drain on resources, rather than a resource in themselves. Their only contribution, it seems, is to make worse the \xe2\x80\x9cdependency ratio,\xe2\x80\x9d a term that enshrines dubious assumptions about who will be financially dependent on whom.'b'In 2050, 'b'Americans age 65 and over are predicted to almost double in number to 83.7 million'b', one-fifth of the population. An aging population does pose real challenges, but increasing numbers of people of working age (as traditionally defined) are unemployed today, while growing numbers continue to work beyond pensionable age.'b'In reality, age can no longer be neatly correlated with economic activity. In particular, old people are themselves significant providers of care, notably the child care provided by grandparents.'b'To be sure, some older public figures attain \xe2\x80\x9cnational treasure\xe2\x80\x9d status, as cuddly, unthreatening George Burns-type figures. And while \xe2\x80\x9cageist\xe2\x80\x9d language demeans and 'b'caregivers\xe2\x80\x99 pay remains poor'b', we no longer cast old people out into the wilds. Instead, innovative services and goods are developing that seek to capitalize on the \xe2\x80\x9csilver dollar.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But the social bias is real, too. When a large sample of Facebook groups created by 20- to 29-year-olds was 'b'examined by a team based at the Yale School of Public Health'b', three-quarters of the groups were found to denigrate old people. More than a third advocated banning old people from public activities like shopping.'b'Such \xe2\x80\x9cgerontophobia\xe2\x80\x9d is harmful because we internalize it. Ageism 'b'has been described as prejudice against one\xe2\x80\x99s future self'b'. It tells us that age is our defining characteristic and that, as midnight strikes on a milestone birthday, we will become nothing but old \xe2\x80\x94 emptied of our passions, abilities and experience, infused instead with frailty and decline.'b''b'In their study comparing the memory of young and old Chinese and Americans'b', Ellen Langer, a social psychologist, and Becca Levy, an epidemiologist, found that the older Chinese people, who, it was hypothesized, were exposed to less ageism than their American counterparts, performed memory tests more like their younger compatriots. Among the Americans, on the other hand, there were significant memory differences between the old and young. The beliefs that we imbibe about our waning powers may turn out to be self-fulfilling. In effect, our culture teaches us how to be old.'b'The historians Thomas R. Cole and David Hackett Fischer have documented how, at the start of the 19th century, the idea of aging as part of the human condition, with its inevitable limits, increasingly gave way to a conception of old age as a biomedical problem to which there might be a scientific solution. What was lost was a sense of the life span, with each stage having value and meaning.'b'Perhaps this is why, as a 2006 study found, 'b'we mispredict the happiness we expect to feel across the course of our lives'b' and assume that we\xe2\x80\x99ll get more unhappy as we age. In fact, the research shows that the opposite is true. For my part, at 64, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t attained serenity (another stereotype of older people), but I am more able to savor life \xe2\x80\x94 and if offered the chance to return to my 14-year-old self, I\xe2\x80\x99d run screaming the other way.'b'A student of mine, nudging 60, recently called age \xe2\x80\x9cthe great liberator.\xe2\x80\x9d Part of what she meant was that old people simply care less about what others think, but also, I think, that our sense of what\xe2\x80\x99s important grows with age. We experience life more intensely than before, whatever our physical limitations, because we know it won\xe2\x80\x99t last forever.'b'How to enable the growing numbers of old people to live comfortable, meaningful lives is a fundamental issue of equality, with benefits for all. If we make the world better for old people, we make it better for everyone, from stroller-pushers to wheelchair-users.'b''b'Maggie Kuhn, the founder of the elder advocacy organization the Gray Panthers, 'b'argued that instead of making a fetish of independence, we should value the idea of interdependence between generations. Thus 'b'age-friendly cities, like Portland, Ore., rethink urban spaces'b' to make them more accessible and encourage the integration of old people into communal life. And programs 'b'like Cleveland\xe2\x80\x99s intergenerational charter schools'b', which provide lifelong education alongside grades K-8, break down the age apartheid now so common. Instead of seeing each other as generic categories, old and young people can discover each other as individuals.'b'Age resistance is a futile kind of life resistance: We can\xe2\x80\x99t live outside time, we begin to age the moment we\xe2\x80\x99re born. But the emerging age-acceptance movement neither decries nor denies the aging process. It recognizes that one can remain vital and present, engaged and curious, indeed continue to grow, until one\xe2\x80\x99s dying breath. Then we need only echo the wish of the British psychoanalyst D. W. Winnicott: \xe2\x80\x9cMay I be alive when I die.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'IN the new year, it goes without saying that we should all eat more vegetables, exercise more often, tweet or text a little less and pray a little more. But for the professional pundit, there\xe2\x80\x99s really only one resolution that matters: Be less wrong.'b'So in that spirit, here is my annual inventory of the places where I went astray in 2014, offered in the hope that beginning 2015 with a confession will lead to fewer mistakes in the year to come.'b'1. 'b'I thought Jeb Bush wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really serious about 2016.'b' In two columns on the Republican presidential field, in 'b'March'b' and in 'b'November'b', I didn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly write off a Bush candidacy. But I spent far more time on Marco Rubio (whose chances I felt were being underestimated) and Rand Paul, and to a lesser extent Chris Christie and Ted Cruz, than I did on the former Florida governor.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s because I strongly suspected various forces would keep Bush on the sidelines: his wife\xe2\x80\x99s likely opposition, a sense of Bush-dynasty fatigue among the party\xe2\x80\x99s machers, and all the very human reasons a wealthy, comfortable, relaxed 60-something who last campaigned for office a dozen years ago might decide to pass on the presidential madhouse.'b'These suspicions could still be vindicated; Bush\xe2\x80\x99s recently announced \xe2\x80\x9cexploration\xe2\x80\x9d could end before the first primary vote is cast. But he suddenly looks much more like a full-speed-ahead candidate than I expected, and \xe2\x80\x94 in what counts as clear bad news for Rubio and Christie, among others \xe2\x80\x94 many of the party\xe2\x80\x99s donors and operatives seem 'b'not at all 'b' 'b'deterred'b' by his fraternal connection to a deeply unpopular president.'b'Jeb the serious candidate isn\xe2\x80\x99t Jeb the front-runner, or at least not yet. But his apparent plan to run is a big, important 2016 fact, and one my 2014 columns failed to sufficiently anticipate.'b'2.\xc2\xa0'b'I was too optimistic about the prospects for demilitarizing the police.'b'\xc2\xa0In an 'b'August column'b' during the early days of protest in Ferguson, Mo., I argued that while many reforms to the criminal justice system might come with difficult trade-offs, the case for limiting the flow of heavy weapons \xe2\x80\x94 grenade launchers, armored cars, and so on \xe2\x80\x94 from the military to local police departments was \xe2\x80\x9ceasy, uncomplicated, clear.\xe2\x80\x9d Crime rates keep falling, the threat of terrorism is more marginal than it seemed after 9/11, and there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a justification for giving cops in places like Ferguson the armaments of an occupying force.\xc2\xa0'b'To which I would have been wise to add: \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet they\xe2\x80\x99re likely to keep getting weapons anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d The flurry of 'b'congressional interest faded'b' once police unions flexed some muscle. The White House is notionally committed to tougher standards, but 'b'its proposals'b' seem likely to add paperwork without meaningfully reducing the flow of arms.\xc2\xa0'b'Programs in motion tend to stay in motion, that much is always true. But I didn\xe2\x80\x99t foresee that Ferguson itself, initially a story that produced bipartisan sympathy for the protesters, would turn into a weak and polarizing exhibit in the case for policing reform.'b'The persistent rioting made the argument that the cops needed all their gear seem more plausible (though I am not convinced), and the facts of the original tragedy, the shooting of Michael Brown, turned out to make a weaker case against the police than suggested by the initial coverage.\xc2\xa0'b'The hard truth \xe2\x80\x94 which is also on display in New York right now \xe2\x80\x94 is that crime and punishment stir up (for good reason) the strongest of human emotions, which makes achieving consensus on reform slow, hard work. This process can be hastened by particular injustices, but when the facts are bad or complicated, it can just as easily be set back.'b'3. 'b'I gave America\xe2\x80\x99s Ebola countermeasures too little credit.'b' In an'b' October column'b' on the public health fiascos that allowed the deadly virus to infect American health care workers, I wrote that if \xe2\x80\x9cwe manage to contain Ebola domestically, then the president and his appointees will look more competent and levelheaded than their critics.\xe2\x80\x9d But I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t particularly confident in that outcome, and so \xe2\x80\x94 worried about a wider outbreak \xe2\x80\x94 I also wrote that \xe2\x80\x9ctravel restrictions increasingly seem like an appropriate hedge against ongoing domestic incompetence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Two months later, there has been no wider outbreak, most of the cases treated domestically have resulted in a cure, and the president and his appointees can reasonably claim vindication. (As can Dr. Paul Farmer, the famous physician-humanitarian, who argued in an October 'b'essay'b' for the London Review of Books that with Western standards of medical treatment, Ebola victims could have a 90 percent survival rate.) So I was too alarmist, often a pundit\xe2\x80\x99s besetting vice.'b'But while pessimism can be an analytic mistake, it\xe2\x80\x99s the happiest way to be wrong. So if infallibility remains out of reach, my hope for 2015 is that my columns will only err in undue pessimism, and that reality will only surprise me \xe2\x80\x94 and you, and all of us \xe2\x80\x94 with good news.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 FACED with a horror like the slaughter of 148 schoolchildren and school staff members by the Taliban in Pakistan, it is tempting to describe the act as \xe2\x80\x9cinhuman\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cmedieval.\xe2\x80\x9d What made the massacre particularly chilling, though, is that it was neither. The killings were all too human and of our time.'b'The Peshawar massacre may have been particularly abhorrent, but the 'b'Taliban have attacked at least 1,000 schools'b' over the past five years. They have butchered hundreds through suicide bombings of churches and mosques. And beyond Pakistan lies the brutality of groups like the Islamic State, Boko Haram and the Shabab.'b'What seems to bind these groups together is that they claim to act in the name of Islam. Why, many ask, do so many of today\xe2\x80\x99s most vicious conflicts appear to involve Islamists? And why do Islamist groups seem so much more vicious, sadistic, even evil?'b'Muslims are not the only religious group involved in perpetrating horrors. From Christian 'b'militias in the Central African Republic reportedly eating their foes'b' to 'b'Buddhist monks organizing anti-Muslim pogroms in Myanmar'b', there is cruelty aplenty in the world. Nor are religious believers alone in committing grotesque acts. Yet, critics argue, there appears to be something particularly potent about Islam in fomenting violence, terror and persecution.'b'These are explosive issues and need addressing carefully. The trouble is, this debate remains trapped between bigotry and fear. For many, the actions of groups like the Islamic State or the Taliban merely provide ammunition to promote anti-Muslim hatred.'b'Many liberals, on the other hand, prefer to sidestep the issue by suggesting that the Taliban or the Islamic State do not represent \xe2\x80\x9creal Islam\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a 'b'claim made recently, in so many words, by both President Obama'b' and 'b'David Cameron, the prime minister of Britain'b'. Many argue, too, that the actions of such groups are driven by politics, not religion.'b'Neither claim is credible. A religion is defined not just by its holy texts but also by how believers interpret those texts \xe2\x80\x94 that is, by its practices. The ways in which believers act out their faith define that faith. The fact that Islamist extremists practice their religion in a manner abhorrent to liberals does not make that practice less real.'b'Nor does it make sense to think of the Taliban or the Islamic State as motivated simply by politics, any more than it does to imagine them as purely religious. Radical Islam is the religious form through which a particular kind of barbarous political rage expresses itself.'b'Instead, we need to ask why political rage against the West takes such nihilistic forms today. And why has radical Islam become its principal vehicle?'b'The character of anti-Western sentiment has changed strikingly in recent decades. There is a long history of anti-imperialist movements stretching from the Haitian revolution of the 1790s to the independence movements of the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s in Africa and Asia. While these challenged Western power and often used violent means, they were rarely \xe2\x80\x9canti-Western\xe2\x80\x9d in an essential sense. Indeed, their leaders often embraced revolutionary ideas that came out of the West, self-consciously locating themselves in the tradition of the European Enlightenment.'b'Frantz Fanon, the Martinique-born Algerian nationalist, was one of the most important anticolonial theorists. The aim, he suggested, was not to reject Western ideas, but to reclaim them.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll the elements of a solution to the great problems of humanity have, at different times, existed in European thought,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'he wrote'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cBut Europeans have not carried out in practice the mission which fell to them.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Anti-imperialists of the past saw themselves as part of a wider political project that sought to modernize the non-Western world, politically and economically. Today, however, that wider political project is itself seen as the problem. There is considerable disenchantment with many aspects of modernity, from individualism to globalization, from the breakdown of traditional cultures to the fragmentation of societies, from the blurring of moral boundaries to the seeming soullessness of the contemporary world.'b'In the past, racists often viewed modernity as the property of the West and regarded the non-Western world as incapable of modernizing. Today, it is radicals who often regard modernity as a Western product, and reject both it and the West as tainted goods.'b'The consequence has been the transformation of anti-Western sentiment from a political challenge to imperialist policy to an inchoate rage against modernity. Many strands of contemporary thought, including those embraced by \xe2\x80\x9cdeep greens\xe2\x80\x9d and the far left, express aspects of such discontent. But it is radical Islam that has become the lightning rod for this fury.'b'There are many forms of Islamism, from the Taliban to Hamas, from the Muslim Brotherhood to Boko Haram. What they have in common is a capacity to fuse hostility toward the West with hatred for modernity and, seemingly, to provide an alternative to both. Islamists marry political militancy with a conservative social sensibility, a hostility to globalization with the embrace of a global ummah (the worldwide community of Muslim believers). In so doing, they turn the contradictory aspects of their rage against modernity into a strength.'b'Jihadism provides Islamist ideology with a military form and seemingly creates a global social movement, at a time when radical alternatives have collapsed. What jihadism does not possess is the moral and philosophical framework that guided anti-imperialist movements. Shorn of that framework, and reduced to raging at the world, jihadists have turned terror into an end in itself.'b'The slaughter in Peshawar, like the mass beheadings by the Islamic State, tells us something about the character of contemporary Islam and of Islamism. It tells us even more about the state of contemporary politics, and especially of radical politics.'b'A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.'b'Anthony Doerr is a fiction writer living in Boise, Idaho, whose most recent novel is 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll the Light We Cannot See.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b''b'READING'b' I just started Joseph Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Hero With a Thousand Faces,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' his famous argument that all stories are variations on a single story, the monomyth. This book comes up often enough in conversation that I\xe2\x80\x99d become embarrassed that I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t read it. I\xe2\x80\x99d shied away from it because some folks, script doctors and the like, have tried to repackage Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s ideas into a one-size-fits-all storytelling formula. But after chewing through 100 pages of Campbell, I\xe2\x80\x99m impressed by its complexity. Watching him perform these staggering acts of synthesis \xe2\x80\x94 he\xe2\x80\x99ll toss together, say, Jungian archetype, Sumerian mythology, the Roman Apuleius, shamanism and Lancelot into the space of a few pages \xe2\x80\x94 is breathtaking.'b''b'LISTENING'b' I listen to podcasts while I run in Boise\xe2\x80\x99s foothills. 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPlanetary Radio\xe2\x80\x9d'b' from the Planetary Society and The New Yorker\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Political Scene.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' Lately, though, along with everybody else, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been listening to 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSerial.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' I love how it\xe2\x80\x99s about the gaps in our memories, and about whether we can ever really know anybody. There\xe2\x80\x99s also something captivating about the voice of the journalist in her conversations with a convicted murderer. They sound like friends; sometimes they seem almost to be flirting. Is he a brilliant sociopath? Or a sympathetic guy in a terrible situation? It is the journalist\xe2\x80\x99s implication in the narrative that compels me \xe2\x80\x94 the storyteller has become part of the story.'b''b'WATCHING'b' My 10-year-old twin sons construct complicated candy dispensers out of 'b'Legos'b', make videos of them, then ritualistically destroy them \xe2\x80\x94 sort of like a 21st-century version of a sand mandala. So I watch those.'b''b'WEARING'b' In my early 20s, a friend and I worked for a few months on a sheep farm in New Zealand. Clearly I\xe2\x80\x99ve been reading Joseph Campbell.'b'CAMBRIDGE, Mass. \xe2\x80\x94 SCIENTISTS have often been accused of exaggerating the threat of climate change, but it\xe2\x80\x99s becoming increasingly clear that they ought to be more emphatic about the risk. The year just concluded is about to be declared the hottest one on record, and across the globe climate change is happening faster than scientists predicted.'b'Science is conservative, and new claims of knowledge are greeted with high degrees of skepticism. When Copernicus said the Earth orbited the sun, when Wegener said the continents drifted, and when Darwin said species evolved by natural selection, the burden of proof was on them to show that it was so. In the 18th and 19th centuries, this conservatism generally took the form of a demand for a large amount of evidence; in the 20th century, it took on the form of a demand for statistical significance.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve all heard the slogan \xe2\x80\x9ccorrelation is not causation,\xe2\x80\x9d but that\xe2\x80\x99s a misleading way to think about the issue. It would be better to say that correlation is not necessarily causation, because we need to rule out the possibility that we are just observing a coincidence. Typically, scientists apply a 95 percent confidence limit, meaning that they will accept a causal claim only if they can show that the odds of the relationship\xe2\x80\x99s occurring by chance are no more than one in 20. But it also means that if there\xe2\x80\x99s more than even a scant 5 percent possibility that an event occurred by chance, scientists will reject the causal claim. It\xe2\x80\x99s like not gambling in Las Vegas even though you had a nearly 95 percent chance of winning.'b'Where does this severe standard come from? The 95 percent confidence level is generally credited to the British statistician R. A. Fisher, who was interested in the problem of how to be sure an observed effect of an experiment was not just the result of chance. While there have been enormous arguments among statisticians about what a 95 percent confidence level really means, working scientists routinely use it.'b'But the 95 percent level has no actual basis in nature. It is a convention, a value judgment. The value it reflects is one that says that the worst mistake a scientist can make is to think an effect is real when it is not. This is the familiar \xe2\x80\x9cType 1 error.\xe2\x80\x9d You can think of it as being gullible, fooling yourself, or having undue faith in your own ideas. To avoid it, scientists place the burden of proof on the person making an affirmative claim. But this means that science is prone to \xe2\x80\x9cType 2 errors\xe2\x80\x9d: being too conservative and missing causes and effects that are really there.'b'Is a Type 1 error worse than a Type 2? It depends on your point of view, and on the risks inherent in getting the answer wrong. The fear of the Type 1 error asks us to play dumb; in effect, to start from scratch and act as if we know nothing. That makes sense when we really don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s going on, as in the early stages of a scientific investigation. It also makes sense in a court of law, where we presume innocence to protect ourselves from government tyranny and overzealous prosecutors \xe2\x80\x94 but there are no doubt prosecutors who would argue for a lower standard to protect society from crime.'b'When applied to evaluating environmental hazards, the fear of gullibility can lead us to understate threats. It places the burden of proof on the victim rather than, for example, on the manufacturer of a harmful product. The consequence is that we may fail to protect people who are really getting hurt.'b'And what if we aren\xe2\x80\x99t dumb? What if we have evidence to support a cause-and-effect relationship? Let\xe2\x80\x99s say you know how a particular chemical is harmful; for example, that it has been shown to interfere with cell function in laboratory mice. Then it might be reasonable to accept a lower statistical threshold when examining effects in people, because you already have reason to believe that the observed effect is not just chance.'b'This is what the United States government argued in the case of secondhand smoke. Since bystanders inhaled the same chemicals as smokers, and those chemicals were known to be carcinogenic, it stood to reason that secondhand smoke would be carcinogenic, too. That is why the Environmental Protection Agency accepted a (slightly) lower burden of proof: 90 percent instead of 95 percent.'b'In the case of climate change, we are not dumb at all. We know that carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas, we know that its concentration in the atmosphere has increased by about 40 percent since the industrial revolution, and we know the mechanism by which it warms the planet.'b'WHY don\xe2\x80\x99t scientists pick the standard that is appropriate to the case at hand, instead of adhering to an absolutist one? The answer can be found in a surprising place: the history of science in relation to religion. The 95 percent confidence limit reflects a long tradition in the history of science that valorizes skepticism as an antidote to religious faith.'b'Even as scientists consciously rejected religion as a basis of natural knowledge, they held on to certain cultural presumptions about what kind of person had access to reliable knowledge. One of these presumptions involved the value of ascetic practices. Nowadays scientists do not live monastic lives, but they do practice a form of self-denial, denying themselves the right to believe anything that has not passed very high intellectual hurdles.'b'Moreover, while vigorously denying its relation to religion, modern science retains symbolic vestiges of prophetic tradition, so many scientists bend over backward to avoid these associations. A vast majority of scientists do not speak in public at all, and those who do typically speak in highly guarded, qualified terms. They often refuse to use the language of danger even when danger is precisely what they are talking about.'b'Years ago, climate scientists offered an increase of 2 degrees Celsius (or 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) as the \xe2\x80\x9csafe\xe2\x80\x9d limit or ceiling for the long-term warming of the planet. We are now seeing dangerous effects worldwide, even as we approach a rise of only 1 degree Celsius. The evidence is mounting that scientists have underpredicted the threat. Perhaps this is another reason \xe2\x80\x94 along with our polarized politics and the effect of fossil-fuel lobbying \xe2\x80\x94 we have underreacted to the reality, now unfolding before our eyes, of dangerous climate change.'b'Readers discuss an essay about religious practices that don\xe2\x80\x99t center on a belief in God.'b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Religion Without God'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by T. He interprets health in terms of his body weight, wealth in terms of his bank account and success in terms of his business card. Much less is said, however, about the equally significant economic division between conservative \xe2\x80\x9cred states\xe2\x80\x9d and liberal \xe2\x80\x9cblue states.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Blue states, like California, New York and Illinois, whose economies turn on finance, trade and knowledge, are generally richer than red states. But red states, like Texas, Georgia and Utah, have done a better job over all of offering a higher standard of living relative to housing costs. That basic economic fact not only helps explain why the nation\xe2\x80\x99s electoral map got so much redder in the November midterm elections, but also why America\xe2\x80\x99s prosperity is in jeopardy.'b'Red state economies based on energy extraction, agriculture and suburban sprawl may have lower wages, higher poverty rates and lower levels of education on average than those of blue states \xe2\x80\x94 but their residents also benefit from much lower costs of living. For a middle-class person , the American dream of a big house with a backyard and a couple of cars is much more achievable in low-tax Arizona than in deep-blue Massachusetts. As Jed Kolko, chief economist of Trulia, recently noted, housing costs almost twice as much in deep-blue markets ($227 per square foot) than in red markets ($119).'b'Driven by oil, the fracking boom and exurban sprawl, many of the red state economies are experiencing a vigorous (if ultimately unsustainable) spurt of growth. Thanks to loose land-use regulations and low labor costs, detached, single-family homes can be churned out quite cheaply, generating more middle-wage, low-skill jobs. And since red states spend less per capita on education, infrastructure and social welfare than their blue state counterparts (and many of them receive more federal dollars than they contribute), their tax burdens are lower, too.'b'To the surprise of many, voters in four red states \xe2\x80\x94 Alaska, Nebraska, South Dakota and Arkansas \xe2\x80\x94 supported referendums in November to raise their state minimum wage. And not just by a little. Controlling for the cost of living, they will have wage floors that are higher than those of many blue states. Once Obamacare is factored in, voters in these states ironically benefit from a somewhat strengthened social safety net, even though it is one that their elected politicians mainly oppose and that is heavily subsidized by blue state tax dollars.'b'For blue state urbanites who toil in low-paying retail, food preparation and service jobs, for the journeyman tradespeople who once formed the heart of the middle class, for teachers, civil servants, students and young families, the American dream of homeownership \xe2\x80\x94 or even an affordable rental apartment \xe2\x80\x94 is increasingly out of reach. Adding insult to injury, rapid gentrification in these larger knowledge hubs brings the constant threat of displacement of creative workers. For even the much better paid techies, engineers, financiers and managers who are displacing them, the metropolitan version of the American dream is a cramped condo or a small house and a long commute. Many are opting to move to cheaper red states instead, further driving their growth.'b'Inequality has grown fastest over the past three decades in larger states with more vibrant knowledge economies, like Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. In 1979, the most unequal states were poor conservative states \xe2\x80\x94 Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, Alabama and Georgia. By 2012, New York, Connecticut, California and Massachusetts joined Mississippi, Louisiana, Florida, Georgia, Texas and Tennessee among the 10 most unequal states.'b'Blue state knowledge economies are also extremely expensive to operate. Their innovative edge turns on a high-cost infrastructure of research universities and knowledge institutions \xe2\x80\x94 a portion of which demand public subsidy. Their size and density require expensive subway and transit systems to move people around. Blue state cities like New York and San Francisco are booming, but they are hampered by potholes and crumbling infrastructure, troubled public school systems, growing inequality and housing unaffordability, and entrenched poor populations, all of which mean higher public costs and higher tax burdens.'b'And yet for all that, they are pioneering the new economic order that will determine our future \xe2\x80\x94 one that turns on innovation and knowledge rather than the raw production of goods.'b'Despite their longstanding divisions, red state and blue state economies depend crucially on one another. Just as Alexander Hamilton\xe2\x80\x99s merchant cities ate and exported the harvests of Thomas Jefferson\xe2\x80\x99s yeomen farmers, and New England textile mills wove slave-harvested cotton, blue state knowledge economies run on red state energy. Red state energy economies in their turn depend on dense coastal cities and metro areas, not just as markets and sources of migrants, but for the technology and talent they supply.'b'Of course, while Massachusetts and Mississippi represent the extremes of America\xe2\x80\x99s politico-economic divide, there are many red states like Utah, Arizona and Texas that are growing their tech and knowledge economies, and a number of historically blue states like Pennsylvania that have benefited from the fracking boom. But in our increasingly competitive global economy, long-term prosperity turns on knowledge, education and innovation. The idea that the red states can enjoy the benefits provided by the blue states without helping to pay for them (and while poaching their industries with the promise of low taxes and regulations) is as irresponsible and destructive of our national future as it is hypocritical.'b'But that is exactly the mantra of the growing ranks of red state politicos. But fracking and sprawling your way to growth aren\xe2\x80\x99t a sustainable national economic strategy.'b'The allure of cheap growth has handed the red states a distinct political advantage. Their economic system may be outmoded and obsolete, but it is strong enough to blight the future. The Democrats may be able to draw on the country\xe2\x80\x99s growing demographic diversity and the liberal leanings of younger voters to win the presidency from time to time, but the real power dynamic is red.'b'As long as the highly gerrymandered red states can keep on delivering the economic goods to their voters, concerted federal action on transportation, infrastructure, sustainability, education, a rational immigration policy and a strengthened social safety net will remain out of reach. These are investments that the future prosperity of the nation, in red states and blue states alike, requires.'b'Heightened partisan rancor is the least of our problems. Over a year, she had seen five other physicians for a \xe2\x80\x9crapid heartbeat\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfeeling stressed.\xe2\x80\x9d After extensive testing, she had finally been referred for psychological counseling for an anxiety disorder.'b'The careful history Dr. Martin took revealed that Betsy was taking an over-the-counter weight loss product that contained ephedrine. Asked why she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t mentioned this information before, she said she\xe2\x80\x99d \xe2\x80\x9cnever been asked.\xe2\x80\x9d Until then, her providers would sooner order tests than take the time to talk with her about the problem.'b'Betsy\xe2\x80\x99s case was fortunate; poor communication often has much worse consequences. A review of reports by the Joint Commission, a nonprofit that provides accreditation to health care organizations, found that communication failure (rather than a provider\xe2\x80\x99s lack of technical skill) was at the root of over 70 percent of serious adverse health outcomes in hospitals.'b'A doctor\xe2\x80\x99s ability to explain, listen and empathize has a profound impact on a patient\xe2\x80\x99s care. Yet, as one survey found, two out of every three patients are discharged from the hospital without even knowing their diagnosis. Another study discovered that in over 60 percent of cases, patients misunderstood directions after a visit to their doctor\xe2\x80\x99s office. And on average, physicians wait just 18 seconds before interrupting patients\xe2\x80\x99 narratives of their symptoms. Evidently, we have a long way to go.'b'Three years ago, my colleagues and I started a program in Harrisburg designed to improve doctors\xe2\x80\x99 communication with their patients. This large urban hospital system serves a city with a population of about 50,000, together with the surrounding metropolitan area of more than 550,000 people.'b'The hospital faces particular challenges: The city has a high poverty rate (32 percent, compared with the state average of 13 percent), and 'b'the metro area has a high rate of childhood obesity'b'. Over all, nearly a third of people around Harrisburg are uninsured, compared with about one in 10 for the rest of Pennsylvania.'b'Our project started with a simple baseline assessment of how we as doctors communicated with our patients. Observation soon revealed that physicians introduced themselves on only about one in four occasions. And without an introduction, it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that patients could correctly identify their physician only about a quarter of the time.'b'Brief, rushed physician encounters were common, with limited opportunity for questions. In one, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, Harvard health policy researchers reported that higher patient satisfaction was associated with improved outcomes for several diseases, including heart attacks, heart failure and pneumonia.'b'The need to train and test physicians in \xe2\x80\x9cinterpersonal and communication skills\xe2\x80\x9d was formally recognized only relatively recently, in 1999, when the American Board of Medical Specialties made them one of physicians\xe2\x80\x99 key competencies. Mr. Abbas has now announced that he will turn to the 'b'International Criminal Court'b' \xe2\x80\x94 a move that will produce 'b'Palestinian'b' charges and Israeli countercharges but not alter the reality on the ground.'b'A European official I met recently expressed sympathy for the Palestinians\xe2\x80\x99 pursuit of a Security Council resolution. I responded by saying that if he favors Palestinian statehood, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to stop giving the Palestinians a pass. It is time to make it costly for them to focus on symbols rather than substance.'b'Since 2000, there have been three serious negotiations that culminated in offers to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s parameters in 2000, former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert\xe2\x80\x99s offer in 2008, and Secretary of State John Kerry\xe2\x80\x99s efforts last year. In each case, a proposal on all the core issues was made to Palestinian leaders and the answer was either \xe2\x80\x9cno\xe2\x80\x9d or no response. They determined that the cost of saying \xe2\x80\x9cyes,\xe2\x80\x9d or even of making a counteroffer that required concessions, was too high.'b'Palestinian political culture is rooted in a narrative of injustice; its anticolonialist bent and its deep sense of grievance treats concessions to Israel as illegitimate. Compromise is portrayed as betrayal, and negotiations \xe2\x80\x94 which are by definition about mutual concessions \xe2\x80\x94 will inevitably force any Palestinian leader to challenge his people by making a politically costly decision.'b'But going to the 'b'United Nations'b' does no such thing. It puts pressure on Israel and requires nothing of the Palestinians. Resolutions are typically about what Israel must do and what Palestinians should get. If saying yes is costly and doing nothing isn\xe2\x80\x99t, why should we expect the Palestinians to change course?'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why European leaders who fervently support Palestinian statehood must focus on how to raise the cost of saying no or not acting at all when there is an offer on the table. Palestinians care deeply about international support for their cause. It will be seen in Israel as a one-sided approach, and it will strengthen politicians who prefer the status quo. These candidates will argue that the deck is stacked against Israel and that the country needs leaders who will stand firm against unfair pressure.'b'Why not wait? If a new Israeli government after the elections is prepared to take a peace initiative and build settlements only on land that is likely to be part of Israel and not part of Palestine, there will be no need for a United Nations resolution.'b'If not, and the Europeans decide to pursue one, it must be balanced. But is this time different?'b'To understand why economists usually downplay the economic role of presidents, let\xe2\x80\x99s revisit a much-mythologized episode in U.S. economic history: the recession and recovery of the 1980s.'b'On the right, of course, the 1980s are remembered as an age of miracles wrought by the blessed Reagan, who cut taxes, conjured up the magic of the marketplace and led the nation to job gains never matched before or since. In reality, the 16 million 'b'jobs America added'b' during the Reagan years were only slightly more than the 14 million added over the previous eight years. And a later president \xe2\x80\x94 Bill something-or-other \xe2\x80\x94 presided over the creation of 22 million jobs. But who\xe2\x80\x99s counting?'b'In any case, however, serious analyses of the Reagan-era business cycle place very little weight on Reagan, and emphasize instead the role of the Federal Reserve, which sets monetary policy and is largely independent of the political process. At the beginning of the 1980s, the Fed, under the leadership of Paul Volcker, was determined to bring inflation down, even at a heavy price; it tightened policy, sending interest rates sky high, with 'b'mortgage rates'b' going above 18 percent. What followed was a severe recession that drove unemployment to double digits but also broke the wage-price spiral.'b'Then the Fed decided that America had suffered enough. It loosened the reins, sending interest rates plummeting and 'b'housing starts'b' soaring. And the economy bounced back. Reagan got the political credit for \xe2\x80\x9cmorning in America,\xe2\x80\x9d but Mr. Volcker was actually responsible for both the slump and the boom.'b'The point is that normally the Fed, not the White House, rules the economy. Should we apply the same rule to the Obama years?'b'Not quite.'b'For one thing, the Fed has had a hard time gaining traction in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, because the aftermath of a huge housing and mortgage bubble has left private spending relatively unresponsive to interest rates. This time around, monetary policy really needed help from a temporary increase in government spending, which meant that the president could have made a big difference. And he did, for a while; politically, the Obama stimulus may have been a failure, but an overwhelming majority of economists believe that it 'b'helped mitigate the slump'b'.'b'Since then, however, scorched-earth Republican opposition has more than reversed that initial effort. In fact, 'b'federal spending'b' adjusted for inflation and population growth is lower now than it was when Mr. Obama took office; at the same point in the Reagan years, it was up more than 20 percent. Do those who were blaming Mr. Obama for all our economic ills now look like knaves and fools? Yes, they do. And that\xe2\x80\x99s because they are.'b'For most people, Ferguson, Mo., will be remembered for one awful August afternoon, when a white police officer there shot and killed an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown.'b'But that incident was only a snapshot in the town\xe2\x80\x99s long and complicated racial history \xe2\x80\x94 a history 'b'characterized by'b' entrenched segregation and economic inequality, as well as by familiar and systemic obstacles that have kept black residents from holding positions of political power.'b'Ferguson\xe2\x80\x99s population is 'b'two-thirds African-American'b', and yet its mayor, city manager and 'b'five of its six'b' City Council members are white. So are its police chief and all but three officers on its 53-member police force.'b'The school board for the Ferguson-Florissant School District is much the same: More than three-quarters of the district\xe2\x80\x99s 12,000 students are black, but the 'b'seven-member board'b' includes only one African-American.'b'Last month the American Civil Liberties Union 'b'sued'b' the school board under the Voting Rights Act, arguing that the way its members are elected blocks minority voters from fully participating in the political process.'b'The method is known as \xe2\x80\x9cat large\xe2\x80\x9d voting, and lets voters cast ballots for all candidates in the district, regardless of where the voters live. Since the district\xe2\x80\x99s voting-age population is 50 percent white and 47 percent black, and since both groups there tend to vote along strict racial lines, the white voters\xe2\x80\x99 candidates almost always win.'b'The lawsuit, filed in a Missouri federal court on Dec. 18, 'b'contends'b' that the white board members have not been attentive enough to the needs of black students, and in 2013 the board dismissed the district\xe2\x80\x99s first black superintendent without explanation.'b'The suit calls for at-large voting to be replaced with another system, like one that allows residents to vote for a candidate who lives in their part of the district, which would make it possible for majority-black neighborhoods to elect board members of their choice.'b'At-large voting is not necessarily discriminatory, but it has long been one of 'b'the most common tools'b' for reducing minority voting power. It is also by far the most common ground for successful claims under the Voting Rights Act, and courts have repeatedly 'b'struck down'b' at-large voting schemes around the country where plaintiffs have shown that, when combined with racial polarization, they weaken minority voters.'b'In 1982, the Supreme Court 'b'explained'b' that minority voting power \xe2\x80\x9cis particularly diluted when bloc voting occurs and ballots are cast along strict majority-minority lines.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is the case in the Ferguson-Florissant School District, where blacks and whites also live in extreme geographical and economic segregation. (The St. Louis metropolitan region as a whole is 'b'among the most racially segregated'b' in the nation.)'b'There are other solutions to the problem of racial polarization. Alternative vote-counting methods \xe2\x80\x94 like 'b'cumulative or choice voting'b' \xe2\x80\x94 may do a better job of giving minorities a voice, especially as redistricting efforts grow more sophisticated. And more municipalities are 'b'starting to realize'b' on their own that there is not much to gain by defending at-large election systems.'b'The bottom line is that while democratic elections will always favor majorities, they must also protect the interests of minority populations of all kinds \xe2\x80\x94 and give them an equal opportunity to elect the candidates they choose.'b'In January 1992, Bill Clinton, then the governor of Arkansas, left the presidential campaign trail to fly home for the execution of a man named Ricky Ray Rector. Mr. Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s decision not to grant clemency to Mr. Rector, who had been sentenced to death for killing a police officer, was 'b'widely seen'b' as an attempt to fend off the familiar charge that Democrats were soft on crime.'b'On Dec. 31, Gov. Martin O\xe2\x80\x99Malley of Maryland, whose name has been mentioned among potential 2016 Democratic presidential candidates, 'b'commuted'b' the sentences of the last four inmates on the state\xe2\x80\x99s death row.'b'Maryland 'b'abolished'b' the death penalty in 2013, but only for new sentences. In resentencing the condemned men to life without parole, Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Malley 'b'said'b' that leaving their death sentences in place would \xe2\x80\x9cnot serve the public good of the people of Maryland \xe2\x80\x94 present or future.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Whether or not Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Malley runs for president, his action is a mark of how quickly the death penalty debate in America has shifted. 'b'Liberals'b' have long opposed capital punishment, and now more conservatives are 'b'speaking out against it'b' as well, variously describing it as 'b'immoral'b', 'b'unjust'b', 'b'racist'b', 'b'arbitrary'b', 'b'costly'b' and 'b'ineptly carried out'b'.'b'Thirty-five people were put to death in 2014, the fewest in 20 years, 'b'according to'b' a report last month by the Death Penalty Information Center. All but seven of the executions took place in three states: Texas, Missouri and Florida. And while two-thirds of those executed were black, only six had been convicted of killing a black person, even though blacks make up almost half of all murder victims.'b'Another sign of the times: Fewer people are put on death row. There were 72 new death sentences in 2014, the lowest number since 1974.'b'In various decisions, the Supreme Court has helped to reduce these numbers, barring the execution of the 'b'mentally ill'b', the 'b'intellectually disabled'b' and those who were 'b'minors at the time of their crimes'b'. But states have found ways around those rulings, and have executed many people who fall into one or more of these categories \xe2\x80\x94 people like 'b'John Errol Ferguson'b', who was schizophrenic and sat on Florida\xe2\x80\x99s death row for 34 years before he was executed in 2013, and 'b'Marvin Wilson'b', who had an I.Q. of 61 and was executed in Texas in 2012.'b'A 'b'study'b' published last June in the Hastings Law Journal found that of the last 100 people to be put to death, one-third had evidence of an intellectual disability, borderline intellectual functioning or a traumatic brain injury. At least 20 others were diagnosed with or showed symptoms of mental illness, such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder. Others had experienced severe trauma in childhood.'b'In other words, while the death penalty may be increasingly infrequent, it is all too often a brutal end to a brutal life. The people executed in recent years were not the \xe2\x80\x9cworst of the worst\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 as many death-penalty advocates like to imagine \xe2\x80\x94 but those who were too poor, mentally ill or disabled to avoid it.'b'In 2014, for the first time, a 'b'Washington Post-ABC News poll'b' found that a majority of Americans favored life without parole over the death penalty. No less pointedly, they urged Mr. Cuomo to address the \xe2\x80\x9cdeeply disturbing inequalities in resources\xe2\x80\x9d that exist between poor and wealthy districts, as well as the destructive pattern of segregation. Mr. Cuomo must take on both of these central issues.'b'On a recent morning at Persahabatan Hospital in East Jakarta, patients, some from remote villages accessible only by boat, gathered in a waiting room. Nearby, lab technicians used new diagnostic technology to test sputum samples for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, in an effort to tackle a growing caseload of the deadly disease.'b'Indonesia\xe2\x80\x99s recently sworn-in president, Joko Widodo, takes the reins of a rising economic power poised to play a larger role on the world stage. But he also confronts a set of entrenched public health problems fueled by the poverty in which millions of Indonesians still live. None is more urgent than the spread of drug-resistant tuberculosis across this sprawling archipelago.'b'Thanks to support from the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, the international financing mechanism established in 2002 to help poor countries address these diseases, Indonesia has been able to provide the costly drugs for drug-resistant tuberculosis to patients free of charge. It has also supplied laboratories like the one at Persahabatan with the Xpert MTB/RIF device, which allows health workers to diagnose suspected cases of drug-resistant disease in under two hours (conventional methods take as long as eight weeks).'b'These are encouraging steps, but as Indonesia is learning, the tools of clinical medicine can do only so much. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a social disease,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Erlina Burhan, the head of pulmonology medicine at Persahabatan, told me, referring to multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have 7,000 new MDR cases a year, and many of those are defaulting on their treatment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to understand why. For one thing, there\xe2\x80\x99s the financial strain; the drugs may be free, but as a recent multinational study found, the cost to patients \xe2\x80\x94 for everything from transportation and hospital stays to months of missed work \xe2\x80\x94 can amount to a year\xe2\x80\x99s earnings. And then there is the treatment itself: a grueling, two-year regimen of toxic drugs involving months of daily injections and possible severe side effects. And so stigmatized is tuberculosis in Indonesia that when volunteers go house to house looking for cases, families often try to hide sick relatives.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMost of our patients don\xe2\x80\x99t know how the disease is transmitted,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Burhan said, \xe2\x80\x9cso they return home and spread their drug-resistant strain to others.\xe2\x80\x9d The World Health Organization estimates that every untreated MDR patient will infect, on average, between 10 and 15 people per year \xe2\x80\x94 and some of those may be their children, in whom tuberculosis is more difficult to diagnose and treat.'b'In October, the W.H.O. reported that improved data collection had revealed an epidemic significantly larger than previously estimated: In 2013, nine million people developed active tuberculosis, and of those, nearly half a million were infected with multidrug-resistant strains. Indonesia, home to the world\xe2\x80\x99s fifth-highest number of tuberculosis cases, is expected to publish its own prevalence survey soon; experts believe those figures will only add to the global burden.'b'The White House should view these trends with alarm. After all, drug-resistant tuberculosis is a threat to people everywhere, including in the United States. An outbreak in New York City that started in the late \xe2\x80\x9980s and involved drug-resistant strains cost at least $1 billion to quell. Given that caring for a single case of extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis can run more than half a million dollars, a similar outbreak today could impose crippling burdens on health departments at the front lines of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s defense. And the United States almost certainly underestimates its vulnerability.'b'Despite congressional calls to increase tuberculosis funding for the current year, President Obama proposed a 19 percent cut to the global tuberculosis budget of the United States Agency for International Development, which would put tuberculosis funding below $200 million for the first time in five years. The spending bill recently passed by Congress rejected those cuts and maintained level funding, at $236 million. That is still far below the $400 million per year public health advocates say is needed to combat the world\xe2\x80\x99s leading curable killer.'b'In 2013, President Obama pledged that America would contribute up to $5 billion to the Global Fund over the next three years. But by opposing increases to bilateral tuberculosis funding, the president jeopardizes this generous investment. While Global Fund grants support the purchase of drugs and diagnostics, like the $30,000 Xpert device, the agency doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have the in-country staff to ensure the tools\xe2\x80\x99 effective implementation. It\xe2\x80\x99s here that U.S.A.I.D. plays a vital role, by training technicians, strengthening supply chains and educating doctors and nurses about novel therapies.'b'Without that help, our aid dollars don\xe2\x80\x99t go nearly as far as they could. Between 2010 and 2012, for example, Indonesia, though a major recipient of Global Fund support, used only half of the funds allocated for tuberculosis control activities because it lacked the capacity to use that aid.'b'Perhaps the most tragic consequence of underfunding tuberculosis control, though, is that it undermines the fight against H.I.V. and AIDS. After billions of dollars and decades of research, antiretroviral drugs have transformed what was a death sentence into a manageable chronic disease. In spite of this monumental public health achievement, the leading killer of people living with H.I.V. today, accounting for one-quarter of AIDS deaths worldwide, is tuberculosis, a disease so neglected that the current first-line treatment is more than 50 years old.'b'Americans can no longer afford to be indifferent to the rise of drug-resistant tuberculosis. As Indonesia illustrates, technology alone can\xe2\x80\x99t solve the problem. At least in the short term, poor countries need the specialized expertise only America can provide. When the president\xe2\x80\x99s budget requests for the next fiscal year are released, they should reflect the reality that if drug-resistant tuberculosis is allowed to flourish in faraway slums, it will most certainly return to haunt us \xe2\x80\x94 and at potentially great cost.'b''b' 'b''b''b''b'A volunteer trip abroad has become almost a rite of passage for a certain set of Americans, particularly students. This Op-Doc video profiles a Kenyan activist who has one simple question for them: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nearly'b' one million people'b' from America volunteer abroad each year. They are mostly young, mostly affluent and overwhelmingly white. It made me wonder: when we look to do community service, why do so many \xe2\x80\x94 particularly the privileged among us \xe2\x80\x94 look to places so far from home?'b'I followed the Kenyan photojournalist and activist Boniface Mwangi as he spoke with American college students to get to the core of why it can be more appealing to \xe2\x80\x9csave\xe2\x80\x9d Africans like him than to address social inequalities on their own soil.'b'As Americans, we\xe2\x80\x99re inundated with images of hungry African children, but what about the plight of children in this country?
