They are pushing them to take an honest look at their motives for helping overseas versus at home, think about how their efforts could potentially diminish or supplant African-grown initiatives and consider a more respectful connection between equals.'b'As Mr. Mwangi said to a group of students at Duke University: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you want to come and help me, first ask me what I want\xe2\x80\xa6 Then we can work together.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 ROBERT J. BEALL, the president and chief executive of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, called his recent decision to sell the royalty rights to his organization\xe2\x80\x99s research a \xe2\x80\x9cgame changer.\xe2\x80\x9d Indeed: Deals like this, in which an investment company 'b'paid the foundation $3.3 billion'b' for its future royalties from several cystic fibrosis drugs it helped finance, could revolutionize the way medical research is funded. Rather than the staid model of government-funded institutions handing out grants to academic research facilities, a new breed of \xe2\x80\x9cventure philanthropies\xe2\x80\x9d like the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation could corral private investment into developing lifesaving drugs quickly and cheaply.'b'The problem is that venture philanthropy is, essentially, another term for privatizing scientific research. Instead of decisions about the fate of scientific funding being made by publicly oriented institutions, those decisions are being put in the hands of anonymous philanthropists and ostensibly benevolent nonprofits.'b'At the risk of oversimplification, biomedical research divides into two categories: private and public. The former is the constellation of big pharmaceutical companies and start-up labs. The latter comprises government agencies and the universities and philanthropies that rely on government support \xe2\x80\x94 directly, through grants, or indirectly, through tax policy. The former can charge whatever it wants for its products; the latter is limited by government rules and price controls.'b'Venture philanthropy complicates this picture by introducing a tax-exempt loophole. An organization like the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation will take in tax-exempt donations to invest in a pharmaceutical company \xe2\x80\x94 in this case, 'b'Vertex Pharmaceuticals'b' \xe2\x80\x94 to develop drugs based on publicly funded research. Venture philanthropies can then sell the results of that research to private industry to deliver drugs to the market.'b'There is nothing to stop pharmaceutical companies from creating their own philanthropies, funding research with tax-exempt dollars and then selling themselves the rights to the intellectual property. Without price controls on the final product that come with public funding, the potential costs of the resulting medicines are limitless.'b'So far, there is no effort to extend government price controls to venture-philanthropy-derived research. The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation did little to lobby for lower prices on the drugs that were developed from the research it funded. As a result, Kalydeco, a cystic fibrosis medication it funded, is one of the most expensive drugs available, at $300,000 a year.'b'The idea of a public-private research transfer is not without precedent. In 1980, Congress passed the 'b'Bayh-Dole Act'b', which allowed publicly funded universities to sell off exclusive licenses on their research to private industry. The act was intended to drive funding for academic research and innovation.'b'But the resulting race for private funding has created perverse incentives to research blockbuster drugs, even if they are not the most imperative from a public policy standpoint. The impetus to produce more and more profitable research has also driven down the quality of academic work, promoting ghostwritten papers, sloppy peer review and the burying of unfavorable clinical-trial results. Venture philanthropy builds off the model created by Bayh-Dole, but with tax exemptions and a sheen of generosity on top of the lucrative payoff.'b'One argument in favor of venture philanthropy is that it creates a way to sustain small foundations that study rare diseases that, from a for-profit point of view, aren\xe2\x80\x99t worth investigating.'b'But while Big Pharma might be faulted for funneling billions of dollars into erectile-dysfunction drugs and off-label drug marketing, researching extremely rare diseases may also represent a misuse of public and private funds. Efforts to cure, rather than treat or prevent, obscure diseases can be expensive, diverting investment from more common afflictions. The high costs of focusing on rare diseases are then eventually pushed onto the health care system by way of egregiously high drug prices. Such a choice involves an incredibly complex moral calculus, one that is best processed by democratic public institutions.'b'To make medical advancements truly philanthropic, the profit motive needs to be removed from the equation. If the intent is to cure rare diseases, then we should be increasing the budget for the National Institutes of Health and other research initiatives. Instead of gala balls and donor drives, higher taxes on the same rich benefactors could be used to fund the research that isn\xe2\x80\x99t already being supported. Biotech patents developed through venture philanthropy should not have exclusive rights attached to them.'b'This would allow generic versions of drugs onto the market, which would go a long way toward keeping health care costs down and not driving the uninsured into debt.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 WHEN I began as the State Department\xe2\x80\x99s envoy for closing the detention facility at 'b'Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay'b', many people advised me that progress was impossible. They were wrong.'b'In the two years before I started, on July 1, 2013, only four people were transferred from Guant\xc3\xa1namo. Over the past 18 months, we moved 39 people out of there, and more transfers are coming. The population at Guant\xc3\xa1namo \xe2\x80\x94 127 \xe2\x80\x94 is at its lowest level since the facility opened in January 2002. We also worked with Congress to remove unnecessary obstacles to foreign transfers. We began an administrative process to review the status of detainees not yet approved for transfer or formally charged with crimes.'b'While there have been zigs and zags, we have made great progress. The path to closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo during the Obama administration is clear, but it will take intense and sustained action to finish the job. The government must continue and accelerate the transfers of those approved for release. Administrative review of those not approved for transfer must be expedited. The absolute and irrational ban on transfers to the United States for any purpose, including detention and prosecution, must be changed as the population is reduced to a small core of detainees who cannot safely be transferred overseas. (Ten detainees, for example, face criminal charges before the 'b'military commissions'b' that Congress set up in lieu of regular courts.)'b'The reasons for closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo are more compelling than ever. As a high-ranking security official from one of our staunchest allies on counterterrorism (not from Europe) once told me, \xe2\x80\x9cThe greatest single action the United States can take to fight terrorism is to close Guant\xc3\xa1namo.\xe2\x80\x9d I have seen firsthand the way in which Guant\xc3\xa1namo frays and damages vitally important security relationships with countries around the world. The eye-popping cost \xe2\x80\x94 around $3 million per detainee last year, compared with roughly $75,000 at a \xe2\x80\x9csupermax\xe2\x80\x9d prison in the United States \xe2\x80\x94 drains vital resources.'b'Americans from across the spectrum agree on closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo. President George W. Bush called it \xe2\x80\x9ca propaganda tool for our enemies and a distraction for our allies.\xe2\x80\x9d Kenneth L. Wainstein, who advised Mr. Bush on homeland security, said keeping the facility open was not \xe2\x80\x9csustainable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In 18 months at the State Department, I was sometimes frustrated by opposition to closing the facility in Congress and some corners of Washington. It reflects three fundamental misconceptions that have impeded the process.'b'First, not every person at Guant\xc3\xa1namo is a continuing danger. Of the 127 individuals there (from a peak of close to 800), 59 have been \xe2\x80\x9capproved for transfer.\xe2\x80\x9d This means that six agencies \xe2\x80\x94 the Departments of Defense, Homeland Security, Justice and State, as well as the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the director of national intelligence \xe2\x80\x94 have unanimously approved the person for release based on everything known about the individual and the risk he presents. For most of those approved, this rigorous decision was made half a decade ago. Almost 90 percent of those approved are from 'b'Yemen'b', where the security situation is perilous. They are not \xe2\x80\x9cthe worst of the worst,\xe2\x80\x9d but rather people with the worst luck. (We recently resettled several Yemenis in other countries, the first time any Yemeni had been transferred from Guant\xc3\xa1namo in more than four years.)'b'Second, opponents of closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo \xe2\x80\x94 including former Vice President Dick Cheney \xe2\x80\x94 cite a 30 percent recidivism rate among former detainees. This assertion is deeply flawed. It combines those \xe2\x80\x9cconfirmed\xe2\x80\x9d of having engaged in hostile activities with those \xe2\x80\x9csuspected.\xe2\x80\x9d Focusing on the \xe2\x80\x9cconfirmed\xe2\x80\x9d slashes the percentage nearly in half. Moreover, many of the \xe2\x80\x9cconfirmed\xe2\x80\x9d have been killed or recaptured.'b'Most important, there is a vast difference between those transferred before 2009, when President Obama ordered the intensive review process by the six agencies, and those transferred after that review. Of the detainees transferred during this administration, more than 90 percent have not been suspected, much less confirmed, of committing any hostile activities after their release. The percentage of detainees who were transferred after the Obama-era review and then found to have engaged in terrorist or insurgent activities is 6.8 percent. While we want that number to be zero, that small percentage does not justify holding in perpetuity the overwhelming majority of detainees, who do not subsequently engage in wrongdoing.'b'Third, a common impression is that we cannot find countries that will accept detainees from Guant\xc3\xa1namo. One of the happiest surprises of my tenure was that this is not the case. Many countries, from Slovakia and Georgia to Uruguay, have been willing to provide homes for individuals who cannot return to their own countries. Support from the Organization of American States, the Vatican and other religious and human rights organizations has also been helpful.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t question the motives of those who oppose the efforts to close Guant\xc3\xa1namo. Some are constrained by an overabundance of caution, refusing to trust the extensive security reviews that are in place. Others are hampered by an outdated view of the risk posed by many of the remaining detainees. A third group fails to recognize that the deep stain on our standing in the world is more dangerous than any individual approved for transfer. These concerns, however well-intentioned, collapse in the glare of a careful examination of the facts.'b'The road to closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo is clear and well lit. We are now approaching the 13th anniversary of the opening of the Guant\xc3\xa1namo detention facility. Imprisoning men without charges for this long \xe2\x80\x94 many of whom have been approved for transfer for almost half the period of their incarceration \xe2\x80\x94 is not in line with the country we aspire to be.'b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'After a Spa Day, Looking Years Younger (O.K., They\xe2\x80\x99re Only 7)'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 3):'b'You report that a mother who treated her 7- and 8-year-old daughters to a spa day said, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want them to feel that my saying \xe2\x80\x98no\xe2\x80\x99 means that I don\xe2\x80\x99t love them.\xe2\x80\x9d This false dilemma sounds like a recipe for family dysfunction, or worse.'b'Be brave, parents: Dare to say no. Andrew Cuomo of New York gave a politically important speech last week that got lost in the news that his father, former Gov. Mario Cuomo, had died that same afternoon. The 'b'speech'b' \xe2\x80\x94 his second inaugural address \xe2\x80\x94 touched on some of the high points of his first term while laying out an ambitious agenda for his next four years.'b'Mr. Cuomo asserted that he had tamed a dysfunctional state capital in his first four years in office. \xe2\x80\x9cWe made the government work,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, adding that the \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x9d included both \xe2\x80\x9cRepublicans and Democrats who put New York first and political parties second, even in this age of hyperpartisanship.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While he acknowledged that more remained to be done to address education, ethical failure and other state problems, much of the speech seemed pitched to a wider audience. In tones and cadence that reminded many of his father, whose oratory made him a national political figure, Mr. Cuomo said that it is important to look beyond New York because \xe2\x80\x9cthe most severe problems we face go beyond the borders of our state.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These problems include economic inequality, which calls into question \xe2\x80\x9cthe American promise itself\xe2\x80\x9d, as well as racial discrimination in education and in the administration of justice. He described \xe2\x80\x9ctwo education systems\xe2\x80\x9d, one for the rich, one for the poor, adding that public education had become \xe2\x80\x9cthe great discriminator\xe2\x80\x9d in some communities. He warned that the American justice system needs review and reform, not just in New York City or even in Ferguson, Mo., but nationwide. At risk, he suggested, \xe2\x80\x9care the primary democratic institutions of this country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Perhaps inevitably, the breadth of the speech raised questions about Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s longer-term ambitions. In his first term, the governor did not seek national attention. He stayed mostly inside the state until last year when he went to Israel, Afghanistan and Puerto Rico. He has publicly dismissed talk of presidential aspirations and said that if Hillary Rodham Clinton seeks the Democratic nomination, he would not.'b'But now he is reportedly planning to attend the annual gathering of financial and political bigwigs in Davos, Switzerland, later this month. And he has scheduled five international trade missions \xe2\x80\x94 China, Mexico, Canada, Israel and Italy. Those trips could help New York\xe2\x80\x99s economy. They could also help fill a gap in the r\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 of an ambitious politician who needs foreign policy experience.'b'Well-organized criminal gangs are increasing the pressure on Europe to deal with illegal migration across the Mediterranean by using a terrible new 'b'tactic'b': Sending rusty old freighters filled with refugees hurtling full throttle toward Italy\xe2\x80\x99s shores and certain disaster. It\xe2\x80\x99s a game of chicken, and the smugglers know that Europe has no moral option but to rescue the ships\xe2\x80\x99 human cargo.'b'More than 3,000 migrants drowned in the Mediterranean in 2014 fleeing conflict-torn regions across the Middle East and North Africa. Even as the number of people trafficked soars, European governments persist in their magical thinking, believing that somehow these people, who have no legal options and no better hope for survival, will abandon dangerous attempts to reach Europe.'b'Italy has stepped up to the immediate challenge, rescuing some 1,200 men, women and children from two separate crewless freighters last week. But the country is overwhelmed. Of the 200,000 refugees and migrants who arrived in Europe in 2014, 160,000 arrived in Italy by sea.'b'Last month, Italy phased out its Mare Nostrum marine rescue program, which was created after more than 350 migrants drowned when their boat sank off the coast of Lampedusa in October 2013. The program is credited with saving more than 100,000 people, but the cost \xe2\x80\x94 9 million euros (about $10.7 million) per month \xe2\x80\x94 was too much for Italy to bear. And Italy, rightly, feels as though Europe should pay for what is essentially a European problem.'b'Europe\xe2\x80\x99s limited replacement for Mare Nostrum, dubbed Triton and administered by the European Union border-control agency Frontex, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come close to Mare Nostrum\xe2\x80\x99s Mediterranean-wide rescue effort. Triton\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x82\xac2.9 million per month budget is only a third of what Mare Nostrum\xe2\x80\x99s was. The British government of Prime Minister David Cameron, which has claimed that rescuing migrants at sea will only encourage more to risk the journey, declined to contribute to Triton at all.'b'In the meantime, the smugglers operating out of the Turkish port of Mersin are using a despicable new tactic that is highly profitable. They are reaping millions of dollars in profits by filling old freighters destined for the scrap heap with mostly Syrian refugees willing to pay $6,000 per person for an illegal passage to Europe. Unlike the rickety boats that have carried most migrants headed for Europe from Libya, the freighters setting out from Turkey can be operated on winter\xe2\x80\x99s stormier seas, allowing smugglers to expand their business into a year-round operation.'b'On Monday, the European Commission 'b'vowed swift action'b' against smugglers aiming dilapidated freighters at Italy\xe2\x80\x99s coastline. But there is only one way to put the smugglers out of business: create more legal avenues for migrants seeking safety, especially those trying to reunite with family members already in Europe.'b'Europe should also move to decriminalize illegal migration. This would encourage migrants to identify smugglers and their unscrupulous agents, and help law enforcement break up the criminal networks that prey on the most vulnerable groups. Given the murderous tactics of the traffickers, European leaders must find the resolve to set aside growing anti-migrant sentiment, and forge a united and adequately financed policy to stop this tragic trend at Europe\xe2\x80\x99s door.'b'Even if they were acquitted on the ludicrous charge of \xe2\x80\x9cdebauchery,\xe2\x80\x9d the 26 Egyptian men on trial in the government\xe2\x80\x99s latest crackdown on gays are likely to suffer a lifetime of public scorn.'b'Over the past two years, there has been no shortage of travesties and injustices in Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s courtrooms. The country\xe2\x80\x99s ousted dictator, Hosni Mubarak, 'b'was sentenced to life'b' in prison in 2012, lying on a stretcher placed within a cage, 'b'only to be acquitted'b' two years later in a subsequent proceeding once his allies were in power again. Mr. Mubarak\xe2\x80\x99s Islamist successor, Mohamed Morsi, who was removed from power in a military coup, 'b'was locked up in a soundproof cage'b' at his trial last year. Three journalists employed by the Doha-based Al Jazeera English network were 'b'outrageously sentenced'b' to lengthy prison terms in June on allegations that they had aided the Muslim Brotherhood, following a ridiculous trial that turned them into scapegoats of a fight between Egypt and Qatar.'b'The 'b'trial underway now'b' seems particularly cruel. On Dec. 7, Mona Iraqi, a television journalist who works for a pro-government channel, barged into a traditional hammam, or bathhouse, in Cairo, to document 'b'what she billed'b' as \xe2\x80\x9cthe biggest den of group perversion\xe2\x80\x9d in the Egyptian capital. The police, operating in concert with her, promptly raided the establishment. Ms. Iraqi posted photos of naked men being corralled by authorities and promised viewers, in a since-deleted Facebook post, that her expos\xc3\xa9 would feature the \xe2\x80\x9cwhole story of the dens for spreading AIDS in Egypt.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Egyptian government 'b'has persecuted gay men with varying degrees of intensity'b' over the past two decades. The latest crackdown has driven the gay community underground like never before. It is not entirely clear why Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s military leaders have ordered, or condoned, the prosecutions of men accused of being gay. In a deeply conservative Muslim country, demonizing sexual minorities has served in the past as an effective way of deflecting attention from actual problems the state has failed to fix.'b'As part of the investigation, most of the men taken into custody were subjected to forensic anal exams, a depraved practice denounced by human rights groups and discredited by international medical professionals. The tests, performed in an effort to determine whether the men had had anal sex, are used as evidence in judicial proceedings.'b'As the trial, which began on Dec. 21, resumed on Sunday, some of the defendants, standing inside a courtroom cage, used hoodies to cover their faces. Some wept, according to reporters allowed inside the courtroom. The judge 'b'said on Monday'b' that he would issue a verdict on Jan. 12. Gay sex is not explicitly illegal under Egyptian law, so authorities have traditionally charged them with \xe2\x80\x9cdebauchery,\xe2\x80\x9d a broad term typically used to prosecute sex workers.'b'Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s treatment of gays is part of a dismal human rights record that has only gotten worse in recent months. The Obama administration and American lawmakers have not done enough to denounce the abuses of an 'b'increasingly authoritarian Egyptian government,'b' which is one of the largest recipients of 'b'American military aid. 'b'As Congress convenes this week, influential lawmakers should take a fresh look at the plight of vulnerable Egyptians and speak out on their behalf. Among them are Representative Kay Granger, a Texas Republican who 'b'has fought efforts'b' to pare back Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s military package, and Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, the incoming chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.'b'The 26 men on trial now may never be able to shed the stigma this prosecution has inflicted on them, their careers and their families. But strong international condemnation may keep authorities in Egypt from victimizing more men.'b'Not long ago, a friend sent me a speech that the great civic leader John Gardner gave to the Stanford Alumni Association 61 years after he graduated from that college. The speech is chock-full of practical wisdom. I especially liked this passage:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe things you learn in maturity aren\xe2\x80\x99t simple things such as acquiring information and skills. You learn not to engage in self-destructive behavior. You learn not to burn up energy in anxiety. You discover how to manage your tensions. You learn that self-pity and resentment are among the most toxic of drugs. You find that the world loves talent but pays off on character.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou come to understand that most people are neither for you nor against you; they are thinking about themselves. You learn that no matter how hard you try to please, some people in this world are not going to love you, a lesson that is at first troubling and then really quite relaxing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gardner goes on in this wise way. And then, at the end, he goes into a peroration about leading a meaningful life. \xe2\x80\x9cMeaning is something you build into your life. You build it out of your own past, out of your affections and loyalties, out of the experience of humankind as it is passed on to you. ... You are the only one who can put them together into that unique pattern that will be your life.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gardner puts \xe2\x80\x9cmeaning\xe2\x80\x9d at the apogee of human existence. His speech reminded me how often we\xe2\x80\x99ve heard that word over the past decades. As my Times colleague April Lawson puts it, \xe2\x80\x9cmeaning\xe2\x80\x9d has become the stand-in concept for everything the soul yearns for and seeks. It is one of the few phrases acceptable in modern parlance to describe a fundamentally spiritual need.'b'Yet what do we mean when we use the word meaning?'b'The first thing we mean is that life should be about more than material success. The person leading a meaningful life has found some way of serving others that leads to a feeling of significance.'b'Second, a meaningful life is more satisfying than a merely happy life. Happiness is about enjoying the present; meaning is about dedicating oneself to the future. Happiness is about receiving; meaningfulness is about giving. Happiness is about upbeat moods and nice experiences. People leading meaningful lives experience a deeper sense of satisfaction.'b'In this way, meaning is an uplifting state of consciousness. It\xe2\x80\x99s what you feel when you\xe2\x80\x99re serving things beyond self.'b'Yet it has to be said, as commonly used today, the word is flabby and vacuous, the product of a culture that has grown inarticulate about inner life.'b'Let me put it this way: If we look at the people in history who achieved great things \xe2\x80\x94 like Nelson Mandela or Albert Schweitzer or Abraham Lincoln \xe2\x80\x94 it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t because they wanted to bathe luxuriously in their own sense of meaningfulness. They had objective and eternally true standards of justice and injustice. They were indignant when those eternal standards were violated. They subscribed to moral systems \xe2\x80\x94 whether secular or religious \xe2\x80\x94 that recommended specific ways of being, and had specific structures of what is right and wrong, and had specific disciplines about how you might get better over time.'b'Meaningfulness tries to replace structures, standards and disciplines with self-regarding emotion. The ultimate authority of meaningful is the warm tingling we get when we feel significant and meaningful. Meaningfulness tries to replace moral systems with the emotional corona that surrounds acts of charity.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a paltry substitute. Because meaningfulness is built solely on an emotion, it is contentless and irreducible. Because it is built solely on emotion, it\xe2\x80\x99s subjective and relativistic. You get meaning one way. I get meaning another way. Who is any of us to judge another\xe2\x80\x99s emotion?'b'Because it\xe2\x80\x99s based solely on sentiment, it is useless. There are no criteria to determine what kind of meaningfulness is higher. There\xe2\x80\x99s no practical manual that would help guide each of us as we move from shallower forms of service to deeper ones. There is no hierarchy of values that would help us select, from among all the things we might do, that activity which is highest and best to do.'b'Because it\xe2\x80\x99s based solely on emotion, it\xe2\x80\x99s fleeting. When the sensations of meaningful go away then the cause that once aroused them gets dropped, too. Ennui floods in. Personal crisis follows. There\xe2\x80\x99s no reliable ground.'b'The philosophy of meaningfulness emerges in a culture in which there is no common moral vocabulary or framework. It emerges amid radical pluralism, when people don\xe2\x80\x99t want to judge each other. Meaningfulness emerges when the fundamental question is, do we feel good?'b'Real moral systems are based on a balance of intellectual rigor and aroused moral sentiments. Meaningfulness is pure and self-regarding feeling, the NutraSweet of the inner life.'b'The cover story of The New York Times Magazine on Sunday, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Wreck of the Kulluk'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by McKenzie Funk, is one of those articles that you can\xe2\x80\x99t put down even though you know how it turns out. The Kulluk was an offshore exploratory drilling rig, owned by Royal Dutch Shell, which, in December 2012, ran aground in some of the most inhospitable waters in the world.'b'Those waters were the Chukchi and Beaufort Seas in the Arctic Circle, more than 1,000 miles from Dutch Harbor, Alaska, the nearest deep-water port. The rig, which had been towed \xe2\x80\x94 with great difficulty \xe2\x80\x94 to the Beaufort Sea, was in the process of being towed out again, barely two months after the drill bit touched the sea floor, before ice formations would make the route impassable. The Kulluk and its tow soon ran into a series of dangerous storms. Although no one died, Funk keeps you on the edge of your seat by describing in detail the hair-raising ordeal, which led to the tow captain of a rescue tugboat cutting the Kulluk adrift to ensure his own men\xe2\x80\x99s safety. The Kulluk\xe2\x80\x99s crew, meanwhile, was airlifted via helicopter, in a dramatic, and dangerous, rescue.'b'Funk also does a nice job laying out all the mistakes Shell made. Despite spending $6 billion preparing to explore for oil in this remote part of the world, it didn\xe2\x80\x99t plan adequately, and it cut too many corners. According to the Coast Guard, 'b'which investigated the Kulluk disaster'b', not only had Shell\xe2\x80\x99s risk management been \xe2\x80\x9cinadequate,\xe2\x80\x9d but there also had been a significant number of \xe2\x80\x9cpotential violations of law and regulations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I came away from Funk\xe2\x80\x99s article, however, with another thought: Even if Shell had done everything right, what were the chances of something bad happening to the Kulluk, or, more broadly, to any drilling program in that part of the Arctic? They were high. Although this area is considered to hold one of the last great oil fields \xe2\x80\x94 with an estimated 23 billion barrels \xe2\x80\x94 is drilling for it really worth the risks?'b'The first issue is the weather. One of the reasons this remote location is at least theoretically accessible to oil companies is because of climate change. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is less ice, and it is receding from the shore,\xe2\x80\x9d said Michael LeVine, the Pacific senior counsel of Oceana, an environmental group dedicated to preserving the world\xe2\x80\x99s oceans. But, he adds, climate change is also affecting the wind, the water and the currents. An area that was already remote, cold and dark is something else as well: unpredictable. Companies trying to explore for oil in the region are essentially flying blind.'b'Then there is the question of whether the government is up to the task of regulating such high-risk ventures. The answer is: probably not. Even after the Deepwater Horizon spill in the Gulf of Mexico \xe2\x80\x94 and despite 'b'some improvements'b' in safety regulations \xe2\x80\x94 government regulation is still way behind the oil industry. \xe2\x80\x9cThe technological capabilities and the need for oil companies to drill in more remote places has outstripped the government\xe2\x80\x99s ability to keep up with it,\xe2\x80\x9d LeVine told me.'b'There are a host of important environmental issues: the industry hasn\xe2\x80\x99t gotten better at dealing with oil spills since the Exxon Valdez spill 25 years ago, for instance. Yet because the climate is so difficult, the chances of an environmental calamity are increased.'b'As regular readers know, 'b'I am hardly opposed to drilling for oil or gas'b'. Yet this particular high-risk venture seems both foolish and unnecessary. For one thing, the world is awash in oil, thanks to a slowdown in demand and increase in supply because of the fracking revolution. For another, the price of oil is so low as to make new, expensive exploration in the Arctic unprofitable.'b'Most of all, though, we\xe2\x80\x99re just not ready to drill for this oil. As LeVine put it, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe we have the technological capability to extract these resources safely.\xe2\x80\x9d To me, that is the real moral of the story of the Kulluk.'b'Oil companies, of course, are fundamentally built to find oil. Shell had once embraced climate change and the need for renewable energy. But it eventually realized that it lacked the proper expertise, and it got rid of its investments in wind and solar to refocus on oil and gas. Now, like every other big oil company, it must explore for oil in evermore hostile environments, because those are the only fields left untapped. Despite its travails with the Kulluk, Shell has submitted a plan that would have it going back to the Chukchi later this year.'b'The oil in the Arctic Circle isn\xe2\x80\x99t going anywhere. If, two decades from now, we need it, maybe by then the industry and the government will be in a position to drill for it \xe2\x80\x94 and regulate it \xe2\x80\x94 safely. But maybe we\xe2\x80\x99ll get lucky. Or smart.'b'Maybe we\xe2\x80\x99ll never need it at all.'b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'A Dec. 14 'b'column by Mark Bittman'b' offered a serious indictment of our wealthy country\xe2\x80\x99s inability to care for its people. But what is particularly galling is that several other countries serve as models of concern for their populace, and yet we ignore those lessons.'b'As you recently reported, Danish fast-food companies 'b'pay'b' their unionized workers at least $20 an hour, with benefits including five weeks of paid vacation. Fast-food workers in America earn an average of less than $9 an hour, contributing to the tens of millions of working poor who are forced to rely on government assistance to survive.'b'In most European countries mothers receive professional parenting support and almost full pay for many months in order to be with their newborns; we are the only developed country to have no maternity leave policy. And sadly we accept too easily that one in five of our children grow up in poverty, more than in most other developed countries.'b'Nor are we troubled that these other countries proudly provide all their citizens with complete medical coverage. Here many of our Republican-led states have, for political reasons, refused to take the 100 percent financing from Washington to extend Medicaid to more people.'b'On most indexes of people\xe2\x80\x99s well-being, the United States lags far behind comparable nations. The time has come for Americans to acknowledge that we as a nation are failing our citizens. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tough pill to swallow but an essential stimulant to political action, both in the streets and in the polling booths, to right the deplorable way we allow our enormous wealth to be used for private rather than public purposes.'b'The quest for an American exceptionalism of which we could once again be proud has the potential for bringing our nation together across political lines. This agenda must be in the forefront as we begin the new year and look ahead to the 2016 campaign.'b'ARTHUR SALZ'b'\nKew Gardens, Queens, Jan. 5, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is professor emeritus of education at Queens College and founder of its Big Buddy program, which pairs college students with homeless youths.'b''b''b'\n'b'Editors\xe2\x80\x99 Note: 'b''b''b'We invite readers to respond briefly by Thursday for the Sunday Dialogue. Email: 'b'letters@nytimes.com'b''b''b'Another year has come and once again I am trying to remember how things were long ago.'b'Before apps, when there were attention spans, before six-star hotels, when we always had Paris, before hedge-fund honchos, when love was all you needed, I think we got by just the same.'b'Before synching, when pen met paper, before screaming screens in taxis, when there were lulls, before virtual community, before cut-and-paste, to the tap of my Olivetti, in the disorder of carbon-stained fingers and the thrill of the class struggle, before information overload, when there was mystery, before carbon footprints, in the heretofore, before CCTV, in invisibility, before hot yoga, in the galaxy of strangeness, my impression, unless I\xe2\x80\x99m wrong, is that we made the most of our lot.'b'Before January cherries, when fruit had seasons, before global avocado, when you were told to eat up, before New World wine, when wine was tannic and acidic, before plate-size cookies, when greed was contained, before fusion, in scattered division, before the obesity onslaught, in our ordinariness, before efficiency took over, before remorseless software, in our afternoon dazes, could we \xe2\x80\x94 could we \xe2\x80\x94 have gotten by all the same?'b'Memory is fading and I may be wrong \xe2\x80\x94 but before celebrities, when there were starlets, before Google Maps, when our compasses were internal, before virtual flirtation, when legs touched under tables, we felt we managed pretty well. Was it all an illusion? We were accused of joining a terrorist group conspiring against the Egyptian state and reporting \xe2\x80\x9cfalse news.\xe2\x80\x9d In reality, we were simply doing our job as journalists.'b'Then, on Jan. 1, Peter Greste, Baher Mohamed and I learned that our appeal had succeeded and that our case would be retried. In issuing the ruling, the judge said that the Arabic service was biased toward the Muslim Brotherhood and had become a threat to national security.'b'Despite the banning of Al Jazeera Mubasher Misr, I accepted the challenge to run the Al Jazeera English bureau because I trusted the professionalism of its journalists and because I believed the Egyptian government would respect the difference between the two channels.'b'From Day 1, I made that distinction clear in every communication and whenever we interviewed people. We conducted our own booking and news-gathering. The reports my team produced for Al Jazeera English were well sourced, fair and balanced.'b'I also emphasized to the management in Qatar that none of our reports should be dubbed in Arabic and broadcast from the Doha studios where Al Jazeera Mubasher Misr continued to defy the Egyptian ban. Hundreds of people sat quietly in chairs. This was at the L.G.B.T. Community Center in Greenwich Village in November, at an event called the Transgender Day of Remembrance.'b'It happens every year, people coming together to mourn trans individuals lost to murder or suicide. As a trans woman, I wish that the one day on the calendar that recognizes transgender experience was about celebrating the successes of our diverse community, rather than counting the lives we\xe2\x80\x99ve lost. But the losses go on, year after year. And so I lit that candle.'b'The weekend after Christmas, 17-year-old Leelah Alcorn left her house in Kings Mills, Ohio, in the middle of the night. She made her way to Interstate 71, where she stepped in front of a tractor-trailer. 'b'A note'b' she left behind on Tumblr read, in part, \xe2\x80\x9cPlease don\xe2\x80\x99t be sad, it\xe2\x80\x99s for the better. 'b'One study'b' suggests that over 40 percent of us attempt it during the course of our lives.'b'I was among that number. In 1986 I stood at the edge of a cliff in Nova Scotia, looking down at the Atlantic, considering the plunge into the sea below.'b'Then I turned back. Somehow, here I am.'b'Early transition is usually best for trans people. But for many of us it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible, because of unsupportive families, because of a lack of resources, because we do not yet have the courage to embark upon what seems like a frightening path. In that scenario, the best strategy may simply be having faith in the future, and finding a way to survive until you\xe2\x80\x99re able to control your own destiny. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if the things that helped me are of any use to someone born, as Leelah was, in 1997. But the last week has given me occasion to think back on how it was I got this far.'b'My own life was saved in part by books. When I found Jan Morris\xe2\x80\x99s 1974 memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cConundrum,\xe2\x80\x9d it was as if I\xe2\x80\x99d found a wormhole to another universe, a galaxy where people like me could thrive. I wish I could have also given Leelah two more recent works: 'b'Janet Mock'b'\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cRedefining Realness\xe2\x80\x9d and 'b'Kate Bornstein'b'\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHello Cruel World.\xe2\x80\x9d They might have made a difference.'b'If reading provided me with solace, so did writing. Keeping a journal, telling stories, inventing worlds gave me comfort until the time came when I had the agency to make my own choices. Narrative helped me find a through-line in the chaos of my life.'b'There were other times, quite frankly, when simply making a lot of noise saved me, too. I pounded my family\xe2\x80\x99s piano until the strings broke; I played in a band that played two songs, one of which was \xe2\x80\x9cTurn on Your Love Light,\xe2\x80\x9d and one of which was not. Sometimes my own voice echoed back at me.'b'Read, Write, Scream is not exactly \xe2\x80\x9cEat, Pray, Love,\xe2\x80\x9d but it worked for me. In 2015, they might be Europe\xe2\x80\x99s catchphrase.'b'As the United States economy slowly recovers, analysts across the political spectrum see little to cheer them from Europe. Germany is widely viewed as a healthy country whose prosperity helps compensate for Europe\xe2\x80\x99s weakness, yet over the past two quarters for which we have data, it has 'b'experienced no net growth at all. 'b' Predictions of decade-long deflation, low productivity and high unemployment are becoming conventional wisdom.'b'What does the Continent need? Most economists and pundits focus on monetary and fiscal policy, as well as labor-market reform. Get the policy levers and economic incentives right, and the Continent might escape the vortex of decline, right?'b'Probably not. As important as good economic policies are, they will not fix Europe\xe2\x80\x99s core problems, which are demographic, not economic. This was the point made in a speech to the European Parliament in November by none other than Pope Francis. As the pontiff 'b'put it'b', \xe2\x80\x9cIn many quarters we encounter a general impression of weariness and aging, of a Europe which is now a \xe2\x80\x98grandmother,\xe2\x80\x99 no longer fertile and vibrant.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But wait, it gets worse: Grandma Europe is not merely growing old. She is also getting dotty. She is, as the pope 'b'sadly explained'b' in an earlier speech to a conference of bishops, \xe2\x80\x9cweary with disorientation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some readers might regret the pope\xe2\x80\x99s use of language \xe2\x80\x94 we love our grandmothers, weary with disorientation or not. But as my American Enterprise Institute colleague Nicholas Eberstadt shows in his research, the pope\xe2\x80\x99s analysis is fundamentally sound.'b'Start with age. According to the United States Census Bureau\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'International Database'b', nearly one in five Western Europeans was 65 years old or older in 2014. This is hard enough to endure, given the countries\xe2\x80\x99 early retirement ages and pay-as-you-go pension systems. But by 2030, this will have risen to one in four. If history is any guide, aging electorates will direct larger and larger portions of gross domestic product to retirement benefits \xe2\x80\x94 and invest less in opportunity for future generations.'b'Next, look at fertility. According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the last time the countries of the European Union were reproducing at replacement levels (that is, slightly more than two children per woman) was the mid-1970s. In 2014, the average number of children per woman was about 1.6. That\xe2\x80\x99s up a hair from the nadir in 2001, but has been falling again for more than half a decade. Imagine a world where many people have no sisters, brothers, cousins, aunts or uncles. That\xe2\x80\x99s where Europe is heading in the coming decades. On the bright side, at least there will be fewer Christmas presents to buy.'b'There are some exceptions. France has risen to exactly two children per woman in 2012, from 1.95 in 1980, an increase largely attributed to a system of government payments to parents, not a change in the culture of family life. Is there anything more dystopian than the notion that population decline can be slowed only when states bribe their citizens to reproduce?'b'Finally, consider employment. Last September, the United States\xe2\x80\x99 'b'labor force participation rate'b' \xe2\x80\x94 the percentage of adults who are either working or looking for work \xe2\x80\x94 reached a 36-year low of just 62.7 percent.'b'Yet as bad as that is, the United States looks decent compared with most of Europe. Our friends across the Atlantic like to say that we live to work, while they work to live. That might be compelling if more of them were actually working. According to the most recent data available from the World Bank, the labor force participation rate in the European Union in 2013 was 57.5 percent. In France it was 55.9 percent. In Italy, just 49.1 percent.'b'One bright spot might seem to be immigration. In 2012, the median age of the national population in the European Union was 41.9 years, while the median age of foreigners living in the union was 34.7. So, are Europeans pleased that there will be new arrivals to work and pay taxes when the locals retire?'b'Not exactly. Anti-immigrant sentiment is surging across the Continent. Nativist movements performed 'b'alarmingly well'b' in European Parliament elections last year. Europe is less like a grandmother knitting placidly in the window and more like an angry grandfather, shaking his rake and yelling at outsiders to get off his lawn.'b'None of this should give Americans cause for schadenfreude. At a purely practical level, a European market in further decline will suppress American growth. But more important, European deterioration will dissipate the vast good the Continent can do in spreading the values of democracy and freedom around the world.'b'So what is the prescription for Europe\xe2\x80\x99s ills \xe2\x80\x94 and the lesson for America\xe2\x80\x99s future?'b'It is true that good monetary and fiscal policies are important. But the deeper problems in Europe will not be solved by the European Central Bank. No matter what the money supply and public spending levels, a country or continent will be in decline if it rejects the culture of family, turns its back on work, and closes itself to strivers from the outside.'b'Europe needs visionary leaders and a social movement to rediscover that people are assets to develop, not liabilities to manage. If it cannot or will not meet this existential challenge, a \xe2\x80\x9clost decade\xe2\x80\x9d will look like a walk in the park for Grandma Europe.'b'We measure our presidents against not only our hopes for the present, which are sometimes unreasonable, but also our understanding of the past, which can be just as flawed.'b'Has a misreading of history informed a misappraisal of Barack Obama?'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a question raised, not explicitly but implicitly, by a new book by the Princeton historian Julian Zelizer, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fierce Urgency of Now,\xe2\x80\x9d to be published on Thursday.'b'Its setting is the 1960s, as the title, a phrase uttered by Martin Luther King Jr., suggests. Its focus is Lyndon Johnson. And one of its conclusions is that despite Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s legend as a peerless legislative tactician, he was largely a hostage of Congress and of forces beyond the presidency.'b'Zelizer reminds us that many of Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s signature victories came during a two-year period when Democrats had two-thirds majorities in both the Senate, where they held 68 seats, and the House, where they held 295.'b'Zelizer also reminds us that Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s trouncing of Barry Goldwater in the 1964 election spooked Republicans to a point where many fought progressive legislation less stridently than before, lest they be portrayed as Goldwater-style extremists.'b'Those dynamics and others worked powerfully to Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s advantage, and when the climate and the Congress changed, so did his fortunes. On the domestic front (as well as on the foreign one), the final two years of his presidency were a bust, at least in comparison with what preceded them.'b'Obama\xe2\x80\x99s name appears just twice in Zelizer\xe2\x80\x99s book. But it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible not to think of him more often, given how frequently the yardstick of Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s presidency has been applied to his.'b'If only Obama were a schmoozer like Johnson. If only he had Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s taste for the muck of lawmaking. If only he had Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s patience for minutiae.'b'Zelizer told me that when he began work on the book more than five years ago, \xe2\x80\x9cI still had a kind of view of Johnson, as many do, as someone who really knew how to work the system. What\xe2\x80\x99s surprising to me is that as conditions in Congress change, he is really shut down. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect the last part of the book: a president who\xe2\x80\x99s really emasculated and can\xe2\x80\x99t get anything done even though he\xe2\x80\x99s trying the same old tricks. It really became crystal clear to me how Congress determines the fate of the presidency.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Republicans currently control both chambers, and have a House majority bigger than before. That bodes disastrously for Obama\xe2\x80\x99s legislative dreams, and it\xe2\x80\x99s the point of reference for his impulse to wield executive authority.'b'Zelizer said that instances over the last 50 years of a president truly imposing his will on a Congress fully or partly controlled by the opposing party are rare. Ronald Reagan got tax cuts in 1981 despite a Democratic majority in the House, but he\xe2\x80\x99d just shellacked Jimmy Carter in the 1980 elections and Democrats were running scared.'b'Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s name is popping up a lot now. This year is the 50th anniversary of many of the laws grouped under the Great Society, and the movie \xe2\x80\x9cSelma\xe2\x80\x9d is 'b'drawing complaints'b' for its portrayal of Johnson as resistant to voting rights for blacks and sharply antagonistic to King.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not fair to Johnson,\xe2\x80\x9d Zelizer told me.'b'But in his view, Johnson has been considered too kindly by writers who attribute the Great Society to his wizardry.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe was cagey, he was smart, he was politically savvy,\xe2\x80\x9d Zelizer said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explain why the bills passed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And Obama can indeed be cold and disengaged. But, Zelizer said, that\xe2\x80\x99s not why he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t scaled the legislative heights that Johnson did.'b'Johnson benefited from \xe2\x80\x9ca vibrant period for grass-roots mobilization as a result of the civil rights movement,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, adding that there was pressure for legislation from the bottom up, which is most effective.'b'There hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been any commensurate mobilization during Obama\xe2\x80\x99s presidency. Zelizer said that voters frustrated with congressional inertia should examine their own exertions \xe2\x80\x94 and the ways in which campaign financing, lobbying and gerrymandering have created a dysfunctional legislative branch \xe2\x80\x94 as much as any president\xe2\x80\x99s character.'b'Zelizer\xe2\x80\x99s read on things leaves ample room for Obama to be questioned on foreign policy and for not making more of his first two years, when Democrats controlled Congress. It\xe2\x80\x99s also possible that he should have made less of them, that 'b'delaying health care'b' would have spared Democrats their 2010 drubbing and given him additional time with a friendly(-ish) Congress.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s undeniable that we treat our presidents as larger than life, simplifying the stories we tell. They\xe2\x80\x99re not always mighty frigates parting the waters. They\xe2\x80\x99re just as much buoys on the tides of history, rising and falling with the swells.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Film Casts Johnson as Villain, Restarting Civil Rights Debate'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 1), about criticism of a film that depicts President Lyndon B. Johnson as \xe2\x80\x9ca laggard on black voting rights who opposed the marches\xe2\x80\x9d:'b'I have seen Ava DuVernay\xe2\x80\x99s new film, \xe2\x80\x9cSelma,\xe2\x80\x9d and I was also part of this newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s team that covered the civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery in 1965. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'b'A source of mine who helped me understand the situation in Selma was a local black attorney named J. L. In my memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cA Writer\xe2\x80\x99s Life,\xe2\x80\x9d I described Mr. Chestnut\xe2\x80\x99s feelings:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBefore the march, Chestnut had admitted to having concerns that the promotion of black people\xe2\x80\x99s rights were being politically exploited by the Democrats in the White House in order to allow President Johnson to singularly dominate the daily headlines, and Chestnut was then bothered by the possibility that \xe2\x80\x98King was no longer the number-one civil rights leader in America; Lyndon Johnson was ... and we\xe2\x80\x99d been outfoxed and were in danger of being co-opted.\xe2\x80\x99 ...
