Not having my annual physical is one small way I can help reduce health care costs \xe2\x80\x94 and save myself time, worry and a worthless exam.'b'Around 45 million Americans are likely to have a routine physical this year \xe2\x80\x94 just as they have for many years running. A poke here, a listen there, a few tubes of blood, maybe an X-ray, a few reassuring words about diet, exercise and not smoking from the doctor, all just to be sure everything is in good working order. Most think of it as the human equivalent of a 15,000-mile checkup and fluid change, which can uncover hidden problems and ensure longer engine life.'b'There is only one problem: From a health perspective, the annual physical exam is basically worthless.'b'In 2012, the Cochrane Collaboration, an international group of medical researchers who systematically review the world\xe2\x80\x99s biomedical research, analyzed 14 randomized controlled trials with over 182,000 people followed for a median of nine years that sought to evaluate the benefits of routine, general health checkups \xe2\x80\x94 that is, visits to the physician for general health and not prompted by any particular symptom or complaint.'b'The unequivocal conclusion: the appointments are unlikely to be beneficial. Regardless of which screenings and tests were administered, studies of annual health exams dating from 1963 to 1999 show that the annual physicals did not reduce mortality overall or for specific causes of death from cancer or heart disease. And the checkups consume billions, although no one is sure exactly how many billions because of the challenge of measuring the additional screenings and follow-up tests.'b'This lack of evidence is the main reason the United States Preventive Services Task Force \xe2\x80\x94 an independent group of experts making evidence-based recommendations about the use of preventive services \xe2\x80\x94 does not have a recommendation on routine annual health checkups. The Canadian guidelines have recommended against these exams since 1979.'b'How can this be? There have been stories and studies in the past few years questioning the value of the physical, but neither patients nor doctors seem to want to hear the message. Part of the reason is psychological; the exam provides an opportunity to talk and reaffirm the physician-patient relationship even if there is no specific complaint. There is also habit. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to change something that\xe2\x80\x99s been recommended by physicians and medical organizations for more than 100 years. And then there is skepticism about the research. Almost everyone thinks they know someone whose annual exam detected a minor symptom that led to the early diagnosis and treatment of cancer, or some similar lifesaving story.'b'One explanation for the ineffectiveness of the annual exam in reducing the death rate is that it does little to avert death or disability from acute problems. Unintentional injuries and suicides are, respectively, the fourth and 10th leading causes of death among Americans. And it does little for chronic conditions without significantly useful interventions such as Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s, the fifth leading cause of death among older people.'b'Further, researchers have long noted that screening healthy people who have no complaints is a pretty ineffective way to improve people\xe2\x80\x99s health. If you screen thousands of people, maybe you\xe2\x80\x99ll find tens whose exams suggest they might have a disease. And then upon further tests, you\xe2\x80\x99ll find it is really only a few individuals who truly have something. And of those individuals, maybe one or two actually gain a health benefit from an early diagnosis.'b'The others may have discovered a disease, but one that either would never have become clinically evident and dangerous, or one that is already too advanced to treat effectively. For instance, early detection of most thyroid cancers leads to surgery, but in many cases those cancers would not have caused serious problems, much less death. Conversely, for individuals whose annual exams lead to the diagnosis of esophageal or pancreatic cancer, the early diagnosis might extend the time they know they have cancer but is unlikely to extend their lives.'b'Some are actually hurt by physicals, because healthy patients who undergo an exam sometimes end up with complications and pain from further screening or confirmatory tests.'b'My New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolution does not mean I won\xe2\x80\x99t get my annual flu shot or a colonoscopy every 10 years \xe2\x80\x94 or eat a balanced diet and get regular exercise. These are proven to reduce morbidity and mortality. Those who preach the gospel of the routine physical have to produce the data to show why these physician visits are beneficial. If they cannot, join me and make a new resolution: My medical routine won\xe2\x80\x99t include an annual exam. That will free up countless hours of doctors\xe2\x80\x99 time for patients who really do have a medical problem, helping to ensure there is no doctor shortage as more Americans get health insurance.'b'MADISON, N.H. \xe2\x80\x94 A LITTLE before noon on Nov. 18, 1970, a blood-flecked hand pawed the top of the southeast face of El Capitan, the massive, 3,000-foot vertical wall in Yosemite National Park known to climbers as the Dawn Wall. A bearded, wild-eyed man eventually pulled himself up and stumbled back into the realm of horizontal existence after 26 nights lashed to the cliff. Approximately 70 reporters and well-wishers rushed forward to greet him. A dozen TV cameras whirred.'b'In California\xe2\x80\x99s beatnik climbing circles, Warren Harding, who completed the first ascent of Yosemite\xe2\x80\x99s grandest wall that day with his partner, Dean Caldwell, stood out for his penchant for fast sports cars and beautiful women and for his voracious consumption of red wine. When asked why he climbed, he responded, succinctly: \xe2\x80\x9cBecause we are insane.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some years later, Mr. Harding, retired from serious climbing, attended a party in Estes Park, Colo., at the home of Mike Caldwell (no relation to Dean Caldwell), a climber and guide. Tommy Caldwell, 36, is poised with a partner, Kevin Jorgeson, 30, to make history by becoming the first to free climb the same face Mr. Harding and Mr. Caldwell conquered.'b'The distinction is that in free climbing, climbers use only their hands, feet, arms and legs to make upward progress \xe2\x80\x94 and not the bolts, pitons and other contrivances Mr. Harding and his partner used, and for which they were criticized. In free climbing, ropes and other equipment are used only to stop a fall.'b'Many climbers consider the Caldwell-Jorgeson effort, begun on Dec. 27, to be perhaps the most difficult free climb ever attempted.'b'The anticipation and spectacle surrounding it \xe2\x80\x94 an adventure that, thanks to cellphones, social media and the Internet, has been shared by millions of people \xe2\x80\x94 surpass anything imaginable in Mr. Harding\xe2\x80\x99s day. He methodically explored the sheer face by rappelling down from the top of El Capitan on reconnaissance missions, searching for the tiniest wrinkles in the smooth rock to pull himself upward. He fell hundreds of times while attempting the route\xe2\x80\x99s numerous pitches (a pitch is a segment of climbing less than the length of a rope), though he was caught each time by his rope.'b'The resulting route is a masterpiece. The hardest section, Pitches 14 and 15, involved traversing horizontally across the blankest portion of the wall for more than 300 feet. Nous f\xc3\xbbmes \xc3\xa9blouis par l\xe2\x80\x99esprit de collaboration, de cr\xc3\xa9ativit\xc3\xa9 et de joie dans lequel furent choisies la couverture et la l\xc3\xa9gende, la caricature habile de Mahomet par Cabu, le visage cach\xc3\xa9 par ses mains pour \xc3\xa9viter d\xe2\x80\x99enfreindre la r\xc3\xa8gle interdisant de montrer l\xe2\x80\x99image du proph\xc3\xa8te, qui restait provocante malgr\xc3\xa9 tout. Assez provocante, apparemment, pour servir de pr\xc3\xa9texte \xc3\xa0 l\xe2\x80\x99attaque de cette semaine.'b'D\xc3\xa8s la publication des dessins, des policiers furent assign\xc3\xa9s \xc3\xa0 la protection de Cabu. Les menaces de mort ne tard\xc3\xa8rent pas \xc3\xa0 affluer \xc3\xa0 son encontre, mais son humour et son optimisme demeur\xc3\xa8rent intactes. Notre ami Cabu a \xc3\xa9t\xc3\xa9 assassin\xc3\xa9. Aujourd\xe2\x80\x99hui, il nous manque.'b'In February 2006 the editors of the French magazine Charlie Hebdo met to discuss a matter of what turned out to be deadly consequence: Would they publish a satirical image of Muhammad on their cover? We were making a documentary about Jean Cabut, known as Cabu, one of the most famous cartoonists in France. So we were there, filming his conversation with his colleagues as they chose the cover. The issue that came out of this meeting \xe2\x80\x94 with a Cabu cartoon on the cover and the images they discussed here \xe2\x80\x94 turned out to be one of the most popular in the magazine\xe2\x80\x99s history. Almost nine years later, gunmen stormed this very meeting and killed 10 editors and cartoonists, including three of the people in this film: Cabu, Bernard Verlhac (known as Tignous) and Georges Wolinski.'b'Beyond his talent as an artist, our friend Cabu was a formidable character \xe2\x80\x94 his Joan of Arc haircut and John Lennon-style round glasses were inimitable. A former children\xe2\x80\x99s television host, he was goofy, kind, sweet. We loved him. But what Cabu loved was provocation and bad taste: a very French \xe2\x80\x94 political and vulgar, yet sharp \xe2\x80\x94 type of irony. He was right at home at Charlie Hebdo, where he could take uncompromising stands on institutions and leaders of all stripes: politicians, bankers, cops \xe2\x80\xa6 and men of God.'b'In this case, Cabu was supporting cartoonists in Denmark who had just grappled with the same issue in September 2005. The Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten had published 12 cartoons considered blasphemous by many followers of Islam. Arab governments protested officially; there were clashes at protests and demonstrations around the world, leading to more than 200 deaths. Charlie Hebdo had decided to reproduce the complete set of cartoons for its Feb. 8 issue.'b'In filming Cabu\xe2\x80\x99s now historic meeting with his editor in chief and fellow cartoonists and editorialists, we could not know that we were capturing on camera such an important moment. We were just amazed by the collaborative, creative, joyful process that led to the cover and caption, Cabu\xe2\x80\x99s drawing of the Prophet Muhammad, cleverly hiding his face with his hands to avoid breaking outright prohibitions on showing the prophet\xe2\x80\x99s likeness, but still provocative. Provocative enough to apparently serve as the root of this week\xe2\x80\x99s attack.'b'As the cartoon was published, police officers were assigned for Cabu\xe2\x80\x99s protection. As the death threats against him soon poured in, his humor and high spirits remained intact. Our friend Cabu was murdered. Today, we miss him.'b'PARIS \xe2\x80\x94 Wednesday was the day when Michel Houellebecq\xe2\x80\x99s latest novel, \xe2\x80\x9cSoumission\xe2\x80\x9d (Submission), hit the bookstores. It has been all Houellebecq all the time lately, as shrewd marketing from his publishing house made sure that this provocative book on France becoming an Islamic republic in 2022 would get prime-time coverage \xe2\x80\x94 and draw maximum controversy.'b'So Wednesday began with Mr. Houellebecq on morning radio, explaining that, contrary to what he said in 2010, Islam is not \xe2\x80\x9cthe dumbest religion\xe2\x80\x9d after all, and that there is \xe2\x80\x9cspace for negotiation.\xe2\x80\x9d Asked whether his novel was intended to scare people, he replied: \xe2\x80\x9cThe scariest part of the novel is actually the part before the Muslims come to power.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To Mr. Houellebecq, the \xe2\x80\x9cterrifying degree of contempt\xe2\x80\x9d in which, in his view, politicians, judges and journalists are now held in France, is much scarier than electing a decent Muslim president.'b'Mr. Houellebecq\xe2\x80\x99s light and, at the same time, terribly serious comments were still resonating when, three hours later, two heavily armed men entered the newsroom of Charlie Hebdo and perpetrated the worst massacre Paris has witnessed in decades, killing 12 people. It soon became clear that the attackers had acted to punish those free spirits who not only dared to publish, almost 10 years ago, the cartoons of Muhammad printed in a Danish newspaper that had sparked deadly protests, but never backed down after.'b'So much for \xe2\x80\x9cspace for negotiation.\xe2\x80\x9d A nation in shock soon forgot Mr. Houellebecq\xe2\x80\x99s niceties about the advantages of \xe2\x80\x9cmoderate Islam.\xe2\x80\x9d Radical Islam had taken over the news. Again.'b'An American colleague has asked me whether the attack on Charlie Hebdo was comparable to 9/11. There is a big difference: While this attack came as a shock to the French because of the target and the high number of casualties, it did not come exactly as a surprise. We have been living with this threat for a long time now.'b'We have witnessed other hideous terrorist crimes, like Mohammed Merah\xe2\x80\x99s killing of seven people, including three children at a Jewish school, three years ago in three separate attacks in southwestern France. We\xe2\x80\x99ve had journalists and NGO workers kidnapped and assassinated in Syria and Africa. We know that the involvement of French armed forces in the fight against Al Qaeda and the Islamic State in Africa and the Middle East \xe2\x80\x94 an involvement that enjoys broad popular support \xe2\x80\x94 makes us a target for revenge. We are wary of the success of the Islamic State\xe2\x80\x99s recruiting campaigns in our mosques, which have sent more than 1,000 young French jihadis to the Syrian and Iraqi battlegrounds.'b'Yet we also have a big, quiet and nonradicalized Muslim community living among us. Islam is the second religion in France, behind Catholicism. France is home to the biggest Muslim community in Europe, as well as the biggest Jewish community. So in order to try to keep everybody reasonably happy together, we have promoted secularism, giving way to a new motto: Libert\xc3\xa9, \xc3\xa9galit\xc3\xa9, fraternit\xc3\xa9, la\xc3\xafcit\xc3\xa9.'b'This is the country where Muslim girls and Jewish boys can\xe2\x80\x99t wear a veil or a yarmulke in public schools. Or where a couple is politely asked to leave if the woman declines to uncover her fully veiled face, as required by the law, during a performance of \xe2\x80\x9cLa Traviata\xe2\x80\x9d at the Paris Op\xc3\xa9ra. It does not make us popular in the Arab world, but somehow it works at home: Muslim schoolgirls attend classes unveiled, and the couple left the Op\xc3\xa9ra without protesting.'b'But France is also the country of Charlie Hebdo. The 45-year-old satirical newspaper is quintessentially French, in its provocative irreverence, its not-so-tasteful yet very witty humor, its refusal to spare any taboo. The popularity of its cartoonists \xe2\x80\x94 the ones who were sprayed with bullets on Wednesday \xe2\x80\x94 extended well beyond Charlie Hebdo. They had created legendary characters for teenagers\xe2\x80\x99 comic books and the gray pages of enlightened newspapers; they were regular guests on TV.'b'But the eccentric team at Charlie Hebdo stubbornly stood its ground when it started to receive threats after publishing the Muhammad cartoons. In 2011, after another devastating front page headlined \xe2\x80\x9cCharia Hebdo,\xe2\x80\x9d the newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s offices were destroyed in an arson attack. The journalists moved over temporarily to Lib\xc3\xa9ration, then to new offices. Unbowed, however, they did not change a thing, giving equal treatment to rabbis, priests, imams, sports figures and politicians.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt may sound a bit pompous, but I\xe2\x80\x99d rather die standing than live on my knees,\xe2\x80\x9d the newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s editor, St\xc3\xa9phane Charbonnier, who was known as Charb, told Le Monde two years ago. On Wednesday, he died standing.'b'In a moving tribute on French TV, Robert Badinter, a former justice minister who led the fight to abolish the death penalty in 1981, said that these cartoonists, our beloved bad boys, were \xe2\x80\x9ctrue heroes\xe2\x80\x9d because they had been \xe2\x80\x9csoldiers of freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is why the French are in shock. This is not blind terrorism. It is terrorism targeted at the heart of the French identity: Mohammed Merah targeted Jewish schools and Muslim immigrants who had joined the French Army because they were symbols of our diversity. The attackers on Wednesday targeted Charlie Hebdo because it is a symbol of our freedom.'b'So what should we do, torn between \xe2\x80\x9cmoderate Islam\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cradical Islam\xe2\x80\x9d? How should we deal with Islam? The attack on Charlie Hebdo \xe2\x80\x9cis not only a crime, it is a trap,\xe2\x80\x9d warned Mr. Badinter. The trap, of course, is to confuse the two. Just like Marine Le Pen, the leader of the National Front, who immediately stoked fears of \xe2\x80\x9cIslamic fundamentalism\xe2\x80\x9d as if it applied to the whole French Muslim community, and as if it were the principal issue.'b'We are obsessed with the rise of Islam. Like Mr. Houellebecq, French intellectuals can debate Islam and secularism for hours. \xe2\x80\x9cLe Suicide Fran\xc3\xa7ais\xe2\x80\x9d (The French Suicide) \xe2\x80\x94 a book by \xc3\x89ric Zemmour, a political essayist whose views have been compared to those of Ms. Le Pen \xe2\x80\x94 has topped the best-seller list.'b'Yet we have been unable to have a rational national conversation about integrating Islam into our core values. If there is a lesson to learn from Salman Rushdie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSatanic Verses,\xe2\x80\x9d from the murder in Amsterdam of Theo van Gogh, from the saga of the Muhammad cartoons and from the attack on Charlie Hebdo\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9csoldiers of freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d it is that radical Islam can only be fought with the support of moderate Islam.'b'It is a long battle. But we are well- equipped for it, as long as we hold firm to our values. Unbowed. Without taboos. Just like Charlie Hebdo.'b'What being an editorial cartoonist looks like now.'b'SPECIALTY license plates \xe2\x80\x94 which bear the logo of a college or a sports team, or a slogan like \xe2\x80\x9cSave Our Seas\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cStop Child Abuse\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 bring in lots of money for state governments, as well as the schools, nonprofit groups, professional organizations and other entities that sponsor them. But these vehicular tags have also become a new frontier in debates over freedom of speech.'b'The United States Supreme Court is hearing a 'b'lawsuit'b' by the 'b'Sons of Confederate Veterans'b'. It wants Texas to issue a specialty plate showing the Confederate battle flag, which a state panel rejected. The group argues that if Texas allows plates that express some opinions, it also must allow the battle flag, even if the symbol offends many people. Anything less, the group says, amounts to discrimination against its viewpoint, in violation of the First Amendment.'b'A similar 'b'case'b' from North Carolina might also go up to the 'b'Supreme Court'b'. In 2011, the State Legislature 'b'approved'b' a specialty plate with the slogan 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChoose Life.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' Those who seek this specialized plate pay $25, $10 of which goes to the state\xe2\x80\x99s highway fund and $15 of which goes to a pregnancy counseling organization. But when the Legislature refused to issue an abortion-rights plate, the 'b'American Civil Liberties Union'b' 'b'sued'b'.'b'So, oddly, liberal supporters of abortion rights are allied, on this issue, with the conservative descendants of Confederate veterans. Both argue that license plates are private, not state, messages and are therefore protected.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t agree. We think that Texas was right to reject the Confederate plates, but that North Carolina should have issued the abortion rights plates.'b'How can this be? Are we merely siding with liberals in both cases? No.'b'Under constitutional doctrine, when private individuals express themselves, the government cannot discriminate based on their opinions. But when government is speaking (as in messages on public monuments, for example) it can and in fact must pick and choose. License plates are an important form of \xe2\x80\x9cmixed speech,\xe2\x80\x9d blending both government and private messages. The court must balance the private right to free speech with the government\xe2\x80\x99s interest in conveying its own messages. A license plate is not a bumper sticker. Only a private person can decide to display a specialty plate \xe2\x80\x94 but only the state can make it available.'b'Texas rightly sought to avoid the perception that the state was speaking in a way that is contrary to constitutional values like equal protection under the law. It wanted to avoid even the risk of seeming complicit in official nostalgia for the institution of slavery.'b'Imagine a person driving behind a car with a Confederate flag on its license plate. Such a person, especially if she were not familiar with the specialty license plate system, could reasonably think that the flag was displayed with the state\xe2\x80\x99s imprimatur.'b'Why is the North Carolina case different? Unlike in the Texas case, there is no strong government interest in denying pro-choice messages. The right to terminate a pregnancy is currently enshrined in law; the government does not have an important interest in preventing citizens from advertising their existing rights.'b'The Supreme Court could therefore side with Texas, but also with the abortion-rights supporters in the North Carolina case. This would require a balancing approach, holding that the state\xe2\x80\x99s comparatively weak interest in denying the pro-choice plate is outweighed by the group\xe2\x80\x99s interest in expression. Nothing in this approach would deny North Carolina\xe2\x80\x99s ability to transmit anti-abortion messages in other ways, as it already may do.'b'Free-speech absolutists say the only way to avoid government favoring of pro-life messages is to turn license plates into a forum for public debate. In their view, once one message is allowed, all messages must be, and anything but pure neutrality in license plate messaging amounts to an abridgment of free speech.'b'The Supreme Court should reject this view. So far, it has said that when the state speaks, there are no constitutional restrictions on what it can say, other than the Establishment Clause, which prohibits state religion. But that is too narrow. An implied endorsement of a racist message, as in the Texas case, could run afoul of the Equal Protection Clause. Texas has a strong interest in avoiding such a violation, and its judgment that such a risk is present should be given deference.'b'Whatever the court decides could have broader implications. In a dispute in its last term over legislative prayer, for instance, it 'b'waffled'b' on whether prayers given by private clergy at a town\xe2\x80\x99s invitation amount to government speech. Earlier, in 2010, the court struggled to evaluate Congress\xe2\x80\x99s decision to transfer a large cross to private ownership, evidently to frustrate a challenge based on the separation of church and state.'b'Denying the Confederate group\xe2\x80\x99s claims would still leave them options. They can use bumper stickers or follow the example of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Dukes of Hazzard\xe2\x80\x9d and paint the flag on their car. But they may not force the state to help them.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Home Schooling: More Pupils, Less Regulation'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 5):'b'The push for looser requirements and less accountability for parents who home-school their children may obscure gaps in home-schooled children\xe2\x80\x99s education.'b'In general, while children who are home-schooled do well on verbal tests, they do not perform as well in mathematics and have been found to have slightly lower scores on the mathematics SAT and ACT exams. This may limit their academic and career options.'b'In school, students learn social skills, bond with their peers and are exposed to diverse opinions. Children who are home-schooled risk being socially isolated.'b'Parents who home-school may be \xe2\x80\x9cdedicated and self-motivated\xe2\x80\x9d teachers, as one person you quote says, but the quality of the instruction delivered has been shown to be correlated with parents\xe2\x80\x99 educational background, not their motivation. Parents who home-school their children may not have the knowledge of specialized subjects and pedagogical techniques equal to that of trained teachers.'b'Home schooling may be the best option for some children. However, an unregulated curriculum combined with no external assessment of performance will leave many children educationally shortchanged, something no parent who elects to home-school wants.'b'MARLA A. Ship,\xe2\x80\x9d but simply could not afford to.'b'HAROLD LANGUS'b'\nStaatsburg, N.Y., Jan. 7, 2015'b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 IF the new Congress can agree on anything this year, it may well be the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal between the United States and 11 other countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region. Passions run high when it comes to trade deals these days, and the Obama administration is working hard to sell it to labor unions, which roundly oppose it.'b'So far the pitch has been about what the deal, as written, will do to help the American economy \xe2\x80\x94 a pitch that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t won over many, on either side of the partisan divide. But there\xe2\x80\x99s one thing the administration can do that will both win over some opponents and address one of the biggest issues in global trade: add a chapter on currency manipulation.'b'It is not unusual for countries to manage their exchange rate \xe2\x80\x94 the value of their currency relative to others \xe2\x80\x94 to make their exports cheap while making others\xe2\x80\x99 exports to them more expensive. This method has been used extensively by, among others, China, Japan, Malaysia and Singapore \xe2\x80\x94 aside from China, all signatories to the partnership.'b'The American dollar is a prime target for these currency managers. First, the dollar is the global trading system\xe2\x80\x99s premier reserve currency, meaning dollars are freely traded and confidently accepted by international investors. And Americans are a highly acquisitive people \xe2\x80\x94 a nice way of saying we buy a lot of stuff. Consumer spending as a share of gross domestic product is about 70 percent here, 55 percent in Europe and 35 percent in China. We\xe2\x80\x99re steady customers for export-led economies.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong with that, until these exporters start buying dollars to raise the value of the dollar relative to their own currencies, thus subsidizing their exports and taxing their imports. In the United States, the result is persistent trade deficits that have been a drag on growth and jobs \xe2\x80\x94 better-than-average manufacturing jobs \xe2\x80\x94 for decades.'b'In a compelling argument for including a chapter in the Trans-Pacific Partnership to restrict currency manipulation, C. Fred Bergsten of the Peterson Institute for International Economics 'b'estimated'b' that America\xe2\x80\x99s trade deficit \xe2\x80\x9chas averaged $200 billion to $500 billion per year higher as a result of the manipulation\xe2\x80\x9d by the rest of the world, resulting in the loss of one million to five million jobs.'b'The challenge is in the details. Countries buy foreign currencies for various reasons, not just to gain a trade advantage, and they shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily be held to account for doing so. Moreover, opponents of such a chapter argue that it would cover the actions of our own central bank, the Federal Reserve, and open it to charges that it also manipulates exchange rates. (When the Fed lowers the short-term interest rate, or engages in \xe2\x80\x9cquantitative easing\xe2\x80\x9d to lower longer-term rates, one clear consequence is to lower the value of the dollar.)'b'But that argument doesn\xe2\x80\x99t quite hold. It\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of intent, and there is a clear test: whether the central bank is engaging in domestic demand management or currency management, and the simplest way to tell is to observe whether the bank is buying foreign currencies. The People\xe2\x80\x99s Bank of China does a great deal of that. Our Fed does almost none.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s important to recognize that deals like the Trans-Pacific Partnership are not necessarily about \xe2\x80\x9cfree trade.\xe2\x80\x9d They are instead a set of rules; some, like lowering tariffs, lead to freer trade, while others, like expanding patent protections, are more protectionist. Rules governing currency tactics certainly fit the framework.'b'Some purchasing of foreign currency should be fine under the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Some developing economies collect dollars to cover their external debts in case of financial crises and large outflows of private capital. With this in mind, Mr. Bergsten suggests that holding enough foreign currency to cover a year\xe2\x80\x99s worth of external liabilities might be a sound benchmark; anything more would be questionable.'b'Once we\xe2\x80\x99ve agreed on what currency management looks like, what actions would a chapter on it take? These could include a tax on the imports of offending countries, fines, the temporary canceling of certain trade privileges and my favorite, 'b'reciprocal currency intervention'b': If countries can go into currency markets and buy dollars, then we must be able to do the same with their currency. That\xe2\x80\x99s not currently possible with China and other countries, which use capital controls to block such large purchases.'b'Speaking of China, even though it\xe2\x80\x99s not part of the partnership talks, rules like these, especially reciprocity, should be applied to it as well. Not to do so would put the signatory countries at a distinct disadvantage to a trade behemoth with a history of undervaluing its currency to maintain trade surpluses.'b'As a White House economist in the first few years of the Obama administration, I learned that many of my colleagues shared my concerns about currency management. For one thing, they often involve more money \xe2\x80\x94 the direct-selling industry, which includes multilevel marketing, claims that it generates $154 billion in annual revenue and has some 90 million members worldwide. For another, most pyramid schemes take advantage of lower-income people, who are lured in by the prospect of making money while working from home, only to discover that, as pyramid scheme experts will tell you, 99 percent of the people who participate wind up losing money, and sometimes a lot of money.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere are millions of victims,\xe2\x80\x9d says a pyramid scheme expert named Bruce Craig. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why people aren\xe2\x80\x99t interested in this.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Craig is a former Wisconsin assistant attorney general, now retired, who brought a number of pyramid scheme lawsuits in his day. He is passionate about the issue. What frustrates him even more than the lack of attention is the way the government has, in his view, largely rolled over for the industry.'b'A pyramid scheme, fundamentally, is a scheme in which the only way to make money is to recruit other people, who recruit other people, and so on. It is a kind of chain letter with a product attached to give it the sheen of legitimacy. Until 1979, the Federal Trade Commission was pretty tough on pyramid schemes, according to Craig. But that year, an administrative judge for the F.T.C. ruled that Amway was not a pyramid scheme because it had certain protections for its members, such as not requiring a large entry fee and buying back excessive inventory. Since then, with a little finesse, pyramid schemes could turn themselves into multilevel marketing companies.'b'Craig has written letters to F.T.C. commissioners asking them to review the Amway decision \xe2\x80\x9con the question of enforcement and enforceability of its rules,\xe2\x80\x9d an issue he believes allows companies like Amway \xe2\x80\x94 and Herbalife \xe2\x80\x94 to pretend to be real when in fact they are pyramid schemes. In one of those letters, he quoted from a 2010 'b'F.T.C. staff report'b' that said that identifying pyramid schemes \xe2\x80\x9centails a complex economic analysis.\xe2\x80\x9d The report added that \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no bright line disclosure that would help consumers identify a fraudulent pyramid from a legitimate [multilevel marketing company].\xe2\x80\x9d Really?'b'When I spoke to John DeSimone, the chief financial officer of Herbalife, he insisted that the company was legit. He said 80 percent of its members never recruit another person. Ackman, for his part, says that 'b'none of this is true'b', and that the F.T.C. will ultimately see that Herbalife is the very definition of a pyramid scheme.'b'Assuming, of course, that the F.T.C. has a definition. On Friday afternoon, I called the agency and asked what distinguished an illegal pyramid scheme from a legal direct-selling company. Even having talked to Craig, I found it hard to believe that it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have some kind of definition.'b'A few hours later, I received an email from an F.T.C. public relations staffer. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d it began, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to offer you any on (or off) record assistance.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'IS email overload bad for you?'b'This is a complicated question. Although researchers have found a correlation between dealing with email and adverse well-being (for example, feeling stressed or emotionally drained), this does not mean that email itself is necessarily the culprit. (Perhaps a busier work schedule is what causes stress \xe2\x80\x94 and spending lots of time on email is a mere artifact of a busier work schedule.) Furthermore, such research suggests that, even if email is the culprit, the sheer volume of email that people handle might not be the problem.'b'This points to another possibility: Could the 'b'frequency'b' with which you check your email play a role in causing stress? After all, three-quarters of workers report replying to email within an hour or less of receiving it, according to a 'b'recent survey'b' of 503 employees at workplaces in the United States.'b'This question motivated us to design an exploratory two-week 'b'field experiment'b', the results of which will appear in next month\xe2\x80\x99s issue of the journal Computers in Human Behavior.'b'We recruited a sample of 124 adults, ranging from students and professors to physicians and I.T. workers. In the first week of the study, we told half our participants \xe2\x80\x94 chosen at random \xe2\x80\x94 to check their email as often as they could each day, while keeping their mailboxes open and email alerts on. Meanwhile, we asked the other participants to check email only three times a day, while keeping their mailboxes closed and alerts off.'b'During the second week, we flipped the instructions, so the email-maximizers became the email-minimizers, and vice versa. This design allowed us to compare how stressed the same individuals felt when they checked their email more versus less often, while keeping everything else constant.'b'At the end of each weekday, the participants reported how the day had gone on a wide range of measures. To assess stress, we asked them, for example, how often they felt unable to control the important things in their life and how often they had trouble coping with all the things they had to do that day.'b'Although the only thing we changed about the participants\xe2\x80\x99 lives was how often they checked their email, we observed a significant reduction in stress when they checked email less frequently. How much less stressed did people feel during their email-minimizing week compared with their email-maximizing week? The reduction in stress was about as large as 'b'the benefit'b' people get from learning relaxation techniques (e.g., taking deep breaths, visualizing peaceful imagery). In other words, cutting back on email might reduce stress as much as picturing yourself swimming in the warm waters of a tropical island several times a day.'b'Checking email less often may reduce stress in part by cutting down on the need to switch between tasks. An unfortunate limitation of the human mind is that it cannot perform two demanding tasks simultaneously, so flipping back and forth between two different tasks 'b'saps cognitive resources'b'. As a result, people can become 'b'less efficient'b' in each of the tasks they need to accomplish. In addition to providing an unending source of new tasks for our to-do lists, email could also be making us less efficient at accomplishing those tasks.'b'Indeed, although the participants in our study sent and received roughly the same number of emails during both weeks, they reported doing so in approximately 20 percent less time during the week when they checked their email less frequently. Constantly monitoring our inboxes promotes stress without promoting efficiency. When it comes to checking email, less might be more.'b'But habits are difficult to break. Even when we asked participants to check email only three times a day, they typically admitted to logging in almost five times a day. And while writing this article about the value of cutting back on email, we found our own eyes drawn toward our inboxes.'b'For some individuals, though, checking email less frequently is simply not an option. The stockbroker who misses a million-dollar deal by logging off email is likely to feel more, not less, stressed. That said, most of us probably check our email more often than is truly necessary to get our job done. A 'b'recent survey'b' found that 55 percent of workers reported checking their email after 11 p.m. \xe2\x80\x94 and 6 percent reported checking email while they or their spouse were in labor. (One of the authors of this article admits to falling into this 6 percent.)'b'Far from offering a magic number that works for all, our findings simply suggest that making the effort to close the gap between necessity and compulsion is worthwhile. So if you\xe2\x80\x99re still hunting for a New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolution, try to resist visiting your inbox as often as you feel compelled to do.'b'NEVER before have so many people been on the move. New opportunity, like a bright star, draws immigrants across the world. In every one of the past four generations my family has moved, hopping from Lithuania to what is now South Africa and on to Britain, Israel and the United States. Sometimes they have found success and happiness. But the other side of displacement, its black sun, is loss.'b'The strain of burying the past, losing one identity and embracing another, can be overwhelming. Home is an indelible place. It is the landscape of unfiltered experience, of things felt rather than thought through, of the world in its beauty absorbed before it is understood, of patterns and sounds that lodge themselves in the psyche and call out across the years. When home is left behind, or shattered, an immense struggle often ensues to fill the void.'b'I was born in London to South African Jewish parents. We left almost immediately for South Africa, lived there for two years and returned to Britain. Although the word was never uttered, we were immigrants. Our priority was assimilation into Englishness. Pogroms and penury had been left far behind. The past was as silent as a village at the bottom of a dam.'b'Why then was I tugged to Israel as a college student? Our Jewish identity had been dribbling away ever since my great-grandparents and grandparents left Lithuania for South Africa around the turn of the 20th century. It was a slow process but appeared inexorable.'b'Having been persecuted as Jews in the Eastern European shtetl, my forebears put their faith in education and science to usher them from backwardness. My father did have a bar mitzvah in Johannesburg in 1934 but hated the experience, seeing it as an exercise in obscurantism and hypocrisy. He reached England in the mid-1950s with no inclination to inflict such instruction on me.'b'His was the silence, or at least discretion, shared by many Jews \xe2\x80\x94 whether Holocaust survivors or not \xe2\x80\x94 in the postwar years, especially in Europe. There was after Auschwitz something shameful about survival that no Jew could abjure. Why them and not me? Better, at least in England, to look forward, work hard, say little, and confine protest to shunning German cars.'b'Tradition and custom and ceremony went missing. No days were different from any other days. We did not have a Christmas tree. Nor did we have anything else. Our deity was academic and professional achievement. My father\xe2\x80\x99s rise as a scientist in his adopted country was meteoric.'b'Nonetheless in time I wanted what I was not given, a Jewish identity, because that, simply, is what I felt myself to be, a Jew. Being called a \xe2\x80\x9cYid\xe2\x80\x9d during my first year in high school stirred within me a lost and then defiant identity. In England, Philip Roth wrote, people\xe2\x80\x99s voices always drop \xe2\x80\x9cjust a little\xe2\x80\x9d when Jews are mentioned \xe2\x80\x94 and indeed my mother\xe2\x80\x99s voice used to drop when she said the word in the land of Lewis Namier\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctrembling Israelites.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Adaptation to England, with its retreat-from-empire gloom, proved too much for my mother, June. Born on Human Street in the small South African mining town of Krugersdorp in 1929, she was bright and full of laughter, with lovely, pale skin and thick, bouncy curls. She was highly strung, with a rapier wit. In 1950, upon graduation from Johannesburg\xe2\x80\x99s University of the Witwatersrand, she married Sydney, a young doctor born on Honey Street in the Berea district of the city. A few years later the girl from Human Street and the boy from Honey Street decided to turn their backs on the horrors of apartheid. They emigrated.'b'June\xe2\x80\x99s first depression occurred soon after. It came on after she was uprooted, bounced back and forth between England and South Africa, set down at last in north London in 1957, pregnant with my younger sister, Jenny. She had a hardworking husband and was obliged to get on with life as best she could as she raised two infants without all the support she had known in South Africa. She placed coins in a meter for hot water. She strained to fit in, to drop South Africa and its tight-knit Jewish community, to belong again. She wanted to help my father, her overriding goal always. Instead, she collapsed.'b'She was admitted in 1958 to a sanitarium near London. Diagnosed with \xe2\x80\x9cpost-puerperal depression,\xe2\x80\x9d she first underwent electroshock treatment on July 30, 1958, and again on Aug. 1, 1958, the day before my third birthday, as it took me more than a half century to discover. Later she suffered from manic depression and never shook it off. In each generation of my family the condition recurred \xe2\x80\x94 a great-uncle in Johannesburg, a cousin who committed suicide in Tel Aviv at age 28. The question is whether my mother\xe2\x80\x99s condition was endogenous, a purely pharmacological issue, or exogenous, a psychological issue tied to our Jewish odyssey of the 20th century and the tremendous pressure of wandering, adapting, pretending, silencing and forgetting.'b'There can be no absolute answer. The study of epigenetics is a relatively new one that seeks to explore how something in the external environment can, in the words of Rachel Yehuda, an Israeli-born neuroscientist and psychiatrist, \xe2\x80\x9caffect the internal environment, and before you know it a gene is functioning in a different way.\xe2\x80\x9d Evidence is growing of such trauma-induced changes. Yehuda quoted Ezekiel in a recent interview with Tablet: \xe2\x80\x9cThe fathers ate sour grapes, and the children\xe2\x80\x99s teeth were set on edge.\xe2\x80\x9d My mother was always on edge. After the electroshock treatment she was like a tree hollowed out by lightning. As her life progressed, she craved return to the sun and South Africa.'b'This was not supposed to happen. As immigrants, our gaze was to be forward-looking. June, despite her suffering, made an immense effort to that end. But the shock of upheaval can prove too much for some people. The project of starting anew collapses; its foundations are too weak.'b'European societies make fitting in harder than America. The difference between those who came first and those who came last in the United States is negligible beside the intricate matter of British ancestry \xe2\x80\x94 not to mention the subtle matter of British anti-Semitism. June had been raised in a cocoon of new South African wealth so enveloping as to eliminate, almost overnight, the Lithuanian past. I was raised an English boy, as if England were my birthright.'b'A child of repetitive Jewish displacement, I would sit in a Christian epicenter of continuity, Westminster Abbey, every school-day morning. This irony was lost on me. I was unaware that my paternal grandparents and much of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s family came from the shtetls of northern Lithuania; or that my upbringing, while bestowing the gifts of a superb liberal education, had also been devoted to the expunging of this past, as well as to the suppression of the not-unrelated history of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s mental breakdown.'b'I see my forebears losing touch with one another and fanning out across the world. I see the ebb and flow of their fortunes and the battle for assimilation. Theirs is a constant, almost manic, reinvention \xe2\x80\x94 in Johannesburg, in London, in Jerusalem, in Cleveland. Yet all the while they carry within them a bipolar gene that forms an unbroken chain with the past, liable to surface at any moment. They fight for that feeling of belonging that goes with home, the elusive place where, as Robert Frost noted, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you have to go there, they have to take you in.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'My mother\xe2\x80\x99s suicide note to my father of July 25, 1978, was found in the Hampstead house on the hill she loved; the house she had, in a bout of manic activity, agreed to sell the previous March to buy a Georgian terraced jewel on Lord North Street in central London, only to cancel the sale when she plunged back into a depression in June.'b'She had suffered from a combination of symptoms: weight loss, dizzy spells, hot flashes, as well as alternating hyperactivity and inertia, or manic depression. In early February, a doctor had again suggested electroshock treatment. No! Two decades on from her 1958 confinement, she would not return to that hell. She would not tolerate again the metal plates being strapped to her swabbed temples, enclosing her skull in its high-voltage carapace.'b'The strain of hiding her condition was enormous. She had to pursue her work as a magistrate and maintain the outward appearance of familial stability. Voiding the real estate deal concluded in manic March filled June with guilt over the time and money wasted. One thing about mania, with its rashness and rages, is that it provides plenty of legitimate reasons for remorse during the ensuing depressive phase.'b'My father came home from work and found the bedroom doors closed. He thought little of it. June was often in bed. He fixed himself a whiskey, sat down with the papers. It was a mild summer\xe2\x80\x99s evening, sunlight glinting through the trees, clouds of gnats against the fence. June\xe2\x80\x99s cycles were running at three-month intervals. With luck, come September she would be active again. Sydney tossed the papers aside. He tried the bedroom door. It was locked. He raced around to the other door, from the bathroom.'b'It was locked. He ran outside. The net curtains were drawn. The windows looked sealed. On closer inspection, one was very slightly ajar.'b'My mother lay sprawled on the bed, a bottle of gin beside her. She had taken large doses of doxepin and Valium, washed down with the gin. Her arms were thrown back behind her head.'b'Her pupils were scarcely responsive, her breathing shallow. The suicide note written to my father was beside her bed: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are made to do great things, make immensely useful discoveries to aid all mankind and I\xe2\x80\x99m leaving you to continue unimpeded by my burden. I so much hoped to help you and to help you and to love and adore you ...\xe2\x80\x9d June survived, just. The emetic effect of the gin probably saved her. She vowed to us all that she would never again \xe2\x80\x9cresort to such a drastic step.\xe2\x80\x9d But death was always the cajoling voice in her ear.'b'June tried to kill herself again on June 15, 1982. Again there was a suicide note. Again, she survived, barely. At last cancer took her on Jan. 2, 1999, at age 69.'b'Mental illness is a charnel house from which nobody escapes unscathed. My parents\xe2\x80\x99 marriage, in its last two decades, was filled with terrible silences and fierce eruptions. After the loss of my mother, I had to find vitality at any price. Every relationship was a mausoleum in the making.'b'When a parent dies unhappy, there is something unresolved that keeps nagging. It is irrational to want to save my mother from her torment \xe2\x80\x94 and now I cannot anyway. Still, because of her, I had to go back. The void, ever renewed, that her absence has left can be explained only by her refusal to stop believing in love, however compromised by frailty her expression of it was. Love and acceptance and stoicism and dignity were, against all odds, her fundamental and enduring lessons. Her spirit, housed too long in that troubled body, had immense strength.'b'IT was my father she had loved most deeply, despite everything. My father, who had begun another relationship to survive, and who had hardened with the demands and the secrecy of that involvement, crumpled with a grief that shocked him after my mother\xe2\x80\x99s death. He wrote to me:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYour expanding memories of Mom have become infinitely precious and important; I share with you the vision of a light which is the obverse of her tormenting darkness and which in some miraculous way has become completely dominant since her death. I hope and pray that this vision of her will be an enduring source of strength and inspiration to you in all the years ahead, ever cherished and unsullied.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor myself, I did have a fleeting dream of a few tranquil years carrying me into the sunset. I still hope for that in a mental and bodily sense. But I know that my spirit will not soon be released from those cruel demons that tore so relentlessly at the entwining fabric of love between Mom and me. I did strive within the feeble limits of my human fallibility to preserve and cherish and sustain her. But alas \xe2\x80\x94 for Mama ultimately, death was the only angel that could shield her from despair.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We were too undone to ask for the urn with my mother\xe2\x80\x99s ashes. I do not know where it ended up. The girl from Human Street left no trace of her anguished passage across the earth, from the Southern to the Northern Hemisphere. After her high school records from Barnato Park in Johannesburg, after the bulk of her medical records from the Holloway Sanatorium near London, her very physical remains vanished, too. From an early age, I had grown used to deploying my imagination as a defense. I told many other stories with many foreign datelines before I realized, returning to the place where I began, that the one story I had to tell was hers \xe2\x80\x94 and through hers that of a far-flung Jewish family, tied by the pain of forgetting, the strain of assimilation, the curse of mental illness and the ever-renewed consolation of love.'b'A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.'b'WELCOME visitors to New York City! This has been the best time ever to urinate on a street, sneak onto the subway or run a red light, for the police force has been on a virtual strike.'b'Police officers 'b'may be making a point for contract negotiations'b'. But many also are genuinely frustrated and, along with millions of other Americans, seem sympathetic to an argument that goes like this:'b''b'The real threat to young black men isn\xe2\x80\x99t white cops. I read it like an evolutionary detective story to find out how we became what we are.'b''b'LISTENING'b' I\xe2\x80\x99ve just digitized all the hundreds of CDs and tapes I own and put them on a sound system called 'b'Sonos'b'. It\xe2\x80\x99s the size of three Olympic pools in a row.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99VE been called many unpleasant things in my life, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve deserved no small number of them. Equality is increasingly being enshrined into law, and one response from those opposed to it is that the law shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t apply to them.'b'Why? Because it contradicts their religious beliefs, which they use as a fig leaf for intolerance.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the new wave, the new frame,\xe2\x80\x9d James Esseks, a lawyer with the A.C.L.U., told me. That\xe2\x80\x99s it.'b'But also, \xe2\x80\x9creligious liberty\xe2\x80\x9d sounds disturbingly like a dog whistle to the crowd that wants specified, codified exemption from anti-discrimination laws; it\xe2\x80\x99s one of the phrases they lean on. If he did, he just sided, for the moment, with religious extremists.'b'As these lamentations about religious liberty get tossed around, it\xe2\x80\x99s worth remembering that racists have used the same argument to try to perpetuate segregation. Esseks noted that even after the Civil Rights Act, the owner of the Piggie Park restaurant chain in South Carolina maintained that he could refuse to serve black people because his religion forbade the mixing of races. The courts were unimpressed.'b'Christian fundamentalists in this country are practiced at claiming marginalization and oppression. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re always saying they\xe2\x80\x99re kept out of the public square, and that\xe2\x80\x99s baloney,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marci Hamilton, a constitutional law expert and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cGod vs. the Gavel.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all over the public square.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'They and their churches inject themselves into political debates while enjoying tax-exempt status. They get public support in questionable circumstances. After a student Christian magazine insisted on its right to funds from the University of Virginia, the Supreme Court decided in 1995 that if a nonreligious publication got financial help from a public school, so must a religious publication, even if it\xe2\x80\x99s proselytizing.'b'And churches have been allowed to adopt broad, questionable interpretations of a \xe2\x80\x9cministerial exception\xe2\x80\x9d to anti-discrimination laws that allow them to hire and fire clergy as they wish.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more, in a country that\xe2\x80\x99s not supposed to promote any one religion over others, we do precisely that.'b'Would we be content to let a Muslim store owner who believes that a woman should always cover her hair refuse service to women who do not? So why should a merchant whose version of Christianity condemns homosexuality get to exile gays and lesbians?'b'Baking a cake, arranging roses, running an inn: These aren\xe2\x80\x99t religious acts, certainly not if the establishments aren\xe2\x80\x99t religious enclaves and are doing business with (and even dependent on) the general public.'b'Their owners are routinely interacting with customers who behave in ways they deem sinful. They don\xe2\x80\x99t get to single out one group of supposed sinners. If they\xe2\x80\x99re allowed to, who\xe2\x80\x99s to say they\xe2\x80\x99ll stop at that group?'b'I respect people of faith. I salute the extraordinary works of compassion and social justice that many of them and many of their churches do. I acknowledge that we in the news media, because we tend to emphasize conflict and wrongdoing and hypocrisy, sometimes focus more on the shortcomings of religious institutions than on their positive contributions.'b'And I support the right of people to believe what they do and say what they wish \xe2\x80\x94 in their pews, homes and hearts.'b'But outside of those places? You must put up with me, just as I put up with you.'b'JOHANNESBURG \xe2\x80\x94 A FEW weeks ago, as I was leaving my office, I stopped at a traffic light and watched a young woman cross the street in front of me. She wore a pair of jean shorts cut fashionably high, and I could see the crease of her left buttock extend each time she took a step. She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been out of place in London or New York or Tokyo. Except that this was Johannesburg, the biggest city in a country known for its high levels of violence against women. As I pulled away, I worried that she might be assaulted.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m not suggesting that she was inviting trouble. I was anxious because she was walking near the spot where a young woman in a miniskirt had been attacked by a crowd of men a few years earlier. I\xe2\x80\x99d also just watched 'b'footage'b' of a crowd attacking and stripping a miniskirt-clad woman in Nairobi just days after the release of the viral video of a woman in New York being catcalled. A few weeks later, another video surfaced in Zimbabwe\xe2\x80\x99s capital, Harare. A girl in a short dress was dragged from a minibus onto the street, where an angry crowd of men stripped her naked.'b'Public strippings represent the front lines of a cultural war against women\xe2\x80\x99s advancements in traditionally conservative but rapidly urbanizing societies. They aren\xe2\x80\x99t really about what women are wearing. They are much more about where women are going.'b'And many African women are going places quickly. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala became the first female finance minister in Nigeria; Liberia\xe2\x80\x99s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, is one of a handful of elected female heads of state in the world. Lupita Nyong\xe2\x80\x99o\xe2\x80\x99s Oscar win and Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie\xe2\x80\x99s literary successes have brought attention to the artistic triumphs of a younger generation of women.'b'Nowhere has progress been more remarkable than in Africa\xe2\x80\x99s legislatures. Africans have significantly outpaced their female peers in America and Europe. In the United States, women hold less than 20 percent of the seats in Congress; similarly, in Britain, women make up just over one-fifth of the members of the House of Commons. Compare this to South Africa, where more than 'b'40 percent'b' of representatives in the National Assembly are women, or Rwanda, where 64 percent of all members of Parliament are women \xe2\x80\x94 making it the only country in the world where women outnumber men in the legislature.'b'Beginning in the 1980s, many African countries started to invest in girls\xe2\x80\x99 education and in small enterprise projects. A generation later, an equal number of girls and boys are enrolled in primary schools across the continent. Many women are successful entrepreneurs and, of course, politicians. Precisely because of these rapid changes in women\xe2\x80\x99s status, the backlash from churches, political parties, traditional leaders and rural officials has been forceful. Outrage at bold women is both spontaneous and organized. The mob mentality that leads to public strippings arises in urban milieus where male aggression against women is seen as acceptable. Meanwhile, many churches systematically preach female subservience, while traditional tribal leaders often blame women for dislodging men from their rightful places in modern societies.'b'It has taken some time for this conservative backlash to develop into a coherent and organized force, but today these churches, traditional leaders and politicians are forming powerful coalitions that are seeking to challenge decades of progress.'b'First, this loose men\xe2\x80\x99s movement developed a set of \xe2\x80\x9cdecency bills\xe2\x80\x9d urging women not to undermine their African culture by dressing \xe2\x80\x9cinappropriately.\xe2\x80\x9d In Uganda, an anti-pornography bill initially sought to criminalize the display of \xe2\x80\x9csexual parts of a person such as breasts, thighs, buttocks or genitalia\xe2\x80\x9d and to ban behavior that might cause sexual excitement. Overzealous police officers began to arrest women wearing short skirts even before Parliament voted on the measure. Fierce opposition from women\xe2\x80\x99s groups forced changes to the final bill signed last year by President Yoweri Museveni, but it remains a vague and problematic law that gives broad discretion to state officials to define pornography and arrest those suspected of an ill-defined crime.'b'Second, and more pernicious, the movement against women\xe2\x80\x99s rights has resorted to bullying and baiting successful women in public spaces. In South Africa, one of the most popular and trusted figures in the country is Thuli Madonsela, who holds the office of public protector. Political cartoonists often depict her as a caped superhero on a mission to bust corrupt politicians. She is widely respected for her refusal to back down in the face of political pressure related to her investigation of the government\xe2\x80\x99s spending on a palatial personal residence for President Jacob G. Zuma.'b'Despite her popularity, it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been an easy ride for Ms. Madonsela and other women who occupy prominent public positions. They have often been subjected to sexist verbal abuse and taunts and jeers about how they look and dress. Members of the ruling party have had to be called to order after insulting Ms. Madonsela\xe2\x80\x99s appearance. Last year, a pregnant member of Parliament was mocked so viciously about the outfit she was wearing that she had to be hospitalized for stress.'b'THESE verbal assaults in the halls of power are mirrored by the experiences of women on the streets, who don\xe2\x80\x99t have easy access to the constitutional or party protections that public figures enjoy. Ordinary African women, it seems, are bearing the brunt of their sisters\xe2\x80\x99 progress. Street harassment is often a sign of deep-seated resentment of women\xe2\x80\x99s changing status in society. For men who were raised to believe that they are entitled to be breadwinners and receive sexual gratification and domestic subservience from women, the shift hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been easy. For younger men, modern values have jostled sharply against the lessons about manhood they learned at home. With high levels of unemployment and gaping inequalities, old conceptions of masculinity die hard.'b'South Africa has what is considered the most progressive constitution in the world, including a bill of rights that promotes and protects women\xe2\x80\x99s rights. Despite this, in 2012, the Congress of Traditional Leaders of South Africa sponsored a bill in Parliament that would have effectively made all women in rural areas legal minors, subject to the whims of traditional chiefs. Had it become law, the bill would have created a separate legal system for millions of people living in rural areas. Chiefs would have been able to force their subjects to adhere to customary laws and practices that are outmoded and unconstitutional, and it would have been a crime for those living in areas covered by traditional courts to opt out and seek justice in the formal legal system.'b'This attempt to disenfranchise millions of women in one of Africa\xe2\x80\x99s most vibrant constitutional democracies demonstrates the extent to which advances in gender equality are often met with hostility.'b'Fortunately, the continent is home to loud and organized women\xe2\x80\x99s movements that have thus far been able to repel many attempts to undermine women\xe2\x80\x99s progress through protests and parliamentary campaigns and the creative use of media and technology.'b'Their protests have been daring and their collective message has been clear: The walk from the streets to the halls of power may be long, but the goal is well within reach.'b'ATLANTA \xe2\x80\x94 THE groundswell of protests over police brutality in the closing days of 2014, when people dropped to the marble floor of Grand Central Terminal and shut down the Brooklyn Bridge, blocked Lake Shore Drive in Chicago and chanted \xe2\x80\x9cI Can\xe2\x80\x99t Breathe\xe2\x80\x9d from Boston to Oakland, summoned ghosts not only of the marches of the civil rights era but of the larger forces that led to the arrival of so many African-Americans in the big cities of the North and West in the first place.'b'Dozens of cities would ultimately join in these demonstrations of discontent. But a map of the largest protests those first nights, and of the high-profile cases of police violence in recent months, lit up like a map of the Great Migration: New York, Chicago, Cleveland, St. Louis, Philadelphia, Washington, Los Angeles, Oakland, all of them the major receiving stations of the movement. These were the places to which generations of African-Americans fled to escape the state-sanctioned violence their descendants have now faced in the North and West.'b'In matters of racial injustice, the South has been the center of attention since before the time of the Civil War. But the North, with its shorter history of a mass black population, has only more recently dealt with the paradox of an enlightened ideal coexisting with racial disparity. The protests have become a referendum on the black condition since the Great Migration. \xe2\x80\x9cThe protests are beginning to wake people up to the idea that the problems are not only there but have been obvious all along,\xe2\x80\x9d the historian Taylor Branch told me. \xe2\x80\x9cIt feels like the South in the 1950s.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It was because of the Great Migration \xe2\x80\x94 six million black Southerners fleeing Jim Crow from World War I to the 1970s \xe2\x80\x94 that African-Americans now live in every state of the union. They were seeking political asylum within their own country in what was, in effect, one of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s largest and longest mass demonstrations against injustice. It was barely recognized for what it was at the time, arising as it did organically, rather than from a single leader, much like the protests today. Both migrants and protesters were pleading with the world to take notice that something was terribly wrong in the places where they lived.'b'In the early decades of the 20th century, a caste system ruled the South with such repression that every four days an African-American was lynched for some perceived breach or mundane accusation \xe2\x80\x94 having stolen 75 cents or made off with a mule. Those conditions forced most every black family to consider the best course of action to feel safe and free. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere can we go,\xe2\x80\x9d a black woman in Alabama wrote in 1902, \xe2\x80\x9cto feel that security which other people feel?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Generations later, police killings of African-Americans occur as often as twice a week for at times mundane infractions and at three times the rate as for whites, according to conservative estimates from recent studies. What happens in the moments after these encounters reveals a disregard for black life as disturbing as the shootings themselves. In the case of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old with a toy gun who was shot within seconds of a squad car\xe2\x80\x99s arrival at a Cleveland park, new video released this week showed officers wrestling the boy\xe2\x80\x99s 14-year-old sister to the ground and handcuffing her as she appeared to run toward her bleeding brother.'b'Such cases force black families again to consider how to safeguard their children and themselves from the violence they suffer at a disproportionate rate at the hands of authorities assigned to protect them. They are still giving a version of the same talk their ancestors gave their children back in the old country of the South, about answering yes, sir, and no, sir, and watching how they comport themselves around the upper caste and the police.'b'Now, as then, those kitchen table discussions signal a painful coming to terms with one\xe2\x80\x99s tenuous condition in one\xe2\x80\x99s own land. What was little understood at the time of the migration was that the refugees from the South shared the same dreams as the immigrants who stepped off the ships at Ellis Island, huddled masses yearning to breathe free. One of the few contemporaneous studies in the early years of the migration, published by the Chicago Commission on Race Relations in 1922, surveyed Southern migrants to determine why they had come north and what they had hoped to find. The migrants responded:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFreedom in voting and the conditions of the colored people here.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFreedom and chance to make a living.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFreedom and opportunity to acquire something.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFreedom of speech, right to live and work as other races.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFreedom of speech and action. Can live without fear, no Jim Crow.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Those desires went little noticed. Indeed, it was resentment toward the Southerners\xe2\x80\x99 arrival and obstacles to their entering the mainstream of Northern life that helped create the current conditions. Northern cities had had limited exposure to African-Americans. These cities were ill-prepared to absorb large numbers of asylum seekers who stood out from the rest of the population.'b'And so the newcomers were met with suspicion. Often recruited as strikebreakers, they were denied access to some unions and trades and were paid the lowest wages for the dirtiest work. They were roped off into overcrowded ghettos by means of redlining and periodic firebombings of homes purchased by black residents who breached the de facto wall of segregation.'b'Unlike the immigrants from Europe, they could not shield themselves from the assumptions about their heritage or blend into the majority just by Anglicizing their names or mastering the senator\xe2\x80\x99s English. They stood out as the children of enslavement and Jim Crow, unable to escape the burden of a pained history.'b'It was a measure of how dire conditions were in the South that the Great Migration continued into the 1970s. When it began, 90 percent of all African-Americans were living in the South. By the time it ended, nearly half of all African-Americans lived elsewhere.'b'Notably, however, high profile-cases of police brutality have recently come to be associated with the North rather than the South. And it is in the South that two recent cases of police shootings of unarmed black people resulted in more vigorous prosecution. Last month, as protests raged over the deaths of Michael Brown in Missouri, Eric Garner in New York and John Crawford and Tamir Rice in Ohio, Randall Kerrick, a police officer in Charlotte, N.C., made his first court appearance on a charge of voluntary manslaughter in the 2013 death of 'b'Jonathan Ferrell'b'. Mr. Ferrell was an unarmed black motorist who was shot 10 times as he sought help after a car accident. In September, Sean Groubert, a South Carolina state trooper, was fired after shooting an unarmed man, 'b'Levar Jones'b', during a traffic stop over a seatbelt violation. In a widely circulated video of the incident, Mr. Jones asked the trooper with humbling composure, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I do, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d Then: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you shoot me?\xe2\x80\x9d He survived his injuries. The trooper was arrested and charged with aggravated assault and battery, a felony that carries a possible 20-year prison term.'b'The nation still has far to go, but this, at least, seems cause for hope. It suggests that the South, after decades of wrestling with its history, is now willing to face injustice head on. And it suggests that the North, after decades of insisting that it was fairer and more free, could eventually do the same.'b'It is not known what will come of the current upheaval in the North. The protests are a response to unprosecuted police brutality but are also a plea for recognition of African-Americans\xe2\x80\x99 humanity. How can success be measured when the goals are so basic and enduring? History tells us that enough people acting together can have an impact beyond what could be imagined. The Great Migration changed American culture as we know it, produced jazz and Motown, playwrights and novelists, and transformed the social geography of most every city outside of the South. At the start of the movement, one of its chroniclers put the migrants\xe2\x80\x99 aims in perspective. \xe2\x80\x9cIf all of their dream does not come true,\xe2\x80\x9d The Chicago Defender newspaper wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cenough will come to pass to justify their actions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If the events of the last year have taught us anything, it is that, as much progress has been made over the generations, the challenges of color and tribe were not locked away in another century or confined to a single region but persist as a national problem and require the commitment of the entire nation to resolve.'b'Twice recently, Iran\xe2\x80\x99s president, Hassan Rouhani, has acted boldly in support of his biggest political gamble, pursuit of a nuclear agreement with the major powers. This would invite more sanctions, new tensions and perhaps even military action and a cyberattack.'b'Gasoline prices have fallen more than 40 percent since the end of June thanks to the collapse of global oil prices.
