I found out the hard way that you can\xe2\x80\x99t get these knuckleheads to agree on anything except their right to be re-elected.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His BlackBerry ring-a-ding dings, flashing a Florida area code.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat better not be Webster or Yahoo,\xe2\x80\x9d he mutters. Listening, he grins. \xe2\x80\x9cHey, Jeb,\xe2\x80\x9d he says warmly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s up? I hope you didn\xe2\x80\x99t take offense when I said I was anti-establishment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Pause. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are, too?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Boehner chuckles as the call ends, thinking an anti-establishment Bush is going to be an even tougher sell than an anti-establishment Boehner.'b'With everything else going on, he even had to come to the defense of Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, one of his top lieutenants, who spoke to a racist group back in 2002.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI told those reporters that I knew, in his heart, Steve wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a white supremacist,\xe2\x80\x9d Boehner says, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could he be when he hangs out with somebody like me? Even President Obama called me a \xe2\x80\x98person of color,\xe2\x80\x99 hailing my orange as \xe2\x80\x98the new black.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'Thinking about Obama makes Boehner wince.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo now President Harvard wants to give everybody free community-college educations? Should we do their homework for them, too? I had to work my way through school as a janitor.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He wonders if the president saw Glenn Thrush\xe2\x80\x99s piece in Politico revealing that, sometimes when Obama calls Boehner, the speaker puts the receiver on his desk, rolls his eyes and lights a Camel while the president drones on.'b'The speaker shrugs, rolls his eyes and lights a Camel. \xe2\x80\x9cThe president keeps saying that he wants to work with us, but then he acts like his pal, the Cuban dictator,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s going to veto the Keystone pipeline. Executive orders have become par for the course. At least he\xe2\x80\x99s par somewhere.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cObama acts all liberated, but he\xe2\x80\x99s just killing time. He was out of town all week and no one even noticed he was gone. Maybe I\xe2\x80\x99ll retire with him. I don\xe2\x80\x99t do legacy and I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear the thought of going through another one of these battles for speaker with peabrains with slingshots.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI can give speeches, get on boards and play Augusta National, just like all those other anti-establishment types.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He refills his glass of red wine as his blue eyes fill with tears.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s still just me, guys,\xe2\x80\x9d he sobs, \xe2\x80\x9cdoing it my way.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'THE France that endured a vicious terrorist attack last week is a France that has suffered, for decades and centuries, from anxieties about its own decline. And for good reason: Since the 18th century, when it bestrode Europe and seemed poised to dominate the globe, France has seen its relative power diminish, suffering defeats and humiliations at the hands of rival forces, from Britain\xe2\x80\x99s navies to Germany\xe2\x80\x99s jackboots to the invading might of American popular culture.'b'Now these longstanding anxieties have been thrown into relief by the murderous attack on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, an attack linked to all the various specters haunting contemporary France: fears of creeping Islamification and rising anti-Semitism, fears of the far right\xe2\x80\x99s growing power and anti-Muslim backlash \xe2\x80\x94 and all of it bound up in a larger sense, amid economic stagnation, of betrayal at the hands of the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s elite.'b'But notwithstanding these declinist fears, France isn\xe2\x80\x99t actually irrelevant or spent. Instead, it\xe2\x80\x99s arguably becoming more important, more central to the fate of Europe and the West.'b'No, the age of the Sun King isn\xe2\x80\x99t about to return. But politically, culturally, even intellectually, events in France over the next half-century could matter more than at any point since before the two world wars. Indeed, more than Germany or Greece or Britain or any other actor, it\xe2\x80\x99s in France that the fate of 21st-century Europe could ultimately be decided.'b'Consider the specific issue at the heart of the Hebdo nightmare: the question of whether European nation-states can successfully integrate Muslim immigrants, and what will happen if they don\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Here France looks like the crucial test case. It has the largest Muslim population of any major European country, and parts of that population are more assimilated and others far more radicalized (16 percent of French citizens expressed 'b'support for the Islamic State'b' in a poll last summer) than elsewhere on the Continent.'b'Not surprisingly, the response to Islam is divided as well: Muslims are regarded 'b'more favorably in France'b' than elsewhere in Western Europe, and yet French politics features an increasingly potent far-right party, Marine Le Pen\xe2\x80\x99s National Front, whose electoral clout is now likely to increase. Meanwhile, France\xe2\x80\x99s foreign policy has distinctive (often military) entanglements across Northern Africa and the Levant, which means the ripples from French domestic politics have more room to spread and then return.'b'So if there\xe2\x80\x99s a path to greater Muslim assimilation and inclusion, it\xe2\x80\x99s more likely to be pioneered in France. If Islamic radicalism is going to gain ground or mutate into something more pervasive and dangerous, it\xe2\x80\x99s also more likely to happen in France\xe2\x80\x99s sphere of influence than elsewhere. And if Europe\xe2\x80\x99s much-feared far right is going to complete its journey from the fringe to the mainstream, it will probably happen first in Paris.'b'French politics is likewise central to the fate of the wider European Union project, which is in crisis at the moment because of the gulf between Germany\xe2\x80\x99s interests and the interests of the E.U. periphery, Greece and Italy and Spain. But that gulf (and the weight of 20th-century history) means that the Germans, however economically dominant, cannot hold the union together on their own. Instead it\xe2\x80\x99s France, for reasons of 'b'history and culture'b' as well as geography, that has to bridge the divide between Europe\xe2\x80\x99s north and south and make the E.U. work politically. Unless, of course, the French gradually and fatefully choose not to, in which case the entire project will fall apart or be completely reconceived.'b'Either way, France\xe2\x80\x99s star may rise as Germany\xe2\x80\x99s descends. Demography, the source of so much Gallic anxiety in the past, suddenly has turned in France\xe2\x80\x99s favor: The Germans are rich but aging, whereas even amid economic drift the French birthrate has risen sharply (suggesting a certain optimism amid the ennui). By the 2050s, under some scenarios, France could once again have the 'b'larger economy'b' and 'b'population'b' \xe2\x80\x94 making it either dominant in a more integrated Europe, or the most important power on a continent more divided than today.'b'Then amid these political and economic patterns there\xe2\x80\x99s an important intellectual possibility \xe2\x80\x94 namely, that if there\xe2\x80\x99s something beyond the West\xe2\x80\x99s current end-of-history torpor, some new ideological conflict or synthesis, it might emerge first in the place where so many revolutions had their birth.'b'France has always been a country of extremes\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0absolutist and republican, Catholic and anticlerical, Communist and fascist. Now it\xe2\x80\x99s once again the place where strong forces are colliding, and where the culture\xe2\x80\x99s uncertainties \xe2\x80\x94 about Islam, secularism, nationalism, Europe; about 'b'modernity itself'b' \xe2\x80\x94 suggest that new ones might soon be born.'b'The decline has been real, but the future is unwritten. If there is real history yet to be made in Europe, for good or ill, it might be made first in la belle France.'b'THE thriller writer Jeffery Deaver has released an original work called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Starling Project\xe2\x80\x9d as an audiobook \xe2\x80\x94 only it\xe2\x80\x99s not what we think of as an audiobook: a printed book read aloud that you can listen to on your laptop or phone. Featuring 29 actors in more than 80 speaking roles combined with \xe2\x80\x9cstate-of-the-art sound and music design,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Deaver\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cbook\xe2\x80\x9d was conceived as an audio drama for Audible. There are no plans to turn it into a traditional text-based book, either on paper or digitally.'b'That was fast. First we went from books to e-books, and now we\xe2\x80\x99re going from e-books to no-books. What\xe2\x80\x99s next? Books embedded in a chip that delivers \xe2\x80\x9ccontent\xe2\x80\x9d directly into our brains?'b'Is such an innovation even necessary? When you think about it, that\xe2\x80\x99s what audio does now. Listening is more efficient than reading: When we read, we absorb print with our eyes and translate it into \xe2\x80\x9cmeaning,\xe2\x80\x9d a cumbersome process that requires us first to see the words, then to make sense of them, and finally to employ our imaginations to conjure up events and sounds and characters that aren\xe2\x80\x99t there. Reception by aural means is more direct: All you have to do is listen. Not only that, you can multitask, driving to work or walking the dog.'b'The simplicity of audio is turning out to be a big advantage for those who love telling stories. To produce a show \xe2\x80\x94 or a non-text-based book \xe2\x80\x94 is relatively cheap. All you need is a writer, a studio with tech support, a few characters and, before you know it, you have \xe2\x80\x9cSerial.\xe2\x80\x9d More people have listened to this wildly popular podcast (nearly five million downloads per episode) about a teenage murder trial than have read Karl Ove Knausgaard\xe2\x80\x99s Proust-length memoir or Elena Ferrante\xe2\x80\x99s trilogy.'b'The podcast, once a form of talk show for the iPhone age, is evolving into a new literary form \xe2\x80\x94 one so new that it\xe2\x80\x99s soon going to require a name of its own. Whatever it\xe2\x80\x99s called, I have become addicted to it. Yes, I still read books, in increasing number now that you can impulse-buy Hermione Lee\xe2\x80\x99s biography of Penelope Fitzgerald while you\xe2\x80\x99re shivering at a bus stop and have it show up on your Kindle reader almost instantly. But there is something about the act of listening that invigorates the mind.'b'Lately I\xe2\x80\x99ve been following a podcast called \xe2\x80\x9cStartUp.\xe2\x80\x9d Produced by Alex Blumberg, a co-founder of NPR\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPlanet Money,\xe2\x80\x9d the show follows Mr. Blumberg\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to raise capital for a new podcast network. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople are leaving the radio in droves and they\xe2\x80\x99re migrating to digital,\xe2\x80\x9d he says in his pitch. But who\xe2\x80\x99s going to put up the money it takes to produce podcasts as they become more ambitious?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStartUp\xe2\x80\x9d would make a great magazine piece, but it\xe2\x80\x99s even more absorbing when you can actually listen to Mr. Blumberg discussing with his wife what he should wear to a meeting with a venture capitalist. As he\xe2\x80\x99s going out the door, she says: \xe2\x80\x9cAre you meeting someone with money?\xe2\x80\x9d He acknowledges that he is. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99d be a higher chance that he\xe2\x80\x99s going to give you money if you\xe2\x80\x99re not wearing running shoes,\xe2\x80\x9d she points out. Mr. Blumberg changes his shoes. It\xe2\x80\x99s a very funny exchange, and even funnier when you hear their voices: the aspiring entrepreneur sheepish, his wife gently ironic.'b'Listening to Mr. Blumberg describe his meeting with the venture capitalist at a sushi restaurant on Pico Boulevard in Los Angeles (I love all these details; they remind me of ... books), I think: Dude, give him the money. Someone is bound to, because \xe2\x80\x9cStartUp\xe2\x80\x9d has 300,000 \xe2\x80\x9clistens\xe2\x80\x9d per episode. By Episode 6, someone has decided to invest \xe2\x80\x94 the venture capitalist guy from lunch.'b'There are obvious limits to the podcast as a literary genre. It can be hard to keep track of all those voices, and the dialogue can feel slack. I was bored at times by the casual \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s just talk into the microphone\xe2\x80\x9d style of \xe2\x80\x9cSerial.\xe2\x80\x9d But at its best it has the tension of those nonfiction classics of an earlier era \xe2\x80\x94 Truman Capote\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIn Cold Blood\xe2\x80\x9d or Norman Mailer\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cExecutioner\xe2\x80\x99s Song.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Listening to a podcast is like watching a movie, listening to music and reading a book all at once. You become attached to the characters, caught up in the story, enthralled by the writing. \xe2\x80\x9cEvery other format is going to shorter and shorter content pieces, so you\xe2\x80\x99re actually swimming upstream,\xe2\x80\x9d the venture capitalist says to Mr. Blumberg. But maybe we\xe2\x80\x99re sick of short attention spans. Maybe we 'b'want 'b'to pay attention.'b'The question arises, Who has time to listen to all these programs? How will we even know what\xe2\x80\x99s out there? My guess is that gatekeepers will arise in the form of targeted magazine-like sites; critics will review them; teachers will teach them. It\xe2\x80\x99s already happening: Robert Boynton, director of the literary reportage concentration at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at New York University, edits a site, 'b'podforum.org'b', with two of his students, that compiles lists of new podcasts. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been listening to one called \xe2\x80\x9cHomemade Stories\xe2\x80\x9d by a Chicago-based black writer named Shannon Cason. Many of Mr. Cason\xe2\x80\x99s stories revolve around his encounters with the police, which seem to happen every time he walks out the door.'b'In the wake of Ferguson and Staten Island and now Cleveland, his account of going for a stroll with his family and being accosted by the police is chilling. \xe2\x80\x9cI told you to watch your surroundings, Anthony, and stop wearing that damn hoodie,\xe2\x80\x9d his wife upbraids their teenage son, who has just been grabbed by a police officer and was about to be thrown atop the hood of a squad car. Some of the story includes sound effects \xe2\x80\x94 a basketball game, dogs barking during an arrest \xe2\x80\x94 that bring an immediacy to the experience you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get in reading.'b'The aural/oral revolution won\xe2\x80\x99t mean the end of the book any more than the e-book did. Besides, the \xe2\x80\x9cnon-text-based\xe2\x80\x9d work of literature has a long tradition. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the history of mankind, words were heard before they were seen,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Albert B. Lord, the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Singer of Tales,\xe2\x80\x9d a classic work of scholarship that traced oral literature from Homer through \xe2\x80\x9cBeowulf\xe2\x80\x9d and the tales, still recited today, of Balkan poets capable of reciting thousands of lines of verse by heart.'b'Progress doesn\xe2\x80\x99t always mean going forward.'b'Readers discuss whether America should adopt European-style policies for caring for the populace.'b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'A Dec. 14 'b'column by Mark Bittman'b' offered a serious indictment of our wealthy country\xe2\x80\x99s inability to care for its people. But what is particularly galling is that several other countries serve as models of concern for their populace, and yet we ignore those lessons.'b'As you recently reported, Danish fast-food companies 'b'pay'b' their unionized workers at least $20 an hour, with benefits including five weeks of paid vacation. Fast-food workers in America earn an average of less than $9 an hour, contributing to the tens of millions of working poor who are forced to rely on government assistance to survive.'b'In most European countries mothers receive professional parenting support and almost full pay for many months in order to be with their newborns; we are the only developed country to have no maternity leave policy. And sadly we accept too easily that one in five of our children grow up in poverty, more than in most other developed countries.'b'Nor are we troubled that these other countries proudly provide all their citizens with complete medical coverage. Here many of our Republican-led states have, for political reasons, refused to take the 100 percent financing from Washington to extend Medicaid to more people.'b'On most indexes of people\xe2\x80\x99s well-being, the United States lags far behind comparable nations. The time has come for Americans to acknowledge that we as a nation are failing our citizens. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tough pill to swallow but an essential stimulant to political action, both in the streets and in the polling booths, to right the deplorable way we allow our enormous wealth to be used for private rather than public purposes.'b'The quest for an American exceptionalism of which we could once again be proud has the potential for bringing our nation together across political lines. This agenda must be in the forefront as we begin the new year and look ahead to the 2016 campaign.'b'ARTHUR SALZ'b' Kew Gardens, Queens, Jan. 5, 2015'b''b''b'The writer is professor emeritus of education at Queens College and founder of its Big Buddy program, which pairs college students with homeless youths.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Readers React'b''b'Bravo to Mr. Salz! As an American who has had the recent pleasure of living in Switzerland, I find myself bemused and puzzled by conservative talk of European \xe2\x80\x9cdysfunction.\xe2\x80\x9d I am sure that many European countries have their problems, but the Switzerland that I lived in was a place of superb public transportation; excellent environmental protection; wonderful parks, roads and other public services; and clean cities.'b'It was also a place where my many low-income friends \xe2\x80\x94 among them artists and single mothers \xe2\x80\x94 could live productive, creative lives free from crushing anxieties about health care, child care, leisure time and other necessities of life. If we in American perceive public and private goods as locked in an unending, zero-sum struggle, with private gain ever the preferred winner, it is not because it has to be that way. CLARK'b' Brooklyn, Jan. 7, 2015'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Your Jan. 7 issue juxtaposes Mr. Salz\xe2\x80\x99s letter urging us to draw lessons from the social welfare systems of Europe and Arthur C. Social science strongly indicates an inverse relationship at the national level between diversity and support for social spending. Growing diversity due to migration and low European birthrates is posing a challenge to political support for social spending, even in traditionally very generous countries.'b'The national contexts for decisions on social welfare policy vary greatly. THOMAS'b' Bellport, N.Y., Jan. 8, 2015'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Mr. Salz is right to point to lessons abroad, but we must look beyond Europe. Take Latin America as an example. It has been a leader in achieving near-universal access to health care by prioritizing the most vulnerable populations \xe2\x80\x94 such as Mexico\xe2\x80\x99s programs for pregnant women and children or Costa Rica\xe2\x80\x99s focus on insuring low-income communities and those without formal employment.'b'Many Latin American cities once plagued by poverty and poor infrastructure are being transformed by urban planning initiatives connecting those in need to essential opportunities. The lesson many leaders abroad are embracing \xe2\x80\x94 and that the United States should embrace \xe2\x80\x94 is that lifting up those so often left behind makes for stronger communities, and stronger economies, for everyone.'b'ANGELA GLOVER BLACKWELL'b' Oakland, Calif., Jan. 8, 2015'b''b''b'The writer is founder and chief executive of PolicyLink, a research and social action institute dedicated to advancing economic and social equity.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'Mr. Fagan and Mr. Snyder make related points that both the mood of the country and the financial might of corporate America preclude any move now toward the creation of progressive programs that are commonplace throughout Europe. So with interest piqued as to how other countries do it, we inform our citizens of the success of the Danish fast-food union winning $20 an hour through collective bargaining, and the fact that Ikea pays its furniture production workers in Sweden about twice what it pays workers in its Danville, Va., plant. Then let everyone look at the M.I.T. Living Wage Calculator with its picture of the shocking gap between typical American wages and what is required to provide bare-bones support for a family, and all this information might just move Americans to demand a resurgent labor movement.'b'Couple this with an education from the Nobel Prize-winning economists Joseph Stiglitz and Paul Krugman as to the benefits of a sharply progressive income tax, a financial transaction tax, and other fiscal policies to raise sufficient revenue, and you\xe2\x80\x99ve created a nation of progressives. But all this takes time.'b'Finally, Mr. Terzuolo is correct that increased immigration in Europe has led to small but growing hostility toward the foreign-born and the benefits they receive, and anger is likely to increase after the attack in Paris. But the percentage of immigrants in those countries is comparable to, or in some cases higher than, the United States, and to date there has been little change in their social welfare policies.'b'I also agree with Mr. Terzuolo that one cannot automatically transfer social welfare policies from one country to another. But certainly nations can learn from the successes of other countries, and then adapt those policies to one\xe2\x80\x99s own situations.'b'ARTHUR SALZ'b' Kew Gardens, Queens, Jan. 8, 2015'b''b'THE only time art ever seems to make news here in the West anymore is when a Pollock or Warhol sells for a sum commensurate with the budget of a \xe2\x80\x9cTransformers\xe2\x80\x9d film. It seems bizarre, then, to find ourselves grappling with international crises in which art is the issue: the imbroglio involving the Sony movie \xe2\x80\x9cThe Interview,\xe2\x80\x9d the massacre at Charlie Hebdo in Paris. The incomprehension, whether bemused or horrified, that we feel toward people who take up arms against the creators of cartoons or comedies is a chastening reminder that there are still cultures in which art is not a harmless diversion or commodity, but something real and volatile, a potential threat to be violently suppressed. These attacks are, in a way, a savage, atavistic show of respect.'b'I was a cartoonist for The Baltimore City Paper from 1997 to 2009, so I well know what influence a political cartoonist wields in this country. The last time art had any real-world effect on United States politics was about 140 years ago, when Boss Tweed was not only driven from power by Thomas Nast\xe2\x80\x99s caricatures of him but ultimately arrested after he\xe2\x80\x99d fled to Spain, where he was recognized from those same cartoons.'b'Much as I admire Steve Bell\xe2\x80\x99s caricatures of George W. Bush as a dung-flinging chimpanzee, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine them landing the former president in The Hague. Most daily editorial cartoonists in the United States produce work about as incisive as a prime-time sitcom, and the rest are consigned to niche markets where they preach to their demographic choirs. I have to wonder whether any of my colleagues felt the same queasy mix of emotions I did on hearing about the assassinations in Paris: beneath the outrage, sorrow and solidarity, a small, irrational twinge of guilt that we\xe2\x80\x99re not doing anything worth shooting us over.'b'Kurt Vonnegut Jr. likened the cumulative firepower of all the art and literature directed against the Vietnam War to \xe2\x80\x9cthe explosive force of a very large banana-cream pie \xe2\x80\x94 a pie two meters in diameter, 20 centimeters thick, and dropped from a height of 10 meters or more.\xe2\x80\x9d A lot of artists in America tend to be self-deprecating futilitarians, because we\xe2\x80\x99ve grown up in a culture in which art doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter except, occasionally, as a high-end investment. When art has been controversial here it\xe2\x80\x99s most often been because it\xe2\x80\x99s deemed obscene. (Sex is our tawdry Muhammad, the thing that cannot be depicted.) But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to think of a time in our recent history when art gave any cause for alarm to anyone in power.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a testament to the brittleness and fragility of ideologies like the thuggish cult of North Korea and the more homicidally literalist sects of Islam that they react so violently to art most Westerners regard as silly and trivial: dumb comedies, crude cartoons. North Korea saw \xe2\x80\x9cThe Interview\xe2\x80\x9d as some sort of invidious state-sponsored attack on its revered leader, the cinematic equivalent of a dirty bomb. It was almost endearing; you wanted to explain to them, No, see, in our country, this is 'b'stupid'b' art. We weren\xe2\x80\x99t even going to go see it in theaters until you threatened to bomb them; we would\xe2\x80\x99ve waited for it on instant streaming. Some part of the international reaction to the Charlie Hebdo massacre was this same kind of condescending incredulity: Wait, this was about 'b'cartoons'b'?'b'It speaks well of our own relatively flexible system that it can accommodate criticism and dissent without lopping anyone\xe2\x80\x99s hands off. But this is also a backhanded testament to our society\xe2\x80\x99s successful denaturing of satire, and the impotence of art in our own culture. Autocrats from Plato on have advocated control and censorship of the arts to ensure the stability of their states and micromanage their people\xe2\x80\x99s inner lives. In the mature democracies of the West, there\xe2\x80\x99s no longer any need for purges or fatwas or book-burnings. Why waste bullets shooting artists when you can just not pay them? Why bother banning books when nobody reads anyway, and the national literature is so provincial, insular and narcissistic it poses no troublesome questions?'b'The real Machiavellian genius of the First Amendment is that free speech turns out to be mostly harmless \xe2\x80\x94 a lot of P.C. nit-picking, dingbat conspiracy theories, tedious libertarian screeds and name calling. The only \xe2\x80\x9cfree speech\xe2\x80\x9d that has any effect in a stable, well-run plutocracy is the kind protected by Buckley vs. Valeo in the form of campaign contributions.'b'American capitalism has its own ingenious system for neutralizing or absorbing dissent: Any art that challenges its fundamental assumptions, its inevitability and rightness, is either ignored, so the artist has to tend bar or learn graphic design, or, if it becomes successful, lavishly rewarded and painlessly welcomed into the system it criticized. As systems of oppression go, this is definitely the one you want to suffer under. Getting paid only 20 bucks a week for my political cartoons was kind of insulting, but at least I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t forced to eat them at gunpoint.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m relieved to live in a place where the worst thing I have to worry about is being called names on the Internet. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to romanticize what happened in Paris: It was obscene and stupid and sad. And yet there is also occasion for pride in it, the kind of somber pride any soldier is entitled to feel in a comrade\xe2\x80\x99s sacrifice. It is a reminder that art is not a frivolous diversion, not just a product or \xe2\x80\x9ccontent.\xe2\x80\x9d It is still alive and dangerous, and still hated and feared by those most deserving of our mockery.'b'A lot of people are calling the cartoonists of Charlie Hebdo \xe2\x80\x9cheroes,\xe2\x80\x9d which it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine happening while they were still alive. (Would Seth Rogen be one if the North Koreans poisoned him?) But if grown-ups are going to use a word as childish as \xe2\x80\x9chero\xe2\x80\x9d at all, then I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid we may have to apply it, now and then, not only to those uniformed few who control drones from Langley or Vegas or bust teenagers selling weed on the street but also to silly, irrelevant people like cartoonists.'b'Last week, we quietly added a few more names to the roll call. And tonight, in the real ceremony, my colleagues and I will salute them with the traditional instruments of our trade \xe2\x80\x94 glasses raised around tables in the bars and cafes and tea houses of the civilized world. And, after a few, we\xe2\x80\x99ll do what cartoonists do \xe2\x80\x94 make cruel, gleeful fun of Islamic wackos and right-wing bigots, opportunistic politicians and useless cartoonists, absolutely everyone. No one will be spared.'b'YEARS ago, while producing the hit TV series \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shield,\xe2\x80\x9d Glen Mazzara noticed that two young female writers were quiet during story meetings. He pulled them aside and encouraged them to speak up more.'b'Watch what happens when we do, they replied.'b'Almost every time they started to speak, they were interrupted or shot down before finishing their pitch. When one had a good idea, a male writer would jump in and run with it before she could complete her thought.'b'Sadly, their experience is not unusual.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve both seen it happen again and again. When a woman speaks in a professional setting, she walks a tightrope. Either she\xe2\x80\x99s barely heard or she\xe2\x80\x99s judged as too aggressive. When a man says virtually the same thing, heads nod in appreciation for his fine idea. As a result, women often decide that saying less is more.'b'Some new studies support our observations. A 'b'study'b' by a Yale psychologist, Victoria L. Brescoll, found that male senators with more power (as measured by tenure, leadership positions and track record of legislation passed) spoke more on the Senate floor than their junior colleagues. But for female senators, power was not linked to significantly more speaking time.'b'Suspecting that powerful women stayed quiet because they feared a backlash, Professor Brescoll looked deeper. She 'b'asked 'b'professional men and women to evaluate the competence of chief executives who voiced their opinions more or less frequently. Male executives who spoke more often than their peers were rewarded with 10 percent higher ratings of competence. When female executives spoke more than their peers, both men and women punished them with 14 percent lower ratings. As this and other research shows, women who worry that talking \xe2\x80\x9ctoo much\xe2\x80\x9d will cause them to be disliked are not paranoid; they are often right.'b'One of us, Adam, was dismayed to find similar patterns when studying a 'b'health care company'b' and advising an international bank. When male employees contributed ideas that brought in new revenue, they got significantly higher performance evaluations. But female employees who spoke up with equally valuable ideas did not improve their managers\xe2\x80\x99 perception of their performance. Also, the more the men spoke up, the more helpful their managers believed them to be. But when women spoke up more, there was no increase in their perceived helpfulness.'b'This speaking-up double bind harms organizations by depriving them of valuable ideas. A University of Texas researcher, Ethan Burris, conducted 'b'an experiment'b' in which he asked teams to make strategic decisions for a bookstore. He randomly informed one member that the bookstore\xe2\x80\x99s inventory system was flawed and gave that person data about a better approach. In subsequent analyses, he found that when women challenged the old system and suggested a new one, team leaders viewed them as less loyal and were less likely to act on their suggestions. Even when all team members were informed that one member possessed unique information that would benefit the group, suggestions from women with inside knowledge were discounted.'b'Obviously, businesses need to find ways to 'b'interrupt'b' this gender bias. Just as orchestras that use blind auditions 'b'increase the number of women who are selected,'b' organizations can increase women\xe2\x80\x99s contributions by adopting practices that focus less on the speaker and more on the idea. For example, in 'b'innovation tournament'b's, employees submit suggestions and solutions to problems anonymously. Experts evaluate the proposals, give feedback to all participants and then implement the best plans.'b'SINCE most work cannot be done anonymously, leaders must also take steps to encourage women to speak and be heard. At \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shield,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Mazzara, the show runner, found a clever way to change the dynamics that were holding those two female employees back. He announced to the writers that he was instituting a no-interruption rule while anyone \xe2\x80\x94 male or female \xe2\x80\x94 was pitching. It worked, and he later observed that it made the entire team more effective.'b'The long-term solution to the double bind of speaking while female is to increase the number of women in leadership roles. (As we noted in 'b'our previous article'b', 'b'research'b' shows that when it comes to leadership skills, although men are more confident, women are more competent.) As 'b'more women enter'b' the upper echelons of organizations, people become more accustomed to women\xe2\x80\x99s contributing and leading. Professor Burris and his colleagues studied a credit union where women made up 74 percent of supervisors and 84 percent of front-line employees. Sure enough, when women spoke up there, they were more likely to be heard than men. When President Obama held his last news conference of 2014, he called on eight reporters \xe2\x80\x94 all women. It made headlines worldwide. Had a politician given only men a chance to ask questions, it would not have been news; it would have been a regular day.'b'As 2015 starts, we wonder what would happen if we all held Obama-style meetings, offering women the floor whenever possible. Doing this for even a day or two might be a powerful bias interrupter, demonstrating to our teams and colleagues that speaking while female is still quite difficult. We\xe2\x80\x99re going to try it to see what we learn. We hope you will, too \xe2\x80\x94 and then share your experiences with us all 'b'on Facebook'b' or in the comments section.'b''b'This is the second of four essays in a series on women at work.'b''b'GRAND GOAVE, Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 Five years is an eternity in the news cycle of natural disasters. It\xe2\x80\x99s been that long since the 2010 'b'Haiti'b' earthquake killed hundreds of thousands of people (no one really knows how many died) and triggered an influx of international aid (an exact accounting remains elusive). Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s trauma has been eclipsed by Oklahoma tornadoes, Pacific typhoons and New York hurricanes. The world moves on.'b'Over the last five years, working as an architect here on reconstruction projects, I\xe2\x80\x99ve witnessed some physical and social recovery. But the disheartening reality is that Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s post-quake economy is identical to its pre-disaster model: Haitians remain dependent on foreign donations to maintain their subsistence existence. NGOs with tunnel vision and international aid agencies with top-down agendas hobble the weak government and cite Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s culture of corruption as an excuse to deny distributing aid through local channels. Economic autonomy is not disaster relief\xe2\x80\x99s primary objective. But Haiti will be a global stepchild until it makes something people want to buy.'b'Different countries have relative economic strengths. The United States fosters innovation, China excels at production, but Haiti barely participates in the global economy. Yet as a low-wage country close to the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest consumer market, it offers advantages. Shipping goods from Haiti is a bargain because containers importing humanitarian aid often leave here empty. Its annual exports are about a third of neighboring Jamaica and less than half of its African cousins Mali and Senegal.'b'Yet Haiti faces big impediments to becoming a successful exporter of manufactured goods. A history of unstable governments and restrictive policies on foreign investment keep multinational corporations away. Convoluted bureaucracies and corruption make business transactions difficult. An unreliable workforce impedes efficiency.'b'Haiti has survived as an insular country since 1804, after a revolution by slaves brought independence from France. Since then, its revolving-door governments have inconsistently invited and spurned foreign investment. Corporate and political distrust still run strong, and this extends to humanitarian efforts. Less than one percent of earthquake-disaster relief and only 15 percent of reconstruction projects have been channeled through the Haitian government.'b'Over the last five years I\xe2\x80\x99ve witnessed how these problems cripple the country. I designed and supervised construction of an orphanage and school in Grand Goave, 15 miles west of the quake\xe2\x80\x99s epicenter. Both projects, the largest reconstruction efforts in Grand Goave, used American volunteers and paid Haitian crews to construct quake-resistant buildings adapted from Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s traditional concrete construction. We were fortunate to have a Haitian-based organization coordinate land acquisition, road access and the few approvals required.'b'But obtaining raw materials was difficult. After the earthquake, prices spiked for items like steel reinforcing. Other materials, like cement, simply couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be found. Specialties, from construction tools to shower curtains, had to be imported from the United States. Delivery times were erratic. A truckload of electrical panels and fixtures delivered to the Port of Miami at the end of May arrived in Haiti just before the American Labor Day weekend in early September, only to be slapped with an arbitrary customs fee.'b'Exporting goods from Haiti is not any easier. The U.S. Department of Commerce reports the time required to process goods for export is more than 24 days, the longest in the Western Hemisphere. Products from Thailand have much further to travel, but they can get to the United States much faster.'b'The biggest impediment I witnessed to Haiti becoming economically viable is the struggle to create consistent quality on a predictable schedule. Some days we were able to pour 30 cubic yards of concrete by hand bucket in six hours; other days we labored into the night and fell short of that result. My business experience provided little guidance for this dilemma, but a book by the historian Laurent Dubois offered insight. In \xe2\x80\x9cHaiti: The Aftershocks of History,\xe2\x80\x9d he describes the operation of so-called lakou, small-scale cooperatives that bundled land ownership and production to circumvent government attempts to create export-scale agriculture and reap the resulting tariffs.'b'The Haitian penchant to thwart \xe2\x80\x9cthe man,\xe2\x80\x9d whether French slave owners or greedy presidents, U.S. Marines or paternalistic aid organizations, is more than an economic gambit; it\xe2\x80\x99s a point of pride. Haitians do not work for money alone. They cherish their independence above all. Their pride in being the first black republic is so palpable one might think they achieved freedom 10 years ago, not 210 years ago.'b'I learned the only way to get things done was to make our objectives align. Sometimes that meant reminding the men that ours was a community effort; sometimes it meant pitching in to erase the line between labor and management. Nothing motivates Haitians more than \xe2\x80\x9ctrumping the blan\xe2\x80\x9d (the Creole word for foreigner). Often this meant doing consciously silly things, such as teetering on a scaffold to demonstrate their superior balance.'b'Our school and orphanage are welcome additions to the community, but a town with orphanages and no factories is still a place of dependency. Yet no aid agency or private concern is introducing manufacturing to Grand Goave.'b'Haiti needs to create a unique economic model, a 21st-century lakou that bypasses a top-down system in favor of small enterprises multiplied many times over. This is already happening, albeit on a tiny scale. During my first year working in Haiti, I searched online for Haitian-related holiday gifts. There was nothing \xe2\x80\x94 absolutely nothing \xe2\x80\x94 for sale from Haiti. Now there are dozens of sites offering goods produced here. Although they consist mostly of nonprofit organizations selling crafts, they\xe2\x80\x99ve contributed to the 3-to-4 percent growth in Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s gross domestic product every year since 2012.'b'This trend can expand if the government improves the environment for entrepreneurs: Make it easier to establish small businesses; smooth transportation obstacles; devote less effort to seeking large corporations; nurture local resources.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s little to lose. NGO\xe2\x80\x99s and aid organizations have improved conditions, but they are often poorly coordinated and lack the scope to propel self-sufficiency. The government is widely perceived as being hobbled by corruption. It needs to demonstrate a new honesty and transparency; capitalize on the NGO presence by coordinating their work, monitoring their progress and directing their vision. Well-coordinated aid could lead to a new, decentralized, economic model. When that occurs, all sorts of interesting things will rise out of Haiti. Including something I\xe2\x80\x99ll want to buy.'b'Things are heating up.'b'KARACHI, PAKISTAN \xe2\x80\x94 In a rare convergence of views, conservative religious political parties and mainstream liberals in Pakistan seem to agree it is a terrible idea to allow special military courts to try suspected terrorists. But they think so for different reasons, highlighting that once again Pakistan is both polarized and confused about how to respond to terrorism.'b'Last Tuesday, the National Assembly and the Senate unanimously adopted (with abstentions but no votes against) the 21st amendment to the Constitution: For two years, military courts will have authority to adjudicate cases involving civilians suspected of links to terrorist organizations. The president approved the law the next day.'b'This is the first major initiative the government has pushed through since the new National Action Plan to counter terrorism was drawn up last month. After the Pakistani Taliban\xe2\x80\x99s rampage on an army-run school in Peshawar on Dec. 16, the government\xe2\x80\x99s immediate, and vengeful, response was to lift a moratorium on the death penalty. But then it put forward a comprehensive program that goes well beyond the usual antiterrorist military operations. Among other measures, the National Action Plan calls for cracking down on hate speech and attacks on religious minorities and for regulating Islamic seminaries.'b'Both the public and parties across the political spectrum have hailed the plan for its holistic approach. Even the opposition party Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, or P.T.I., which has led antigovernment protests for months and is generally reluctant to condemn Islamists, came out in support of the government\xe2\x80\x99s new counterterrorism strategy.'b'But what did the government do last week by passing the constitutional amendment? Instead of revamping the criminal justice system, as the new action plan called for, it cited the failings of civilian courts, such as backlogs and corruption, to increase the remit of military courts: In other words, it ceded yet more control to an armed services that already dominates security and foreign policy making. And with that, it crushed hopes that Pakistan \xe2\x80\x94 which has spent half of its history under martial law \xe2\x80\x94 was undergoing a democratic transition after the May 2013 election, the first in which power was transferred from one civilian government to another through the ballot box.'b'Last week\xe2\x80\x99s amendment to the Constitution is a step backward; civilian courts had been enjoying unprecedented independence in recent years, after a long history of operating at the military\xe2\x80\x99s behest and on occasion providing it legal cover for unconstitutional takeovers. The move also increases the risk of human rights violations against terrorist suspects since the special military courts\xe2\x80\x99 decisions will not be subject to appeal.'b'Like other progressive Pakistanis, I was even more dismayed to realize that political parties with purportedly liberal agendas supported the amendment, and despite understanding it would be a setback for democracy. Members of the opposition Pakistan Peoples Party refused to vote for the law on Monday, Jan. 5, because that was the birthday of the party\xe2\x80\x99s founder, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, a former prime minister and president of Pakistan who is seen as an icon of democracy. They just voted for it the next day. One P.P.P. leader said he had done so against his conscience. Another called the amendment a \xe2\x80\x9cbitter pill\xe2\x80\x9d that was required to save the country.'b'Some parties abstained, such as the right-wing religious groups Jamaat-e-Islami and Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam. But this was not in the interest of democracy; it was because the amendment applies to \xe2\x80\x9cany terrorist group, armed group, wing and militia or their members using name of religion or a sect.\xe2\x80\x9d These religious parties, which are accused of maintaining links with the Taliban and Al Qaeda, fear that the new law will mean more security crackdowns on religious groups and seminaries.'b'The already confused and confusing debate about extremism in Pakistan has just become even more fraught. In the name of keeping the military out of civilian affairs, Pakistani liberals now find themselves having to defend a criminal justice system they have been criticizing for being sympathetic to extremist groups. (In the past Pakistani lawyers have feted the assassin of a politician critical of anti-blasphemy laws, and banned the sale at bar association canteens of drinks made at factories owned by Ahmadi Muslims, a sect they consider heretical.) And conservative religious political parties are having to take a stance against the military, even though historically they have enjoyed its patronage and formed governments with its backing as part of a strategy to sideline secular political parties.'b'Yet the greatest contradiction of all is that so many parliamentarians \xe2\x80\x94 including 247 members of the National Assembly \xe2\x80\x94 would vote to empower the military when many of them distrust it. Journalists and politicians, including the former head of P.T.I., believe the military may have orchestrated the antigovernment protests last year in the hope of triggering early elections. But now some of these politicians appear to be kowtowing to the army, presumably so they can complete their terms in office.'b'They seem to think they must sacrifice democracy in order to save it. But how soon will there be too little of it left to save?'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Liberation of Growing Old'b',\xe2\x80\x9d (Sunday Review, Jan. 4):'b'Nelson Mandela was 89 when he and others formed the Elders, a group of global leaders. SOLONCHE Blooming Grove, N.Y., Jan. 4, 2015'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Teach Congress a Lesson'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Jan. 2): Representatives David N. Cicilline and Scott Rigell reasonably propose mandating ethics training for the House of Representatives. The serious issues relating to congressional ethics, however, cannot be remedied with a few hours of training.'b'Members must balance the conflicting demands of their office, constituents, party and ever-present fund-raising needs. As the writers acknowledge, these tasks often present ethical traps that are complex and ambiguous.'b'The House and Senate Ethics Manuals, each hundreds of pages long, haven\xe2\x80\x99t been updated since 2008 and 2003, respectively; the manuals are virtually silent on issues like \xe2\x80\x9csuper PACs\xe2\x80\x9d and the use of social media.'b'After a series of contentious matters, the House Ethics Committee recently acknowledged the need for clearer guidance on the ubiquitous question of conflict of interest.'b'The simple truth is that the House is a political body run by the majority party. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'As Refugee Tide Swells, Lebanon Plans a Visa Requirement for Syrians'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 3):'b'It comes as no surprise that Lebanon is imposing visa restrictions on Syrian refugees. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Bad Loans for Troops'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cKeeping Track\xe2\x80\x9d editorial, Dec. 31):'b'The lenders who make up our organization extend credit to help members of the military and other consumers live better. Unlike payday lenders, we make traditional installment loans, with a set payment each month to buy furniture, automobiles and other essentials. Unfortunately, you support rules to amend the Military Lending Act that will disrupt and deter a lending process that works smoothly and quickly.'b'For no good reason, lenders would have to check a database to verify that a consumer is a member of the military or a dependent before making a loan. The database can\xe2\x80\x99t support that traffic, and a result will be delays in credit approvals for service members and civilians.'b'The Defense Department must look closely at the effect on all consumers and not rush to enact rules that will harm service members, not help them.'b'CHRIS STINEBERT'b'\nWashington, Jan. 6, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is president and chief executive of the American Financial Services Association, the national trade group for the consumer credit industry.'b''b'TEL AVIV \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWHAT are you,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9ca leftist?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We were both wearing the surplus United States Marines uniforms given to prisoners at Israeli Military Jail No. 6.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt depends how you define \xe2\x80\x98left,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d I said.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t get clever with me. Why are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to be part of a system whose main task is the violent occupation of millions of people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn other words: You love Arabs, and don\xe2\x80\x99t care about Israeli security.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think the occupation undermines all of our security, 'b'Palestinians'b'\xe2\x80\x99 and Israelis\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re betraying your people,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMe? Desertion.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is a growing chasm between Israeli rhetoric and reality. In the discourse of 'b'Israel'b'\xe2\x80\x99s Knesset and media, the Israel Defense Forces represent a \xe2\x80\x9cpeople\xe2\x80\x99s army.\xe2\x80\x9d Refusal to serve is portrayed by politicians and pundits \xe2\x80\x94 many of whom began their careers through service in elite units \xe2\x80\x94 as treacherous and marginal. This rhetoric becomes the common wisdom: A popular bumper stickers reads, \xe2\x80\x9cA real Israeli doesn\xe2\x80\x99t dodge the draft.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The outrage is disproportionate. Rarely do more than a few hundred Jewish Israelis publicly refuse to serve each year in protest against Israel\xe2\x80\x99s occupation of the Palestinian territories. The shrill condemnation of refusers is thus an indication of the establishment\xe2\x80\x99s panic.'b'Last year brought something of a surge in refusals. Open letters of refusal were published by a group of 'b'high schoolers'b', a group of 'b'reservists'b', veterans of the elite intelligence 'b'Unit 8200'b' and alumni and former staff members of the prestigious 'b'Israel Arts and Sciences Academy'b'. All were denounced by politicians and in the media: In September, the Knesset\xe2\x80\x99s opposition leader, the Labor member Isaac Herzog, 'b'blasted'b' the letter from Unit 8200 as \xe2\x80\x9cinsubordination.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Aggression toward refusers is widespread. When I accompanied a refuser named Udi Segal to his draft station during the Gaza war this summer, we were met by a group draped in Israeli flags and chanting, \xe2\x80\x9cUdi, you\xe2\x80\x99re a traitor! Go live in Gaza!\xe2\x80\x9d After signing the scholars\xe2\x80\x99 letter, Raya Rotem, a former literature teacher whose husband was killed in the 1973 Yom Kippur War, received a threatening phone call. And a friend of 50 years severed ties with her.'b'The idea that the \xe2\x80\x9creal Israelis\xe2\x80\x9d serve and those who refuse are \xe2\x80\x9ctraitors\xe2\x80\x9d is a false dichotomy. As Ms. Rotem told me, \xe2\x80\x9cIsraeli patriotism today means resisting anything which frames the occupation as normal.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s also inaccurate: The reality is that a majority of Israeli citizens do not serve in the military, including Palestinian citizens of Israel, or the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'fifth column'b',\xe2\x80\x9d as they are often branded, and the ultra-Orthodox, or \xe2\x80\x9c'b'leeches'b',\xe2\x80\x9d as they\xe2\x80\x99ve been called.'b'The largest group is the 1.7 million Palestinian citizens of Israel. Members of this community are not required by law to enlist, and only a tiny fraction volunteer (about 100 Christians and a few hundred Muslims in 2013). In 2014, the defense forces began sending \xe2\x80\x9c'b'voluntary draft notices'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to Christian Arab citizens, inciting Palestinian protests at 'b'Hebrew University'b' and in 'b'Tel Aviv'b'.'b'Even among the Druze, an Arabic-speaking minority whose male members have been drafted since 1956 and whose Arab and Palestinian identities are often played down or denied, dissent is rising. Omar Saad, a soft-spoken viola player, is the most prominent of a rising number of Druze refusers. He spent the first half of 2014 in and out of jail. In his letter of refusal, he 'b'wrote'b', \xe2\x80\x9cHow can I bear arms against my brothers and people in Palestine?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The next biggest group of nonserving Israelis are the Haredim, ultra-Orthodox Jews. Historically, they have been exempted from service as long as they were enrolled full-time in a yeshiva. Recently, though, a coalition 'b'formed'b' in the Knesset over a proposal to draft the Haredim \xe2\x80\x94 which resulted in a 'b'500,000-strong public demonstration'b'. Most Haredim cite religious reasons for refusing, but the Haredi refusenik Uriel Ferera, recently released after six months in jail, 'b'gave the occupation as a primary factor in his decision'b'.'b'There are also thousands of \xe2\x80\x9cgray refusers,\xe2\x80\x9d who find quieter ways to get out of the army, mostly by seeking mental health exemptions, known as a \xe2\x80\x9cProfile 21.\xe2\x80\x9d Like most public refusers in recent years, I was released after a month in military jail with a Profile 21.'b'Most of the prisoners with me in Military Jail No. 6 were Mizrahim (Jews of Middle Eastern origin), Ethiopians and Russians. Many of these members of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s most 'b'marginalized'b' Jewish communities told me of their intention to \xe2\x80\x9cget out on 21,\xe2\x80\x9d despite the risk this entailed for their future: Employment and 'b'educational'b' opportunities often depend on completing military service.'b'In a recent interview, 'b' the Israeli author Amos Oz'b' urged politicians to act as \xe2\x80\x9ctraitors,\xe2\x80\x9d and make peace. But the type of traitors Mr. Oz wishes for \xe2\x80\x94 visionary ministers, peace-minded military men \xe2\x80\x94 are nonexistent. The most left-wing of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu\xe2\x80\x99s potential challengers in Israel\xe2\x80\x99s coming election is the same Mr. Herzog who attacked the 8200 refusers.'b'Peace won\xe2\x80\x99t come from the next Knesset, or the one after that. But some hope for a less violent, more decent future lies with the real traitors, the disregarded millions of Israeli citizens who have refused to serve in the army.'b'The reasons for not serving may differ between a Palestinian youth from Acre and a Haredi from Beit Shemesh, between an 8200 veteran and an Ethiopian immigrant, between me and the deserter in Military Jail No. 6, but there is a deeper consensus: We all refuse to see the government as a moral guide and military service as sacrosanct. As the Israeli government leads us further from peace, and the army faithfully executes its violent orders, this is the kind of treachery we need most.'b'DURHAM, N.C. \xe2\x80\x94 WITH Washington bitterly divided between a Democratic White House and a Republican Congress, it seems unlikely that America will see substantive progress on the grand challenges of the day, ranging from immigration to energy policy and entitlement programs.'b'At times like these, we have historically looked to our 50 states to be, as Justice Louis D. Brandeis memorably 'b'called'b' them, laboratories of democracy, testing grounds for innovative policies that can be replicated by other states or translated to the federal level.'b'Some of the most notable federal policy innovations of the last generation have originated in the states, including school vouchers, energy efficiency standards, welfare reform and the Affordable Care Act. Governors like Bill Clinton and George W. Bush leveraged their state policy successes as springboards to the Oval Office.'b'The problem is, just when we need their innovative energies, the states are looking less and less likely to be fountainheads of new federal policy over the next generation.'b'What has changed? First, state politics have become much more partisan. After the 2014 elections, 60 percent of the states are completely controlled by a single party. The power of state policy innovations is that they traditionally had bipartisan fingerprints, allowing an enterprising national politician from either party to lay claim to them. In the new world of single-party states, very little bipartisan legislation will emerge.'b'We will see no Democrat willing to adopt the radical tax reforms of Gov. Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, and surely no Republican could champion the 'b'Safe Act'b' that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, got passed in New York \xe2\x80\x94 one of the strictest gun control bills in the nation.'b'Of course, these ideas may diffuse to other like-minded states. But more likely, these new initiatives will be at one end of the political spectrum or the other, limiting the potential for federal adoption.'b'Second, it has become clear that \xe2\x80\x9cscaling\xe2\x80\x9d successful state policies is harder than it appears, because of both political forces and policy realities. Every technocrat in Washington dreams of finding a successful policy at the state level, an early childhood education program in North Carolina or a creative prison reform initiative in Texas, and using it as a model for federal legislation. The logic is that once a state \xe2\x80\x9claboratory\xe2\x80\x9d has tested and approved a particular policy innovation, it will have the same \xe2\x80\x9ctreatment\xe2\x80\x9d effect in the other 49 states.'b'But that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been the case. Increasingly, efforts to \xe2\x80\x9cfederalize\xe2\x80\x9d state innovations have been hobbled by political backlash. The Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s Race to the Top program used billions of dollars of prize money to persuade states to adopt several education policy reforms that had been proven to work around the nation. Part of the package was Common Core, which, in part because of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s imprimatur, is now toxic on the right (and, because of opposition from some teachers, is just as toxic on the left).'b'Of course, despite their zeal for federalism, many conservatives never really agreed with Justice Brandeis\xe2\x80\x99s nostrum to begin with. They worry that successful state policies might not translate well to the federal level, even under ideal conditions \xe2\x80\x94 witness the 'b'skepticism'b' with which Congressional Republicans greeted President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s announcement last week of a new initiative to help students attend community college, based on a program in Tennessee.'b'And they have a point: It turns out scaling a successful state program often ends up with a one-size-fits-all policy that might work well in Ohio but fall flat in Arizona. An economic development program centered on promoting entrepreneurship might work in Silicon Valley, Boston or Austin, Tex., but fail miserably in an area without leading universities and a highly educated work force.'b'Moreover, federal mandates, in which Washington sets up rules and the states run with them, hopefully innovating along the way, have not fared much better. The Medicaid expansion was intended to be a core pillar of the Affordable Care Act, but following a 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision, many states chose to opt out.'b'Finally, all politics aside, while tax revenues have been increasing recently, many states remain cash-strapped since the Great Recession, limiting their ability to initiate significant economic or social programs of any kind.'b'Taken together, these forces mean that while states might experiment with numerous policies over the coming years, very few will ever go national. For those of us frustrated with federal gridlock, the states will provide little comfort going forward. The 50 laboratories of democracy will produce many so-called cures, but none of them will go down very well in our nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital.'b'It should come as no surprise that the very first move of the new Republican Senate is an attempt to push President Obama into approving the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil from Canadian tar sands. After all, debts must be paid, and the oil and gas industry \xe2\x80\x94 which gave 87 percent of its 2014 campaign contributions to the G.O.P. \xe2\x80\x94 expects to be rewarded for its support.'b'But why is this environmentally troubling project an urgent priority in a time of plunging world oil prices? Well, the party line, from people like Mitch McConnell, the new Senate majority leader, is that it\xe2\x80\x99s all about jobs. And it\xe2\x80\x99s true: Building Keystone XL could slightly increase U.S. employment. In fact, it might replace almost 5 percent of the jobs America has lost because of destructive cuts in federal spending, which were in turn the direct result of Republican blackmail over the debt ceiling.'b'Oh, and don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me that the cases are completely different. You can\xe2\x80\x99t consistently claim that pipeline spending creates jobs while government spending doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s back up for a minute and discuss economic principles.'b'For more than seven years \xe2\x80\x94 ever since the Bush-era housing and debt bubbles burst \xe2\x80\x94 the United States economy has suffered from inadequate demand. Total spending just hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been enough to fully employ the nation\xe2\x80\x99s resources. In such an environment, anything that increases spending creates jobs. And if private spending is depressed, a temporary rise in public spending can and should take its place. That\xe2\x80\x99s why a great majority of economists believe that the Obama stimulus did, in fact, reduce the unemployment rate compared with what it would have been without that stimulus.'b'From the beginning, however, Republican leaders have held the opposite view, insisting that we should slash public spending in the face of high unemployment. And they\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten their way: The years after 2010, when Republicans took control of the House, were marked by an unprecedented decline in real government spending per capita, which leveled off only in 2014.'b'The evidence overwhelmingly indicates that this kind of fiscal austerity in a depressed economy is destructive; if the economic news has been better lately, it\xe2\x80\x99s probably in part because of the fact that federal, state and local governments have finally stopped cutting. And spending cuts have, in particular, cost a lot of jobs. When the Congressional Budget Office was asked how many jobs would be lost because of the sequester \xe2\x80\x94 the big cuts in federal spending that Republicans extracted in 2011 by threatening to push America into default \xe2\x80\x94 its best estimate was 900,000. And that\xe2\x80\x99s only part of the total loss.'b'Needless to say, the guilty parties here will never admit that they were wrong. But if you look at their behavior closely, you see clear signs that they don\xe2\x80\x99t really believe in their own doctrine.'b'Consider, for example, the case of military spending. When it comes to possible cuts in defense contracts, politicians who loudly proclaim that every dollar the government spends comes at the expense of the private sector suddenly begin talking about all the jobs that will be destroyed. They even begin talking about the multiplier effect, as reduced spending by defense workers leads to job losses in other industries. This is the phenomenon former Representative Barney Frank dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cweaponized Keynesianism.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And the argument being made for Keystone XL is very similar; call it \xe2\x80\x9ccarbonized Keynesianism.\xe2\x80\x9d Yes, approving the pipeline would mobilize some money that would otherwise have sat idle, and in so doing create some jobs \xe2\x80\x94 42,000 during the construction phase, according to the most widely cited estimate. (Once completed, the pipeline would employ only a few dozen workers.) But government spending on roads, bridges and schools would do the same thing.'b'And the job gains from the pipeline would, as I said, be only a tiny fraction \xe2\x80\x94 less than 5 percent \xe2\x80\x94 of the job losses from sequestration, which in turn are only part of the damage done by spending cuts in general. If Mr. McConnell and company really believe that we need more spending to create jobs, why not support a push to upgrade America\xe2\x80\x99s crumbling infrastructure?'b'So what should be done about Keystone XL? If you believe that it would be environmentally damaging \xe2\x80\x94 which I do \xe2\x80\x94 then you should be against it, and you should ignore the claims about job creation. The numbers being thrown around are tiny compared with the country\xe2\x80\x99s overall work force. And in any case, the jobs argument for the pipeline is basically a sick joke coming from people who have done all they can to destroy American jobs \xe2\x80\x94 and are now employing the very arguments they used to ridicule government job programs to justify a big giveaway to their friends in the fossil fuel industry.'b'The solidarity march of more than one million people in Paris on Sunday was rich in placards and symbols but appropriately devoid of speeches. Like many in the vast throng that filled the broad boulevards between Place de la R\xc3\xa9publique and Place de la Nation, the world leaders who marched a portion of the route with President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande locked arms and embraced. But there was no podium, no pulpit, only ubiquitous signs reading \xe2\x80\x9cJe suis Charlie.\xe2\x80\x9d For the moment, that said it all.'b'Charlie, as the world has come to know, is Charlie Hebdo, the satirical weekly tabloid that was attacked by two radical Islamist gunmen on Wednesday. An apparent ally of those gunmen allegedly killed a policewoman and burst into a kosher supermarket in Paris, murdering several people there. In the end, 17 people and the three terrorists were dead, and \xe2\x80\x9cJe suis Charlie\xe2\x80\x9d swiftly became a declaration of solidarity and grief, displayed on kiosks, armbands, headbands, TV screens and banners.'b'There were some other signs, too \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cI am Charlie, cop, Jew\xe2\x80\x9d read some, and many displayed a simple pencil, symbol for the freedom of expression that came under attack when the brothers Ch\xc3\xa9rif and Sa\xc3\xafd Kouachi massacred cartoonists and editors at Charlie Hebdo, evidently because the magazine had published cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s much that can and should be discussed as a result of the tragedy \xe2\x80\x94 about freedom of the press, about the growing backlash across Europe against Muslim immigrants, about Islamist terrorism and Islamic fundamentalism. Certainly many of the dozens of national leaders in the Paris march \xe2\x80\x94 including the leaders of Britain, Germany, Spain, Italy, Turkey, Jordan, Israel, the Palestinian Authority and Greece \xe2\x80\x94 could have said plenty. Many of their countries have known vicious terrorist attacks in recent years; many are contending with rising anti-immigrant movements. The White House will gather leaders in Washington next month for a'b' summit meeting'b' on preventing terrorism, the American attorney general, Eric Holder Jr., announced.'b'But with the horror and fears raised by the attacks still fresh, it was important and proper that the first response in Paris \xe2\x80\x94 as elsewhere in France, across Europe and across the Atlantic \xe2\x80\x94 was a resounding and united demonstration of outrage and solidarity. Simply by turning out in vast numbers, the marchers eloquently demonstrated a shared conviction that Charlie Hebdo was exercising a right fundamental to democracy, the right of free expression. No perceived provocation, no grievance and certainly no religious conviction justifies killing those who wield only a pen.'b'The Charlie Hebdo murders are certain to intensify exploration for effective ways to combat terrorism. The probability that one of the Kouachi brothers had trained with Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and was on American watch lists should prompt a search for better cooperation and communication among Western allies and new ways to deal with the veteran jihadists who return to Europe after training and fighting with groups abroad.'b'Perhaps the greatest danger in the wake of the massacres is that more Europeans will come to the conclusion that all Muslim immigrants on the Continent are carriers of a great and mortal threat. Anti-immigrant sentiments were already at a dangerous level, making it essential for national and pan-European leaders in coming days to underscore that extremism is not inherent to the Muslim faith, and that the Islamists themselves are hardly a single entity.'b'That point was searingly made by the'b' brother of Ahmed Merabet,'b' a French police officer who was one of the people gunned down in the Charlie Hebdo attack. \xe2\x80\x9cMy brother was Muslim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malek Merabet, \xe2\x80\x9cand he was killed by two terrorists, by two false Muslims.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan does a masterful political Jekyll and Hyde. A cable from the American ambassador to Baku released on WikiLeaks described him as a Michael Corleone-Sonny Corleone figure \xe2\x80\x94 referring, respectively, to the coolly calculating and the impetuously violent brothers of the \xe2\x80\x9cGodfather\xe2\x80\x9d mafia family. Mr. Aliyev is \xe2\x80\x9cpro-Western\xe2\x80\x9d in many of the ways the West admires: He is suave, well dressed and well spoken in English; he is ready to send his country\xe2\x80\x99s ample supplies of oil and gas to Europe and to Israel; his Islam is moderate and modern; and he hosts lavish international events like the Eurovision Song Contest in 2012 and the European Games to be held next June.'b'He is also hugely corrupt, and his authoritarian regime has one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s worst records on human rights.'b'Last month, continuing a crackdown on independent media and nongovernmental organizations, police officers 'b'raided'b' the offices of the United States-financed Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty in Baku \xe2\x80\x94 known locally as Radio Azadliq \xe2\x80\x94 taking away computers and documents and sealing the premises. A dozen R.F.E./R.L. employees were detained and questioned.'b'A few weeks earlier, the government 'b'jailed'b' a well-known investigative reporter, Khadija Ismayilova, who had worked for the broadcaster and had reported on the lucrative business dealings of Mr. Aliyev\xe2\x80\x99s family. The government first tried to frighten and blackmail her, then hit her with the Orwellian charge that she had pushed a lover toward suicide. Another critic of the regime, Leyla Yunus, a prominent human rights activist, has been in jail since April along with her husband, Arif Yunus.'b'Mr. Aliyev, of course, is not the only dictator whose skillful politics and control of valuable natural resources have confronted American and European policy makers with what the cable released by WikiLeaks called \xe2\x80\x9ca choice between U.S. interests and U.S. values.\xe2\x80\x9d His father, Heydar Aliyev, ruled Azerbaijan with an iron hand from 1969 to his death in 2003, first as its Soviet boss and then as its president. The son, assisted by Azerbaijan\xe2\x80\x99s oil wealth, has steadily built on the father\xe2\x80\x99s cult of personality through three questionable elections.'b'Yet even as Mr. Aliyev cultivates the West, he is convinced that foreign-financed organizations, including R.F.E./R.L., are out to get him. Like his partner in authoritarianism, Vladimir Putin, he sees a hostile American hand behind everything from the ouster of President Viktor Yanukovych in Ukraine to the various Arab uprisings, and he is determined to nip any such opposition in the bud. On Dec. 4, Mr. Aliyev\xe2\x80\x99s top lieutenant, Ramiz Mehdiyev, published a 60-page manifesto complaining of a \xe2\x80\x9cfifth column\xe2\x80\x9d of nongovernmental organizations plotting a revolution, and suggesting that Ms. Ismayilova was getting her information from \xe2\x80\x9cforeign spies.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The West must understand that the authoritarian Mr. Aliyev is the real Mr. Aliyev. As he accelerates his campaign to crush opponents and any other semblance of freedom, the United States and Europe should make far clearer than they have that while they may be compelled to do business with him, they have no illusions about what he is and the severe damage he is doing to his country.'b'Hands down, 2014 was the best year for the labor market since the Great Recession hit in late 2007.'b'But it would be wrong to simply root for more of the same. Recent progress does not so much point a way forward as highlight weaknesses that need to be corrected and risks that need to be avoided in order not to backslide.'b'The 'b'December employment report'b', released Friday, showed that 252,000 jobs were added last month, bringing the job creation total for 2014 to nearly three million \xe2\x80\x94 well ahead of tallies from the past seven years. In all, nearly a million of the jobs created in 2014 \xe2\x80\x94 a third of the total \xe2\x80\x94 were in low-wage sectors, including retail, restaurants, bars and hotels, temporary work services, home health care and nursing homes.'b'Poor job quality is one of the reasons that wage growth has been relentlessly sluggish. Over all, wages rose a mere 1.7 percent in 2014, barely outpacing inflation.'b'Clearly then, the economy needs faster job growth, better jobs and higher pay. But how? As the economist 'b'Jared Bernstein recently noted'b', a big reason the labor market improved last year is that the fiscal austerity and budget battles that hurt growth in 2013 no longer exerted a drag on growth in 2014.'b'The Federal Reserve can help the labor market by delaying any interest rate increase until clear signs of inflationary pressure emerge in wages and prices. For now, the Fed is projecting steadily higher inflation as the labor market improves and oil prices rise, a scenario that suggests rate increases sooner rather than later. But the Fed could be wrong. The labor market could remain stuck in a low-wage rut while the effects of low oil prices \xe2\x80\x94 including a stronger dollar and global economic weakness \xe2\x80\x94 dent what growth there has been in manufacturing and other higher-paying sectors. A premature rate hike would make that bad situation much worse.'b'It would be great to bolster low-wage jobs with a higher federal minimum wage in 2015 and to foster middle-class jobs with robust infrastructure spending, increased support for public employment and enhanced protections for collective bargaining. At the very least, however, it is imperative not to undo the progress to date with reactionary politics and erroneous policy.'b'An 'b'extended video'b' released last week of the shooting death of Tamir Rice in Cleveland appears to show an unconscionable level of human depravity on the part of the officer who shot him, a stunning disregard for the value of his life and a callousness toward the people who loved him.'b'His black life didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to matter.
