So, in the demand for justice, timorousness must be the enemy, tirelessness must be the motto and righteousness must be the compass.'b'The world must be made to acknowledge that Tamir Rice\xe2\x80\x99s life mattered.'b'NEW HAVEN \xe2\x80\x94 ONE of my elderly patients has Type 2 diabetes and heart disease. He takes a number of medications, including insulin to control his blood sugar levels. A few years ago, he was driving when his blood sugar suddenly dropped. He felt lightheaded for a moment, and then ran into a tree.'b'There are roughly 11 million Americans over age 65 with diabetes. Most of them take medications to reduce their blood sugar levels. The majority reach an average blood sugar target, or \xe2\x80\x9chemoglobin A1C,\xe2\x80\x9d of less than 7 percent. Why? Early studies showed that this can reduce the risk of diabetes complications, including eye, kidney and nerve problems. As a result, for more than a decade, medical societies, pharmaceutical companies and diabetes groups have campaigned with a simple, concrete message \xe2\x80\x94 to get below seven. Many patients carry report cards with their scores to clinic appointments. Doctors are often rewarded based on how many of their patients hit the target.'b'All of this sounds great. But, at least for older people, there are serious problems with the below-seven paradigm.'b'To begin with, the health benefits of this strategy are uncertain for older people. Those early studies that were the rationale for going below seven were conducted in people with Type 1 diabetes or with younger patients with newly diagnosed Type 2 diabetes. Subsequent trials of older patients raised doubts about the benefits.'b'Worse, targeting low blood sugar levels can cause harm. In one instance, investigators actually had to stop a trial early because patients who were targeting hemoglobin A1C levels of six or below had significantly higher rates of death than patients targeting levels in the sevens. We don\xe2\x80\x99t know exactly why this happened. What we do know is that aiming for levels below seven increases the risk for \xe2\x80\x9chypoglycemia,\xe2\x80\x9d or low blood sugar reactions. Severe reactions can result in confusion, coma, falls, fractures, abnormal heart rhythms and even death.'b'Older people are especially susceptible to severe hypoglycemia. With age, kidneys become less efficient, which causes insulin (or other drugs) to accumulate in the body; this, in turn, can lead to hypoglycemia. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, older people often take multiple medications, some of which may interact with diabetes drugs. This, too, may cause hypoglycemia. Using multiple medications or complex insulin regimens also increases the chances of errors, such as taking the wrong dose or the wrong type of insulin. Finally, older people have fewer warning symptoms when they experience mild dips in blood sugar, and this leaves less time for them to react and treat the problem before it becomes severe. This is precisely what happened to my patient.'b'Given the questionable benefits and the very real risks of going below seven, the American Geriatrics Society and the Veterans Affairs diabetes guidelines have, for years, recommended a cautious, case-by-case approach for older patients. For those with serious health problems, or prior history of hypoglycemia, going below seven may not be worth the risks involved. The problem is that we haven\xe2\x80\x99t put these guidelines into practice.'b'In a 'b'new study'b' published today in JAMA Internal Medicine, my colleagues and I used nationally representative data from 2001 to 2010 and showed that 62 percent of adults over age 65 went below seven. But here\xe2\x80\x99s the catch. We found absolutely no difference in how people were treated based on their health. In other words, patients in poor health and at risk for hypoglycemia tended to be treated as aggressively as far healthier patients. This seems to confirm that we have been adhering to a one-size-fits-all approach, despite the risks that it poses to millions of older Americans.'b'Part of the problem is that there are strong incentives in place to keep the status quo. The diabetes drug industry has a vested interest in selling its products to as many Americans as it can, and has been incredibly successful at doing so. Sales of diabetes drugs in 2013 were about equal to the combined revenue of the National Football League, Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association. There is nothing wrong with the industry selling its drugs, but it is the job of the medical profession to guide what treatment patients receive. To do this properly, doctors with financial ties to diabetes drug industry shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be writing guidelines on how to use these drugs. At present, this is still common.'b'Ultimately, changing current paradigms requires that doctors partner with their patients in making decisions about treatment. Patients need to understand that there are different options, with different risks. The goal is not to get a perfect score on a report card, but to weigh these risks to make a good decision.'b'My patient was terrified at the prospect of having another car wreck \xe2\x80\x94 a completely reasonable concern \xe2\x80\x94 and we decided to use less insulin and let his sugars run higher, in the eights. It\xe2\x80\x99s possible this slightly raises his risk of kidney or eye problems. But this was a risk that he was more than happy to take.'b'LAGOS, Nigeria \xe2\x80\x94  My compatriots moan ceaselessly about wicked politicians who pocket the wealth from our nation\xe2\x80\x99s natural resources with impunity, yet most are reluctant to do anything about it. This is not surprising \xe2\x80\x94 there are inherent risks in challenging authority, especially in a country like Nigeria, where, in the words of former President Olusegun Obasanjo, politics is a \xe2\x80\x9cdo or die affair.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet, in a land where most people go along to get along, Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s writers and performers have always been a feisty lot. For the generation that came of age at independence in 1960, art and politics mixed with a general optimism about the country\xe2\x80\x99s future. And as the last decades of the last century unfolded amid greed, corruption and state-sponsored violence, they took it upon themselves to become the voice of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s conscience.'b'The work of a new generation of Nigerian writers, by comparison, has grown inward-looking and politically remote, the inversion of the Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka\xe2\x80\x99s much-quoted admonition, \xe2\x80\x9cThe man dies in all who keep silent in the face of tyranny.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s not that the writers of today are afraid to address the problems that plague our country \xe2\x80\x94 they do so with eloquence and compassion. But there is more gloom than hope in their writing. Their work is weighed down by a despair that stems from the fact that the people most in need of reading what they have to say are paying little or no attention.'b'This was not the case during the first decades of independence. Ken Saro-Wiwa\xe2\x80\x99s campaign for the rights of the much-abused Ogoni people in the oil-rich Niger delta drew worldwide attention. His organization, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, became one of the largest in Nigeria. His artistic and political reputation spread far beyond his homeland, especially after Gen. Sani Abacha\xe2\x80\x99s military government had him tried on trumped-up charges and executed in 1995. Amid the international outrage that followed, human rights activists brought a lawsuit against the Shell oil company, and Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth of Nations for more than three years.'b'The reputation of Nigerian writers remains broad, but it is not deep. Wole Soyinka\xe2\x80\x99s poems and plays earned him the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986; novels like Saro-Wiwa\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSozaboy\xe2\x80\x9d (about a young soldier caught up in the civil war), or Chinua Achebe\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThings Fall Apart\xe2\x80\x9d (which traces the cultural destruction of a village at the hands of well-meaning missionaries) are honored the world over; Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the musician who pioneered Afrobeat with songs of protest and rebellion, was the subject of a popular Broadway musical.'b'But Broadway is a long way from  Lagos, and, high-minded as they might be, the opinions of the Nobel committee have little to do with the price of oil in Abuja. Our writers are celebrated overseas, but that\xe2\x80\x99s because they write in English, only one of the 500 or more languages and dialects used by the country\xe2\x80\x99s 250 ethnic groups. In any case, many Nigerians can\xe2\x80\x99t read.'b'One may wonder why a government that draws much of its popular support by putting people on the payroll has never created a censorship bureau for printed material (there is a film censorship board). In fact, there is no need. Saro-Wiwa was hanged for his activism, not his literary work; Wole Soyinka, accused of supporting the Igbo people, spent two years in prison during the murderous Biafran war. In his memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Man Died,\xe2\x80\x9d he saw with uncanny accuracy that postwar Nigeria would be governed \xe2\x80\x9cby a new military ethic \xe2\x80\x94 coercion.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'No Nigerian artist in any genre has been more scathing about the country\xe2\x80\x99s colossal failure of leadership than Fela Kuti, who died in 1997 at the age of 58 but whose ironic, mournful music plays nonstop in dance halls, bars and cafes across the country. In songs like \xe2\x80\x9cShuffering and Shmiling,\xe2\x80\x9d he describes the lot of the great mass of Nigerians who live without running water or regular power as they struggle to get through the workaday world. In \xe2\x80\x9cOpen and Close,\xe2\x80\x9d he berates his compatriots for allowing themselves to be abused. In \xe2\x80\x9cArmy Arrangeement\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94 a play on a pidgin word \xe2\x80\x94 he rails against the underhanded dealing of politicians, bureaucrats and businesspeople.'b'And yet what irked the authorities even more than his politics was his lifestyle \xe2\x80\x94 smoking marijuana during live performances, wandering about in public in his underwear, living openly with his 27 wives. In all of this he seemed to challenge the illusion of order in a country that began falling apart even as it was gaining its independence.'b'Despite the outspokenness of these men, they seem to have had little domestic influence on a population that is still largely rural and woefully under-educated. A new generation of writers, singers and stand-up comics may draw urbane audiences. But to the politicians gearing up for elections next month, what the artistic community says about them remains of little consequence.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve never voted in Nigerian elections and I won\xe2\x80\x99t again this year,\xe2\x80\x9d A. Igoni Barrett, the short story writer, told me recently: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m less an apathetic voter than a thoroughly disillusioned citizen.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another writer, Eghosa Imasuen, admits readily enough to disillusion but finds himself struggling against apathy.'b'Comments like these raise age-old questions of artistic integrity and the writer\xe2\x80\x99s duty to confront tyranny and injustice. Soyinka, Saro-Wiwa and others of their generation did not hesitate to do so. But things are different today. The climate has changed. Three decades of military dictatorship have given way to a listless democracy, where corruption rules, apathy spreads and a dangerous vacuum is filled with the likes of the murderous Boko Haram insurgency.'b'No amount of noise making from the chattering classes seems to reach our politicians, and that is exactly what makes our predicament so dangerous. If our leaders refuse to listen when our artists speak of ennui, anger and despair, they set themselves up for the fate that befalls all rulers who remain deaf to simmering discontent. We must break out of this national lassitude before it\xe2\x80\x99s too late.'b''b'\n'b'Adewale Maja-Pearce'b' is a writer and critic, and the author, most recently, of the memoir \xe2\x80\x9cThe House My Father Built.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'HAMBURG, Germany \xe2\x80\x94 Another Chapter 11 for Greece, the third in five years \xe2\x80\x94 and no exit in sight. Ms. Merkel, as is her habit, deploys innuendo and leaks. Mr. Tsipras flings wild-eyed threats. He wants to \xe2\x80\x9ctear up\xe2\x80\x9d austerity pledges and stop servicing Greek debt, invoking the metaphor of the Cold War\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear standoffs: \xe2\x80\x9cIf one side pushes the red button, then all will lose.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is the core of the crisis: a monetary game of chicken. As we know from war gaming, the party that appears to be crazier than the rest tends to score. Strategists call this the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'rationality of irrationality'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Foam at the mouth, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll get your way more easily than meekly asking for another 100 billion euros.'b'Crazy the game is not. The Greeks have been saved twice: in 2010, 'b'with 110 billion euros'b' ($147 billion), and in 2012, 'b'with 130 billion euros'b' ($173 billion). In 2011, private investors had to take a 'b'50 percent write-down'b' on their holdings of Greek government debt. These bailouts have created their own expectations in Greece.'b'Monetary war is a bit like nuclear war in this respect: Everyone knows how to start one, but nobody knows how it will end. A Grexit might get rid of a noisome neighbor, but it might also bring down the whole house of the euro.'b'In their more sober moments, Greek politicians might play a friendlier game. They could trot out what they have already achieved. Growth, which just three years ago was in negative territory, with the Greek economy 'b'shrinking about 7 percent a year'b', is now not much worse than Germany\xe2\x80\x99s. Unemployment \xe2\x80\x94 'b'still a whopping 25 percent'b' \xe2\x80\x94 is falling, though ever so slightly.'b'Unfortunately, there is a darker side. Austerity measures inflicted by the eurozone and the International Monetary Fund have not been quite as cruel as Athens keeps claiming. The debt of Greece\xe2\x80\x99s central government has almost doubled since 2011, and gross external debt has since risen from 'b'370 billion euros to 412 billion'b' over the same period. So Greece is still living beyond its means.'b'Hence crisis No.3. Athens\xe2\x80\x99s exposure to foreign lenders is rising once more. In everyday language, the Greeks cannot get their act together. Worse, if Mr. Tsipras does win a parliamentary majority at the end of the month, he has pledged to unleash a wave of public spending to reward his supporters.'b'Strangely, this gambit is not irrational brinkmanship. If Syriza does come to power (though at the moment its lead is shrinking), the new government will yield here and there to make nice with Ms. Merkel. But any government, left-wing or centrist, knows one big thing: Greece has a history of bailouts on its side. That will dampen the passions of ardent reformists.'b'By contrast, the German leader does not have Europe on her side. France and Italy, just to name the big two, have been trying to get out from under the chancellor\xe2\x80\x99s whip for years. Unable, like Greece, to bring forward labor market reforms and economic liberalization, Paris and Rome are clamoring for an end to fiscal discipline, which would allow them to allocate their (or their creditors\xe2\x80\x99) money to lavish deficit spending. The Mediterranean mood is working for Athens.'b'Also, with its tiny economy, Greece can and will be saved, again. It is too small to fail, so to speak. But together, France and Italy represent Europe\xe2\x80\x99s hard-core problem, which is economic stagnation over time \xe2\x80\x94 despite a long history of deficit spending.'b'Forget the Grexit issue: It\xe2\x80\x99s Europe\xe2\x80\x99s historical trends that should worry us. In the decades since the economic miracle days of the \xe2\x80\x9970s, real growth in the European Union has dropped on average by three-quarters of a percentage point. Productivity growth has likewise slid, to 0.4 percent from about 2 percent per year. These ailments are deeply embedded in economies that lag behind on investment, innovation and competitiveness.'b'Greece\xe2\x80\x99s problems are peanuts, relatively speaking. Unlike Greece, the European Union is enormously rich \xe2\x80\x94 its G.D.P. is actually a little larger than the United States\xe2\x80\x99. Sixty years ago, when the foundation was established, the average life expectancy of a child with cystic fibrosis was five years. Today, because of innovative new treatments, average life expectancy is 41 years.'b'Without the foundation\xe2\x80\x99s venture philanthropy approach, this progress would simply not have happened.'b'By investing in early-stage research, we ensure that people who suffer from this rare disease are not left out in the cold waiting until those in government and industry decide to address the urgent need for cystic fibrosis treatments.'b'Nearly every cystic fibrosis drug available today exists because of our support. Any funds generated from our research investments are plowed directly back into new research to find a cure and improve the health and quality of life of people with the disease.'b'We are concerned about the high price of cystic fibrosis drugs, which we know place a burden on patients and families and are unsustainable for the health care system over all. But no matter how categorically they reject terrorism committed in the name of Islam, many French citizens still view them with suspicion, not entirely unjustly. For decades, Islamists have been hard at work in prisons, industrial suburbs and neighborhood mosques, peddling a strong religious identity and hope for the future to disaffected young people.'b'Islam has become more than a religion: To many French youths of immigrant origin, it now provides a culture that 'b'France'b' itself has not managed to instill. For some, a desire for life has been replaced by a desire for death: the death of others, of infidels, and one\xe2\x80\x99s own death as a martyr bound for paradise. That is how Al Qaeda and now the Islamic State have recruited volunteers to train in Iraq, Yemen, Pakistan or Libya.'b'The French government has not paid serious and sustained attention to the situation in its often dreary suburbs, a neglected zone where unsocialized youths live \xe2\x80\x94 or merely survive. Islamist recruiters target this empty space, abandoned by the state. The increasingly racist language of the right-wing National Front, and a 'b'current of intellectual discourse'b' that accuses immigrants and their children of blurring France\xe2\x80\x99s national persona, have fostered resentment among young people whose Frenchness is always questioned, and never taken for granted.'b'The novelist Michel Houellebecq\xe2\x80\x99s latest book, \xe2\x80\x9cSubmission,\xe2\x80\x9d imagines a France governed in 2022 by a Muslim president who sends women back into the home and legalizes polygamy. A recent polemic, \xe2\x80\x9cThe French Suicide,\xe2\x80\x9d by the journalist \xc3\x89ric Zemmour, ascribes the decline of France to the pernicious influence of the student uprisings in May 1968, immigration, 'b'same-sex marriage'b' and feminism: ultraconservative and reactionary ideas that have made this book a huge best seller and that resemble those of the National Front (albeit unintentionally, according to Mr. Zemmour).'b'France has been bruised, traumatized, left reeling. The French are frightened \xe2\x80\x94 or more precisely, they are being frightened. The National Front has made fear its credo. As economists have pointed out, nations in the West ought to be 'b'more worried about their aging populations'b' than about their immigrants. If a magic wand were to send all of France\xe2\x80\x99s Muslim immigrants back where they came from, the nation would come to a halt economically.'b'France is thus torn between an ever-more-powerful extreme right (polls suggest that the National Front\xe2\x80\x99s leader, Marine Le Pen, could prevail \xe2\x80\x94 if not outright, then in a runoff \xe2\x80\x94 in the 2017 presidential election) and its liberal traditions of asylum. The right wing demands closing borders and pulling back, while the left wing is determined to remain true to its humanist principles.'b'Changing the daily lives of French Muslims demands a new political vision, a real determination to confront the problems of the troubled suburbs, and an acknowledgment of the identity of French youths, who have been left to fend for themselves, victims of racism whenever they look for work or go out for an evening of fun. They have their work cut out for them in the prisons as well, now ideal venues for indoctrination that generates fodder for jihad. They enjoy their handsome buildings and a \xe2\x80\x9cmagnificent\xe2\x80\x9d farmers\xe2\x80\x99 market.'b'Le Guin describes a festival day with delicious beer and horse races: \xe2\x80\x9cAn old woman, small, fat, and laughing, is passing out flowers from a basket, and tall young men wear her flowers in their shining hair. A child of nine or ten sits at the edge of the crowd, alone, playing on a wooden flute.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It is an idyllic, magical place.'b'But then Le Guin describes one more feature of Omelas. In the basement of one of the buildings, there is a small broom-closet-sized room with a locked door and no windows. A small child is locked inside the room. It looks about 6, but, actually, the child is nearly 10. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is feebleminded. Perhaps it was born defective, or perhaps it has become imbecile through fear, malnutrition and neglect.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Occasionally, the door opens and people look in. The child used to cry out, \xe2\x80\x9cPlease let me out. I will be good!\xe2\x80\x9d But the people never answered and now the child just whimpers. It is terribly thin, lives on a half-bowl of cornmeal a day and must sit in its own excrement.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey all know it is there, all the people of Omelas,\xe2\x80\x9d Le Guin writes. \xe2\x80\x9cSome of them have come to see it; others are content merely to know it is there. They all know it has to be there. Some of them understand why, and some do not, but they all understand that their happiness, the beauty of their city, the tenderness of their friendships, the health of their children ... depend wholly on this child\xe2\x80\x99s abominable misery.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is the social contract in Omelas. One child suffers horribly so that the rest can be happy. If the child were let free or comforted, Omelas would be destroyed. Most people feel horrible for the child, and some parents hold their kids tighter, and then they return to their happiness.'b'But some go to see the child in the room and then keep walking. They don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be part of that social contract. \xe2\x80\x9cThey leave Omelas; they walk ahead into the darkness and they do not come back.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In one reading this is a parable about exploitation. According to this reading, many of us live in societies whose prosperity depends on some faraway child in the basement. When we buy a cellphone or a piece of cheap clothing, there is some exploited worker \xe2\x80\x94 a child in the basement. We tolerate exploitation, telling each other that their misery is necessary for overall affluence, though maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s not.'b'In another reading, the story is a challenge to the utilitarian mind-set so prevalent today.'b'In theory, most of us subscribe to a set of values based on the idea that a human being is an end not a means. You can\xe2\x80\x99t justifiably use a human being as an object. It is wrong to enslave a person, even if that slavery might produce a large good. It is wrong to kill a person for his organs, even if many lives might be saved.'b'And yet we don\xe2\x80\x99t actually live according to that moral imperative. Life is filled with tragic trade-offs. In many different venues, the suffering of the few is justified by those trying to deliver the greatest good for the greatest number.'b'Companies succeed because they fire people, even if a whole family depends on them. Schools become prestigious because they reject people \xe2\x80\x94 even if they put a lifetime of work into their application. Leaders fighting a war on terror accidentally kill innocents. These are children in the basement of our survival and happiness.'b'The story compels readers to ask if they are willing to live according to those contracts. Some are not. They walk away from prosperity, and they make some radical commitment. They would rather work toward some inner purity.'b'The rest of us live with the trade-offs. The story reminds us of the inner numbing this creates. The people who stay in Omelas aren\xe2\x80\x99t bad; they just find it easier and easier to live with the misery they depend upon. I\xe2\x80\x99ve found that this story rivets people because it confronts them with all the tragic compromises built into modern life \xe2\x80\x94 all the children in the basements \xe2\x80\x94 and, at the same time, it elicits some desire to struggle against bland acceptance of it all.'b'In another reading, the whole city of Omelas is just different pieces of one person\xe2\x80\x99s psychology, a person living in the busy modern world, and that person\xe2\x80\x99s idealism and moral sensitivity is the shriveling child locked in the basement.'b'Writing this column on Monday afternoon, I can only guess at the final score of the big game between Ohio State and Oregon. Following an internal investigation, the mayor did the right thing and dismissed Mr. Cochran for what he called poor judgment: specifically, for failing to get approval for the book\xe2\x80\x99s publication, for commenting publicly on his suspension after being told not to, and for exposing the city to possible discrimination lawsuits.'b'Cue up the 'b'outraged'b' 'b'claims'b' that Mr. Cochran\xe2\x80\x99s rights to free speech and religious freedom have been violated \xe2\x80\x94 an assertion that is as wrong as it was predictable.'b'Mr. Cochran said he was fired \xe2\x80\x9cfor no reason other than my Christian faith.\xe2\x80\x9d But he and his sudden coterie of supporters have it backward. His position as a high-level public servant makes his remarks especially problematic, and requires that he be held to a different standard.'b'Unfortunately, Georgia\xe2\x80\x99s lawmakers are headed in the opposite direction, considering for the second year in a row a 'b'\xe2\x80\x9creligious-freedom\xe2\x80\x9d bill'b' that, like 'b'others around the country'b', would do little more than provide legal cover for anti-gay discrimination.'b'The First Amendment already protects religious freedom. Nobody can tell Mr. Cochran what he can or cannot believe. If he wants to work as a public official, however, he may not foist his religious views on other city employees who have the right to a boss who does not speak of them as second-class citizens.'b'The legacy of America\xe2\x80\x99s war in Afghanistan, which nominally ended on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve, will come into sharper focus in the coming decade. Historians will spend years figuring out what went right or wrong and which of Washington\xe2\x80\x99s programs will prove to be of lasting value.'b'There is one crucial piece of unfinished business that will speak volumes at the end of the day: whether the United States kept its promise to Afghan military interpreters who were offered the opportunity to resettle in America in recognition of the monumental risks they took.'b'Congress created special visa programs for Afghan and Iraqi military linguists starting in 2006. Early on, it was managed with callous disregard for its intended Afghan beneficiaries; only a fraction of the petitions submitted were approved. Secretary of State John Kerry has taken commendable steps over the past two years to streamline the review process and approve a higher percentage of cases. But the State Department remains hamstrung by a problem of its own making that only Congress can fix.'b'About 12,000 Afghan linguists have pending applications for the special visa. Under current law, however, the State Department has the authority to issue only 4,000 visas over the next two years. This logjam was entirely avoidable if only Washington bureaucrats had operated with greater dispatch. During some of the toughest years of the war, American officials in Kabul and Washington sat on, or rejected, the bulk of applications in the pipeline. In 2010 and 2011, for instance, only a few dozen Afghan linguists \xe2\x80\x94 an astonishingly small number \xe2\x80\x94 were allowed to immigrate.'b'At the time, some American officials in Kabul took the view that the program would worsen the country\xe2\x80\x99s brain drain and that enabling young, bilingual, educated Afghans to leave their homeland would send the wrong message about the state of a war that Washington portrayed with disingenuous optimism over the years. Many Afghan linguists actually 'b'received rejection letters'b' that described them, indefensibly and without evidence, as suspected threats.'b'The sad result was more than 6,500 visa slots that Congress set aside for the early years of the program expired, 'b'leaving brave Afghans and their families in limbo'b'. Many are living in hiding today, unable to return to their native provinces where the Taliban hold sway.'b'Fortunately, their plight came to the attention of American servicemen and servicewomen, who have lobbied their representatives in Congress seeking help. In the Senate, John McCain, a Republican from Arizona, and Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat from New Hampshire, championed the cause.'b'In an era of partisan acrimony and gridlock on Capitol Hill, their leadership on this issue has been inspirational. Lawmakers should ensure those are financed and approved either as part of the defense bill, if they actually manage to pass one this year, or through stand-alone legislation.'b'Failing to give all eligible and deserving applicants a fair shot at a new start in the United States would represent an abdication of a promise that helped persuade linguists to put their lives on the line. That would add a shameful chapter to the legacy of a war that has been grim enough for Afghans.'b'AMSTERDAM \xe2\x80\x94 Something snapped. I was 13 years old, dreaming of books and girls and nothing else \xe2\x80\x94 a healthy Dutch kid with a Moroccan background who freewheeled through life. Then something happened that made me feel different from the pack. One day in history class, the fatwa against Salman Rushdie became the subject. Our teacher talked about freedom of expression; I talked about insulting the Prophet. There was an awkward silence. What was that Abdelkader guy talking about? Fatwhat?'b'But our teacher, Mr. Fok, understood me. He claimed the fatwa didn\xe2\x80\x99t make sense. How could somebody be offended by fiction? How could using one\xe2\x80\x99s imagination lead to the death sentence?'b'I remember standing up, my voice rising as I struggled to make an argument about the holiness of the Prophet to me and my community. And the more Mr. Fok responded with cold and rational analysis the angrier I got. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t he get that this was about more than reason and common sense? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t he get that mocking the Prophet was a moral crime?'b'My classmates looked at me like a madman. By then I was standing and shouting. I\xe2\x80\x99d never felt such anger before. This wasn\xe2\x80\x99t about a novel, this was about me. About us. I wanted revenge. Mr. Fok just looked at me, amazed by my temper and a bit annoyed, and dismissed me from class.'b'For the first time in my life I felt what it meant to be Muslim. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to feel that way. I wanted to blend in, to look normal like the other kids in my class. After the frustration and anger ebbed, I felt shame \xe2\x80\x94 for letting my religion down, letting my family down, letting myself down. Shame for an anger I didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand.'b'I grew up in a relatively traditional Moroccan family. We observed Ramadan but my father rarely went to the mosque. There were two books in our house, the Quran and the phone book. We never looked at either of them.'b'We didn\xe2\x80\x99t talk much about the fatwa but it was impossible to ignore. Muslims were marching through the streets of Rotterdam. It was the first time we felt seen as part of a community that had questions to answer: Which side are you on? Why are you offended? Where does this anger come from? Can Islam coexist with Western values?'b'The world didn\xe2\x80\x99t stop reminding me I was a Muslim. My name, my background, my skin, my family and the events unfolding in the world all led to more self-questioning.'b'Islam told me God is One and the Prophet is his messenger. Adhere to the five pillars and all will be well. But we were living in a non-Muslim country. But I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Dutch, nor was I secular. I had to find a way to reconcile my religious background with a secular world. I felt orphaned.'b'And resolving that dilemma is much harder in a secular society that seems to have stopped struggling with these big questions altogether.'b'In the end, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t find the answers in holy texts. I found them in literature.'b'I read Kafka\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cMetamorphosis\xe2\x80\x9d and Camus\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cThe Plague.\xe2\x80\x9d I thought back on my younger days lashing out against \xe2\x80\x9cThe Satanic Verses.\xe2\x80\x9d I remembered sneaking into a bookshop and seeing the book piled up ready to be read but my English was insufficient to understand it. The book turned me away; the curiosity stayed.'b'When I was 17, I found \xe2\x80\x9cThe Satanic Verses\xe2\x80\x9d tucked away in a school library. I grabbed it, started reading and was mesmerized. Here was a young man struggling with his faith in a faithless world \xe2\x80\x94 an immigrant son from a deeply religious home thrown into a world where everything is embraced and nothing is sacred. It confirmed what I had felt deep inside: a free and open society is a threat to religious people. Their religion will be mocked \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes even suppressed \xe2\x80\x94 and this will provoke anger.'b'And now it\xe2\x80\x99s happening again. The rise of extremists who lure young Muslims in the West with visions of Islamic utopia is creating nausea among European Muslims. Boys and girls are leaving their families and being converted into killing machines. They are leaving not from Baghdad but from Brussels and The Hague. We insist that this can\xe2\x80\x99t be our Islam and if this is Islam we don\xe2\x80\x99t want it. But I know from my own experience that the lure of extremism can be very powerful when you grow up in a world where the media and everyone around you seems to mock and insult your culture.'b'And European governments are not helping fight extremism by giving in to Islamophobia cooked up by right-wing populists. What I see is a lack of courage to embrace the Muslims of Europe as genuinely European \xe2\x80\x94 as citizens like everyone else.'b'One of the first people the terrorists in Paris killed was one of us: Mustapha Ourrad, an Algerian-born copy editor at Charlie Hebdo. And every time a European Muslim sees that image of Mr. Merabet\xe2\x80\x99s last moments, he sees himself lying there on the cold pavement. Helpless. And the next question will be: What will I say tomorrow at work or at school?'b'What happened last week is not about lack of humor, or a failure to understand caricature. They came back to rescue their God and left 12 dead behind. They fell prey to a powerful delusion.'b'It was the same delusion I felt as a teenager: that by attacking the messenger your anger will disappear and you will be victorious. We are here to stay.'b'TORONTO \xe2\x80\x94 The Sri Lanka that Pope Francis is now visiting to canonize an 18th-century missionary is a radically different country than it was just one week ago. Mr. Kouachi wanted, 'b'according to testimony'b' given at a 2008 court hearing, to \xe2\x80\x9cburn synagogues,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cvandalize Jewish stores in Paris\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cterrorize the Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d We know that dream was shared by Amedy Coulibaly, the 'b'gunman who laid siege to a kosher supermarket'b' in Paris on Friday and 'b'killed four'b' of the terrified hostages \xe2\x80\x94 Yoav Hattab, Yohan Cohen, Philippe Braham and Fran\xc3\xa7ois-Michel Saada \xe2\x80\x94 for one reason: They were Jews.'b'In 2012, the French Islamist 'b'Mohammed Merah'b' murdered three students and a teacher at a Jewish school in Toulouse. In May, the Syria-returned Frenchman 'b'Mehdi Nemmouche'b' killed four people in an attack on a Jewish museum in Brussels.'b'Anti-Semitism manifested its hateful ways again last summer when synagogues and Jewish-owned shops were attacked in and near Paris after Israel\xe2\x80\x99s incursion into Gaza. The destruction of Jewish businesses recalled painful images of past suffering endured by Europe\xe2\x80\x99s Jews, including the violent attacks on Jewish merchants on Kristallnacht, the infamous night of Nov. 9, 1938, which was the beginning of the Nazi pogrom against Austrian and German Jews. In France, 75,000 French Jews were deported to Nazi concentration camps during World War II.'b'It is no wonder that feelings of insecurity and isolation have resurfaced, and that some French Jews are asking themselves if they have a future in France, home to Europe\xe2\x80\x99s largest Jewish population. Many have already left for Israel \xe2\x80\x94 'b'nearly 7,000 last year'b' \xe2\x80\x94 and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who attended the march in Paris on Sunday, urged more French Jews to do so, telling them: \xe2\x80\x9cIsrael is your home.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'An exodus of Jews would suit last week\xe2\x80\x99s attackers just fine. The terrorists hoped that the murder of Jews and the cartoonists who dared to sketch the Prophet Muhammad would trigger a spiral of polarizing hate and fear. Since the attacks last week, there have been more than 'b'50 anti-Muslim episodes across France'b', including 21 shootings aimed at mosques and other Muslim buildings. French Muslims, too, are afraid.'b'Prime Minister Manuel Valls has promised that all French citizens can count on government protection of their places of worship. But the theological and legal complications in the proposal run deeper yet, and disentangling the civil and religious dimensions of marriage would be incredibly thorny.'b'For one thing, mainstream Protestant theology considers marriage to be an essentially civil institution, albeit one with deep religious significance. Protestants have not historically recognized the idea of \xe2\x80\x9creligious marriage\xe2\x80\x9d distinct from civil marriage.'b'So asking couples to \xe2\x80\x9cbe married in Christian rites\xe2\x80\x9d first and only then get married civilly would require \xe2\x80\x94 for Protestants \xe2\x80\x94 a significant retreat from principles established since the Reformation.'b'On the civil side of the ledger, Ephraim Radner, an Episcopal priest and a co-author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Marriage Pledge,\xe2\x80\x9d who was featured in your article, might want to reconsider his admiration for the French system. In fact, French law, in\xc2\xa0the name of preserving the state\xe2\x80\x99s monopoly over marriage, prohibits clergy from conducting religious wedding ceremonies for couples not yet civilly married. Some American states have similar provisions, though their enforceability is uncertain.'b'PERRY DANE'b'\nCamden, N.J., Jan. 4, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a law professor at Rutgers.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Moment of Optimism on Sudan Peace Fades as New Talks Approach'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Addis Ababa Memo, Jan. 9) leaves out the most important element to the fading of hope in Sudan: the failure of the United States and the international community to stand up to President Omar Hassan al-Bashir and support the modest commitments that were made to his victims.'b'First, the United Nations failed to hold its peacekeeping mission accountable and provide adequate support to succeed. Now Mr. Bashir is expelling United Nations officials, bombing civilians and demanding that all United Nations peacekeepers leave the country. The response from the Obama administration and other governments has been tepid statements of concern and regrets about the unsurprising failure of peace talks.'b'There were more victims of violence and more displacement in Darfur in 2014 \xe2\x80\x94 almost 500,000 \xe2\x80\x94 than in any year since the height of the genocide. The failure of the United States and the United Nations to protect innocent people and to press Mr. Bashir \xe2\x80\x94 a man wanted for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity \xe2\x80\x94 means that 2015 will be worse.'b'\xc2\xa0TOM ANDREWS'b'\nPresident'b'\nUnited to End Genocide'b'\nWashington, Jan. 12, 2015'b''b''b''b'WILL \xe2\x80\x9cmoderate Muslims\xe2\x80\x9d finally \xe2\x80\x9cspeak up\xe2\x80\x9d against their militant coreligionists? People around the world have asked (but, as in the past, have not all seriously examined) this question since last week\xe2\x80\x99s horrific attacks on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket in Paris.'b'In fact, Muslim statesmen, clerics and intellectuals have added their voices to condemnations of terror by leaders around the world. But they must undertake another essential task: Address and reinterpret Islam\xe2\x80\x99s traditional take on \xe2\x80\x9cblasphemy,\xe2\x80\x9d or insult to the sacred.'b'The Paris terrorists were apparently fueled by the zeal to punish blasphemy, and fervor for the same cause has bred militancy in the name of Islam in various other incidents, ranging from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini\xe2\x80\x99s fatwa against the writer Salman Rushdie in 1989 to the threats and protests against the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten for publishing cartoons lampooning the Prophet Muhammad in 2005.'b'Mockery of Muhammad, actual or perceived, has been at the heart of nearly all of these controversies over blasphemy.'b'This might seem unremarkable at first, but there is something curious about it, for the Prophet Muhammad is not the only sacred figure in Islam. The Quran praises other prophets \xe2\x80\x94 such as Abraham, Moses and Jesus \xe2\x80\x94 and even tells Muslims to \xe2\x80\x9cmake no distinction\xe2\x80\x9d between these messengers of God. Yet for some reason, Islamist extremists seem to obsess only about the Prophet Muhammad.'b'Even more curiously, mockery of God \xe2\x80\x94 what one would expect to see as the most outrageous blasphemy \xe2\x80\x94 seems to have escaped their attention as well. Satirical magazines such as Charlie Hebdo have run cartoons ridiculing God (in the Jewish, Christian and Muslim contexts), but they were targeted with violence only when they ridiculed the Prophet Muhammad.'b'Of course, this is not to say extremists should threaten and harm cartoonists for more diverse theological reasons; obviously, they should not target them at all. But the exclusive focus on the Prophet Muhammad is worth pondering. One obvious explanation is that while God and the other prophets are also sacred for Judaism and Christianity, the Prophet Muhammad is sacred only for Muslims. In other words, the zeal comes not from merely respect for the sacred, but from militancy for what\xe2\x80\x99s sacred to us \xe2\x80\x94 us being the community of Muslims. So the unique sensitivity around Muhammad seems to be a case of religious nationalism, with its focus on the earthly community \xe2\x80\x94 rather than of true faith, whose main focus should be the divine.'b'Still, this religious nationalism is guided by religious law \xe2\x80\x94 Shariah \xe2\x80\x94 that includes clauses about punishing blasphemy as a deadly sin. It is thus of vital importance that Muslim scholars courageously, even audaciously, address this issue today. They can begin by acknowledging that, while Shariah is rooted in the divine, the overwhelming majority of its injunctions are man-made, partly reflecting the values and needs of the seventh to 12th centuries \xe2\x80\x94 when no part of the world was liberal, and other religions, such as Christianity, also considered blasphemy a capital crime.'b'The only source in Islamic law that all Muslims accept indisputably is the Quran. And, conspicuously, the Quran decrees no earthly punishment for blasphemy \xe2\x80\x94 or for apostasy (abandonment or renunciation of the faith), a related concept. Nor, for that matter, does the Quran command stoning, female circumcision or a ban on fine arts. All these doctrinal innovations, as it were, were brought into the literature of Islam as medieval scholars interpreted it, according to the norms of their time and milieu.'b'Tellingly, severe punishments for blasphemy and apostasy appeared when increasingly despotic Muslim empires needed to find a religious justification to eliminate political opponents.'b'One of the earliest \xe2\x80\x9cblasphemers\xe2\x80\x9d in Islam was the pious scholar Ghaylan al-Dimashqi, who was executed in the 8th century by the Umayyad Empire. His main \xe2\x80\x9cheresy\xe2\x80\x9d was to insist that rulers did not have the right to regard their power as \xe2\x80\x9ca gift of God,\xe2\x80\x9d and that they had to be aware of their responsibility to the people.'b'Before all that politically motivated expansion and toughening of Shariah, though, the Quran told early Muslims, who routinely faced the mockery of their faith by pagans: \xe2\x80\x9cGod has told you in the Book that when you hear God\xe2\x80\x99s revelations disbelieved in and mocked at, do not sit with them until they enter into some other discourse; surely then you would be like them.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Just \xe2\x80\x9cdo not sit with them\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that is the response the Quran suggests for mockery. Not violence. Not even censorship.'b'Wise Muslim religious leaders from the entire world would do Islam a great favor if they preached and reiterated such a nonviolent and nonoppressive stance in the face of insults against Islam. That sort of instruction could also help their more intolerant coreligionists understand that rage is a sign of nothing but immaturity. The power of any faith comes not from its coercion of critics and dissenters. It comes from the moral integrity and the intellectual strength of its believers.'b'President Obama was criticized for failing to attend, or send a proper surrogate to, the giant antiterrorism march in Paris on Sunday. That criticism was right. But it is typical of American politics today that we focus on this and not what would have really made the world feel the jihadist threat was finally being seriously confronted. And that would not be a march that our president helps to lead, but one in which he\xe2\x80\x99s not involved at all. That would be a million-person march against the jihadists across the Arab-Muslim world, organized by Arabs and Muslims for Arabs and Muslims, without anyone in the West asking for it \xe2\x80\x94 not just because of what happened in Paris but because of the scores of Muslims recently murdered by jihadists in Pakistan, Yemen, Iraq, Libya, Nigeria and Syria.'b'Abdul Rahman al-Rashed, one of the most respected Arab journalists, wrote Monday in his column in\xc2\xa0Al-Sharq Al-Awsat:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cProtests against the recent terrorist attacks in France should have been held in Muslim capitals, rather than Paris, because, in this case, it is Muslims who are involved in this crisis and stand accused. ... The story of extremism begins in Muslim societies, and it is with their support and silence that extremism has grown into terrorism that is harming people. It is of no value that the French people, who are the victims here, take to the streets. ... What is required here is for Muslim communities to disown the Paris crime and Islamic extremism in general.\xe2\x80\x9d ('b'Translation by Memri.org'b'.)'b'The truth is there is a huge amount of ambivalence toward this whole jihadist phenomenon \xe2\x80\x94 more than any of us would like to believe \xe2\x80\x94 in the Arab-Muslim world, Europe and America. This ambivalence starts in the Muslim community, where there is a deep cleavage over what constitutes authentic Islam today. We fool ourselves when we tell Muslims what \xe2\x80\x9creal Islam\xe2\x80\x9d is. Because Islam has no Vatican, no single source of religious authority, there are many Islams today. The puritanical Wahhabi/Salafi/jihadist strain is one of them, and its support is not insignificant.'b'Ambivalence runs through Europe today on the question of what a country should demand of new Muslim immigrants by way of adopting its values. Is 'b'Stratfor\xe2\x80\x99s George Friedman'b' right when he argues that Europeans adopted multiculturalism precisely because they didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to absorb their Muslim immigrants, and many of those Muslim immigrants, who went to Europe to find a job, not a new identity, didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to be absorbed? If so, that spells trouble.'b'Ambivalence runs through Washington\xe2\x80\x99s ties with Saudi Arabia. Ever since jihadists took over Islam\xe2\x80\x99s holiest shrine in Mecca in 1979, proclaiming that Saudi Arabia\xe2\x80\x99s rulers were not pious enough, Saudi Arabia has redoubled its commitment to Wahhabi or Salafist Islam \xe2\x80\x94 the most puritanical, anti-pluralistic and anti-women version of that faith. This Saudi right turn \xe2\x80\x94 combined with oil revenues used to build Wahhabi-inspired mosques, websites and madrassas across the Muslim world \xe2\x80\x94 has tilted the entire Sunni community to the right. Look at a picture of female graduates of Cairo University in 1950. Few are wearing veils. Look at them today. Many are wearing veils. The open, soft, embracing Islam that defined Egypt for centuries \xe2\x80\x94 pray five times a day but wash it down with a beer at night \xe2\x80\x94 has been hardened by this Wahhabi wind from Arabia.'b'But U.S. presidents never confront Saudi Arabia about this because of our oil addiction. As I\xe2\x80\x99ve said, addicts never tell the truth to their pushers. The Saudi government opposes the jihadists. Unfortunately, though, it\xe2\x80\x99s a very short step from Wahhabi Islam to the violent jihadism practiced by the Islamic State, or ISIS. The French terrorists were born in France but were marinated in Wahhabi-Salafi thought through the web and local mosques \xe2\x80\x94 not Voltaire.'b'Also, the other civil war in Islam \xe2\x80\x94 between Sunnis and Shiites \xe2\x80\x94 has led many mainstream Sunni charities, mosques and regimes to support jihadist groups because they\xe2\x80\x99re ferocious fighters against Shiites.\xc2\xa0Finally \xe2\x80\x94 yet more ambivalence \xe2\x80\x94 for 60 years there was a tacit alliance between Arab dictators and their Sunni religious clergy. The regimes funded these uninspired Muslim clerics, and these clergy blessed the uninspired dictators\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 and both stifled the emergence of any authentic, inspired, reformist Islam that could take on Wahhabism-Salafism, even though many Muslims wanted it. An authentic reformation requires a free space in the Arab-Muslim world.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMuslims need to \xe2\x80\x98upgrade their software,\xe2\x80\x99 which is programmed mainly by our schools, television and mosques \xe2\x80\x94 especially small mosques that trade in what is forbidden,\xe2\x80\x9d Egyptian intellectual Mamoun Fandy wrote in Al-Sharq Al-Awsat. ('b'Also translated by Memri.org.'b') \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no choice but to dismantle this system and rebuild it in a way that is compatible with human culture and values.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In short, jihadist zeal is easy to condemn, but will require multiple revolutions to stem \xe2\x80\x94 revolutions that will require a lot of people in the Arab-Muslim world and West to shed their ambivalence and stop playing double games.'b'Can 'b'Jeb Bush'b' win the Republican presidential nomination while defying the most ideologically committed wing of his party?'b''b'Bill Clinton'b' did this successfully in 1992, when he staked out conservative stands opposed by the liberal wing of his party \xe2\x80\x94 the so-called 'b'Sister Souljah strategy'b', designed to distance himself from the dogma of the left generally and from Jesse Jackson specifically.'b'Over the past 23 years, however, the voting public has become more 'b'politically consistent'b', with the Democratic left and Republican right each exerting greater influence on their respective parties, particularly in primary elections.'b'In 1994, as 'b'Figure 1'b' shows, median Republican and Democratic voters were relatively close to each other, near the center on an ideological scale. This provided a base of support for candidates of both parties to run campaigns accommodating centrist voters.'b'As Figure 2 shows, only 34 percent of Republicans and 36 percent of Democrats today fall 'b'into the middle range'b'. And, if he does, will his party allow him to make use of it?'b'The lifting of the California ban against selling foie gras (the hyperfattened liver of geese or ducks, brought about by overfeeding the live animals) is pretty much a nonissue, except to point out that as a nation we have little perspective on animal welfare. To single out the tiniest fraction of meat production and label it \xe2\x80\x9ccruel\xe2\x80\x9d is to miss the big picture, and the big picture is this: Almost all meat production in the United States is cruel.'b'The sale and production of foie gras was prohibited in California in 2012. Though the ban was widely ignored \xe2\x80\x94 foie gras was served for free in many restaurants and 'b'sold illegally in others'b' \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s now legal to serve it. (Production remains banned.)'b'But so what? Foie gras is among the most overrated of luxury ingredients, ranking right up there with caviar and truffles. Done right, all three are delicious, but we can call them rich people\xe2\x80\x99s food, and as such they\xe2\x80\x99re not that important except to chefs who want to impress rich people or rich people who want to be impressed.'b'Of the three, from the point of view of pleasure, foie gras is the least important (many organ meats are more enjoyable), although it\xe2\x80\x99s the easiest to produce and the least expensive. The best truffles are white, mostly Italian, 'b'difficult to find'b' and stunningly pricey \xe2\x80\x94 upward of $1,000 a pound. The best caviar (beluga) comes from Iran, Russia and a couple of other countries with shores on the Caspian Sea; not only are prices comparable to truffles, fishing these endangered sturgeon is strictly regulated.'b'Foie gras is not only available at relatively moderate prices (you can buy it now for something like $50-$75 a pound), but it\xe2\x80\x99s also never out of season and produced domestically. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a showpiece: Most chefs cook it not because they love it but to appeal to food snobs, who can report, \xe2\x80\x9cWe went to XX last night and had the most amazing foie.\xe2\x80\x9d Right. (See 'b'this headline'b', which is vulgar but not wrong; don\xe2\x80\x99t bother to read the \xe2\x80\x9cstory.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m not aware of a movement against killing sturgeon or other fish whose eggs can be used to make imitation caviar. This may be because fish are generally under-considered in the world of animal welfare, or because the most desired caviar comes from so far away or because it\xe2\x80\x99s more precious than foie gras. But it also may be because caviar doesn\xe2\x80\x99t invoke horrible images of 'b'gavage'b', as the process of overfeeding poultry is called \xe2\x80\x94 images that feature, not to put too fine a point on it, funnels.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not a pretty thought, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a less pretty sight. Of course, 'b'foie gras can also be produced without actually force-feeding'b' because, like many animals \xe2\x80\x94 including humans and dogs \xe2\x80\x94 ducks and geese will happily eat anything that meets their standards. You don\xe2\x80\x99t have to force them: They will stuff themselves anyway. So although the process may be \xe2\x80\x9cunnatural,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s not necessarily \xe2\x80\x9ctorture.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As to whether this is \xe2\x80\x9cgood\xe2\x80\x9d for the animals, that\xe2\x80\x99s another question. But let\xe2\x80\x99s get our priorities straight. Statistically, foie gras is insignificant; according to a spokesman at Hudson Valley Foie Gras, one of the country\xe2\x80\x99s main producers, the market in the United States involves just under 600,000 animals per year.'b'My elementary math estimates that the United States chicken broiler industry kills more birds than that every single hour of every single day. (We produced an estimated 38.5 billion pounds of chicken in 2014, at an average of 6 pounds per bird.) Almost all of those birds are raised in conditions that range from unnatural to torturous.'b'If you allow that the same is true of most animals raised in the United States, from dairy cows (which last year produced roughly 206 billion pounds of milk) to egg-laying hens (over 98 billion eggs) to cattle raised for beef (24 billion pounds), you are looking at an industry that produces cruelty on a scale that\xe2\x80\x99s so big and overwhelming few of us can consider it rationally or regularly. And if you consider that cattle, for example, evolved to graze on grasses and are often fattened on grains \xe2\x80\x94 to which their digestive systems must then adapt \xe2\x80\x94 you might say that part of that industry\xe2\x80\x99s routine is force-feeding.'b'This is not to say a few thousand ducks and geese don\xe2\x80\x99t matter; it is to say that it\xe2\x80\x99s important to keep perspective. Although the plaintiffs used a federal statute (see the Poultry Products Inspection Act) to overturn the ban, and although that makes some animal welfare advocates uneasy, federal law is often used to trump state regulations, both good and bad. The legal experts I spoke to were wary, but did not see that this ruling, for example, set a precedent that might threaten California\xe2\x80\x99s new egg-raising requirements, 'b'about which I wrote on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day'b'.'b'So, since this is not the last word on foie gras in California (or elsewhere), let\xe2\x80\x99s stay tuned. This is best seen as a test case, not as a significant defeat or victory. Foie gras itself just isn\xe2\x80\x99t that important.'b'IN 1974, I graduated from Skyline High School in Oakland, Calif., an underachieving student with lousy SAT scores. Allowed to send my results to three colleges, I chose M.I.T. and Villanova, knowing such fine schools would never accept a student like me but hoping they\xe2\x80\x99d toss some car stickers my way for taking a shot. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford tuition for college anyway. I sent my final set of stats to 'b'Chabot'b', a community college in nearby Hayward, Calif., which, because it accepted everyone and was free, would be my alma mater.'b'For thousands of commuting students, Chabot was our Columbia, Annapolis, even our Sorbonne, offering courses in physics, stenography, auto mechanics, certified public accounting, foreign languages, journalism \xe2\x80\x94 name the art or science, the subject or trade, and it was probably in the catalog. The college had a nursing program that churned out graduates, sports teams that funneled athletes to big-time programs, and parking for a few thousand cars \xe2\x80\x94 all free but for the effort and the cost of used textbooks.'b'Classmates included veterans back from Vietnam, women of every marital and maternal status returning to school, middle-aged men wanting to improve their employment prospects and paychecks. Many lives will be changed.'b'Chabot College is still in Hayward, though Mr. Coovelis, Ms. Fitzgerald and Mr. Kennedy are no longer there. I drove past the campus a few years ago with one of my kids and summed up my two years there this way: \xe2\x80\x9cThat place made me what I am today.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama this week 'b'proposed'b' privacy laws that could give Americans greater control over their personal information. But Republicans in Congress will likely undermine or ignore many of the measures.'b'Some of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'ideas'b' should have bipartisan appeal. For example, he wants to forbid companies from using data about students that they collect when they sell software and services to primary and secondary schools for marketing purposes. That measure is based on a law that 'b' California adopted 'b'last year with Democratic and Republican votes in the State Legislature. Most members of Congress would have a hard time justifying voting against a bill that sought to protect the privacy of minors.'b'But another proposal in Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s package could result in less protection for consumers. It would require retailers, banks and other companies who have been hacked to notify customers whose data had been stolen within 30 days after officials learned of the breach. The problem is that such a law could invalidate existing state laws and prevent states from enacting new privacy laws.'b'Most states and the District of Columbia already have disclosure laws. Alabama, New Mexico and South Dakota do not. Some states have laws that are stronger than what Mr. Obama proposed. For example, California, Connecticut and New Jersey generally 'b'require notification'b' of a data breach as soon as possible. Many states allow consumers to \xe2\x80\x9cfreeze\xe2\x80\x9d credit reports so that hackers cannot sign up for credit cards and loans in their names. Other states allow residents to sue businesses for not protecting their data. Privacy law experts say Congress could use a data breach laws to pre-empt these state requirements.'b'Mr. Obama and 'b'lawmakers in Congress'b' say a federal law would establish a national standard for businesses to follow. As a practical matter, privacy advocates say, companies are not hamstrung by having to follow different state policies because they usually do whatever is required by the strongest state law in all states. Another problem with the president\xe2\x80\x99s proposal is that it does not require businesses to improve the security of their computer systems so data are not stolen in the first place.'b'There is no doubt that federal law does not adequately protect the privacy of Americans. Numerous reports produced by 'b'Congress'b', the 'b'Federal Trade Commission'b' and newspapers including 'b'The Times'b' have documented the widespread collection of data like Internet browsing histories, retail store purchases and health information. Some companies known as data brokers organize and analyze vast sums of such data into dossiers on individuals and families that can be used to target people based on their medical conditions, economic desperation and their willingness to spend money.'b'In 2012, Mr. Obama wisely called for a \xe2\x80\x9c'b'privacy bill of rights'b'\xe2\x80\x9d that would give individuals more control over how their information is collected and used. The president now says his administration will produce such a bill of rights in the next 45 days. But nobody realistically expects the current Republican-led Congress to adopt a strong law that truly empowers consumers.'b''b'State lawmakers'b' in California, Oklahoma, Texas and elsewhere have been willing to pass privacy laws. Those efforts are insufficient, but at least those lawmakers are trying, unlike members of Congress who have taken little interest in a privacy bill of rights because Internet companies and advertisers have heavily lobbied against it. That is why Mr. Obama must be careful not to give Congress an opportunity to undermine state laws.'b'What is a year of your life worth? How about 10 years? Or 20? In many ways the question is unanswerable: Who can assign a dollar amount to the experience of watching a child grow up, of being able to care for an elderly parent?'b'But when the government has wrongfully convicted and imprisoned someone, a cash payout is the most meaningful way to make amends and achieve some measure of belated justice.'b'Scott Stringer, the New York City comptroller, appears to understand this. On Sunday, Mr. Stringer\xe2\x80\x99s office 'b'announced'b' payments totaling $17 million to three men who spent a combined 60 years in prison. The men \xe2\x80\x94 Robert Hill, Alvena Jennette and Darryl Austin \xe2\x80\x94 were each convicted of murders in cases handled by Louis Scarcella, a Brooklyn homicide detective whose tactics are now 'b'under review'b' by Kenneth Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney. Their convictions were 'b'vacated'b' in May after prosecutors admitted that a witness Mr. Scarcella repeatedly used was unreliable. (Last year, Mr. Stringer paid $6.4 million to David Ranta, who was freed in 2013 after serving 23 years on a wrongful murder conviction, also involving Mr. Scarcella.)'b'Compensating those who have been wrongfully convicted is not just about correcting a manifest injustice. People who come out of prison after many years face all kinds of obstacles to rebuilding their lives.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s true for Mr. Hill and Mr. Jennette, half-brothers who live together and struggle to find jobs, according to their lawyer. Mr. Austin died in prison in 2000.'b'Thirty states, the federal government and the District of Columbia 'b'have laws'b' providing for compensation to the wrongfully convicted \xe2\x80\x94 'b'from $5,000 per year'b' in Wisconsin to $80,000 per year in Texas. But, over all, 'b'almost a third'b' of those exonerated get nothing. And those who get something often must 'b'jump through multiple hoops'b', like demonstrating they are innocent or showing intentional misconduct by the police or prosecutors.'b'Under New York\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'compensation law'b', a judge determines the amount of money to be paid, a process that can take years to complete, as can federal civil-rights lawsuits like the ones these men were considering bringing against the city. While the payouts offered by Mr. Stringer were in part an effort to avoid costly litigation, and thus are significantly lower than what these men 'b'might have won'b' in court, they have the benefit of being swift and certain.'b'That is especially important to exonerees who may need prompt help in adjusting to the outside world and who do not receive the same critical re-entry services like job training and substance-abuse treatment that parolees get. Going forward, New York and other states should provide such critical services to the wrongfully convicted immediately upon their release.'b'Nearly every day, there is another story of a man or woman walking out of prison after years of wrongful incarceration, whether because of newly uncovered DNA evidence, a mistaken identification or a prosecutor\xe2\x80\x99s misconduct. It would be nice to think that officials entrusted with the power to put people behind bars will always do the right thing, but it helps when real money is on the line.'b'NEW DELHI \xe2\x80\x94 There are two key requirements for a truly representative democracy: First, that anyone of good character can run for election, without regard to income, gender or social status; and second, that voters determine which qualities are most important in those they elect.'b'The Indian state of Rajasthan has struck a blow against both of these freedoms. Last month, the governor issued an executive order barring citizens with less than eight years of formal education from running for election for village council head. The rationale was to create more effective and less corrupt administrations. The effect, however, will be to disempower the historically disadvantaged \xe2\x80\x94 women and the poor. Upward of half the state\xe2\x80\x99s adult male population and three-quarters of its adult female population have been disqualified from running in the elections that begin this week.'b'There are some 250,000 village councils, or Gram Panchayats, in 'b'India'b'. Elections are held every five years, and voter turnout regularly surpasses that in state and national elections. The demographic makeup of those elected is also more diverse, in large part a result of the constitutional requirement that a certain fraction of council head positions, or Pradhans, be reserved for women, lower castes and tribal groups. As of 2009, only 11 percent of India\xe2\x80\x99s national legislators were women, compared with 40 percent of village council heads.'b'The councils choose which public goods to invest in \xe2\x80\x94 from drinking-water facilities to roads \xe2\x80\x94 and where to put them. They implement welfare schemes and public jobs programs, and decide who will benefit. Over the last decade, as India has expanded its social safety net and increased investments in rural infrastructure, the financial stakes of village elections have risen. The politicians behind the education requirement have argued that less educated leaders failed to be effective administrators and were less able to resist corruption and negotiate with district officials.'b'There is some evidence that supports this position. However, it may also reflect a less enlightened agenda. The election of villagers from historically disadvantaged groups poses a major challenge to the traditional elite, who are used to controlling council resources.'b'The recent order is only the latest example of Rajasthan\xe2\x80\x99s limiting voters\xe2\x80\x99 choices. Earlier in December, the governor issued another ordinance requiring candidates to have a functional toilet, effectively eliminating many of the poor. And unfortunately, other states tend to follow Rajasthan\xe2\x80\x99s example. Back in 1992, it became the first state to require that candidates for village council positions have no more than two children \xe2\x80\x94 a rule that particularly hurts lower castes and tribal groups, where fertility rates are highest. Since then, 10 other states have passed fertility limits on local leaders (though four have since revoked the law). A recent paper found that these limits increased the incidence of sex-selective abortions, and a qualitative study in Northern India from 2005 reported that men got around the law by disowning later-born children and occasionally deserting their wives.'b'Rajasthan has a terrible record on women\xe2\x80\x99s education and female empowerment. The state has the country\xe2\x80\x99s second-lowest female literacy rate: 52 percent. And it has some of the most skewed child sex ratios, as a result of sex-selective abortion and reduced parental investment in daughters. According to the 2011 census, there were 883 girls for every 1,000 boys under age 6.'b'Village councils headed by women can catalyze change. In research published in the Quarterly Journal of Economics in 2009 and in Science magazine in 2012, my colleagues and I showed that living in a village that had elected a female leader caused villagers to report lower bias against female leaders. By creating empowered female role models, it led villagers to state more equal aspirations for their teenage sons and daughters and to reduce their daughters\xe2\x80\x99 domestic chores and increase their schooling.'b'In 2010, my colleagues and I surveyed newly elected village chiefs in 247 village councils, in regions where women have historically faced significant discrimination. Our sample included 34 women who had defeated male candidates for the council head position. These women, who had successfully challenged the traditional village male elite, were the aspirational symbols for new India. But this year, 82 percent of them have been disqualified from running.'b'The governor\xe2\x80\x99s order won\xe2\x80\x99t hurt only women who want to run for office; it will have negative consequences for all women living in these villages.'b'The governor issued the education requirement when the state legislature was out of session. As a result, it is open to a legal challenge, and a case is being heard in the state\xe2\x80\x99s High Court. Unfortunately, any change will most likely come too late for this election.'b'Education is, of course, vital. In surveys, including ones we conducted in Rajasthan in 2010, voters consistently report a strong preference for educated leaders. Requiring a benchmark for education, however, will discriminate against able leaders who have been denied schooling because of gender, poverty or caste, and who have nevertheless worked to educate themselves.'b'There are better ways of ensuring that elected politicians are competent and effective. In the month before the 2010 election, we worked with a local nonprofit group in Rajasthan on a voter awareness campaign involving theater shows and the distribution of posters and calendars. The campaign caused more literate villagers to enter the fray as candidates, and these candidates gained a higher fraction of the vote. And if the state government is truly worried about the increasing administrative demands on council heads, it could simply provide them with better support.'b'Voters, not distant state officials, are likely to make the best choices as to who will most effectively represent them. A de facto handing over of local political control to the better off will not help solve Rajasthan\xe2\x80\x99s gap between rich and poor, or stark gender inequality.'b'PARIS \xe2\x80\x94 About four years ago, a friend invited me to lunch with some cartoonists from Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper. Charlie was looking for new writers. I was looking for work.'b'To prepare for the meeting, I read Charlie Hebdo. I hardly knew what to make of it. It was one of those French things, like the shops that sell nothing but taxidermied animals, that have no American equivalent. Charlie Hebdo\xe2\x80\x99s pages of cartoons \xe2\x80\x94 typically about religion, sex, politics or some combination of the three \xe2\x80\x94 came from a strain of Frenchness I didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand.'b'At the lunch, I also didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what to make of the three editors: St\xc3\xa9phane Charbonnier, Jean Cabut and Laurent Sourisseau. They were grown men who went by strange nicknames \xe2\x80\x94 Charb, Cabu and Riss \xe2\x80\x94 and had the aura of local legends. Practically everything they said seemed like an inside joke that made the others chuckle.'b'The three men listened politely as I pitched them story ideas in my pockmarked French. One, I think it was Cabut, drew me a sweet cartoon; it was his way of connecting. But they were members of a French fraternity whose references eluded me. We parted with smiles, and never spoke again.'b'Last week, after gunmen killed 10 people at Charlie Hebdo\xe2\x80\x99s weekly news meeting, I spoke to the friend who had organized that meeting. \xe2\x80\x9cTwo of the three people with whom you had lunch are dead,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. (Riss was shot in the shoulder, but survived.)'b'France can sometimes seem bafflingly foreign, but the past week has made me understand Charlie Hebdo, and the country, better. It also shocked me into a sense of belonging. Like many expatriates, I experienced the attacks not as an outsider observing France, but as a Parisian and a parent.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s partly because, in the confusion of events last week, the locals didn\xe2\x80\x99t know any more than we foreigners did. For once, we were all equally disoriented.'b'And events were unfolding so close by. Charlie Hebdo\xe2\x80\x99s offices are a 10-minute walk from my apartment. The winner was an Alabamian who had walked her daughter to dance class on the same sidewalk where, just before, a policeman was shot dead.'b'It also helped that Paris suddenly became friendlier. Parents smiled at one another at our school drop-offs. A waiter at my local cafe seemed elated to see me. My downstairs neighbor, who usually approached me only to complain about noise, attempted to hug me (I converted this to a handshake).'b'We all struggled to control the narrative for our kids. Mine could hear police cars from their schoolyard. On Friday, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to mention the hostage crisis unfolding in Vincennes, a few miles away. But when I picked up my daughter from school, she immediately asked: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s happening at Vincennes?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'She was clutching a copy of Le Petit Quotidien, a French newspaper for 6- to 10-year-olds, with the headline \xe2\x80\x9cJournalists in Danger.\xe2\x80\x9d She asked whether I was in danger, too. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s starting to get stressful,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.'b'Then, when I didn\xe2\x80\x99t answer my phone, one of my 6-year-olds told my husband I might be dead.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you think that?\xe2\x80\x9d my husband asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause of Charlie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'His twin brother said a classmate had taught him how to stop bad guys: You point at the ceiling, say \xe2\x80\x9clook at the bird,\xe2\x80\x9d and then when the man looks up, you rush in and kick him. He spent part of Saturday chasing another friend around our apartment, while one of them shouted \xe2\x80\x9cCharlie!\xe2\x80\x9d and the other said, \xe2\x80\x9cJe vais te massacrer\xe2\x80\x9d (I\xe2\x80\x99m going to massacre you).'b'For some parents in France, talking about events was even more complicated. You can just say, this isn\xe2\x80\x99t Islam, and that you\xe2\x80\x99re shocked, and that you\xe2\x80\x99re against what happened."\xe2\x80\x99'b'Belkaid wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a fan of Charlie Hebdo. Even my friend who set up the lunch told me this week that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t always his cup of tea either, but that he admired the principle of free speech behind it.'b'I get that principle now, too. When Charlie Hebdo was attacked, they immediately grasped what was at stake.'b'Though we live along the protest route in Paris, I\xe2\x80\x99d never marched for anything. I was just another face in the Parisian crowd. And for the first time ever, that felt exactly right.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s being called the most significant election in 'b'Sri Lanka'b' in decades.
