SWARTZ'b'\nNew York, Jan. 14, 2015'b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 WE live in an era of unusual political polarization, but the polarization isn\xe2\x80\x99t simply between the two parties; there are also splits within them.'b'Last week the Republican Party\xe2\x80\x99s divisions were on display, when Speaker of the House John A. Boehner \xe2\x80\x94 who helped his party gain its largest majority since the Truman administration \xe2\x80\x94 faced an uprising. The revolt was led by conservatives against a man whose voting record is unquestionably conservative. It was another indication that the tension on the right these days is not about policy or ideology but tone and temperament.'b'Mr. Boehner is hardly a perfect leader, but what got him into trouble was less a failure to lead than a failure to fight. The Republican Party is more uniformly conservative than ever. What some on the right are insisting on from Republican leaders, but not getting, is greater confrontation, more strident rhetoric and legislative brinkmanship. Hence the unhappiness.'b'What informs these demands is an apocalyptic view of American life during the Obama era. America is \xe2\x80\x9cvery much like Nazi Germany,\xe2\x80\x9d in the words of Ben Carson, a Tea Party favorite. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas said we had a couple of years to turn this country around or \xe2\x80\x9cwe go off the cliff to oblivion.\xe2\x80\x9d Mark Levin, a popular radio talk show host, warned that Republicans were \xe2\x80\x9cendorsing tyranny\xe2\x80\x9d if they didn\xe2\x80\x99t support shutting down the government in 2013.'b'Those of us who are conservative and deeply concerned about the damage inflicted on the country by the president but don\xe2\x80\x99t share this doom-laden view are labeled by some on the right as cowardly and unprincipled. Which raises a significant political and philosophical issue: Is there a conservative disposition? The answer, I think, is that there is, and what I\xe2\x80\x99ve just described is not it.'b'What often masquerades as conservatism these days is really populism. There is room for populism within conservatism, but it should not define conservatism. In fact, it is often in conflict with it.'b'Conservatism, for starters, is rooted in human experience. It appreciates the complexity of human society. It believes in a givenness to human nature and in enduring principles, yet it has the capacity to apply those principles to changing circumstances. And because it isn\xe2\x80\x99t a rigid ideology, it leaves itself open to self-examination and self-correction. Authentic conservatism has a high regard for things empirical, for facts that can lead us to better apprehend the truth.'b'Conservatism is famously anti-utopian, understanding life\xe2\x80\x99s imperfections and the limitations of politics. Knowing this, those on the right shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t become enraged or forlorn when the world itself doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fully conform to their hopes. Conservatism considers one of the cardinal virtues to be prudence. And no conservative \xe2\x80\x94 certainly no one familiar with the magnificent history of the Constitution \xe2\x80\x94 should be opposed to compromise per se. Whether or not accommodation is wise depends on whether an agreement nudges things in the right direction.'b'This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that conservatives shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t fight passionately for liberty and justice. Today\xe2\x80\x99s Republicans, for example, should advance a policy agenda that systematically transforms welfare-state programs into a market-friendly safety net. Nor does it mean that conservatism is merely a disposition, unconnected to a political theory. It simply means that conservatives should make their case with an urgency balanced by practical wisdom, equanimity and a sense of proportion. Their passion should also be balanced by gratitude.'b'In a marvelous 1976 essay, the historian Gertrude Himmelfarb contended that the key word to describe the conservative disposition was \xe2\x80\x9cenjoyment.\xe2\x80\x9d Unlike those who are \xe2\x80\x9calways lusting after something that is not,\xe2\x80\x9d the conservative tends to find delight in the achievements and blessings we have.'b'This matters because disposition is not incidental to politics; it is central to it. Voters rightly base their judgments on more than how politicians check the boxes on policy positions. What also matters is the cast of mind of public officials, their sensibilities and temperament.'b'One\xe2\x80\x99s disposition speaks to something far deeper than merely tone and style. It influences when and how we act, including the fights (or deals) we are drawn to or away from. It determines not just what our priorities are but how we interpret the world. Our lives, then, are determined in large part by our intellectual and psychological predispositions. Think of the difference in attitude between the resentfulness of Richard Nixon and the sunny optimism of Ronald Reagan. One had an enemies list while the other told his aides, \xe2\x80\x9cRemember, we have no enemies, only opponents.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Fairly or not, there are some widespread negative impressions of the Republican Party: opposed to change, too extreme and inflexible, unwilling to compromise. Which is why Republicans, in selecting a presidential nominee, should choose someone with a conservative disposition, who is seen as a reassuring agent of change, and who can persuade voters rather than hector them.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s a good rule of thumb for politics: The stronger one\xe2\x80\x99s philosophical convictions are, the more important temperamental moderation is. Magnanimity, winsomeness and grace aren\xe2\x80\x99t antithetical to conservatism. They are an essential part of it.'b'ELI LILLY charges more than $13,000 a month for Cyramza, the newest drug to treat 'b'stomach cancer'b'. The latest medicine for lung 'b'cancer'b', Novartis\xe2\x80\x99s Zykadia, costs almost $14,000 a month. Amgen\xe2\x80\x99s Blincyto, for leukemia, will cost $64,000 a month.'b'Why? Drug manufacturers blame high prices on the complexity of biology, government regulations and shareholder expectations for high profit margins. In other words, they say, they are hamstrung. But there\xe2\x80\x99s a simpler explanation.'b'Companies are taking advantage of a mix of laws that force insurers to include essentially all expensive drugs in their policies, and a philosophy that demands that every new health care product be available to everyone, no matter how little it helps or how much it costs. Anything else and we\xe2\x80\x99re talking death panels.'b'Examples of companies exploiting these fault lines abound. An article in 'b'The New England Journal of Medicine'b' last fall focused on how companies buy up the rights to old, inexpensive generic drugs, lock out competitors and raise prices. For instance, albendazole, a drug for certain kinds of parasitic infection, was approved back in 1996. As recently as 2010, its average wholesale cost was $5.92 per day. By 2013, it had risen to $119.58.'b'Novartis, the company that makes the leukemia drug Gleevec, keeps raising the drug\xe2\x80\x99s price, even though the drug has already delivered billions in profit to the company. In 2001 Novartis charged $4,540, in 2014 dollars, for a month of treatment; now it charges $8,488. In its pricing, Novartis is just keeping up with other companies as they charge 'b'more and more'b' for their drugs. They know we can\xe2\x80\x99t say no.'b'But what if we didn\xe2\x80\x99t require insurance companies to cover all drugs? We can see the answer in Europe. Many European countries say no to a handful of drugs each year, usually those that are both pretty ineffective and highly costly. Because they can say no, yes is not a guarantee. So companies have to offer their drugs at prices that make them attractive to these health care systems. A recent survey of cancer drug policies revealed you don\xe2\x80\x99t have to say no very often to get discounts for saying yes. Of the 29 major cancer drugs included in the study that are available in the United States, an estimated 97 percent and 86 percent are also available in Germany and France, respectively.'b'As a consequence of the stand taken by those countries, prices in Europe for prescription drugs are 50 percent below what we pay, according to a McKinsey study from 2008. Gleevec costs $4,500 per month in Germany today, and $3,300 per month in France, less than what Americans paid in 2001.'b'Saying no, or even the threat, works to lower prices in the United States, too. But it\xe2\x80\x99s rare. 'b'In 2012'b', my hospital said we wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give the 'b'colon cancer'b' drug Zaltrap to our patients because it cost twice as much as another drug (Genentech\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Avastin'b') that was just as good. When we refused to use it, the company realized that other cancer hospitals and doctors might follow, and halved its price nationwide.'b'More recently, Express Scripts, a company that manages pharmacy benefits, showed that approval was no guarantee. It was therefore able to 'b'play'b' two makers of treatments for 'b'hepatitis C'b' off against each other. Express Scripts said yes to AbbVie\xe2\x80\x99s Viekira Pak (for the most common subtype, genotype 1 disease), and said no to Gilead\xe2\x80\x99s Sovaldi and Harvoni. Another pharmacy benefit program, CVS Caremark, played it the other way, closing out AbbVie and choosing Gilead.'b'Either way, the lesson is that Express Scripts, once it showed it could say no, got AbbVie to discount its product. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t saying how much, but Steve Miller, a senior executive, said it had \xe2\x80\x9csignificantly narrowed the gap between prices charged in the United States and Western Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d Sounds like the kind of progress we need.'b'You might worry about patients being harmed through these moves. But we rejected Zaltrap knowing it was no better than the alternative. Express Scripts and CVS Caremark played the two drug manufacturers off against each other because both manufacture effective treatments.'b'The industry might argue that drug spending is only 10 percent of all health care spending, but that 10 percent equals around $300 billion per year. More important, the costs of high-priced drugs are being passed on to patients. Lilly\xe2\x80\x99s drug Cyramza will cost the average 'b'Medicare'b' patient $2,600 per month without supplemental insurance. That\xe2\x80\x99s more than most Medicare-age people earn each month, before taxes. Actually, high prices get passed on to us all, either through individual costs or insurance.'b'That leaves us with two options. We can free insurers and government programs from the requirement to include all expensive drugs in their plans as we explain to the public that some drugs are not effective enough to justify their price. If we do this, we can be confident that manufacturers will lower their prices to ensure their ability to sell their products. Or we can piggyback on the gumption of bolder countries, and demand that policy makers set drug prices in the United States equal to those of Western Europe. Either approach would be vastly superior to the situation we have today.'b'Another video in another police shooting emerged this week \xe2\x80\x94 and it shows yet another case that demands empathy, and an understanding of the fraught moments that can lead to such an outcome, and the complexity of the legal process that follows.'b''b'The video showed'b' an officer in Montana shooting and killing a passenger in a car at a traffic stop in a \xe2\x80\x9chigh crime\xe2\x80\x9d area of Billings.'b'The dashcam video shows the young police officer, Grant Morrison, approaching the passenger side of the car and immediately saying:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHands up. All four of you, hands up. What were you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Then Morrison asks one of the occupants his name. \xe2\x80\x9cRichard,\xe2\x80\x9d a voice can be heard to reply.'b'Morrison repeats his command that everyone put their hands up or else he\xe2\x80\x99s going to shoot. He draws his gun, and fires three shots into the car, and again yells, \xe2\x80\x9cHands up! Hands up!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'(The actions of the people in the car are obscured on the video.)'b'Richard Ramirez is shot. His lung is punctured.'b'The encounter lasts about 30 seconds.'b'Morrison sobs after the shooting, at the scene, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought he was going to pull a gun on me.\xe2\x80\x9d As Morrison leans on the hood of a police cruiser, another officer seeks to comfort him, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe he was. Maybe he was.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ramirez was high on methamphetamine, but unarmed.'b'There is a coroner\xe2\x80\x99s inquest with a jury.'b'Morrison reportedly says of when he shot Ramirez, \xe2\x80\x9cI knew in that moment, which later was determined to be untrue, but I knew in that moment that he was reaching for a gun.\xe2\x80\x9d He continues, \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t take that risk. ... I wanted to see my son grow up.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The jury clears Morrison of wrongdoing.'b'Ramirez\xe2\x80\x99s family was not happy. 'b'As CBS News reported'b': \xe2\x80\x9cRamirez\xe2\x80\x99s family wanted criminal charges against the officer and said Ramirez was a victim of racial profiling.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrison is white, Ramirez was \xe2\x80\x9chalf-Mexican.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'By the way, this was not the first time in Morrison\xe2\x80\x99s five-year career that he had shot and killed an unarmed man who was high on methamphetamine and who failed to comply with his instructions. In February of 2013, Morrison shot and killed Jason James Shaw. In that case, another officer testified that Morrison said, \xe2\x80\x9cI know you have a gun!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cI will shoot you.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrison was also cleared by a jury of wrongdoing in that killing.'b'This case is an example of how complicated police interaction can be, and it raises many questions that the police and the public must wrestle with as the country debates policing practices, crime, appropriate use of force and the impact on minority communities.'b'First, and this cannot be said often enough, police officers do dangerous work that few of us would sign up to do. When the job is done well, it keeps communities safe and society civil. But the way that is accomplished is that the officers must encounter a disproportionate number of people who break the law, and we must ask to what degree that skew \xe2\x80\x94 the types of people they encounter \xe2\x80\x94 warps their perception of citizens in general.'b'If you overwhelmingly see the bad in people, does it diminish your impulse to search for the good? And if part of your job is to patrol \xe2\x80\x9chigh crime\xe2\x80\x9d areas, are you predisposed to lump in some non-criminals with the actual criminals in those areas? Furthermore, are your fears heightened and is your trigger finger made more itchy in those areas because you are more worried about making it home to your family than about the person you encounter making it home to theirs?'b'Another line of questioning we must explore involves appropriate use of force. Both men shot and killed by Morrison had taken drugs, but that is not a capital offense in a court of law, if you make it alive to a court of law. Both, reportedly, did not properly comply with police instructions \xe2\x80\x94 possibly because of the drug use \xe2\x80\x94 but that, too, is not a capital offense, assuming that you make it alive to a courtroom. Is there a better, more responsible approach to noncompliance than the use of deadly force?'b'(In the case of Shaw, a stun gun was used first, but a heavy jacket reportedly blunted the effect.)'b'And why should police officers so often worry about the presence of a gun anyway? This is a question we have to ask ourselves as a nation in love with our firearms. In 2013, 'b'Illinois became the last state 'b' to allow the concealed carry of firearms. Not that criminals, by definition, care much about laws anyway, but now even more people can legally have concealed guns on them. That has to raise the anxiety of police officers. Furthermore, as the Pew Research Center found last month: \xe2\x80\x9cFor the first time in more than two decades of Pew Research Center surveys, there is more support for gun rights than gun control.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is also the question of whether bias and profiling play a role in officers\xe2\x80\x99 propensity to use deadly force, as Ramirez\xe2\x80\x99s family suggest. There is some conflict here. Studies using simulations in 2002 and 2005 showed that people were more likely to shoot unarmed black men, while, in the case of the latter study, letting armed white people slip by. On the other hand, a study published last year found that participants \xe2\x80\x9cwere more likely to feel threatened in scenarios involving black people. But when it came time to shoot, participants were biased in favor of black suspects, taking longer to pull the trigger against them than against armed white or Hispanic suspects.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These are not apples-to-apples studies, and the scenarios don\xe2\x80\x99t neatly align with the Morrison shootings, but it is worth considering that the science around the issue does not make for simple talking points.'b'Then there is the issue of who gets the benefit of the doubt in police shootings. As 'b'The New York Times pointed out in December'b', grand jury indictment of police officers in deadly forces cases was rare, saying \xe2\x80\x9cthe justice system can favor the police, often shielding them from murder or serious manslaughter charges.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the end, this is again about fears, what informs and activates fears, the actions police officers take \xe2\x80\x94 reasonable or not \xe2\x80\x94 in response to those fears, and whether jurors generally find the officers\xe2\x80\x99 fears justified.'b'The men Morrison killed should not have used drugs and should have quickly complied with his commands. Should there have been some punishment for that? Yes. Should that punishment have been death? But for such an idea to work, states and localities that have been starving community colleges for decades will need to begin holding them to higher standards and commit to sustained financing instead of using the new federal money to dodge their own financial obligations.'b'The president\xe2\x80\x99s proposal deserves to be taken seriously by the public, state legislatures, municipal authorities and, of course, Congress, which will be asked to underwrite it. Although many details have yet to be worked out, the preliminary plans released last week call for an estimated $60 billion in new spending over 10 years to help cover tuition and fees for full-time and half-time students who maintain a 2.5 grade point average \xe2\x80\x94 about a C-plus \xe2\x80\x94 and who make consistent progress toward completion.'b'The program would help as many as nine million students and would be open to colleges that offer credit toward a four-year degree or occupational training programs that offer certificates or degrees in high-demand areas. The federal government would cover three-quarters of the average cost of community college for those students, and states that choose to participate would cover the remainder. If all states participate, the administration estimates, the program could save each full-time student an average of $3,800 a year.'b'Some argue that the program is unnecessary because community college, where tuition averages about $3,330 a year, is reasonably priced and made even more so by the federal Pell Grants available to poor and working-class students. However, tuition accounts for only about one-fifth of the costs of attending a community college. These costs \xe2\x80\x94 as defined by the federal guidelines \xe2\x80\x94 include housing, food, books, transportation and other expenses. These are often insurmountable expenses for community college students \xe2\x80\x94 about one in three come from families with annual incomes below $20,000. Students, many of them struggling academically to begin with, typically try to make up the shortfall by working long hours. Their studies suffer, and they often drop out.'b'This is a particularly severe problem in urban community colleges, where the three-year graduation rate hovers around 15 percent. But, as President Obama pointed out in his announcement, efforts like the Accelerated Study in Associate Programs at the City University of New York can dramatically increase student success, as defined by graduation rates and the rate at which students move on to four-year degrees. ASAP, which began in 2007, provides money for books, coaching, tutoring, tuition waivers and transportation. Fifty-seven percent of last year\xe2\x80\x99s graduates finished in three years.'b'Despite higher upfront costs, the cost per ASAP graduate is actually lower than it is for traditional students because students in the program move through the system more quickly. One study found that for every dollar invested in ASAP, $3.50 in tax revenues and unused social service benefits was gained.'b'As rules are written for the national program, the White House and Congress must make sure that only institutions with a demonstrable commitment to helping students graduate are rewarded. States should be required to sustain significant investments in their community colleges, revise accrediting rules so that community colleges are held to higher standards and make sure that students who graduate from those colleges can easily transfer to public four-year schools.'b'The skepticism that has greeted Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s proposal in some quarters has overtones of the skepticism that greeted 19th-century educators when they began to agitate for free, universal public high schools. Their efforts proved crucial at a time when the country was moving away from farming and toward a world in which reading, writing and reasoning would be critical. Expanded access to community college could do the same thing for the country in the information age.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s a scary thought: New York State\xe2\x80\x99s politicians suddenly have an extra $5 billion to spend. Here are a few better ideas:'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 New York needs $22 billion over the next 20 years to build better drinking-water facilities, and an additional $29.7 billion for wastewater infrastructure, according to the American Society of Civil Engineers. A drop here or there could help.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 The Metropolitan Transportation Authority faces a $15 billion deficit in its five-year capital plan. Even a modest transfusion could benefit the system\xe2\x80\x99s 8.7 million daily riders.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 Nearly a quarter of the state\xe2\x80\x99s major roads are in poor condition, and thousands of older bridges need repairs.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 Farmland could be bought or protected, especially in the upper Hudson region.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 And if Albany runs out of ideas, some of the money could be put away for leaner times.'b'The $5 billion comes from banks and insurance groups that have been fined for various transgressions \xe2\x80\x94 irresponsible peddling of mortgage-backed securities, helping Americans avoid taxes or illegally doing business with countries facing sanctions. The fines have been divided among various entities, including the federal government, with $5 billion flowing to New York.'b'That is a hefty sum. But in Albany hefty sums can disappear quickly, especially if indiscriminately applied to broad tax relief or ongoing programs. That\xe2\x80\x99s why the money should be used for focused, one-shot investments that can bring tangible relief to as many New Yorkers as possible.'b'North Korea thrust itself back into the international limelight with its recent hacking of Sony Pictures. As always, however, the gravest danger from North Korea is the threat that its unpredictable leaders could one day unleash a nuclear weapon, either in anger or by mistake.'b'With so many crises demanding the attention of President Obama and other world leaders, it is tempting, even convenient, to relegate North Korea to the back burner when it is not testing a nuclear device or a missile. The North has not conducted nuclear and missile tests in nearly two years, in large measure because China has been more aggressive in pressuring Pyongyang to behave by withholding vital supplies of jet fuel and heating oil.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s tactics have been a useful short-term check on the North, but they are not a durable answer to the nuclear threat, which continues to grow. North Korea poses a unique danger because it is actually trying to target the United States with nuclear weapons. Experts believe that Pyongyang probably had no nuclear weapons in January 2003 when it walked away from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Yet today the regime may have enough fissile material for as many as a 'b'dozen'b' warheads, in addition to increasingly capable missiles with which to deliver them.'b'Siegfried Hecker, a prominent North Korean specialist who has visited the country several times, wrote recently in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists that the regime is becoming ever more convinced that it needs its nuclear arsenal to survive and that, as a result, the chance of ensuring the long-term goal of a Korean Peninsula without nuclear weapons is growing increasingly dim.'b'Even so, the North on Saturday made public an overture that may suggest a new willingness to engage on the nuclear issue. Ostensibly to promote dialogue on the divided peninsula, it offered to impose a 'b'temporary moratorium on nuclear tests'b' if the United States canceled its joint annual military exercises with South Korea.'b'It is easy to be skeptical, even dismissive, of such a proposal given the North\xe2\x80\x99s brutality toward its people, its history of provocations and its failure to abide by international commitments. The State Department rejected the initiative out of hand, and privately, some officials said they read it as a threat intended to give the North an excuse to carry out a nuclear test as the Americans were carrying out their military exercises.'b'In any case, the Obama administration is sticking to its policy of \xe2\x80\x9cstrategic patience\xe2\x80\x9d toward the North \xe2\x80\x94 imposing tough sanctions and refusing a new round of nuclear negotiations until the North takes steps to halt its program \xe2\x80\x94 and even ratcheting it up. On Jan. 2, it imposed 'b'new sanctions'b' on the North in retaliation for the Sony hacking that can be used in the future to increase pressure on the nuclear and missile programs.'b'Several American analysts on North Korea outside the administration viewed the new North Korean proposal as a serious one deserving of a serious response. While the North doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really expect Washington to cancel the military exercises, one analyst argued, the exercises could be modified in some way to show good will and open room for negotiation. A group of experts, including two former senior American negotiators, plans to hold unofficial talks with some North Koreans in Singapore next week to explore ways to restart negotiations on a nuclear agreement. Recent overtures by South Korea and North Korea to meet bilaterally could offer another path to engagement.'b'North Korea and its nuclear ambitions have long been a tough problem, but the world cannot acquiesce as Pyongyang builds an increasingly capable arsenal. Mr. Obama pledged to reduce nuclear proliferation worldwide, but his policy has failed to curb North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear development. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to understand what America would lose by testing the North\xe2\x80\x99s intentions once again, especially as China may be ready to be a more responsible partner in finding a solution.'b'JERUSALEM \xe2\x80\x94 At the turn of the last century, Nachman Syrkin, a young democratic socialist drawn to the \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical Zionism\xe2\x80\x9d of Theodor Herzl, was a student in Berlin, a member of a discussion group of \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s from the Russian Pale of Settlement. One day, the speaker was a left-wing intellectual eager to prove that an emancipated Europe would be a home to all Jews \xe2\x80\x94 that separatist nationalisms were a mark of obsolete despair. He held up his tattered jacket. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe wool was taken from sheep which were pastured in Angora; it was spun in England, woven in Lodz. The buttons came from Germany; the thread from Austria\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 at which point Syrkin called out, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the rip in the sleeve was no doubt from Kiev!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For Israel\xe2\x80\x99s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, last week\xe2\x80\x99s crimes in Paris were that kind of Zionist d\xc3\xa9j\xc3\xa0 vu, instructive for emancipated citizens and for Jews \xe2\x80\x94 often the same people, yet distinct enough from each other to learn different lessons. The enemy has changed since Syrkin\xe2\x80\x99s time but, for Mr. Netanyahu, apparently, not much else has. The Jewish response must be to self-segregate: affirm, in principle, the liberal values of the West, but deny that they ever worked well enough for diaspora Jews; insist that we fight for our freedoms from our own ground.'b'Who exactly are \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x9d? That question is superfluous, because anti-Semites will let us know. And their hatred, which tracks from the Roman expulsion, has migrated in this generation to \xe2\x80\x9cIslamic radicalism,\xe2\x80\x9d which must be confronted globally, and which, Mr. Netanyahu says, Israel is confronting in the form of Iran and Hamas. Even Yair Lapid, the self-described \xe2\x80\x9ccentrist\xe2\x80\x9d former finance minister who leads the youthful, hip Yesh Atid party, told an audience in Beersheba on the eve of Paris\xe2\x80\x99s unity rally that the need to fight terrorism \xe2\x80\x9cis now reaching the Europeans,\xe2\x80\x9d and that European Jewry \xe2\x80\x9cmust understand that there is just one place for Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Meanwhile, academic experts appear on television here, lamenting what they call France\xe2\x80\x99s great disaster \xe2\x80\x94 its inability, or unwillingness, to invest in 10 percent of its population, Muslim immigrants from its former colonies in North Africa, leaving them alienated and unassimilated. Every Jew needs a rabbi, presumably.'b'Mr. Netanyahu rightly implies, if only intuitively, that the crimes against the satirists at Charlie Hebdo and the Jews at Hyper Cacher were not motivated by quite the same madness. He would have wanted Israel to join.'b'CHICAGO \xe2\x80\x94 Friday marks the 150th anniversary of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman\xe2\x80\x99s famous field order to confiscate 400,000 acres of land from former slave-owners and distribute it to former slaves \xe2\x80\x94 the promise of 40 acres and mule that we so often hear about.'b'In the wake of the Civil War, the United States could have provided a solid foundation for black economic development. But the government failed to follow through with General Sherman\xe2\x80\x99s ambitious land reform initiative; instead his order was repealed by President Andrew Johnson in the fall of 1865 and former slaves were drawn into various forms of peonage, which kept them in economic bondage.'b'Today, 21 years after the end of apartheid, South Africa finds itself at a moment of comparable significance. The country has a land reform program, but its implementation is in many ways undermining instead of promoting black economic development.'b'Due to colonial and apartheid-era land theft, when South Africa held its first democratic election in 1994 whites owned about 87 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s total land, although they constituted just over 10 percent of the population. The post-apartheid state has tried to address past land theft through a multifaceted land reform strategy that includes land restitution \xe2\x80\x94 a program providing compensation to individuals and communities dispossessed of land after 1913 as a result of racially discriminatory laws and practices. Although the South African government has made significant investments in land reform, the ruling African National Congress has made decisions and promoted policies that are calcifying the existing economic order rather than transforming it.'b'In the course of 150 interviews with people who received compensation through the land restitution program, it became clear that the government\xe2\x80\x99s policy is deeply flawed.'b'Of the nearly 80,000 claims filed primarily by blacks, the post-apartheid state has settled about 70 percent by distributing a Standard Settlement Offer, which is symbolic monetary compensation that is unrelated to the current or past market value of the property confiscated. Such compensation was particularly unjust for former owners like the Majolas, a black family that had owned property in Sophiatown \xe2\x80\x94 a once-vibrant, mixed-race community near downtown Johannesburg, which apartheid authorities uprooted to create a white suburb called Triumph. (We have used a pseudonym to protect the family\xe2\x80\x99s privacy.)'b'South Africa\xe2\x80\x99s land restitution authorities did not give the dispossessed residents of Sophiatown the option of receiving land in their former neighborhood or elsewhere. Instead, the state paid them a mere 40,000 rand per claim (approximately $3,500). In the case of the Majola family, the law mandated that each of the six surviving siblings receive about 6,600 rand ($570), since their deceased parents owned the home. As one family member said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a case of take the money and go type of thing.\xe2\x80\x9d Sadly, these small sums were all the Majolas and their former neighbors were offered, despite the fact that several houses in Sophiatown are currently on the market for upwards of 700,000 rand ($60,000), about 20 times the value of the compensation the siblings received.'b'Although the situation is deeply unfair for families like the Majolas, defenders of the current policy argue that the South African government has no viable alternatives because it has a limited budget and it must spend on other costly priorities like education and health. Others believe that this is the price South Africans had to pay to end apartheid without a full-scale civil war and keep the economy intact.'b'The problem is that white South Africans are receiving far more compensation than blacks.'b'When the post-apartheid state wants to put the Majolas and other dispossessed blacks back into their homes, it pays the current owners market-related compensation through voluntary exchange or by exercising eminent domain. This most often involves amounts that are several orders of magnitude higher than a typical settlement offer proposed to dispossessed blacks. For instance, this month a white farmer was paid nearly 1.5 million rand ($130,000) for 165 hectares in the northern Mpumalanga region. It is patently unfair for current owners (who are mostly white) to systematically receive higher compensation than owners dispossessed by prior governments (who are mostly black).'b'Furthermore, when the government allows current owners to keep their property, they receive a significant additional benefit. The modest payment given to families like the Majolas negates any outstanding claims to their former properties \xe2\x80\x94 effectively sanitizing the property rights of current owners by removing the stench of past land theft, but without properly compensating blacks.'b'Given the state of public opinion, this inequity could have devastating consequences for South Africa\xe2\x80\x99s future. Professor James Gibson of Washington University, St. Louis, surveyed 3,700 South Africans and found that two of every three blacks agreed with the statement: \xe2\x80\x9cLand must be returned to blacks in South Africa, no matter what the consequences are for the current owners and for political stability in the country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'South Africa may have avoided civil war during the transition to democracy two decades ago, but that does not mean the country\xe2\x80\x99s impoverished majority is content with their lot or that the risk of instability has disappeared.'b'The United States failed to institute meaningful land reform when it had the opportunity 150 years ago, and today we are living with the consequences in the form of persistent racial inequalities.'b'South Africa must not make the same mistake. The country began its second round of land restitution in June 2014; this time the government must get it right.'b'TEL AVIV \xe2\x80\x94 There is great irony to Israel\xe2\x80\x99s instinctive response to terror attacks on Jews in Europe \xe2\x80\x94 and the devastating attack last week on a kosher grocery store in Paris was no different.'b'Pack your belongings! Regrettably, some politicians are proposing the kind of Internet censorship and surveillance that would do little to protect their citizens but do a lot to infringe on civil liberties.'b'In Paris, a dozen interior ministers from European Union countries including France, Britain and Germany 'b'issued a statement'b' earlier this week calling on Internet service providers to identify and take down online content \xe2\x80\x9cthat aims to incite hatred and terror.\xe2\x80\x9d The ministers also want the European Union to start monitoring and storing information about the itineraries of air travelers. And this week, French officials said they had 'b'arrested 54 people'b' for hate speech, including a controversial comedian.'b'Appealing as these measures may sound in the aftermath of a tragedy, they are deeply flawed. Countries like France and Germany have long had stricter controls on speech than the United States. For example, their governments have in the past forced Internet firms like 'b'Yahoo'b' and 'b'Twitter'b' to take down Nazi propaganda. But those decisions are generally made by government officials or judges, not technology companies.'b'Internet service providers do not have the staff or the skill to determine what content is likely to lead to terrorist attacks. That is why a blanket mandate to censor terrorism-related information could force these businesses to err on the side of caution and take down information that might be offensive but would not lead to an imminent attack. In fact, an Internet service provider might well have taken down satirical cartoons of the kind Charlie Hebdo published.'b'Besides, even if Internet companies blocked videos and other propaganda produced by terrorist groups from their networks, that action would not necessarily prevent Europeans from finding that information. In the movie, which closely reflects the true story, the students enter the nation\xe2\x80\x99s pre-eminent robotics competition, an event sponsored by NASA and the Navy. They win widespread recognition for their accomplishments and, when the movie ends in 2004, their future is bright.'b'Unfortunately, that\xe2\x80\x99s not how the story really ends.'b'All four students were born in Mexico and were brought across the border illegally as children. Though they grew up in Arizona and viewed themselves as Americans, the law did not. They lived with the daily threat of deportation. Oscar Vazquez dreamed of joining the Army \xe2\x80\x94 he was officer of the year in his J.R.O.T.C. program \xe2\x80\x94 but discovered he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t enlist because he didn\xe2\x80\x99t have legal residency. Cristian Arcega was a geeky brainiac who found few outlets for his smarts in gang-torn West Phoenix. Lorenzo Santillan was a former gang member himself looking to stay clean. And Luis Aranda, the only one who had gotten a work permit, just the year before, was a hulking giant of a kid who rarely spoke.'b'This ragtag group from Carl Hayden Community High School in West Phoenix constructed the robot out of cheap plastic tubing and garbage. It smelled so bad, they called the machine Stinky. The other entrants \xe2\x80\x94 almost all college students \xe2\x80\x94 had corporate sponsors and serious budgets. This was an underwater robotics contest, but Carl Hayden didn\xe2\x80\x99t even have a swimming pool. Nonetheless, Stinky came in first place.'b'After the event, lower ranked contestants went on to rewarding jobs at tech companies and research institutes. Meanwhile, the Carl Hayden students struggled to afford tuition for college.'b'Lorenzo Santillan considered becoming a mechanical engineer, but instead earned a cheaper associate degree in cooking. Today he works as a line cook. Luis Aranda studied cooking as well but did not complete a degree and now works as a janitor.'b'Cristian Arcega, the most technically skilled member of the team, made it to Arizona State University on a scholarship. But in 2006, during his freshman year, Arizona voters passed Proposition 300, an anti-immigrant measure that prohibits undocumented students from receiving any state financial aid or qualifying for in-state tuition \xe2\x80\x94 more than tripling his tuition. He dropped out and is now unemployed. He is trying to 'b'crowdfund'b' enough money to return to school full time.'b'Oscar Vazquez\xe2\x80\x99s story is the most dramatic. He also had a scholarship to A.S.U., and after working menial jobs for a year, was able to attend. He was a sophomore when Proposition 300 passed, and managed to stay in school only by piecing together more scholarships, all while leading the university\xe2\x80\x99s robotics team to regional championships. He graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering in 2009 and applied for legal residency.'b'Not only was his application denied, but he was also summarily banned from the United States for 10 years for living here without a visa. He ended up working on an assembly line in Mexico.'b'After a year, his ban was reversed when Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, interceded on his behalf. Mr. Vazquez returned, enlisted in the Army, and served a tour of combat duty in Afghanistan. He is finally a citizen, and repairs trains in Montana for the railroad company BNSF.'b'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the program created by President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s executive order that shields some undocumented students and young adults from deportation, didn\xe2\x80\x99t go into effect until 2012. Had it been in place when the Carl Hayden students were in high school, allowing them to legally work, their lives might have turned out very differently. They have surmounted enormous odds, but none were able to professionally pursue their passion for robotics. It is a startling rebuke to the American dream.'b'House Republicans seem to view this as a fitting outcome. This week, John A. Boehner, the speaker of the House, 'b'introduced legislation'b' that would roll back the president\xe2\x80\x99s order. If he is successful, talented young people like Mr. Santillan and Mr. Arcega could be deported at any moment. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter a while you get used to disappointment,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Arcega said to me this week. \xe2\x80\x9cI try not to have high expectations anymore.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Those who oppose granting residency to these immigrants argue that it would deny resources to existing residents and citizens. But we\xe2\x80\x99ve already invested in these students all through elementary and high school. Why not continue and get a return on that investment?'b'There is rising demand for the talent these students possess. We grant roughly 85,000 H1B visas, for immigrants with special skills, to engineers to fill jobs here. In doing so, we overlook a generation of students who are deemed foreigners but who grew up here and plan to stay. When their visas expire, a majority of H1B visa holders will leave, and take the skills they developed with them. At a time when science and technology prowess will be critical to this country\xe2\x80\x99s growth, we can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to squander the homegrown brainpower of students like Oscar, Lorenzo, Luis and Cristian.'b'Last Sunday, as lovers of free speech filled the streets of Paris, lovers of elegant English period soap opera were watching \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey\xe2\x80\x9d in America. The episode featured a frisky Lady Mary, in 1924, asking her maid to purchase a contraceptive device for her in advance of a hookup with Lord Gillingham. She pointed to a section in a book, likely one of the pioneering sex manuals of the British botanist Marie Stopes, for guidance.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMarried Love,\xe2\x80\x9d first published by Dr. Stopes in 1918, was banned as obscene in the United States until 1931. But they are with us still. The orthodox newspaper in Israel, HaMevaser, scrubbed women from the photo of the Paris unity rally \xe2\x80\x94 gone, erased, so as not to offend.'b'And in our own country, which once criminalized the poems of Allen Ginsberg, the novels of Henry Miller and the sensible sex advice of Dr. Stopes, Mike Huckabee has attacked the Obamas\xe2\x80\x99 parenting because they allow their children to listen to Beyonc\xc3\xa9. The singer\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics are \xe2\x80\x9ctoxic mental poison,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. This is very curious, even for Huckabee, who has made millions promoting himself as a victimized rube. Huckabee has performed, with Ted Nugent, the song \xe2\x80\x9cCat Scratch Fever.\xe2\x80\x9d In his world, it\xe2\x80\x99s O.K. for a middle-aged man to crow about pubescent promiscuity, but not a young woman.'b'Sex is at the root of most free speech fights. Whatever it is that incites lust, it also incites the censorious. Religion is not far behind. You could argue that the two are twined, and it would be hard to rebut. The simple genius of the First Amendment ties free speech to protection from a state religion \xe2\x80\x94 in the same sentence. There could be no real free expression, the American founders recognized, in a nation with a state-sanctioned religion.'b'This freedom, by its very definition, sets up a serious conflict in the interconnected global village. Protected speech in this country is blasphemous in another. Satire, in the form of silly Seth Rogen movie, is a provocation prompting a 'b'cyberwar'b' in the closed society of North Korea.'b'China, rapidly trying to catch up with Western democracies in all things monetary and technological, is medieval in the realm of free expression. It\xe2\x80\x99s an evolving construct, to be sure, and may never find favor in the majority of the world\xe2\x80\x99s countries.'b'It still has trouble finding favor in our country. How about handing in our phones before entering a theater?'b'MICHELLE VACCHIO'b'\nInwood, N.Y., Jan. 15, 2015'b''b'Ah, Switzerland, famed for cuckoo clocks and sound money. Other nations may experiment with radical economic policies, but with the Swiss you don\xe2\x80\x99t get surprises.'b'Until you do. On Thursday the Swiss National Bank, the equivalent of the Federal Reserve, 'b'shocked the financial world'b' with a double whammy, simultaneously abandoning its policy of pegging the Swiss franc to the euro and cutting the interest rate it pays on bank reserves to minus, that\xe2\x80\x99s right, minus 0.75 percent. Market turmoil ensued.'b'And you should feel a shiver of fear, even if you don\xe2\x80\x99t have any direct financial stake in the value of the franc. For Switzerland\xe2\x80\x99s monetary travails illustrate in miniature just how hard it is to fight the deflationary vortex now dragging down much of the world economy.'b'What you need to understand is that all the usual rules of economic policy changed when financial crisis struck in 2008; we entered a looking-glass world, and we still haven\xe2\x80\x99t emerged. In many cases, economic virtues became vices: Willingness to save became a drag on investment, fiscal probity a route to stagnation. And in the case of the Swiss, having a reputation for safe banks and sound money became a major liability.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s how it worked: When Greece entered its debt crisis at the end of 2009, and other European nations found themselves under severe stress, money seeking a safe haven began pouring into Switzerland. This in turn sent the 'b'Swiss franc soaring'b', with devastating effects on the competitiveness of Swiss manufacturing, and threatened to push Switzerland \xe2\x80\x94 which already had very low inflation and very low interest rates \xe2\x80\x94 into Japanese-style deflation.'b'So Swiss monetary officials went all out in an effort to weaken their currency. You might think that making your currency worth less is easy \xe2\x80\x94 can\xe2\x80\x99t you just print more bills? \xe2\x80\x94 but in the post-crisis world it\xe2\x80\x99s not easy at all. Just printing money and stuffing it into the banks does nothing; it just sits there. The Swiss tried a more direct approach, selling francs and buying euros on the foreign exchange market, in the process acquiring a huge hoard of euros. But even that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t doing the trick.'b'Then, in 2011, the Swiss National Bank tried a psychological tactic. \xe2\x80\x9cThe current massive overvaluation of the Swiss franc,\xe2\x80\x9d it declared, \xe2\x80\x9cposes an acute threat to the Swiss economy and carries the 'b'risk of a deflationary development'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d And it therefore announced that it would set a minimum value for the euro \xe2\x80\x94 1.2 Swiss francs \xe2\x80\x94 and that to enforce this minimum it was \xe2\x80\x9cprepared to buy foreign currency in unlimited quantities.\xe2\x80\x9d What the bank clearly hoped was that by drawing this line in the sand it would limit the number of euros it actually had to buy.'b'And for three years it worked. But on Thursday the Swiss suddenly gave up. We don\xe2\x80\x99t know exactly why; nobody I know believes the official explanation, that it\xe2\x80\x99s a response to a weakening euro. But it seems likely that a fresh wave of safe-haven money was making the effort to keep the franc down too expensive.'b'If you ask me, the Swiss just made a big mistake. But frankly \xe2\x80\x94 francly? \xe2\x80\x94 the fate of Switzerland isn\xe2\x80\x99t the important issue. What\xe2\x80\x99s important, instead, is the demonstration of just how hard it is to fight the deflationary forces that are now afflicting much of the world \xe2\x80\x94 not just Europe and Japan, but 'b'quite possibly China too'b'. And while America has had a pretty good run the past few quarters, it would be foolish to assume that we\xe2\x80\x99re immune.'b'What this says is that you really, really shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let yourself get too close to deflation \xe2\x80\x94 you might fall in, and then it\xe2\x80\x99s extremely hard to get out. This is one reason that slashing government spending in a depressed economy is such a bad idea: It\xe2\x80\x99s not just the immediate cost in lost jobs, but the increased risk of getting caught in a deflationary trap.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also a reason to be very cautious about raising interest rates when you have low inflation, even if you don\xe2\x80\x99t think deflation is imminent. But why? There\xe2\x80\x99s no sign of accelerating inflation in the actual data, and 'b'market indicators of expected inflation'b' are plunging, suggesting that investors see deflationary risk even if the Fed doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'And I share that market concern. If the U.S. recovery weakens, either through contagion from troubles abroad or because our own fundamentals aren\xe2\x80\x99t as strong as we think, tightening monetary policy could all too easily prove to be an act of utter folly.'b'So let\xe2\x80\x99s learn from the Swiss. DANIELS'b'\nNew York, Jan. 12, 2015'b''b'In recent weeks, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly noted his concern about the unhealthy tensions in New York City between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio. He also sees an alluring political vacuum tempting him to step forward as an impartial healer and arbitrator. \xe2\x80\x9cI think everybody in New York City knows that this situation is unsustainable,\xe2\x80\x9d he said on Wednesday morning.'b'There is indeed a useful role here for Mr. Cuomo. He could help a great deal if he acts as a partner instead.'b'Mr. Cuomo has already offered a few useful ideas. During a recent preview of his annual budget presentation and State of the State address next week, he hinted at possible reforms of the grand jury system, following a Staten Island grand jury\xe2\x80\x99s failure to indict a police officer in the death of an unarmed civilian, Eric Garner. He also spoke of the need to better protect police officers in the line of duty.'b'There are other concrete measures he can take to help:'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 He should resist efforts by the police unions to undermine parts of a crucial pension reform 'b'approved in 2012'b'. With pension rates for state and local government employees rising rapidly, Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s pension package that year was designed to cut rates statewide for future employees by $80 billion over 30 years. It increased the retirement age for most employees, reduced pension padding and raised pension contribution rates, among other changes.'b'The unions were furious, New York City police officials particularly so because newer employees who became disabled on the job would get only half of their salary as one part of their pension, not the usual 75 percent.'b'Now the unions are using their unhappiness with Mr. de Blasio to curry favor with Mr. Cuomo, and to persuade him to reopen the pension law and increase disability pensions for newer employees. This would not only undermine the 2012 reforms but would wind up costing the city about $6 billion over 30 years for all uniformed employees. Mr. Cuomo, who once called the reforms \xe2\x80\x9cbold and transformational,\xe2\x80\x9d should not retreat now. Local prosecutors have an inherent conflict of interest because they work so closely with the police. There should be another option in cases where the police are involved.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 He should veto a 'b'sneaky little bill'b' that passed without notice last year and would vastly undermine the authority of the city\xe2\x80\x99s police commissioner in disciplinary matters. Instead of allowing the commissioner to mete out proper punishment to wayward officers, it would leave the choices to collective bargaining, giving the police union far too much control over important personnel decisions.'b'Mr. Cuomo has lamented that recent shootings and protests have left people \xe2\x80\x9cconfused, disappointed and angry\xe2\x80\x9d about the justice system. He has the power to help heal those wounds if he treads very carefully.'b'This past fall, a project started called ('b'Human) Wasteland'b', which maps reports of human waste throughout the city of San Francisco. Yes, a disproportionate amount of poop on the streets is not from dogs but from humans.'b'Some in the blogosphere tended to play this for laughs, but the reality isn\xe2\x80\x99t very funny. There are thousands of homeless people in San Francisco and scant access to public bathrooms. We associate sanitation problems with the Third World, not the First, but the fact is that even in a city like this one, bursting from all its economic growth, more than 7,000 people are homeless and without places to sleep \xe2\x80\x94 or go to the bathroom.'b'Perhaps more than any other city, San Francisco loves process and, accordingly, a consortium of groups led by 'b'Hyphae Design Lab'b' published a comprehensive \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Public Toilet Project Masterplan'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to design and deploy better public restrooms in the city. Design can\xe2\x80\x99t solve homelessness, but a number of interesting projects like this one have emerged that offer thoughtful \xe2\x80\x94 albeit incremental \xe2\x80\x94 solutions to the problems that arise from it.'b'The Tenderloin Public Toilet Project (better known as the PPlanter), created by Hyphae Design Laboratory through a participatory design process, is one. It\xe2\x80\x99s a cheap and mobile street urinal with sink that doubles as a planter and was built for $2,000. (As an added bonus in this drought-plagued state, the urine collected, after being filtered, is used to water the plants.) PPlanter underwent a test phase in 2103 and a second version is currently set up at a truck stop and a community outreach center in West Oakland.'b'The goal is still to provide this Tenderloin project as a free service, but as Hyphae\xe2\x80\x99s Brent Bucknum explains, long-term maintenance continues to be the major hurdle in funding new models of urban sanitation.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEither we need cities and economic development agencies to earmark money for public services, once again, or we need more of a \xe2\x80\x98pay-as-you-go model,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cA secondary social benefit of this model would be that the project would provide a more socially universal solution for tourists, workers \xe2\x80\x94 and everyone else. This is just another thought, in a still very uncharted interesting new arena for urban infrastructure.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Virginia Gardiner began her research on a waterless toilet system that turns human waste into a source of clean energy when she was a graduate student in industrial design. Today, she\xe2\x80\x99s CEO of Loowatt, a London-based company that produces context-specific toilets that use a patented sealing mechanism to wrap human waste in biodegradable polymer film. The film, which lines the toilet bowl, is pulled through the mechanism when the toilet is \xe2\x80\x9cflushed,\xe2\x80\x9d enclosing the waste in a removable cartridge. The cartridge is then emptied, daily to weekly depending upon factors like location and usage patterns, into an anaerobic digester, where the waste and polymer film are converted into natural gas and fertilizer.'b'The innovations here lie in the waterless toilet that provides a hygienic and odorless experience and the value-generating treatment solution that supports the toilet. Loowatt toilets can be built in many shapes and sizes, to work in a variety of different scenarios.'b'Currently, the technology is used to serve highly disparate communities: A pilot program in Madagascar features home toilets that are linked to an energy-generating digester in the community. In London, a modified version is deployed at events and festivals in locations where water or power is in short supply. \xe2\x80\x9cThis started out as just the idea to make a value-generating waterless toilet, and to challenge the \xe2\x80\x98flush and forget\xe2\x80\x99 norm that I grew up taking for granted,\xe2\x80\x9d says Gardiner. \xe2\x80\x9cLater I became aware of the many practical applications.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Back in San Francisco, 'b'LavaMae'b' (a play on \xe2\x80\x9cwash me\xe2\x80\x9d in Spanish) expands the program to include showers, because there are only eight shelter facilities in San Francisco that offer public showers. LavaMae uses a repurposed city bus outfitted with two shower-and-toilet modules to \xe2\x80\x9cdeliver dignity, one shower at a time.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Painted bright blue, the bus announces it presence boldly \xe2\x80\x94 LavaMae\xe2\x80\x99s founder envisions a future version featuring LED screens with programmed messages about homelessness to help break down stereotypes around it \xe2\x80\x94 as it parks in two different locations for several hours at a time, three times a week, to serve San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s homeless population (including the neighborhoods that rank highest on the aforementioned waste map). In 2015, LavaMae is ramping up from one bus to four \xe2\x80\x94 and it needs to.'b'The idea for LavaMae was born from the frustration of a public relations executive, Doniece Sondaval, who witnessed the rapid gentrification of her neighborhood \xe2\x80\x94 and the displacement of neighbors that has come with it. To pull off this modestly scaled but expanding endeavor, she has assembled an eclectic group of public and private sector partners, from Google to Kohler to the San Francisco Department of Public Health, to provide a basic service. Its implementation \xe2\x80\x94 requiring everything from access to fire hydrants to the obtaining of street parking permits \xe2\x80\x94 has been arduous, but that bus, once destined for the scrap heap, now assists in deterring potential public health problems and, perhaps most critically, in helping a population struggling to retain its dignity.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe call them guests,\xe2\x80\x9d says Sandoval when talking about the thousands of people who\xe2\x80\x99ve used the service in its first six months. \xe2\x80\x9cWe realize that we\xe2\x80\x99re in the hospitality business. We\xe2\x80\x99re not doing case management; we\xe2\x80\x99re trying to get these folks cleaned up, trying to help eliminate the obstacles if they\xe2\x80\x99re applying for jobs or we\xe2\x80\x99ve found that they have jobs and they\xe2\x80\x99re just trying to stay clean. We want them to feel like we\xe2\x80\x99ve created something just for them, that when they\xe2\x80\x99re here we care about them and that we see them as people. We see a lot of regulars so we know their names, know their stories. It\xe2\x80\x99s had an impact we didn\xe2\x80\x99t anticipate having.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sandoval\xe2\x80\x99s background in P.R. and marketing shows in all the good ways on this project: LavaMae takes its visual cues from design-savvy brands like Method Cleaner and Virgin America (if only all the city\xe2\x80\x99s buses looked so good), was initially financed by a crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo, and has a temporary existence in line with the current vogue for tactical urbanism. Sandoval and Lava Mae\xe2\x80\x99s designer, the architect 'b'Brett Terpeluk'b', wanted to create a beautiful design for a population that always gets castoffs. A mobile shower facility doesn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9csolve\xe2\x80\x9d homelessness, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a proactive response to a dire need.'b"Sandoval harbors no fantasies about LavaMae as a permanent solution. For her, the shower facilities are an end goal. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be a permanent fixture,\xe2\x80\x9d she says. \xe2\x80\x9cI think this should be a government responsibility. I want the government to say, \xe2\x80\x98a private citizen has stepped forward to show us the desire and need for this, so let\xe2\x80\x99s go for it.'\xe2\x80\x9d"b'Indeed, while the ingenuity of these efforts is indisputable, what it all means for the future of services once squarely in the domain of government is more complicated. With everything from parks to health care to transportation, the respective roles of the private and public sectors are evolving \xe2\x80\x94 and are more and more complex. Are we to view the convenience and increasing ubiquity of Uber as a replacement for public transit? (Some do.) A for-profit endeavor like 'b'HandUp'b' crowdsources funding for homeless individuals (the donor selects the person he or she wants to help), but should we see it as a replacement for city services? What does this sort of targeted solutionism mean for civic responsibility? For the social contract?'b'The question of whether the right funding models exist for social impact projects like these remains. PPlanter had highly successful test runs last year employing homeless residents to do maintenance, for example. This provided a compelling way to monitor both the social and technical aspects of the project but establishing the structures to employ the homeless through government models has been challenging, Bucknum says: \xe2\x80\x9cDespite this amazing social infrastructure prototype, we have not found funding outside of initial government grants for construction, from the private sector.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Our country is confronting so many issues that feel intractable, from homelessness to inequality, climate change to immigration. It\xe2\x80\x99s normal to feel overwhelmed, even hopeless, and then to respond with apathy, despair or inaction. Small-scale projects like PPlanter, Loowatt and LavaMae should be embraced \xe2\x80\x94 but as part of a more systemic approach. No single intervention, whether it comes from economists, architects or scientists, is enough. But a bunch of good ones can help show the way.'b'The last time Greeks faced a general election, two and a half years ago, the eurozone faced an existential crisis. There were rumors of bank runs in Athens, of pre-emptive Iberian exits from the monetary union, even of Germans unilaterally calling it quits. Greeks are now returning to the polls on Jan. 25 to face choices similar to those in 2012.'b'One beleaguered option is to \xe2\x80\x9cstay the course\xe2\x80\x9d of their international bailout arrangements and the harsh adjustments they impose. This is the position argued by Prime Minister 'b'Antonis Samaras'b'. The alternative is \xe2\x80\x9canything else\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a cacophonous policy mix proposed by the main opposition party, Syriza. Depending on whom you ask, this includes a unilateral moratorium on foreign debt and the rollback of the structural reforms that have helped restore international competitiveness and fiscal sustainability.'b'Yet something crucial that has been ignored by most media has changed since 2012. These elections are not about how to manage the economic debacle, but rather about how to steer an incipient recovery. The Greek economy has been growing since the first quarter of last year, according to Eurostat. In the third quarter, the country\xe2\x80\x99s growth was higher than that of any other eurozone member, including Germany. This is not just a rebound: Unemployment has been declining and now stands roughly where it was before the worst point of the crisis two years ago. All this suggests that reforms are belatedly but surely yielding results.'b'Yet with elections just one week away, political risk is back in vogue. Over the last two months, as elections became certain, markets fretted. From the investors\xe2\x80\x99 point of view, the main risk is that the Greeks will opt for a Syriza government, ushering a confrontation with the country\xe2\x80\x99s lenders and a shaky macroeconomic policy plan based on nationalization, forced wage inflation and unaffordable subsidies. Given where polls stand, a Syriza government with some moderating coalition force is the most likely outcome.'b'Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s leader, 'b'Alexis Tsipras'b', has worked to soften his party\xe2\x80\x99s image since the last elections. A few months ago he could be found at the Ambrosetti Forum on the shores of Lake Como, preaching the values of European integration and the importance of the euro. He has surrounded himself with economists who profess a willingness to come to a \xe2\x80\x9cnegotiated solution\xe2\x80\x9d with the country\xe2\x80\x99s creditors and who frequently clash with the party rank-and-file who favor unilateral default and \xe2\x80\x9cGrexit.\xe2\x80\x9d Ultimately, however, there is no way around it: The party\xe2\x80\x99s ideology is hostile to the market economy and the reforms 'b'Greece'b' has been implementing.'b'The clearest indication of what Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s policy plan would mean came from Tsipras himself. In September 2012, he stated in the Greek Parliament that he wished the country \xe2\x80\x9chad become 'b'Argentina'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Back in 2011 economists such as Nouriel Roubini and Paul Krugman also used Argentina as an example to follow. Even last weekend, in the midst of the campaign, Prime Minister Samaras addressed Argentina and its 2001 debt crisis. So what does it mean to \xe2\x80\x9cturn into Argentina?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The last decade of Argentine economic history offers two valuable lessons for Greece. The first is that Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s threat of a debt moratorium is an empty one: Debts do not go away just because one chooses not to pay them. Witness Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s decade-long legal saga in New York courts. The country\xe2\x80\x99s refusal to pay holdouts of its debt restructuring in 2005 has not ushered in prosperity; it has brought a prolonged legal battle, isolation from world markets, and as of last summer, a second default. There is no reason to believe a unilateral Greek refusal to pay would yield different results.'b'What is more, Greece\xe2\x80\x99s eurozone partners have already said they would consider negotiating on debt relief \xe2\x80\x94 provided Greece sticks to its commitments and negotiates in earnest within the framework of the eurozone. And unlike in 2010, the monetary union now possesses the processes and institutions to deal with fiscal and macroeconomic imbalances in an orderly manner, rather than the ad hoc fashion \xe2\x80\x94 to put it mildly \xe2\x80\x94 advocated by Syriza.'b'The second lesson is perhaps more crucial: Economic populism and monetary wizardry are short-sighted. They do not yield development, only isolation and imbalances. In the case of Argentina, after a decade of extremely heterodox policy, citizens have to contend with stagflation \xe2\x80\x94 meaning negative growth and around 40 percent of annual inflation \xe2\x80\x94 capital controls, anachronistic foreign currency controls, and increasingly authoritarian economic management by a government eager to micromanage the behavior of private companies. This is why a country as energy-rich as Argentina finds itself importing natural gas at exorbitant prices just to keep the lights on.'b'No development can be built that way. It is hard to believe that Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s talk of \xe2\x80\x9cfree electricity\xe2\x80\x9d and a renationalization of the energy market would lead to a better outcome. It should therefore come as no surprise that when Argentines head to their own polls later this year, they will elect a government eager to undo these policies and reintegrate the country into the world.'b'The Greek dilemma is different from Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s in yet another way. Its debt negotiations are not with private holdouts from an imperfect restructuring. They are with fellow eurozone countries, some of which are poorer than Greece, and pay higher interest rates to finance Greek loans. The moral dimension of defaulting on the Slovakian taxpayer \xe2\x80\x94 who has to make do with a much lower minimum wage than his Greek counterpart \xe2\x80\x94 is at least as dishonest as the economic rationale behind Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s plans. The only alternative here is a negotiated way respecting both the existing agreements and European solidarity, a value that may not be financial but is at the cornerstone of the support Greece got at its time of most need.'b'Mr. Tsipras is right about one thing: Argentina offers apt economic parallels for the Greek electorate. But it is an example to avoid, not to follow. Debt default and unilateral withdrawal from the globalized world would not lead Greece to a renaissance. It would lead the country back to ruin. After years of recession and reforms, it would be a sad sight for Greece to follow Argentina, precisely when the former is recovering and the latter is finally about to turn its back on shortsighted populism.'b'TOKYO \xe2\x80\x94  Bolstered by his party\xe2\x80\x99s victory in Diet elections last month, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has renewed his vow to free 'b'Japan'b' from the fetters of the past, especially its defeat in 'b'World War II'b'. Mr. Abe and his supporters view the prevailing accounts of that era as \xe2\x80\x9cmasochistic\xe2\x80\x9d and a hindrance to taking pride in what he calls the \xe2\x80\x9cnew Japan.\xe2\x80\x9d They propose to modify the article in Japan\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution that states the Japanese people \xe2\x80\x9cforever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These aspirations have been laid out in a map of Japan that the Japanese Foreign Ministry published on its website last April, with translations in 12 languages. The map extends beyond Japan\xe2\x80\x99s internationally recognized boundaries, incorporating in the name of ryodo \xe2\x80\x94 or the \xe2\x80\x9cinherent territory\xe2\x80\x9d of Japan \xe2\x80\x94 many islands claimed by neighboring countries. Those lands,  the argument goes, are integral to  Japan\xe2\x80\x99s very being.'b'In fact, the Abe government\xe2\x80\x99s expansionist view undermines Japan\xe2\x80\x99s interests, both economic and strategic.'b'Ryodo promotes a notion of Japan\xe2\x80\x99s territory that circumvents history, particularly the history of how Japan laid claim to these islands in the first place \xe2\x80\x94 through imperial wars with 'b'China'b' and 'b'Russia'b', through wars of conquest against Koreans, through the extermination or assimilation of indigenous peoples.'b'Partly as a result, Japan is embroiled in many territorial disputes. China and 'b'Taiwan'b' contest the Senkaku Islands, which Beijing calls the Diaoyu and Taipei the Diaoyutai. South Korea claims Takeshima (calling it Dokdo) where it has stationed military police since 1954. Russia claims sovereignty over what Japanese know as the Northern Territories, four islands in the Kuril chain northeast of Hokkaido where Russians have lived since 1945, numbering about 20,000 today.'b'Under the terms of the United Nations Convention on the 'b'Law of the Sea'b' (UNCLOS), Japan already has access to vast fisheries and rides up to $3.6 trillion in seabed materials. The disputed islands would add much more.'b'According to some estimates, including by the U.S. Energy Information Administration, the East China Sea holds 200 million barrels in proved and probable 'b'oil'b' reserves (the world consumes around 90 million barrels of liquid fuels each day) and between 1 and 2 trillion cubic feet of natural gas (the United States consumed about 26 trillion cubic feet in 2013). Japan and China contest nearly 17 percent of the area.'b'A volcano on one of the southern Kurils has rhenium, a rare-earth metal with a melting point that makes jet-engine designers dream. There are also vast quantities of untapped methane hydrate in the seabed between Japan and the Korean Peninsula. After gas was extracted from similar deposits elsewhere for the first time in 2013, a spokesman for the Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation said, \xe2\x80\x9cJapan could finally have an energy source to call its own.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The lure of such riches might seem like reason enough for resource-poor Japan to claim these territories. The government spent $250 billion on imported fuel in 2012. And the cost of decommissioning the nuclear reactors at Fukushima after the meltdown following the March 2011 tsunami is expected to reach at least $90 billion.'b'Yet Japan risks losing access to many of these resources because of its brinksmanship. UNCLOS does not determine sovereignty over land, and it allows for joint development agreements in waters around contested territory. When disputes heat up, however, they naturally tend to scuttle any joint schemes.'b'In 2008 China and Japan agreed to explore together four gas fields in the East China Sea. But the project was scuttled the following year, after China went at it alone. Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s maximalist policy only undermines the prospects that this development project could be revived, or that new ones involving Japan might be struck.'b'The costs of Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s territorial revisionism are also strategic. Ryodo implicitly dismisses as partial the terms of the 1951 San Francisco Peace Treaty, which formally ended World War II between Japan and the Allies. The agreement redrew Japan from the massive empire it had become during the war \xe2\x80\x94 stretching from northern China to Guadalcanal \xe2\x80\x94 more or less into the country familiar today. (Some islands, notably Okinawa, reverted to Japan in the intervening years.) Many Japanese at the time, including Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi \xe2\x80\x94 who was accused of being a Class A war criminal \xe2\x80\x94 were infuriated, claiming in particular that the Kurils were \xe2\x80\x9cessential\xe2\x80\x9d to the Japanese.'b'In a separate agreement that went into force at the same time, the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty of 1951, the United States would \xe2\x80\x9cmaintain armed forces of its own in and about Japan\xe2\x80\x9d in order \xe2\x80\x9cto deter armed attack upon Japan.\xe2\x80\x9d By the time the treaty was revised in 1960, Japan had acquired limited self-defense forces, and the two countries undertook various commitments in case of \xe2\x80\x9can armed attack against either Party in the territories under the administration of Japan.\xe2\x80\x9d These still stand today, hence the critical importance also for the U.S. government of properly defining what Japan is.'b'Officials in Washington and Tokyo are currently reviewing each side\xe2\x80\x99s responsibilities in the event of a threat to the peace and security of Japan. In other words, the very notion of ryodo challenges the United States\xe2\x80\x99 postwar security commitments even as it risks triggering them.'b'Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s revanchist view of the past is central to his vision of a future in which Japan \xe2\x80\x9conce again shines on the world\xe2\x80\x99s center stage.\xe2\x80\x9d But it distorts history in  a way that undermines the country\xe2\x80\x99s major interests and, arguably, its identity. The constitutional changes advocated by Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s party include an \xe2\x80\x9cobligation\xe2\x80\x9d for citizens of Japan to \xe2\x80\x9cdefend the nation\xe2\x80\x99s inherent territory, inherent seas and inherent skies,\xe2\x80\x9d disputed islands and all. In his bid to claim more for Japan, Mr. Abe may reap less.'b''b'\n'b'Alexis Dudden 'b'is a professor of history at the University of Connecticut.'b''b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94  On Tuesday, the French police arrested the controversial French comedian Dieudonn\xc3\xa9 M\xe2\x80\x99bala M\xe2\x80\x99bala. On one hand, the republic prides itself as the nation of Voltaire, with a tradition of trenchant social satire \xe2\x80\x94 to which Charlie Hebdo clearly saw itself as heir. On the other hand, France has restrictive privacy laws, some of the toughest hate speech laws in the European Union and a ban on Holocaust denial. This combination of Voltairean bravado and restrictive measures has created a deeply contradictory attitude toward free speech.'b'The Roman Catholic Church was a favorite target for French satirists, but its power and influence have long since declined. French anticlericalism has found instead a new object: Islam. But Islam plays a complex role in French society. At the same time, politicians and pundits often present Islam as a threat to French values and identity and insist on labeling the whole North African population as Muslim. This creates a perception of North African communities as not really being part of the French nation, and justifies discrimination against them.'b'At the same time, a consciousness of the sordid history of French anti-Semitism \xe2\x80\x94 from the Dreyfus affair to the Vichy regime \xe2\x80\x94 means that writers and cartoonists are far less willing to cross the line when it comes to making jokes about Jews or Judaism than they are about Muslims or Islam.'b'It is not difficult to understand why many, particularly within North African communities, see in this a case of unequal treatment \xe2\x80\x94 of certain communities having special protections, while others have to put up with hatred and offense.
