Their failure to complete higher education isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a function of 'b'financial hardships'b' and related stresses,\xc2\xa0though those are primary reasons. Academic\xc2\xa0readiness factors in.'b'Jon Schnur, the executive chairman of America Achieves, said that there\xe2\x80\x99s a significant difference in graduation rates between students who need remediation after they\xe2\x80\x99ve enrolled and those who don\xe2\x80\x99t. The failures of elementary, middle and secondary schools shadow them.'b'Those failures persist, and they\xe2\x80\x99re demonstrated every three years when PISA tests \xe2\x80\x94 which compare 15-year-olds in countries around the world \xe2\x80\x94 are done. American kids tend to perform in the middle of the heap.'b'The America Achieves report, looking at PISA results from 2003 to 2012, which is when the tests were last administered, had a bit of good news. While American kids from middle-class families haven\xe2\x80\x99t markedly improved their international standing in math and science over recent years, kids from poorer families have done precisely that.'b'Poverty may well make educational advancement much harder, but doesn\xe2\x80\x99t prohibit it. If we take the right steps \xe2\x80\x94 including more aggressive recruitment and rewarding of exemplary teachers and the continued implementation of higher standards \xe2\x80\x94 we can help kids at every rung of the economic ladder.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll of these need to be backed by funding,\xe2\x80\x9d Schnur, who has advised the Obama administration on education, told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are great examples of what works, such as quality preschool and early learning for low-income children.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the State of the Union both last year and the year before it, President Obama called for universal preschool (to no avail). Some studies have shown that disadvantaged children start falling behind even before that point.'b'The moral is this: Education is a continuous concern and must be a continuous investment, cradle to Ivory Tower. If we don\xe2\x80\x99t recognize and act on that, our reality will never meet our expectations.'b'AS much as we love our digital devices, many of us have an uneasy sense that they are destroying our attention spans. We skitter from app to app, seldom alighting for long. Our ability to concentrate is shot, right?'b'Research shows that our intuition is wrong. We can focus. But our sense that we can\xe2\x80\x99t may not be a phantom. Paying attention requires not just ability but desire. Technology may snuff out our desire to focus.'b'The idea that gadgets corrode our attention span sounds logical. Screen-based activities can take 'b'upward of 11 hours'b' of a teenager\xe2\x80\x99s day, and many demand rapid shifts of attention: quick camera cuts in videos, frenetically paced games, answering questions in multiple apps, not to mention web design that invites skimming. And we often do all this simultaneously, so attention bounces between two (or three or eight) fast-paced tasks. The theory is that the brain\xe2\x80\x99s plasticity turns this quick mental pivoting into a habit, rendering us unable to sustain attention.'b'But there\xe2\x80\x99s little evidence that attention spans are shrinking. Scientists use \xe2\x80\x9cspan\xe2\x80\x9d to mean two separate things: how much we can keep in mind, and how well we can maintain focus. They measure the former by asking people to repeat increasingly long strings of digits in reverse order. They measure the latter by asking people to monitor visual stimuli for occasional, subtle changes. Performance on these tests today looks a whole lot as it did 50 years ago.'b'Scientists also note that although mental tasks can change our brains, the impact is usually modest. For example, 'b'practice with action video games'b' improves some aspects of vision, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a small boost, not an overhaul of how we see. Attention is so central to our ability to think that a significant deterioration would require a retrofitting of other cognitive functions. Mental reorganization at that scale happens over evolutionary time, not because you got a smartphone.'b'But if our attention span is not shrinking, why do we feel it is? Why, in a 'b'2012 Pew survey'b', did nearly 90 percent of teachers claim that students can\xe2\x80\x99t pay attention the way they could a few years ago? It may be that digital devices have not left us unable to pay attention, but have made us unwilling to do so.'b'The digital world carries the promise of amusement that is constant, immediate and limitless. If a YouTube video isn\xe2\x80\x99t funny in the first 10 seconds, why watch when I can instantly seek something better on BuzzFeed or Spotify? The Internet hasn\xe2\x80\x99t shortened my attention span, but it has fixed a persistent thought in the back of my mind: Isn\xe2\x80\x99t there something better to do than what I\xe2\x80\x99m doing?'b'Are we more easily bored than we were 20 years ago? Researchers don\xe2\x80\x99t know, but recent studies support the suggestion that our antennas are always up. People\xe2\x80\x99s performance on basic 'b'laboratory tests of attention'b' gets worse if a cellphone is merely visible nearby. In 'b'another experiment'b', people using a driving simulator were more likely to hit a pedestrian when their cellphone rang, even if they had planned in advance not to answer it.'b'The direst prediction offered by digital critics \xe2\x80\x94 our phones are really pocket-size deep fryers for the mind \xe2\x80\x94 may be untrue, but the alternative I\xe2\x80\x99ve suggested sounds nearly as bad. The appetite for endless entertainment suggests that worthier activities will be shoved aside. We may buy Salman Rushdie\xe2\x80\x99s book, but we\xe2\x80\x99ll end up sucked in by Flappy Bird.'b'That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t quite seem to be the case, either. Research shows, for example, that the amount of leisure reading hasn\xe2\x80\x99t changed with the advent of the digital age. Before we congratulate ourselves, though, let\xe2\x80\x99s acknowledge that brainier hobbies have never been that popular. There have always been ways to kill time.'b'Still, digital activities may be different. Over the last decade, neuroscientists 'b'distinguished two systems of attention'b' and associated thought. One is directed outward, as when you scroll through your email or play Candy Crush. The other is directed inward, as when you daydream, plan what you\xe2\x80\x99ll do tomorrow, or reflect on the past. Clearly, most digital activities call for outwardly directed attention. These two modes of attention work like a toggle switch; when one is on, the other is off. In fact, when attention is outwardly directed, the inwardly directed attention system is somewhat suppressed. Given the amount of time people spend with digital devices, that sounds ominous.'b'Will we actually lose our ability to daydream? Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope not. Among daydreaming\xe2\x80\x99s many merits, 'b'research shows'b', is an association with greater creativity. But there is a dark side of inwardly directed thought, too. Daydreaming often distracts us when we\xe2\x80\x99re trying to get something done. And reflection can turn ugly, as when we ruminate about some past insult or error.'b'Digital devices are not eating away at our brains. They are, however, luring us toward near constant outwardly directed thought, a situation that\xe2\x80\x99s probably unique in human experience. A flat cap on time with devices \xe2\x80\x94 the restriction we first think of for ourselves and our kids \xe2\x80\x94 might help. So would parking devices in another room for a while. But it would be more effective if we could learn to recognize in ourselves when escape from our thoughts is O.K. and when reflection is in order. As a bonus, judgments like that require inwardly directed attention, a mental habit that in our smartphone era, we\xe2\x80\x99d be dumb to lose.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve never been a fan of global conferences to solve problems, but when I read that 'b'the Obama administration is organizing'b' a Summit on Countering Violent Extremism for Feb. 18, in response to the Paris killings, I had a visceral reaction: Is there a box on my tax returns that I can check so my tax dollars won\xe2\x80\x99t go to pay for this?'b'When you don\xe2\x80\x99t call things by their real name, you always get in trouble. And this administration, so fearful of being accused of Islamophobia, is refusing to make any link to radical Islam from the recent explosions of violence against civilians (most of them Muslims) by Boko Haram in Nigeria, by the Taliban in Pakistan, by Al Qaeda in Paris and by jihadists in Yemen and Iraq. We\xe2\x80\x99ve entered the theater of the absurd.'b'Last week the conservative columnist 'b'Rich Lowry wrote an essay'b' in Politico Magazine that contained quotes from White House spokesman Josh Earnest that I could not believe. I was sure they were made up. But I checked the transcript: 100 percent correct. I can\xe2\x80\x99t say it better than Lowry did:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe administration has lapsed into unselfconscious ridiculousness. Asked why the administration won\xe2\x80\x99t say [after the Paris attacks] we are at war with radical Islam, Earnest on Tuesday explained the administration\xe2\x80\x99s first concern \xe2\x80\x98is accuracy. We want to describe exactly what happened. These are individuals who carried out an act of terrorism, and they later tried to justify that act of terrorism by invoking the religion of Islam and their own deviant view of it.\xe2\x80\x99'b'This makes it sound as if the Charlie Hebdo terrorists set out to commit a random act of violent extremism and only subsequently, when they realized that they needed some justification, did they reach for Islam.'b'The day before, Earnest had conceded that there are lists of recent \xe2\x80\x98examples of individuals who have cited Islam as they\xe2\x80\x99ve carried out acts of violence.\xe2\x80\x99 Cited Islam? According to the Earnest theory ... purposeless violent extremists rummage through the scriptures of great faiths, looking for some verses to cite to support their mayhem and often happen to settle on the holy texts of Islam.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama knows better. I am all for restraint on the issue, and would never hold every Muslim accountable for the acts of a few. But it is not good for us or the Muslim world to pretend that this spreading jihadist violence isn\xe2\x80\x99t coming out of their faith community. It is coming mostly, but not exclusively, from angry young men and preachers on the fringe of the Sunni Arab and Pakistani communities in the Middle East and Europe.'b'If Western interventions help foster violent Islamic reactions, we should reduce them. To the extent that Muslim immigrants in European countries feel marginalized, they and their hosts should worker harder on absorption. But both efforts will only take you so far.'b'Something else is also at work, and it needs to be discussed. It is the struggle within Arab and Pakistani Sunni Islam over whether and how to embrace modernity, pluralism and women\xe2\x80\x99s rights. That struggle drives, and is driven by, the dysfunctionality of so many Arab states and Pakistan. It has left these societies with too many young men who have never held a job or a girl\xe2\x80\x99s hand, who then seek to overcome their humiliation at being left behind, and to find identity, by \xe2\x80\x9cpurifying\xe2\x80\x9d their worlds of other Muslims who are not sufficiently pious and of Westerners whom they perceive to be putting Muslims down. But you don\xe2\x80\x99t see this in the two giant Muslim communities in Indonesia or India.'b'\xc2\xa0Only Sunni Arabs and Pakistanis can get inside their narrative and remediate it. But reformers can only do that if they have a free, secure political space. If we\xe2\x80\x99re not going to help create space for that internal dialogue, let\xe2\x80\x99s just be quiet. 'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t say stupid stuff.'b' And don\xe2\x80\x99t hold airy fairy conferences that dodge the real issues, which many mainstream Muslims know and are actually starved to discuss, especially women.'b'The Arab journalist Diana Moukalled, 'b'writing in the London-based Asharq Al-Awsat last week'b', asked: \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t all these events now going on around us and committed in our name require us to break the fear barrier and begin to question our region and our societies, especially the ideas being trafficked there that have led us to this awful stage where we are tearing at one another\xe2\x80\x99s throats \xe2\x80\x94 to mention nothing of what as a result also happens beyond our region?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And 'b'a remarkable piece in The Washington Post'b' Sunday by Asra Q. Nomani, an American Muslim born in India, called out the \xe2\x80\x9chonor corps\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a loose, well-funded coalition of governments and private individuals \xe2\x80\x9cthat tries to silence debate on extremist ideology in order to protect the image of Islam.\xe2\x80\x9d It \xe2\x80\x9cthrows the label of \xe2\x80\x98Islamophobe\xe2\x80\x99 on pundits, journalists and others who dare to talk about extremist ideology in the religion. ... The official and unofficial channels work in tandem, harassing, threatening and battling introspective Muslims and non-Muslims everywhere. ... The bullying often works to silence critics of Islamic extremism. ... They cause governments, writers and experts to walk on eggshells.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I know one in particular.'b'Key Democrats have reached agreement on a set of policies known as \xe2\x80\x9c'b'inclusive capitalism'b'\xe2\x80\x9d: a forceful market-oriented economic agenda intended to counter inequality, restrain the accrual of vast wealth at the top and provide the working and middle classes with improved economic opportunities.'b'From the White House to Congress to liberal think tanks, recent Democratic proposals would substantially alter the rules of the marketplace. These include major revisions of the tax code, legislation to pressure corporations to increase pay to match productivity growth and an expansion of refundable tax credits to include low-income workers as well as households making as much as $80,000 a year.'b'According to a report by the former Treasury secretary 'b'Lawrence Summers'b' and Ed Balls, a top British Labor Party politician, unless there is serious government intervention, inequality and a lack of financial resources among those in the bottom half of the income distribution will result in \xe2\x80\x9cinsufficient aggregate demand \xe2\x80\x93 too little spending by consumers and businesses to keep gross domestic product at its capacity.\xe2\x80\x9d Developed nations \xe2\x80\x9cneed new social and political institutions to make 21st century capitalism work for the many and not the few,\xe2\x80\x9d Summers and Balls wrote.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cInclusive capitalism,\xe2\x80\x9d according to its advocates, 'b'seeks'b' \xe2\x80\x9cto make our economic system more equitable, more sustainable and more inclusive.\xe2\x80\x9d It is 'b'an international movement'b' that has now made its way into 'b'Democratic Party'b' circles.'b'Mark Carney, the Canadian governor of the Bank of England, 'b'articulated a fundamental premise'b' of inclusive capitalism in a speech delivered in Britain last May: \xe2\x80\x9cJust as any revolution eats its children,\xe2\x80\x9d Carney said, \xe2\x80\x9cunchecked market fundamentalism can devour the social capital essential for the long-term dynamism of capitalism itself.\xe2\x80\x9d Among the attendees at the conference in London in May were such Democratic and liberal luminaries as Bill Clinton; Eric Schmidt, executive chairman of Google; and Summers, who served 'b'President Obama'b' as a top economic adviser.'b'Two of the earliest advocates of inclusive capitalism were the late 'b'C.K. Prahalad'b', professor of business at the University of Michigan, and 'b'Stuart L. Hart'b', professor emeritus of strategic management at Cornell. In a widely cited 2002 article, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Fortune at the Bottom of the Pyramid'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Prahalad and Hart argued that powerful corporations could \xe2\x80\x94 must \xe2\x80\x94 improve the conditions of the world\xe2\x80\x99s poor by promoting commercial activity, employment opportunities, access to credit, and wealth creation among those at the bottom of income distribution \xe2\x80\x93 a group they refer to as the fourth tier, the world\xe2\x80\x99s poorest four billion people.'b'Prahalad\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'core thesis'b' was that the poor could be the'b'The concept of inclusive capitalism has expanded over the past 13 years to apply to those at the bottom and middle of the ladder in developed nations, including the United States. The fundamental \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d argument is that business enterprises lose profit-making opportunities when consumers have little money to spend. Inadequate purchasing power among the many threatens corporations and poses a direct danger to the top 1 percent, and, indeed, to capitalism itself.'b'As testimony to the power of the concept of \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism,\xe2\x80\x9d President Obama in his 'b'State of the Union address'b' called for the enactment of tax policies designed to provide a larger share of market-driven economic growth to the working and middle classes. In a May 7, 2014, speech in Dublin, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Global Lessons for Inclusive Growth'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Jason Furman, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, outlined central elements of the White House agenda. Administration policies, Furman argued, would result in \xe2\x80\x9chigher median incomes, lower poverty rates, and broader, more inclusive growth.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Representative Chris Van Hollen, ranking Democrat on the House Budget Committee, outlined additional inclusive capitalism policies in \xe2\x80\x9c'b'An Action Plan to Grow the Paychecks of All, Not Just the Wealth of a Few'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Summers-Balls report \xe2\x80\x93 \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Report of the Commission on Inclusive Prosperity'b'\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 is the most comprehensive summary. This report, which uses the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d more than a dozen times, was published by the Center for American Progress, a Democratic think tank founded by John Podesta \xe2\x80\x93 Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s former chief of staff who in February 'b'will join Hillary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s exploratory presidential campaign'b'.'b'Those pressing the Democratic Party to take more populist stands contend that the lack of a persuasive Democratic economic program 'b'contributed to, or drove, devastating losses'b' in the 2014 elections in states as diverse as North Carolina, Maryland, Iowa and Colorado. According to an Oct. 13, 2014, Gallup 'b'pre-election survey'b', voters believed Republicans were better equipped to handle the economy than Democrats by 50 percent to 39 percent.'b'If policies grounded in \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d become central to the party platform, it will mark the party\xe2\x80\x99s strongest commitment to the economic interests of working- and middle-class Americans since Franklin Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s New Deal. The new agenda stands apart from Lyndon Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s War on Poverty, which was focused primarily on the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Other America'b'\xe2\x80\x9d of the very poor.'b'The most damaging contemporary American trend that the proposals seek to counter is the sharply declining share of national income flowing to labor, and the parallel increase in the share flowing to owners of capital. This trend, which accelerated sharply in 2000, is shown in 'b'Figure 1'b', a graphic produced by the White House.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe need to share the wealth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Senator Charles E. Schumer, chairman of the Senate Democratic Policy and Communications Committee and a leading proponent of the party\xe2\x80\x99s focus on economics.'b'Schumer, in an interview, voiced strong enthusiasm for the Summers report. \xe2\x80\x9cIt could bring together the left and center and even parts of the right,\xe2\x80\x9d Schumer suggested.'b'In his State of the Union address, Obama put it this way: \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s close loopholes so we stop rewarding companies that keep profits abroad, and reward those that invest in America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His plan calls for the imposition of new taxes on the wealthy and on major financial institutions, totaling $320 billion over 10 years. The money would be used to finance tax cuts and credits for low-to-moderate-income men and women, and to make attendance at community colleges tuition-free.'b'Not only would Obama raise 'b'capital gains tax'b' rates from 23.8 to 28 percent for couples making more than $500,000 in taxable income, but he would eliminate a provision in tax law that allows the very rich to avoid taxation on much of the wealth passed on to their children and he would end a current exemption from taxation on the increase in the value of stocks, bonds and other assets when passed on through inheritance.'b'This exemption, technically called the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'stepped up basis'b',\xe2\x80\x9d is crucial to the unrestricted intergenerational transfer of wealth, a practice that 'b'many liberals'b', and even some conservatives, contend conflicts with equality of opportunity. The Obama plan additionally calls for 'b'a .07 percent fee'b' on financial institutions with more than $50 billion in assets that would produce $110 billion in revenue over 10 years.'b'Van Hollen, in turn, would raise revenues by imposing a transaction tax on stock trades. He would use the money to finance a $1,000 tax credit for workers making less than $100,000 annually, a $20,000 deduction for two-earner families, an annual $250 payment to those who put at least $500 into an approved retirement pension plan, and to substantially increase child care tax credits.'b'Van Hollen would also bar large corporations from deducting C.E.O. and other corporate compensation over $1 million unless employees got pay raises reflecting increases in worker productivity and the cost of living.'b'The Summers-Balls report includes many of the proposals outlined by Obama and Van Hollen. Balls 'b'warned on his blog'b' that \xe2\x80\x9cunfettered markets and trickle-down economics are leading to increasing levels of inequality, stagnating wages and a hollowing out of decent, middle income jobs.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Their report addresses four major economic developments broadly undermining wages and working conditions:'b'First, that \xe2\x80\x9cincreasing global economic integration has also meant increased competition for many workers who produce tradable goods and services.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Second, that \xe2\x80\x9cadvances in robotics and artificial intelligence have put intermediate-skill jobs at risk in what economists call a hollowing out of the labor market.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Third, that \xe2\x80\x9cMajor corporations have opted to use subcontracting to perform basic functions, and many workers are now classified as independent contractors, eroding basic labor law protections.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And fourth, \xe2\x80\x9ccorporations have come to function much less effectively as providers of large-scale opportunity. Increasingly, their dominant focus has been on maximization of share prices and the compensation of their top employees.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In addition, Summers and Balls argue that competition in the banking sector has broken down and \xe2\x80\x9cwill need interventions to support the reasonable functioning of the free market.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What do these points actually signify in practice? In a section titled \xe2\x80\x9cU.S. Policy Response,\xe2\x80\x9d Summers and Balls call for making parent companies responsible for the working conditions of employees of subcontractors; adopting government policies favoring employee stock ownership so that workers benefit from the growing share of national income flowing to capital as opposed to wages; and imposing tough and costly sanctions on employers who use illegal tactics to fight unionization.'b'Not stopping there, Summers and Balls call for a substantial boost in the $24,000 pay ceiling under which employees must get time and a half for overtime work beyond 40 hours a week; increased infrastructure spending of $100 billion a year, or $1 trillion over 10 years; and strengthened provisions in trade agreements guaranteeing collective bargaining rights and basic environmental protections to reduce the movement of American companies to countries with the lowest labor standards.'b'Among their other proposed policy initiatives are creation of an income tax credit for those with moderate pay levels. It would start at $23,260 for joint filers with children, just where the current earned-income tax credit phases out. At $85,000, the credit would diminish, reaching zero at $95,000. They would also change the mortgage interest and property tax deductions into tax credits. Deductions inherently provide larger benefits to those in higher tax brackets. Credits provide equal benefits to all who qualify.'b'Republican leaders in Congress have 'b'already stiff-armed'b' these proposals.'b'In response to Obama\xe2\x80\x99s plan to tax the wealthy to boost breaks for the working class, Michael Steed, spokesman for the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, said in a statement, \xe2\x80\x9cMore Washington tax hikes and spending is the same old top-down approach we\xe2\x80\x99ve come to expect from President Obama that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t worked.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe president needs to stop listening to his liberal allies who want to raise taxes at all costs and start working with Congress to fix our broken tax code,\xe2\x80\x9d Senator Orrin Hatch, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said in a statement,'b'Taken together, the Obama, Van Hollen, and Summers interpretations of \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d are a victory for the left of the Democratic Party. This is especially the case for the 'b'Economic Policy Institute'b', which has been conducting a lonely fight for stronger legislative and regulatory initiatives to counter stagnating wages.'b'Josh Bivens, the research director at E.P.I., said in an email that the proposals did indeed \xe2\x80\x9clook like a shift in the Democratic Party on economic policy.\xe2\x80\x9d He said his hope was that \xe2\x80\x9cthe next two years becomes a competition about who is willing to be the most aggressive in trying to boost low/middle-class incomes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Dean Baker, co-director of the 'b'Center for Economic and Policy Research'b', called the Obama plan \xe2\x80\x9ca pretty big deal. Raising the capital gains tax rate and ending the stepped-up basis at death are changes that almost exclusively hit the wealthy, and they amount to a fair bit of money.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While none of the proposals, or their advocates, acknowledge this explicitly, one of the objectives of the evolving Democratic economic agenda is to get back support among whites without college degrees \xe2\x80\x93 the polling shorthand version of what is sometimes still called the white working class.'b'In 2014, these voters, who made up 36 percent of the electorate, 'b'cast their ballots'b' for Republican House candidates by a 30-point margin (64-34 percent). This was nearly double the 16-point Republican margin among white college graduates, 57-41.'b'Inclusive capitalism has its critics on the left, nicely summed up by the Guardian columnist 'b'Nafeez Ahmed'b'. He argued last May that the inclusive capitalism movement represented \xe2\x80\x9cless a meaningful shift of direction than a barely transparent effort to rehabilitate a parasitical economic system on the brink of facing a global uprising.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Andrew Grove, founder of Intel, put the push toward \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d in a more positive light. \xe2\x80\x9cOur generation has seen the decisive victory of free-market principles over planned economies,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'he told the Economist'b' in 2012. \xe2\x80\x9cSo we stick with this belief largely oblivious to emerging evidence that while free markets beat planned economies, there may be room for a modification that is even better.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While the new agenda has no chance of passage in the Republican-controlled Congress, Democrats plan to use the tenets of inclusive capitalism in the 2016 elections. One Democratic goal in putting specific policies forward is to use them as wedge issues to force Republicans to choose between their affluent backers and their supporters in the white working class. This will be no easy task because a decisive majority of whites without college degrees has been voting against Democratic candidates for two decades, making it very difficult for the party to break what has been a Republican hammerlock since 1994.'b'The circumstances facing President Obama as 'b'he delivered his State of the Union address Tuesday night'b' could not have seemed less promising: a presidency with only two years left to get anything done in a Congress that is now totally in the control of a party that has routinely ignored his pleas for cooperation. So he chose wisely to send a simple, dramatic message about economic fairness, about the fact that the well-off \xe2\x80\x94 the top earners, the big banks, Silicon Valley \xe2\x80\x94 have done just great, while the middle and working classes remain dead in the water. His remedy: skim from the rich and redistribute to those below, while deploying other weapons to raise wages and increase jobs.'b'He did not frame the debate over inequality as starkly as many economists have, preferring instead to talk about the virtues of \xe2\x80\x9cmiddle-class economics.\xe2\x80\x9d But he came close. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s now up to us to choose who we want to be over the next 15 years, and for decades to come,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWill we accept an economy where only a few of us do spectacularly well? Or will we commit ourselves to an economy that generates rising incomes and chances for everyone who makes the effort?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama knows his prospects of getting Congress to agree are less than zero; Republicans dismissed his ideas before he even voiced them. That does not make them irrelevant. Mr. Obama was speaking not just to the present but to the future, to the 2016 presidential elections and even beyond. By simply raising the plight of the middle class (and, looming behind it, the larger issue of economic inequality), he has firmly inserted issues of economic fairness into the political debate. Hillary Rodham Clinton or whomever the Democrats nominate cannot ignore them now. Even Republicans, disinclined to raise taxes on top-tier earners, may find attractive the idea of doing something for those in the middle.'b'Further, while the rhetoric was combative, even defiant in parts, the president\xe2\x80\x99s proposal is hardly radical. It would raise the capital gains tax to 28 percent \xe2\x80\x94 which is where it was in the Reagan era. It would impose ordinary income tax rates on dividends and end a provision in the tax code that shields hundreds of billions of dollars in appreciated wealth passed on to heirs. These changes, plus a new fee on big banks, would finance a set of tax breaks for middle-income families, including credits for two-earner couples, increased child care and college tuition credits, as well as other programs, including two years of tuition-free community college for some students. And the whole thing is designed to be revenue-neutral, the tax increases paying for the new programs to avoid the endless wrangling over deficits that have exhausted both political parties as well as the American public.'b'It was hardly surprising that a president who expects so little from Congress devoted some of his speech to celebrating the things that he has accomplished against considerable odds. With Congress\xe2\x80\x99s help, he rescued the automobile companies, jump-started the renewable energy industry, imposed new rules on financial institutions and, most dramatically, engineered a major overhaul of the health care system. On his own initiative, he ordered major reforms in immigration policy, forged a landmark agreement with the automobile companies on fuel efficiency and proposed tough restrictions on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants.'b'His task will be to defend these initiatives from almost certain congressional attack, wielding his veto pen, or threatening to wield it, much as President Bill Clinton found himself doing after Newt Gingrich and his Republican majority took over the House in 1995. President Obama should also seek out opportunities to use his executive authority to improve conditions for the middle class and for workers, such as fixing overtime rules, and, at every opportunity, use the bully pulpit on important matters like improving the minimum wage.'b'There is one other thing he must do: Resist his instinct to follow the false promise of compromise. Give-and-take is part of the legislative process, but trade-offs amounting to Republican legislative triumphs are unacceptable. Gridlock seems almost foreordained over the next two years. Mr. Obama should do nothing to confuse the voters as to where the responsibility lies.'b'AT some point in the next few weeks, the Democratic National Committee will announce the location of its 2016 convention. Philadelphia and Columbus are in the running, but for many, the money is on Brooklyn. And the site does seem attractive: The convention would take place at the Barclays Center, a state-of-the-art arena in the hippest borough of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s media capital.'b'But setting aside the wisdom of hosting a Democratic convention in the bluest spot east of Berkeley, the committee should look elsewhere. Brooklyn and Barclays are a logistical and ethical minefield.'b'First, logistics. Despite an estimated 2,000 hotel rooms in Downtown Brooklyn, most of the expected 35,000 visitors will sleep in Manhattan. Though the arena is quite accessible by subway, the city has proposed moving thousands of delegates along temporary dedicated bus lanes across the bridges and through Downtown Brooklyn \xe2\x80\x94 a potential traffic mess along an already congested corridor.'b'More important, the Barclays Center\xe2\x80\x99s neighborhood setting \xe2\x80\x94 a busy commercial center shoehorned into a dense residential zone \xe2\x80\x94 means there will be little parking available and little margin of error for vehicles serving the arena and the trucks going to its loading docks.'b'Backers profess no worries; after all, they say, critics of the arena raised similar concerns after 2003 when its developer, Forest City Ratner, announced that the Nets basketball team would move there from New Jersey, and traffic has been manageable. But arena events still vex the nearest neighbors, especially when limousines and other private vehicles lurk on residential blocks, since there\xe2\x80\x99s little streetside parking and few places to legally idle.'b'The convention would ripple farther than boosters admit. A political conclave, in this security-conscious era, entails a much more robust police presence, with the potential for street and even sidewalk closures in the surrounding blocks (Mayor Bill de Blasio did not acknowledge that nearby businesses might have to close for the convention until that uncomfortable possibility was raised in Politico). And, of course, space must be found for the armies of reporters, film crews and protesters who would inevitably follow.'b'Then there\xe2\x80\x99s the arena itself. Do the members of the Democratic National Committee realize that the convention would be in a major construction zone? While the Barclays Center interior is finished (though workers are retrofitting a green roof), its neighboring sites in the Atlantic Yards megaproject, a forest of residential skyscrapers now called Pacific Park Brooklyn, have only just gotten started. Two of those towers that abut the arena will be under construction in summer 2016, bracketing an entire flank of the arena with cranes and construction equipment.'b'The arena also raises ethically sticky questions for the Democrats. While the Barclays Center is owned primarily by Forest City Ratner, 45 percent of it is owned by the Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov (who also owns 80 percent of the Brooklyn Nets). Mr. Prokhorov has a necessarily cordial relationship with Russia\xe2\x80\x99s president, Vladimir V. Putin \xe2\x80\x94 though he has been critical of Mr. Putin in the past, last year, at the Russian president\xe2\x80\x99s request, he tried to transfer ownership of the Nets to one of his Moscow-based companies. An oligarch-owned arena is an odd place to host one of American democracy\xe2\x80\x99s premier events.'b'The dubious optics extend to Forest City Ratner\xe2\x80\x99s other partner, the Greenland Holding Group, a Chinese conglomerate that owns most of the planned 16-tower project tethered to the arena. Owned by the government of Shanghai, Greenland now reaps the benefit of the subsidies, tax breaks and cheap land that Forest City Ratner wangled for the project in the 2000s.'b'Perhaps the diciest symbolism regards Greenland and Forest City Ratner\xe2\x80\x99s extensive use of a federal program called EB-5, which allows foreign investors to get visas in exchange for a short-term $500,000 investment (an amount that, on paper, is purported to create 10 jobs).'b'Greenland and Forest City Ratner have already reportedly raised some $250 million through the program; put differently, a Chinese government is making a profit by marketing American residency to its own nationals \xe2\x80\x94 a bizarre, if legal, twist on the law\xe2\x80\x99s intent.'b'Forest City Ratner has long defended the project by citing its promise to include 2,250 \xe2\x80\x9caffordable housing\xe2\x80\x9d units (out of 6,430 total). It\xe2\x80\x99s a promise that the mayor is happy to repeat: At the Dec. 15 groundbreaking for a tower on the eastern end of the site, Mr. de Blasio cited a \xe2\x80\x9c100 percent affordable\xe2\x80\x9d tower as \xe2\x80\x9ca symbol of what we intend to do with our affordable housing plan over and over.\xe2\x80\x9d But affordable housing is a vague term, and in this case, half of those units will go to households earning six figures. While most New Yorkers could use help with housing costs, this departs from Forest City\xe2\x80\x99s promise to help more working-class residents.'b'While Mr. de Blasio tries to sell Barclays Center and Atlantic Yards as an icon of a hip, prospering city, in reality Brooklyn continues to struggle with yawning socioeconomic challenges, including a 35 percent child poverty rate. And while that shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a reason not to boost one\xe2\x80\x99s own city, Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s challenge today is not boosting its profile but dealing with the attractiveness of its already enormous global cachet. The last decade has seen a cascade of Manhattan and global wealth pouring into the borough, buying up huge chunks of working-class neighborhoods and converting them into fields of luxury condos. This is gentrification on steroids, an enormous challenge that the mayor can barely dent.'b'The Barclays Center/Atlantic Yards megaproject, which relied on a dubious finding of blight to deliver a gentrifying district to a developer via eminent domain, was even touted as a response to gentrification, but has hardly proven so.'b'Brooklyn and Barclays are fine places to visit. But they are the last place that a political party intent on building a base among the struggling American middle class should choose for its quadrennial close-up.'b'Some Argentines are calling Alberto Nisman, the maverick prosecutor, the 86th casualty of one of the deadliest, unsolved terrorists attacks in modern history: the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires. That seems fitting whether 'b'his death over the weekend'b' turns out to be a suicide, as the government of 'b'President Cristina Fern\xc3\xa1ndez de Kirchner'b' seems eager to establish, or the murder of a man who had learned too much.'b'This much is clear: The best hope of definitively establishing the truth about the horrific 'b'July 18, 1994, bombing'b' and its tortured, politicized investigation is to impanel an international team of jurists who can take a fresh, objective look at the evidence.'b'The truth became more important after Mr. Nisman\xe2\x80\x99s body was discovered inside his apartment on Sunday, hours before he was expected to testify on his startling allegation that Ms. Kirchner cut a deal with the Iranian government to protect some of the culprits of the attack.'b'Ms. Kirchner\xe2\x80\x99s late husband, former president N\xc3\xa9stor Kirchner, appointed Mr. Nisman to lead the inquiry a decade ago after acknowledging a shocking series of blunders by those assigned to the case over the years. Mr. Nisman, 51, became convinced that the bombing was carried out by the Shiite militant movement Hezbollah under orders of the Iranian government. Based on the prosecutor\xe2\x80\x99s investigation, Argentina got Interpol to issue arrest notices for 'b'seven prominent Iranians'b', including a Hezbollah leader and several government officials.'b'In a strange twist, in January 2013, Argentina announced it had reached a deal with Iran to establish a \xe2\x80\x9ctruth commission\xe2\x80\x9d that would investigate the case jointly. The notion that Iran could be counted on to play a constructive role was questionable at best and rightly met with skepticism from Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s Jewish community.'b'Earlier this month, Mr. Nisman unveiled a 'b'300-page complaint charging'b' that Ms. Kirchner and Foreign Minister H\xc3\xa9ctor Timerman conspired to absolve top Iranian officials in exchange for commercial deals that would benefit both cash-strapped governments. President Kirchner issued stern denials. Mr. Nisman said he would corroborate the allegations in a congressional hearing on Monday.'b'According to the Argentine press, there were no signs that Mr. Nisman was suicidal in recent days. Over the weekend, he prepared for the hearing. He wrote a grocery list for his maid to run to the store on Monday. Despite having a 10-person security detail, Mr. Nisman signaled that he was concerned for his safety, telling an Argentine journalist, Natasha Niebieskikwiat, on Saturday: 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI might turn up dead from all this.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Ms. Kirchner, a pugnacious stateswoman who has been vindictive toward enemies in the press and politics, weighed in on the case in 'b'a lengthy, rambling statement'b' posted on her personal website late Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cSuicide,\xe2\x80\x9d she wrote, is always a befuddling act. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat led a person to make such a terrible decision and end their life?\xe2\x80\x9d Missing from her note was a message of condolence for Mr. Nisman\xe2\x80\x99s family. But the most glaring omission is the fact that the manner of death is far from a settled question.'b'SEOUL, South Korea \xe2\x80\x94  While 'b'North Korea'b' draws world attention with spectacular and seemingly bizarre actions like the hacking of Sony\xe2\x80\x99s computers or outbursts of bellicose rhetoric, Pyongyang has quietly initiated a round of reforms aimed at liberalizing the economy.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely that 'b'Kim Jong-un'b', the young North Korean leader who inherited power in December 2011, will allow economic liberalization to lead the way for political and social change. The repressive regime will continue to be a thorn in the side of world leaders who want to dismantle Pyongyang\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program.'b'But the economic changes hold great promise for improving the lives of millions of North Koreans who have suffered in deep poverty for decades. The new policies should be welcomed and supported by the outside world.'b'The impoverished countryside is the site of a major effort to open up the farming economy. My talks with North Korean refugees and migrant workers in China, as well as nongovernmental organization personnel on the ground, confirm what has been reported in South Korean media over the last few years: An agricultural system apparently implemented in 2013 allows farmers \xe2\x80\x94 who have always worked for a token payment and fixed rations \xe2\x80\x94 to register their households as \xe2\x80\x9cwork teams.\xe2\x80\x9d Such teams are now allowed to keep a larger portion of their harvest, some reports say more than 30 percent. Moreover, for the foreseeable future these family-based groups will toil in the same fields, year after year, giving them an incentive to take better care of the land. Before the change, farmers had worked on land that belonged to state-managed farms and were often moved from one field to another.'b'A new set of market-oriented reforms adopted by the Central Committee of the Workers\xe2\x80\x99 Party and by the cabinet of ministers on May 30, 2014, appears to aim to liberalize the economy as a whole. The content of this classified economic policy document was first partially leaked to the South Korean daily Segye Ilbo in June. Later it was confirmed by many sources and is now widely discussed by Pyongyang watchers.'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cMay 30 Measures,\xe2\x80\x9d as they\xe2\x80\x99ve come to be known, envision the significant reduction of state control of the economy and a dismantling of central planning. Managers of state enterprises will be allowed to purchase items on a free market, making deals with other enterprises or even private businesses. They will be given the right to fire and hire workers, and pay them as much as they want.'b'At coal mines near the border with China, where the new \xe2\x80\x9csystem of managerial responsibility\xe2\x80\x9d has been tested since late 2013, the best miners may now receive up to $70 a month, an exorbitant wage for the North.'b'Mr. Kim has also left untouched the unofficial private economy, which began to grow in the 1990s and now contributes significantly to North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s tiny G.D.P., as much as 50 percent by some estimates. This economy of small businesses like food stalls, bicycle repair shops and truck deliveries, as well as larger ones like small coal mines and fishing companies, has never been explicitly accepted by the government. But since Mr. Kim\xe2\x80\x99s ascension, officials have left this gray market alone.'b'The agricultural reforms are already bearing fruit. In 2013, the country enjoyed the best harvest in decades when \xe2\x80\x94 in a first since the 1980s \xe2\x80\x94 it produced nearly enough food to feed its population on a subsistence level.'b'People on the ground are not surprised. Once farmers were turned from serfs to sharecroppers, the labor input increased dramatically, and it was enough to make a quick difference in  an economy where wooden plows and  oxen still reign supreme.'b'The 2014 harvest was also impressive, in spite of severe drought. European workers from nongovernmental organizations and groups of visiting Chinese experts whom I recently met say that the efficiency of the farmers who now work for a share of crops, instead of fixed rations, increased dramatically. Indeed, as one migrant worker in China told me: \xe2\x80\x9cFarmers take care of the fields, they now believe that the more they produce, the better they eat.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The full impact of the reforms in industry will not be felt for a while, but it is likely to be strong: The Hyundai Research Institute even predicts that in 2015 North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s gross domestic product will increase 7 percent.'b'From Mr. Kim\xe2\x80\x99s point of view, it makes sense to usher in economic changes: The old system was slowly falling apart, eroding from within by the development of an unofficial economy and growing disappointment in the official ideology. The reforms are risky, but without reforms the regime is certainly doomed.'b'While the changes are positive for regular North Koreans, one should harbor no illusions: North Korea will remain a problematic place.'b'The regime will never surrender its 'b'nuclear weapons'b'. The leaders firmly believe that they need them as a diplomatic tool and as a deterrent, and their worries have not been ameliorated by the fate of Saddam Hussein and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the only dictator in history who swapped his nuclear weapons program for the promise of economic benefits from the West.'b'North Korea will remain a human rights abuser. In China, economic reforms led to social liberalization; many Chinese can now do things that would have gotten them killed in the days of Mao. This is not going to happen in North Korea \xe2\x80\x94 because of South Korea.'b'Thanks to strict information control in the North, rumors abound about the economic success of the South, but the true scope of that success remains unknown. If ordinary North Koreans were to become less fearful of the authorities, while also learning about the affluence of the South, they might do what the East Germans did: get rid of the regime and pave the way for a unified Korean Peninsula. From the regime\xe2\x80\x99s viewpoint, this means that only by keeping the populace terrified (but better fed) do they have some chance of maintaining authority.'b'Nevertheless, a reforming North Korea will be an unstable place, with the specter of implosion always looming. The regime\xe2\x80\x99s implosion could mean a civil war in a nuclear state in a region where interests of the United States and China clash.'b'Still, a prospering North Korea will be less inclined to deliberately destabilize the environment: Its leaders will need stability in their neighborhood to make money. Even if North Korea remains repressive, the lives of citizens will improve. And few people would argue that living in a starving dictatorship is better than living in a modestly affluent one.'b''b'\n'b'Andrei Lankov, 'b' a historian of North Korea and a professor at Kookmin University in Seoul, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Real North Korea.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 Since the Arab Spring 'b'began four years ago'b' whole swathes of the Middle East have been transformed from authoritarian police states into ungoverned, and ungovernable, spaces. In Iraq and Syria, the vacuum left by the receding state has been filled by various Islamist movements. Yet even in these countries, the national governments still retain sovereignty and control over their capital cities.'b'Not so in 'b'Libya'b', where rogue militias 'b'conquered Tripoli'b' in August and set up rival political institutions, forcing the internationally recognized House of Representatives to relocate to the eastern town of Tobruk. Since then, Libya boasts two administrations both claiming to be sovereign.'b'To preserve a semblance of neutrality, the 'b'Libyan Central Bank'b' pays salaries to the militias and bureaucrats of both warring blocs. For months, both sides had clung to hopes of scoring a decisive victory and riding off with the country\xe2\x80\x99s considerable oil wealth. As that prospect waned and the costs of prolonged conflict grew ever greater, moderates of both factions met for peace talks in Geneva. Progress at the negotiating table has led to a 'b'conditional cease-fire'b'.'b'The West\xe2\x80\x99s approach to this crisis has relied on an 'b'oversimplified narrative'b', which sees a legitimate anti-Islamist government in Tobruk facing off against an Islamist administration in Tripoli. This obscures reality: It is local leaders and militia commanders, and not the politicians of both administrations, who hold power in Libya. Moreover, the fighting had descended into a zero-sum grudge match unrelated to religion, with each side ruthlessly attempting to destroy its 'b'opponent\xe2\x80\x99s key infrastructure'b'. In response, businessmen and civic leaders urged their political and militia representatives to embrace dialogue. Some hard-line politicians have balked; they are now being left behind.'b'The coming negotiations should not merely include rival parliamentarians. They should also bring to the table local civic and militia leaders from different tribal and regional blocs, all of whom are seeking to save Libya from destruction while strengthening their positions in a post-conflict settlement.'b'All parties know that these talks are the last chance for a nonmilitary solution. If dialogue fails, the country will be de facto partitioned and the war over resources will resume with increased intensity. If that happens, Italy\xe2\x80\x99s prime minister, Matteo Renzi, has threatened to push for a peacekeeping force.'b'If the international community wishes to give both sides the right incentives to reach a lasting deal, Western democracies must reconsider the logic behind their policies. The 'b'Nov. 6, 2014'b', ruling by the Tripoli-based Libyan Supreme Court provides the perfect pretext. It stated that the constitutional amendment giving rise to the House of Representatives was procedurally invalid, that the June 2014 election should never have happened, and that consequently the ensuing body cannot be vested with sovereignty.'b'Western nations have barely responded \xe2\x80\x94 meekly pointing out that they are studying the decision and that the court\xe2\x80\x99s ruling was made under duress. But Islamist militia pressure on the court does not necessarily invalidate its carefully worded opinion, which states that neither the House, nor its opponents, nor the expired Parliament, are to be considered Libya\xe2\x80\x99s sovereign authority.'b'Western governments are reluctant to acknowledge the implications of the Supreme Court ruling because many of them are secretly cheering for the Tobruk faction to either reconquer the country or dominate a national unity government. After all, the Tobruk government claims to be fighting Ansar al-Sharia in Benghazi \xe2\x80\x94 the very same group that 'b'killed the American ambassador'b', Christopher Stevens, in 2012.'b'Perversely, the West\xe2\x80\x99s ability to act as a neutral party and promote compromise is hindered by the fact that it has already recognized Tobruk as Libya\xe2\x80\x99s sole sovereign. This aligns the United States and Europe with Egypt and the United Arab Emirates, which are 'b'backing'b' Tobruk militarily out of a desire to defeat the Muslim Brotherhood throughout the region. Conversely, Tobruk\xe2\x80\x99s opponents receive significant support from Qatar and Turkey.'b'The door is still open for Western nations to formally withdraw their recognition of the House of Representatives in light of the Supreme Court decision. Because the Islamist-aligned \xe2\x80\x9cgovernment\xe2\x80\x9d in Tripoli is 'b'fracturing by the day'b' and possesses an even more tenuous claim to legitimacy than its rival, such a move would leave Libya without any sovereign authority.'b'Western nations should make clear that they will not recognize any sovereign authority if negotiations fail to produce a national unity government committed to completing the constitutional process. They should also take strong steps to prevent regional interference while simultaneously inviting both sides\xe2\x80\x99 external patrons to the table.'b'Once denied outside assistance, the legal trappings of sovereignty, or the possibility of acquiring either via force, both warring blocs would run out of cash and face strong incentives to compromise.'b'And with 'b'oil prices at historic lows'b', the incentives for rogue actors to smuggle pirated oil would be marginal. Finding buyers, even among Russian mafia syndicates or the Libyan factions\xe2\x80\x99 Gulf patrons, would be challenging.'b'Critics argue that withdrawing recognition of the House of Representatives would be a reward to rogue militias for their brutal takeover of Tripoli and their ongoing support of jihadi elements. They also claim that it would provide an incentive for the Islamists to make the talks fail. Both assertions are false. If the West pledges that it will only recognize a Libyan government committed to a transition to constitutional governance, that would effectively stifle the dream of many Islamists that seek to capture the Libyan state and its resources by force.'b'The war in Libya is not about religion or ideology; it is about greed and vengeance. By not lending our tacit support to either side, and firmly preventing meddlesome regional actors from helping their clients, we could remove the poisonous injections of cash and weapons that drive the conflict.'b''b' 'b''b'Jason Pack'b','b' a researcher at Cambridge University and president of 'b'Libya-Analysis.com'b', is the author of the Tony Blair Foundation\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Libya Situation Report'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Redefining Mental Illness'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Sunday Review, Jan. 18):'b'T. M. Luhrmann encourages us to rethink mental diagnoses like schizophrenia, as well as how these conditions are treated, because they lack discrete biological markers. However, as a clinician and neuroscientist, I question her support for abandoning schizophrenia and other illnesses as distinct diagnostic categories simply because psychotic symptoms, such as hearing voices or feeling paranoid, can exist as part of other illnesses, or even among healthy individuals.'b'Mental illness may not differ from other medical conditions in this regard. High blood pressure can occur during numerous illnesses, or even as a normal physiological response to stress. But no one would argue that hypertension isn\xe2\x80\x99t also a \xe2\x80\x9creal\xe2\x80\x9d medical diagnosis in itself, among individuals meeting certain criteria. Similarly, painkillers can bring effective relief without correcting whatever biological abnormality necessitates their use.'b'Indeed, as Ms. Luhrmann suggests, talk therapies can be very helpful for individuals with psychosis or other disabling symptoms, regardless of whether they target the root biological causes of these syndromes.'b'While destigmatizing schizophrenia and other psychiatric conditions remains essential, it does a disservice to patients to suggest that their illness is not legitimate, nor treatable by medication, simply because our biological understanding of these illnesses remains incomplete.'b'JOSHUA L. ROFFMAN'b'\nCharlestown, Mass., Jan. 19, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is an associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and director of the Brain Genomics Laboratory at Massachusetts General Hospital.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'T. M. Luhrmann hit the bull\xe2\x80\x99s eye. Contemporary neurobiological psychiatry, with its heavy reliance on treatment by diagnosis, presumes that each human life with a psychiatric illness is best explained by a disorder of brain biochemistry that needs to be corrected. However, psychiatric conditions and life narratives inform each other.'b'The effective psychiatric professional understands how to engage the person\xe2\x80\x99s condition and life narrative using tools of biology and psychosocial interventions so that impairment is diminished, while adaptive attitudes and behaviors are fostered.'b'MICHAEL J. DUKE'b'\nNew York, Jan. 12, 2015'b''b'DURHAM, N.C. \xe2\x80\x94 SINCE the terror attacks in Paris two weeks ago, the French police have been on the hunt for Hayat Boumeddiene, the partner of Amedy Coulibaly, one of the slain gunmen. She is now suspected to be in Syria. Some news reports speculate that Ms. Boumeddiene, 26, may have been \xe2\x80\x9c'b'the more radical of the two'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet one of the first questions that French authorities intend to ask her is, they say, \xe2\x80\x9cif she did this under influence, if she did it by ideology, if she did it to aid and abet.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While much will be made in the coming months of France\xe2\x80\x99s intelligence failures, the West\xe2\x80\x99s inability to appreciate the role that women play in terror should come under the highest scrutiny. Take the role of women in the Islamic State group, also known as 'b'ISIS'b' or ISIL. While the group oppresses many women, many also flock to its ranks. Roughly 10 percent of its Western recruits are female, often lured by their peers through social media and instant messaging. The percentage is much higher in France: An estimated 63 of the 350 French nationals believed to be with the group are women, or just under 20 percent.'b'This story is both a new one and an old one. Women have long been involved in terror of all stripes, from female neo-Nazis in Europe to Chechen \xe2\x80\x9cblack widow\xe2\x80\x9d suicide bombers.'b'Indeed, despite stereotypes about their domesticity and passivity \xe2\x80\x94 the idea that they must always be under men\xe2\x80\x99s influence or tricked into joining \xe2\x80\x94 women are drawn to groups like the Islamic State by many of the same forces as men: adventure, inequality, alienation and the pull of the cause.'b'Once there, they commit violence against other women, including as part of all-female brigades enforcing female morality codes requiring modest dress and sex segregation. They operate checkpoints and go on home raids; they are also reportedly recruiters, trainers of female suicide bombers, wives and homemakers, fund-raisers and propagandists. They also help sanitize the group\xe2\x80\x99s image by posting photos of themselves drinking milkshakes on Instagram and writing chatty, lighthearted tweets.'b'But the news media and policy makers are playing catch-up when it comes to understanding the full extent of women\xe2\x80\x99s roles in jihadist groups. A large part of the problem is the tendency to fixate on terrorist violence against women, whether it be Boko Haram\xe2\x80\x99s mass kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria or the Islamic State\xe2\x80\x99s sexual violence, slavery, kidnappings and forced marriage. We prefer to see terror through the lens of gender, positing radical Muslim men against women, with the West as their only defender.'b'Myths and misinformation abound. Islamic State fighters are afraid of Kurdish all-women brigades (they aren\xe2\x80\x99t). Women join groups like the Islamic State only to become \xe2\x80\x9cjihadi brides\xe2\x80\x9d (they don\xe2\x80\x99t). The Islamic State mandated 'b'female genital mutilation'b' in Mosul, Iraq (it didn\xe2\x80\x99t).'b'Aphorisms about the motivations of terrorists are appealing; if only it were true that, as the saying goes, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat terrorists fear most is educated girls.\xe2\x80\x9d But building schools and investing in girls\xe2\x80\x99 education should be long-term investments that are ends in themselves, not knee-jerk reactions to extremist violence. Merely defining the West in contrast to \xe2\x80\x9cbarbarism\xe2\x80\x9d and talking of \xe2\x80\x9crescuing\xe2\x80\x9d women fall short at best; at worst, doing so sets women up as symbolic targets for terrorist violence, squeezing them between terror and counterterror.'b'Instead, more attention must be paid to the specific factors that attract women to terrorist groups and the roles they play once there. For example, European women in the Islamic State have spoken of how alienation and restrictions on their religious practices back home, like France\xe2\x80\x99s ban on wearing burqas in public, helped push them into the group (Ms. Boumeddiene\xe2\x80\x99s reported loss of her job as a cashier for wearing the niqab should be examined in this light).'b'Efforts to prevent women from leaving for Iraq and Syria need to address such grievances, just as programs for those who return must be tailored to their specific experiences in the group. The strong influence of social media and peer networks also points to including more young women in these efforts, as well as female community leaders and family members.'b'This may not sound like much, but for some governments, such targeted approaches are a long way off. Many still deny women\xe2\x80\x99s involvement in terror at all, particularly in jihadist groups, or focus only on women\xe2\x80\x99s role in preventing men from radicalizing. Meanwhile, those same groups are deploying more female suicide bombers who can easily evade detection because of such blind spots. Earlier this month Boko Haram detonated bombs strapped to three girls \xe2\x80\x94 possibly some of the abducted schoolchildren \xe2\x80\x94 who were able to make it past security guards because of their age and gender.'b'Terrorists are strategic about using women, in increasingly chilling ways. To fight them, we have to move past simplistic assumptions about gender and terror and get serious about helping women and girls who are on this deadly path, as well as their would-be victims.'b'PRESIDENT OBAMA\xe2\x80\x99S economic proposals in Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s State of the Union address were a disappointment. His ideas \xe2\x80\x94 free community college, an enhanced tax credit for child care and higher taxes on high-income earners and large financial institutions \xe2\x80\x94 failed to go beyond mere talking points. With no chance of engaging the Republicans, they will surely die without a hearing.'b'But the president\xe2\x80\x99s proposals do invite a case for a comprehensive tax and entitlement reform, one based not on redistribution but on growth, work and opportunity.'b'Our unwillingness to confront mounting inefficiencies in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s tax code and growing obligations in entitlement programs has led to increasingly limited options.\xc2\xa0Corporate tax reform is held hostage to the misguided idea that tax cuts and tax increases must be balanced within the corporate sector alone, and to the faulty assumption that beneficial tax reform will not raise economic activity.'b'Piling up child tax credits and subsidies for health care over narrow household income ranges, as the president proposes, leads to high rates of taxation on earnings from work as assistance is phased out.\xc2\xa0Likewise, raising marginal tax rates on investment by the well-to-do reduces asset prices and is a threat to continued economic expansion.'b'So how 'b'can 'b'we enhance growth, work and opportunity? Four steps can help get us there.'b'The first is to move to a simple business tax system, with a lower marginal tax rate and no special industry preferences. There would be no separate corporate tax, only a single business income tax for all businesses. Ideally, investment would be expensed, and its cost deducted in the year it was made, rather than deducted gradually. Businesses would be able to bring back overseas profits free of additional United States taxes. A one-time modest tax on current overseas earning could be used to help finance reform. Such a business income tax would encourage both growth and investment opportunities in the United States, while offering more jobs and higher wages to American workers.'b'The second step is to use the individual income tax to better reward work. The top tax rate for most Americans would be the same as the business income tax rate. To maintain progressivity, a surtax on wages would be collected on very high earners. To make work more attractive, low-income workers, including single workers, would receive an expanded earned-income tax credit and a tax credit to buy health insurance (as opposed to the more complex subsidies that exist under the Affordable Care Act). The earned-income tax credit would be phased out gradually.'b'Workers would have the choice of switching to options available under current law for employer-provided health insurance and a health savings account, or a tax deduction for their own health insurance and health savings account as incomes rise. Reductions in marginal tax rates to support work would be paid for by limits on tax deductions for more affluent households.'b'The third step focuses on education and training. Like investment in technology and machines, investment in human capital should be deductible from income. Out-of-pocket educational expenses for bona fide\xc2\xa0schooling and vocational training could be tax deductible for all but affluent households. Personal re-employment accounts could be made available to all individuals facing more than temporary unemployment, with individual financial support for training and a bonus for re-employment.'b'The fourth step is to strengthen retirement security, while acknowledging the need for fiscal consolidation in entitlement spending. Minimum benefits for Social Security and Medicare could be strengthened to ensure that people with low lifetime incomes avoid poverty in old age. To reduce future deficits in these programs and to free up funds to support work and opportunity for younger workers in the future, Social Security benefit growth would be slowed for more affluent individuals.'b'In the same spirit, changing Medicare so that individuals would purchase insurance from one of a number of competing plans, with the federal government paying part of the cost, could focus the largest subsidies for health insurance on those with low lifetime incomes. Converting Medicaid to a block grant \xe2\x80\x94 in which federal support would be turned over to states \xe2\x80\x94 would give governors the flexibility to support health insurance tax credits for low-income residents, community health centers or other experiments in health insurance and delivery at the state level.'b'These four steps offer a road map for growth, work and opportunity without sacrificing income security. Other policies, including free trade, open competition and immigration reform, are also important. But these four steps can take place in a budget discussion, and congressional leaders and the White House have both emphasized the need for a more timely budget resolution.'b'While the reforms I sketched are comprehensive, they can be implemented in discrete steps \xe2\x80\x94 no \xe2\x80\x9cgrand bargain\xe2\x80\x9d is required. And realistic proposals to advance growth, work and opportunity, not ideological talking points, are what we need right now.'b'So the Republican establishment is breathing easy now that the Supreme Court is on the verge of issuing a ruling in favor of 'b'same-sex marriage'b', thus taking the question out of nasty old politics? \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s probably going to be a relief,\xe2\x80\x9d a Republican committeeman from California 'b'told'b' Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin of The New York Times, explaining that with such a ruling, \xe2\x80\x9cthen it\xe2\x80\x99s off the table.\xe2\x80\x9d Praise the Lord and thank the court.'b'You have to admire the chutzpah of party operatives whose national platform calls for limiting marriage to opposite-sex couples, and for whom denouncing \xe2\x80\x9cjudicial activism\xe2\x80\x9d is usually as natural as saluting the flag, lining up right behind the justices who they hope will relieve them of the pesky problem of choosing sides in a fast-fading culture war.'b'But the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 sighs of relief are premature: not because the court will let them down by sending the marriage issue back to the states (of course it may, but I doubt it will), but because marriage equality isn\xe2\x80\x99t the end of the story. It is only, to borrow from Winston Churchill, the end of the beginning.'b'Last April, the Supreme Court ducked 'b'a case'b' that pitted the asserted right of a company \xe2\x80\x94 a New Mexico wedding photography shop \xe2\x80\x94 to refuse to provide its services to a same-sex couple against the couple\xe2\x80\x99s right to be served like anyone else by a business licensed to open its doors to the public. The company, Elane Photography, had lost in the New Mexico Supreme Court. It brought a free-speech claim on appeal, arguing that its owner was being compelled by the state (New Mexico\xe2\x80\x99s Human Rights Act covers sexual orientation) to use her \xe2\x80\x9cexpressive\xe2\x80\x9d photographic talents in violation of her religious beliefs.'b'The justices turned the appeal down without comment or recorded dissent. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean the court didn\xe2\x80\x99t look closely at the case, Elane Photography v. Willock, which it took to its closed-door, justices-only conference for three consecutive weeks. And that case was just the leading edge of a pipeline\xe2\x80\x99s worth of cases in which florists, bakers and owners of wedding venues are invoking claims of conscience to shield them from having to do business with gay men and lesbians.'b'If this issue appears less than earth-shattering \xe2\x80\x94 won\xe2\x80\x99t there always be a friendlier florist, baker or hotel owner around the corner? \xe2\x80\x94 then try substituting \xe2\x80\x9cinterracial couple\xe2\x80\x9d as the object of discrimination in the years after the Supreme Court, in 'b'Loving v. Virginia'b', struck down state prohibitions on interracial marriage. Of course, by 1967, when the court ruled in Loving, Congress had passed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, with its prohibition against racial discrimination in employment and public accommodations. (It took until 1983, in the 'b'Bob Jones case'b', for the court to rule that a university that claimed a religious basis for a ban on interracial dating among its students was therefore ineligible for tax-exempt status.) There is no federal anti-discrimination law that applies to sexual orientation, and 29 states lack such laws as well.'b'A federal measure called the Employment Non-Discrimination Act, protecting gays and lesbians against discrimination on the job, has been pending for years. A version passed the Senate in 2013 but died in the Republican-controlled House. Some major gay-rights groups withdrew their support for the bill last year because the current version contains such a broad set of religion-based exemptions. For example, a religious organization is permitted to require broad categories of employees \xe2\x80\x94 well beyond those who directly serve the organization\xe2\x80\x99s religious mission \xe2\x80\x94 to adhere to a set of \xe2\x80\x9csignificant religious tenets,\xe2\x80\x9d the definition of which would not be subject to judicial review, that plausibly would make it impossible for a gay person to obtain or keep a job.'b'A bill now pending in the Virginia House of Delegates would permit any licensed business, private or public, to refuse service to gay or bisexual people because of \xe2\x80\x9creligious or moral convictions\xe2\x80\x9d held by the business owner \xe2\x80\x9cwith respect to same-sex \xe2\x80\x98marriage\xe2\x80\x99 or homosexual behavior.\xe2\x80\x9d (The bill\xe2\x80\x99s sponsor, Delegate Bob Marshall, a co-sponsor of the state\xe2\x80\x99s ban on same-sex marriage that was struck down last year in federal court, placed the word \xe2\x80\x9cmarriage\xe2\x80\x9d in quotes in the text of the bill.)'b'If the Virginia bill got through the Legislature, Terry McAuliffe, the state\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic governor, would veto it. It won\xe2\x80\x99t become law, but in the meantime, every Republican legislator in the increasingly purple state will have to choose sides.'b'The fact is that religion is on the march, and it can only be emboldened by the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s ruling last June in the 'b'Hobby Lobby case'b'. That decision, the legal consequences of which are still playing out, permitted an employer running an ordinary for-profit retail business to claim a religious exemption from compliance with the federal requirement to include contraception coverage in its employee insurance plan. (And on Tuesday of this week, the court abandoned its age-old stance of deference toward prison administrators and ruled that a Muslim prison inmate had the right under federal law to keep a beard despite the Arkansas prison\xe2\x80\x99s ban on facial hair. While Islam does not require men to wear beards, the inmate\xe2\x80\x99s belief that he should have one was sufficiently \xe2\x80\x9csincere\xe2\x80\x9d to invoke the statute\xe2\x80\x99s protections, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. 'b'wrote'b' for the unanimous court.)'b'However the justices proceed to resolve the increasingly audacious claims of religious conscience in a post-Hobby Lobby, post-marriage equality world, it\xe2\x80\x99s safe to predict that politicians will be confronting these issues under the glare of a public spotlight. Republicans who expect the Supreme Court to give them a pass from having to take a stand are in for a rude surprise.'b'The same might be said of the consequences for Republicans of prevailing in their latest attack on the Affordable Care Act. This spring, the Supreme Court will hear 'b'arguments'b' in King v. Burwell, the cynical effort manufactured by right-wing think tanks to unravel the law (I\xe2\x80\x99ve 'b'written'b' about this case previously.) At stake is whether the insurance exchanges the federal government set up when 36 Republican-led states refused to set up their own will be dismantled, and whether the millions people who bought subsidized policies on the federal exchanges will have to look elsewhere or go without.'b'Leading Republicans, including Mitch McConnell, now the Senate majority leader, 'b'cheered'b' when the court agreed to hear the case. Suppose constituents who have paid no attention to the seemingly arcane issue in the case turn to their Republican governors and say something like: The Supreme Court says the law will work only with state exchanges, so why can\xe2\x80\x99t we have a state exchange? In other words: Save our insurance.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s been grimly amusing to watch the scramble that\xe2\x80\x99s now taking place as some of the Affordable Care Act\xe2\x80\x99s most prominent detractors realize they might actually need something with which to placate not only consumers but also the insurance and health care industries. Randy E. Barnett, an architect of the original constitutional attack on the law, published 'b'an op-ed'b' last month in USA Today under the title \xe2\x80\x9cHow to Finally Kill Obamacare.\xe2\x80\x9d Republicans \xe2\x80\x9cneed to start right away,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, in order to have a \xe2\x80\x9cwell-vetted replacement in the pipeline\xe2\x80\x9d that would serve the additional purpose of assuring the justices that they would not simply be tossing millions of people into a void. Among his proposals is to \xe2\x80\x9crestore the private insurance market\xe2\x80\x9d by pricing insurance \xe2\x80\x9caccording to risk\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 in other words, to do away with a centerpiece of the current law, which relies on the principles of \xe2\x80\x9cguaranteed issue\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccommunity rating\xe2\x80\x9d to bar insurers from penalizing people who have ever actually needed medical care.'b'A Wall Street Journal op-ed by Yuval Levin and James C.
