That was evident in the 2014 election.'b'RICHARD A. ROSEN'b'\nMount Vernon, N.Y., Jan. 21, 2015'b''b'I grew up in the small town of Gibsland, in northern Louisiana. It is dirt poor, but proud. And it\xe2\x80\x99s an overwhelmingly African-American community.'b'(There are fewer than 1,000 people in Gibsland; more than 80 percent of them are black; the median household income is $27,292, little over half the national average of $51,939; and the poverty rate is 28 percent, compared with the national rate of 15 percent.)'b'My mother, one of my brothers and a raft of relatives still live in Gibsland. Another brother moved to the next town over, Minden, a big city relatively speaking (it has 13,000 people), where he is a high school teacher. Minden, just west of Gibsland, is also majority African-American and relatively poor \xe2\x80\x94 55 percent of the residents are black, the median household income is $30,411 and 24 percent of the residents are poor.'b'For years, one of the largest employers in that area was the Louisiana Army Ammunition Plant, about four miles from Minden. The Environmental Protection Agency eventually listed the plant as a Superfund site because for more than 40 years \xe2\x80\x9cuntreated explosives-laden wastewater from industrial operations was collected in concrete sumps at each of the various load line areas,\xe2\x80\x9d and emptied into \xe2\x80\x9c16 one-acre pink water lagoons.\xe2\x80\x9d It was determined that the toxic contamination in soil and sediments from the lagoons was a \xe2\x80\x9cmajor contributor\xe2\x80\x9d to toxic groundwater contamination.'b'But wait, it gets worse.'b'When the plant ceased production, as The Times-Picayune of New Orleans pointed out, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Army awarded now-bankrupt Explo Systems a contract in 2010 to \xe2\x80\x98demilitarize\xe2\x80\x99 the propellant charges for artillery rounds\xe2\x80\x9d on the site. The company conducted \xe2\x80\x9coperations\xe2\x80\x9d there \xe2\x80\x9cuntil a 2012 explosion sent a mushroom cloud 7,000 feet high and broke windows a mile away in Doyline,\xe2\x80\x9d another small community in the area.'b'But wait, it gets worse.'b''b'According to The Shreveport Times'b', \xe2\x80\x9cinvestigation by state police found the millions of pounds of propellant stored in 98 bunkers scattered around\xe2\x80\x9d the site. It turned out that when Explo went bankrupt, it simply abandoned the explosives, known as M6. Now there was a risk of even more explosions, so there was need for a plan to get rid of the M6, and quickly.'b'(By the way, Shreveport is the largest city near the site, and it, too, is majority black, has a median household income well below the national average and a poverty rate well above it.)'b'But wait, it gets worse.'b'According to the website Truthout:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAfter months of bureaucratic disputes between the Army and state and federal agencies, the Environmental Protection Agency (E.P.A.) recently announced an emergency plan to burn 15 million pounds of M6 \xe2\x80\x94 up to 80,000 pounds a day over the course of a year \xe2\x80\x94 on open \xe2\x80\x98burn trays\xe2\x80\x99 at Camp Minden, a disposal process that environmental advocates say is outdated and has been outlawed in other countries. The operation would be one of the largest open munitions burn in U.S. history.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed, Robert Flournoy, an environmental toxicologist and former Louisiana Tech professor, wrote in The Shreveport Times this week:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe E.P.A. says this is a safe way to destroy the propellant. I strongly disagree with their decision and their safety statement. I have over 42 years of environmental experience and can say without a doubt the open-tray method is not safe. The E.P.A. has produced no data to the safety of such a burn and repeatedly ignores requests for such data from media, citizens, state officials and environmental professionals. In addition to the air contamination risk, we have three other issues: explosive detonation, groundwater contamination and soil contamination.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And yes, again, it gets worse.'b'A local television news station, KTBS in Shreveport, pointed out last week:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s expected to be the nation\xe2\x80\x99s largest open burn in history. And now, it seems there\xe2\x80\x99s even more explosive material at Camp Minden than we all previously thought. We\xe2\x80\x99ve all heard the number 15 million pounds of explosives, but documents from the E.P.A. show there\xe2\x80\x99s millions more pounds.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This week, a group of \xe2\x80\x9c71 social and environmental justice organizations\xe2\x80\x9d across the country 'b'sent a letter of protest'b' to the E.P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s assistant administrator Cynthia Giles, saying in part:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy definition, open burning has no emissions controls and will result in the uncontrolled release of toxic emissions and respirable particulates to the environment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Feeling the pressure from local citizen and environmentalist rightly concerned about the immediate and long-term health implications, the E.P.A. recently delayed the burn by 90 days to allow the state\xe2\x80\x99s department of environmental quality and the National Guard to \xe2\x80\x9cselect their own alternative for disposing of the explosive material,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'according to The Times-Picayune'b'.'b'Still, these little places in the woods aren\xe2\x80\x99t yet out of the woods. It\xe2\x80\x99s still not clear what will eventually happen with the explosives.'b'We have to stop and ask: How was this allowed to come to such a pass in the first place? How could this plant have been allowed to contaminate the groundwater for 40 years? How could the explosives have been left at the site in the first place? How is it that there doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be the money or the will to more safely remove them? Can we imagine anyone, with a straight face, proposing to openly burn millions of pounds of explosives near Manhattan or Seattle?'b'This is the kind of scenario that some might place under the umbrella of \xe2\x80\x9cenvironmental racism,\xe2\x80\x9d in which disproportionately low-income and minority communities are either targeted or disproportionately exposed to toxic and hazardous materials and waste facilities.'b'There is a long history in this country of exposing vulnerable populations to toxicity.'b'Fifteen years ago, Robert D. Bullard published 'b'Dumping in Dixie: Race, Class and Environmental Quality'b'. In it, he pointed out that nearly 60 percent of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s hazardous-waste landfill capacity was in \xe2\x80\x9cfive Southern states (i.e., Alabama, Louisiana, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Texas),\xe2\x80\x9d and that \xe2\x80\x9cfour landfills in minority ZIP codes areas represented 63 percent of the South\xe2\x80\x99s total hazardous-waste capacity\xe2\x80\x9d although \xe2\x80\x9cblacks make up only about 20 percent of the South\xe2\x80\x99s total population.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More recently, in 2012, a study by researchers at Yale found that \xe2\x80\x9cThe greater the concentration of Hispanics, Asians, African-Americans or poor residents in an area, the more likely that potentially dangerous compounds such as vanadium, nitrates and zinc are in the mix of fine particles they breathe.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Among the injustices perpetrated on poor and minority populations, this may in fact be the most pernicious and least humane: the threat of poisoning the very air that you breathe.'b'I have skin in this game. My family would fall in the shadow of the plume. But everyone should be outraged about this practice. Of all the measures of equality we deserve, the right to feel assured and safe when you draw a breath should be paramount.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s raise the gas tax.'b'There are several reasons we need to discuss this now. One is that plummeting gasoline prices make the idea very timely. Also, people will be asking you this week what you thought of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s State of the Union address. Even though he did not mention the gas tax, bringing it up will allow you to avoid having an opinion on whether it\xe2\x80\x99s time to close the capital gains stepped-up-basis loophole.'b'The gas tax raises much-needed money for roads and mass transit. Our roads, you may have noticed, are falling apart. Every time you hit a pothole, yell: \xe2\x80\x9cRaise the gas tax!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Even more important, it encourages Americans to use fuel-efficient cars. While we\xe2\x80\x99re all happy as clams about falling gas prices, every gallon produces more than 19 pounds of planet-warming emissions. We just had the hottest year on record. The ice floes are melting. Walruses keep piling up along the Alaskan shore, where the babies can get squashed.'b'Raise the gas tax and remember the walruses.'b'Plus, it\xe2\x80\x99s not really a tax! Or at least not necessarily. Just ask Ronald Reagan. When he entered office, Reagan said he didn\xe2\x80\x99t see the likelihood of a gas tax increase \xe2\x80\x9cunless there\xe2\x80\x99s a palace coup.\xe2\x80\x9d But then, you know, stuff happened and The Great Communicator discovered that a levy on gasoline wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really a tax, but merely a \xe2\x80\x9cuser fee.\xe2\x80\x9d So no problem at all, and under his administration the, um, fee was more than doubled.'b'Ah, Ronald Reagan. Perhaps you noticed, during the State of the Union, that President Obama was urging Congress to bring the capital gains tax back up to Reagan-era levels? Who\xe2\x80\x99d have thought? We live in ironic times, people.'b'But about the gas tax. It was also raised under George H.W. (The Good One) Bush, and then again under Bill Clinton. Remember Al Gore breaking the tie in the Senate? Ah, Al Gore.'b'And that was it. The federal gas tax, currently 18.4 cents a gallon, is not indexed for inflation, and it has not gone up since 1993. The Highway Trust Fund, which pays for the federal highway construction program, keeps falling deeper into the red. It\xe2\x80\x99s currently scheduled to implode sometime this spring.'b'The White House has been very clear about its lack of enthusiasm for solving the problem with a gas tax increase. Mainly, the objection is that if Congress wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t pass Obama\xe2\x80\x99s proposal to pay for early education with a tobacco tax, it\xe2\x80\x99s not going to fund road repair with a gas tax. This is a pretty good point. However, deeply cynical souls could also argue that the current majority likes road construction more than preschool.'b'During the State of the Union, Obama made his pitch for another idea: reform the tax on overseas business profits, creating a one-time-only windfall of revenue for the government to use in a mega-road-building spree.'b'Three reasons the gas tax is a better idea:'b'1) Walruses.'b'2) Half the members of Congress are eyeing that very same windfall to pay for their own pet programs.'b'3) Only works once. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just a coward\xe2\x80\x99s way out,\xe2\x80\x9d says Senator Bob Corker, a Tennessee Republican. Genuine fiscal conservatives hate the idea of paying for permanent ongoing programs with one-shot revenues. Corker has been known to complain that he\xe2\x80\x99s been in the Senate for eight years and never saw Congress permanently solve a problem.'b'Last year Corker and Senator Chris Murphy, a Democrat of Connecticut, floated the idea of raising the gas tax 12 cents over two years. \xe2\x80\x9cOur bet when we went out on a limb last year was that we could position it as a topic for serious discussion this year, and I hope it\xe2\x80\x99s going to pay off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Murphy.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s working, sort of. A number of prominent Republicans have been muttering things like \xe2\x80\x9cnothing is off the table.\xe2\x80\x9d Senator James Inhofe, the new chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, and a man whose position on global warming makes him an enemy to walruses everywhere, has said a gas tax is \xe2\x80\x9cone of the options.\xe2\x80\x9d An option that is not off the table! Truly, the worm has turned.'b'On the other hand, Representative Paul Ryan, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, recently announced: \xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t pass a gas tax.\xe2\x80\x9d That would seem to be somewhat discouraging, but there are still these gleams of hope that Republicans might come around since:'b'\xe2\x80\x94 You can call it a user fee. (Ask Ronald Reagan.)'b'\xe2\x80\x94 President Obama doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like it.'b'\xe2\x80\x94 Compromise is possible. Many conservatives hate the fact that the Highway Trust Fund also helps support mass transit and invests in things like highway beautification and bike paths. There might be some room for give here. Let\xe2\x80\x99s throw something in the fund under the proverbial bus. I nominate \xe2\x80\x9ctransportation museums.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Walrus seconds the motion.'b'As presented in 'b'his State of the State address'b' on Wednesday, 'b'Gov. Andrew Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s ambitious projects'b' for his second term include a much-needed increase in the minimum wage, reform of the justice system, some forgiveness of student loans and a new commission to determine fair pay for legislators. At the top of his list is reforming the New York\xe2\x80\x99s educational system. This is a laudable undertaking that has long needed addressing, Mr. Cuomo said, but also one that will put him directly at loggerheads with the powerful teachers\xe2\x80\x99 unions.'b'The governor left unanswered a raft of questions, including whether he\xe2\x80\x99s really getting to the heart of the problem. Most of New York\xe2\x80\x99s educational difficulties are about money, beginning with the politically skewed and unfair way the Legislature hands out money for schools, often depriving the poorest and the least politically powerful districts of the funds and support they need.'b'The governor, who also used the speech to outline a $150 billion budget, conceded that his proposals would be hard to pass in a Legislature divided between a Democratic Assembly and a Republican Senate. But he made clear his willingness to use the budget as a cudgel, which he has become particularly adept at doing. If the Legislature passes his reforms, he said, he would add an additional $1.1 billion (or 4.8 percent) in the pot for schools. If not, he warned, he would limit the increase to 1.7 percent.'b'Among Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s top priorities is to revamp a teacher evaluation system that he calls \xe2\x80\x9cbaloney.\xe2\x80\x9d Fewer than 1 percent of the state\xe2\x80\x99s teachers were rated ineffective in the most recent evaluations, while only about a third of the state\xe2\x80\x99s students in grades 3 through 8 were proficient in math and language arts. He wants to make it harder for teachers to get tenure and easier to fire ineffective and bad teachers. He wants to bring in a receiver or turnaround specialist to take over schools designated as failing for three years. And he wants to increase the number of charter schools while adding an \xe2\x80\x9canti-creaming\xe2\x80\x9d provision to make certain these schools don\xe2\x80\x99t pick the best students. He wants to require these schools to take a certain percentage of poor or disadvantaged students.'b'Holding the $23.1 billion education budget hostage to reform, however, could mean shorting the state\xe2\x80\x99s schoolchildren. Most estimates of the need, particularly in poorer areas, run from $2 billion to more than $5 billion a year over the present budget.'b'Many of his proposals are likely to ignite the ire of teachers\xe2\x80\x99 unions that did not endorse him in the last election, and he can expect considerable resistance from them and their friends in Albany. On the whole, these provisions make good sense. In the long run, however, the most important thing he can do to help the system and the students it is meant to serve is to make sure that all districts \xe2\x80\x94 not just the wealthier ones \xe2\x80\x94 receive the money they need.'b'Since the end of the 1970s, something has gone profoundly wrong in America.'b'Inequality has soared. 'b'Educational progress slowed'b'. Incarceration rates quintupled. Family breakdown accelerated. Median household income stagnated.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s morning again in America\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that was a campaign slogan by President Ronald Reagan in 1984. But, in retrospect, the average American has been stuck since the Reagan era in a predawn darkness of stagnation and inequality, and we still haven\xe2\x80\x99t shaken it off, particularly since 2000. Inequality has increased further under President Obama.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the context for Obama\xe2\x80\x99s call, in 'b'his State of the Union address'b', for greater economic fairness. But first, the caveats. His proposals are dead on arrival in Congress. They won\xe2\x80\x99t be implemented and probably won\xe2\x80\x99t change the public\xe2\x80\x99s thinking: 'b'Research by George C. Edwards'b', a political scientist, finds that presidential speeches rarely persuade the public much.'b'Remember the 2014 State of the Union address? Of course not. Of 18 proposals in it, there was action on two, 'b'according to PBS'b'. Or Obama\xe2\x80\x99s passionate call in his 2013 State of the Union for measures to reduce gun violence? Nothing much resulted, and the word \xe2\x80\x9cguns\xe2\x80\x9d didn\xe2\x80\x99t even pass his lips this time.'b'Yet the bully pulpit still can shape the national agenda and nag at the American conscience. I don\xe2\x80\x99t fully agree with Obama\xe2\x80\x99s solutions \xe2\x80\x94 how could he skip over early-childhood interventions?! \xe2\x80\x94 but he\xe2\x80\x99s exactly right in the way he framed the inequality issue: \xe2\x80\x9cWill we accept an economy where only a few of us do spectacularly well?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some background. Even with the global Great Depression, the United States performed brilliantly in the first three-quarters of the 20th century, with incomes and education mostly rising and inequality flat or falling \xe2\x80\x94 and gains were broadly shared by poor and rich alike. High school graduation rates surged, G.I.\xe2\x80\x99s went to college, and the United States led the world in educational attainment.'b'And, in part of this remarkable era, the top federal income tax rate 'b'exceeded 90 percent'b'. Republicans might remember that point when they warn that Obama\xe2\x80\x99s proposals for modestly higher taxes would savage the American economy.'b'Then, for average Americans, the roof fell in around the end of the 1970s. The \xe2\x80\x9970s were \xe2\x80\x9cthe end of normal,\xe2\x80\x9d the economist James K. Galbraith argues in a new book of that title. Afterward, the economy continued to grow over all, but the spoils went to the wealthy and the bottom 90 percent barely benefited.'b'Median household income is little greater today than it was in 1979. Today, 'b'the typical family in Canada appears better off'b' than the typical American family.'b'By some measures, education \xe2\x80\x94 our seed corn for the future \xe2\x80\x94 has pretty much stalled. More young American men today have less education than their parents (29 percent) than have more education (20 percent). Among industrialized countries as a whole, 70 percent of 3-year-olds go to preschool; in the United States, 38 percent do.'b'I wonder if the celebration of unfettered capitalism and \xe2\x80\x9cgreed is good\xe2\x80\x9d since the Reagan era didn\xe2\x80\x99t help shape social mores in ways that accelerated inequality.'b'In any case, Reagan was right on one point \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthe best social program is a productive job\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and Obama offered sound proposals to increase incentives for work. Better child-care and sick-leave policies would also make work more feasible. The United States is the only country among the 34 in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development that provides no paid maternity leave.'b'Oddly, Obama didn\xe2\x80\x99t push early-childhood initiatives, focused on kids from newborns to 5 years old, that have a particularly strong evidence base for creating opportunity.'b'Early-education initiatives poll well, and some of the leaders in programming have been red states like Oklahoma. So while the Obama agenda is mostly for show, expansion of preschool could actually occur at least at the state level.'b'Obama rightly heralded the fall in teenage pregnancy rates. But he had little to do with it (although the MTV show \xe2\x80\x9c16 and Pregnant\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'played a role!'b'), and about 30 percent of American girls still get pregnant by age 19. Making reliable birth control available to at-risk teenagers 'b'would help them'b', reduce abortion rates and even pay for itself in reduced social spending later.'b'In America, 'b'we have subsidized private jets'b', big banks and hedge fund managers. Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it make more sense to subsidize kids? So if higher capital gains taxes can pay for better education, infrastructure and jobs, of course that trade-off is worthwhile.'b'Congressional Republicans seem focused on a pipeline that isn\xe2\x80\x99t even economically viable at today\xe2\x80\x99s oil prices. Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope that the national agenda can broaden along the lines that Obama suggests, so that the last 35 years become an aberration rather than a bellwether.'b'Under Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., the Supreme Court has developed a remarkably sanguine view of race in America. \xe2\x80\x9cThings have changed dramatically,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Roberts 'b'wrote'b' in 2013 in striking down the heart of the Voting Rights Act.'b'In other words, he seemed to suggest, this is no longer the country of Bull Connor and fire hoses, and any lingering effects of our entrenched history of racial discrimination are best dealt with if everyone would simply agree to treat each other as equals.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Roberts 'b'wrote'b' in a 2007 case.'b'The court\xe2\x80\x99s latest target in its quest for a race-blind nation is the 'b'Fair Housing Act'b', approved by Congress in 1968 as the final cornerstone of civil rights legislation and broadened in 1988. The act makes it illegal to refuse to sell, rent \xe2\x80\x9cor otherwise make unavailable or deny\xe2\x80\x9d a property to anyone because of race, sex or other protected categories.'b'The question before the judges during oral arguments on Wednesday morning was this: Does that language require that the discrimination be intentional, or does it allow plaintiffs to claim a discriminatory effect, regardless of intent?'b'If ever there was a legal issue that appeared to be settled, this is it. Over four decades, every one of the 11 federal appeals courts to consider the law has found that it covers claims of discriminatory effect. A 2013 'b'regulation'b' issued by the Department of Housing and Urban Development provides explicitly for such claims.'b'This legal consensus is easy to understand. The law was meant to be a broad and powerful tool against the effects of unjust discrimination in housing. Today, persistent housing segregation remains a fact of life for many blacks, with a range of adverse consequences including poorer economic prospects, lower property values and inferior public schools.'b'The ability to show discriminatory effect has only become more important as intentional discrimination has become harder to prove. To take one prominent example, the Justice Department relied on it to negotiate 'b'the largest-ever fair-lending settlement'b' \xe2\x80\x94 $335 million \xe2\x80\x94 with Bank of America in 2011. The bank\xe2\x80\x99s mortgage unit, Countrywide Financial, had charged higher average fees and interest rates to black and Latino borrowers than to whites with the same credit risk, a practice that former assistant attorney general Thomas Perez called \xe2\x80\x9cdiscrimination with a smile.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Even so, the Roberts court had agreed on two earlier occasions to review the scope of the act, suggesting to many people that it is not happy with the law\xe2\x80\x99s mainstream interpretation. The cases were withdrawn or settled at the last minute, with help from the federal government and civil-rights groups worried about how the court would rule.'b'On Wednesday, the justices finally 'b'got their shot'b' \xe2\x80\x94 a third case, out of Dallas, involving federal tax credits that encourage developers to build low-income housing.'b'The challengers argue that the law\xe2\x80\x99s language was never meant to cover anything beyond intentional discrimination. If it did, they say, insurers, developers and lenders could be forced to make race-based decisions in order to avoid liability under the law.'b'During oral argument, Justice Antonin Scalia appeared to support the law\xe2\x80\x99s broader reading. When Congress amended the act in 1988, 'b'he reminded'b' the challengers\xe2\x80\x99 lawyer, it was clearly aware of the discriminatory effect standard, yet did not write it out of the law. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t that kill your case?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.'b'The Fair Housing Act has functioned well, and to the benefit of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable renters and home buyers, for more than 40 years. The court could demonstrate a greater appreciation of the stubborn and long-term effects of racial discrimination, not to mention a basic respect for the expertise of a federal agency, by upholding the universal interpretation of the appellate courts.'b'When we think of the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, certain events tend to come to mind: the March on Washington, for example, or perhaps the Freedom Rides or sit-ins. Others, however, have faded from our collective memory. One of those is the story of the Black Panther Party, the subject of this Op-Doc video. Founded in 1966 in Oakland, Calif., to combat police violence, the Black Panther Party and its story are a key part of our nation\xe2\x80\x99s still-complicated racial narrative.'b'When it was conceived, the Black Panther Party called for \xe2\x80\x9can immediate end to police brutality and murder of Black people.\xe2\x80\x9d Relying on the right to bear arms contained in the Second Amendment to the Constitution, the Panthers organized armed citizen patrols to monitor police behavior. It was a controversial approach to an intractable problem, but it provoked important debate.'b'Of course, the police violence and misconduct that inspired the founding of the Black Panther Party 50 years ago have not gone away. In just the last six months, the deaths of Michael Brown, John Crawford III, Eric Garner and Tamir Rice \xe2\x80\x93 and the lack of indictment of police officers for any of their deaths \xe2\x80\x94 have shaken black communities to the core.'b'But today, unlike in the 1960s, there are no shootouts between protesters and police. There are no organized groups calling for armed revolution on the evening news. Young people protesting police violence are armed not with rifles, but cellphones; shouting not \xe2\x80\x9cOff the Pig,\xe2\x80\x9d but \xe2\x80\x9cHands Up, Don\xe2\x80\x99t Shoot,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI Can\xe2\x80\x99t Breathe.\xe2\x80\x9d Though the problems remain the same, the protests are different. What we\xe2\x80\x99re waiting to see is whether police departments and elected officials will be any more responsive to demands for change and accountability than they were 50 years ago.'b'Yes, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the March on Washington are part of the political legacy inherited by today\xe2\x80\x99s activists. But so too is the Black Panther Party. Both stories inform not only where we are today, but also where we might be heading.'b''b'This video is part of a series produced by independent filmmakers who have received major support from the Ford Foundation and additional support from the nonprofit Sundance Institute.'b''b'Op-Docs is The New York Times editorial department\xe2\x80\x99s award-winning forum for short, opinionated documentaries, produced with wide creative latitude and a range of artistic styles, covering current affairs, contemporary life and historical subjects.'b'Op-Doc videos are produced by both renowned and emerging filmmakers who express their views in the first person, through their subjects, or more subtly through an artistic approach to a topic. Each Op-Doc is accompanied by a director\xe2\x80\x99s statement.'b'Since we started Op-Docs in 2011, we have introduced several series: Scenes (for very short work \xe2\x80\x94 snippets of street life, brief observations and interviews, clips from experimental works), Verbatim (which transforms legal transcripts into dramaticperformances), and Animated Life (which explores pivotal moments of scientific discovery). Interactive and multimedia special projects include \xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Short History of the Highrise'b'\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Notes on Blindness'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Honors for Op-Docs include two News and Documentary Emmy Awards, a Peabody Award and the World Press Photo Multimedia Award for Interactive Documentary \xe2\x80\x94 as well as official selections at leading international film festivals (including Sundance, the New York Film Festival, Telluride, SXSW and Sheffield Doc/Fest).'b'Join the conversation on Twitter: Follow the comissioning editor for opinion video, Kathleen Lingo ('b'@kLL5'b'), and 'b'@nytopinion'b' for updates. You may submit an Op-Doc through this 'b'pitching form'b'. Send comments or queries to 'b'opinion.video@nytimes.com'b'.'b'The Obama administration has taken 'b'two actions'b' that seem a refreshing departure from six years of aggressively attacking investigative journalism. The Justice Department abandoned an attempt to force James Risen, a New York Times reporter, to testify about a confidential source. And it tempered internal guidelines for trying to obtain records or testimony from the news media during leak investigations.'b'But these developments are gallingly late, and they do not really settle the big issues raised by President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s devoted pursuit of whistle-blowers and the reporters who receive their information.'b'Mr. Risen was being threatened with a jail sentence in the trial of Jeffrey Sterling, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer who is charged with providing classified information for a chapter in a book by Mr. Risen detailing a botched covert effort during the Clinton administration to thwart Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program. The decision not to try to compel Mr. Risen\xe2\x80\x99s testimony was announced in a court motion last week \xe2\x80\x94 but only after Mr. Risen was made to testify at a pretrial hearing and said he would neither reveal his confidential sources nor provide details that might help the government identify them.'b'Soon after the motion was filed, the Justice Department announced a revision in guidelines on leak investigations to delete a reference that offered protections only to \xe2\x80\x9cordinary news-gathering activities\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a vague term that could have been exploited by zealous prosecutors.'b'Both shifts seemed like an attempt by Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. to soften his reputation before he leaves office. It\xe2\x80\x99s not yet clear whether they mean more respect over time for the crucial role of a free press and the ability of reporters to protect their sources.'b'They do not erase the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s record of bringing more leak cases than all the president\xe2\x80\x99s predecessors combined. Beyond the Risen case, the Justice Department secretly subpoenaed telephone records from Associated Press reporters and editors during a leak investigation and obtained a search warrant for a Fox News reporter\xe2\x80\x99s emails as part of another inquiry.'b'The abandoned pursuit of Mr. Risen leaves behind an atrocious legal precedent: a 2-to-1 ruling in 2013 by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Virginia, which denied the existence of any reporter\xe2\x80\x99s privilege in the First Amendment or common law. That position was advocated by the Justice Department, and it was repeated in briefs asking the Supreme Court to deny Mr. Risen\xe2\x80\x99s request for review, which it did. The Fourth Circuit includes Maryland and Virginia, home to most national security agencies.'b'Two things are clear. First, dedicated journalists like Mr. Risen are willing to stand up to protect the identity of their sources. The second is the need for a strong federal shield law broadly protective of reporters who do that under the pressure of a high-profile leak investigation.'b'BERLIN \xe2\x80\x94 I am a patriot. Being German, those words don\xe2\x80\x99t come easily, particularly for a leftish, skeptical urbanite like myself. And particularly not now, just a few days before we commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. But yes, I love my country.'b'The reason I say it out loud, now, is that I feel I have to defend Germany against those on the streets of Dresden who also call themselves \xe2\x80\x9cpatriots\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cPatriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the West,\xe2\x80\x9d to be precise, which is the name of a loose alliance that brings thousands to the streets every Monday. Since the terror attacks in Paris, the movement has grown: The police counted 25,000 demonstrators on Jan. 12, the Monday after the attacks, a 7,500 jump from the week before. (It canceled its Jan. 19 protest over security concerns.)'b'Known by its German acronym, Pegida, the group has inflicted great harm on the country\xe2\x80\x99s international reputation. Our neighbors and allies are asking whether Germany is stumbling back into the darkness of xenophobia, and rightfully so. Many Germans are asking the same question these days.'b'There are two ways to look at the situation. The optimistic take is to note that, for all the attention Pegida gets inside of Germany and abroad, Germany has never been as liberal, culturally diverse and open toward minorities as it is today.'b'Last year a biennial poll conducted by the 'b'Friedrich Ebert Foundation'b', a foundation associated with the left-wing Social Democrats (and thus unlikely to underestimate the problem), found that anti-foreigner attitudes were at a historic low. While its 2012 poll found that about a quarter of Germans reported hostile views toward foreigners, only 7.5 percent did in 2014. And anti-Semitism, which is on the rise elsewhere in Europe, has dropped significantly, to 4.1 percent from 8.6.'b'Apart from the polls, there is quite a bit of evidence for a new openness. On Jan. 12, 100,000 people went to the streets nationwide in counterdemonstrations against Pegida, showing their solidarity with German Muslims. In Leipzig, 4,800 pro-Pegida protesters were met by 30,000 counterprotesters.'b'Meanwhile, all over Germany, private initiatives are popping up to help refugees. In Duisburg, a local politician has collected 100 bicycles for refugee children. In Zirndorf, doctors are providing refugees with free medication. Even in Dresden, Pegida\xe2\x80\x99s stronghold, groups are helping refugees with the hard tasks of getting settled, like providing translation services at appointments with authorities.'b'Still, the enormous support for Pegida requires us to consider another, darker reading of the situation, as evidence of troubling developments within German society.'b'One is the failure of mainstream politics. There is a tendency among the major parties to move toward the center of the political spectrum, creating an ideological void at its far right and left ends. The far right in particular has lacked political representation in the past years, which helps explain why a new populist party, Alternative f\xc3\xbcr Deutschland, had such enormous success in European and state elections last year. While leaders of the Alternative, as it\xe2\x80\x99s called, claim to be primarily anti-European Union, many have also expressed support for Pegida.'b'Another change revolves around the Internet. In this view, the Pegida people are just the usual frustrated lot looming at the edges of society. Now, emboldened by the reinforcement they find in like-minded communities online, they\xe2\x80\x99re taking to the streets.'b'And a third is the persistence of regional differences. Though Pegida has drawn support in western Germany, it is strongest in the former East Germany. In the East, xenophobic attitudes are still more common than in the West, for a complex mix of reasons, including higher unemployment rates, but also because of feelings of inferiority.'b'We also have to ask what Pegida says about Germany, whatever its causes. It certainly indicates that the relative social peace we are experiencing right now is fragile. But it also shows how the country, still new to the multiethnic game, is struggling with its identity. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t until the 1950s that the first waves of immigrants arrived, the \xe2\x80\x9cGastarbeiter\xe2\x80\x9d (guest workers) from Turkey and Italy who came to fill the labor gap in the country\xe2\x80\x99s prospering postwar economy.'b'For decades, Germany was able to pretend that the guest workers were just that, guests. But the third generation of Turkish immigrants is now reaching adulthood. At the same time, immigration numbers are rising: Germany\xe2\x80\x99s immigrant population grew by about 430,000 last year. Many came from the Southern European countries that still suffer from the euro crisis, but last year Germany also welcomed some 220,000 refugees, mostly from Syria, Eritrea, Serbia and Afghanistan.'b'The white face of German society is changing at a rapid pace. In this context, the Pegida protests are getting such attention because they act as a weekly checkup of German society. It\xe2\x80\x99s as if every Monday, the news media are putting a trembling hand to the country\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, checking its temperature, wondering whether our ugly, xenophobic past is taking over again. And we don\xe2\x80\x99t have to look back to the 1930s to find that past; in the early 1990s, when the country last saw similar numbers of refugees, an irrational fear of foreigners taking the jobs of \xe2\x80\x9creal Germans\xe2\x80\x9d gripped the country, culminating in anti-immigrant riots in several cities, with several deaths, many wounded and thousands scared.'b'Last week, a 20-year-old refugee from Eritrea was found stabbed to death near his apartment in Dresden. Neighbors reported that swastikas had been painted onto the door of his apartment. Germans held their breath. Was this a neo-Nazi murder? Was there a connection to the Pegida rallies? Then, on Thursday, authorities arrested one of the victim\xe2\x80\x99s roommates, another asylum seeker, who they say has admitted to the attack. Still, we don\xe2\x80\x99t trust ourselves. Why should our neighbors? Why should you?'b'However the investigation turns out, I am an optimist, believing that we will not see history repeated. Germany has come a long way since even the early \xe2\x80\x9990s. And rather than causing violence, Pegida has set off a public debate on Germany\xe2\x80\x99s national identity. This is long overdue. Prominent conservative politicians like Peter Tauber, the secretary general of the Christian Democratic Party, have demanded a new, clearer framework for immigration. Last week, Chancellor Angela Merkel declared that \xe2\x80\x9cIslam is part of Germany.\xe2\x80\x9d It was an assessment, rather than an ideological statement. It was the simple acknowledgment of a simple reality.'b'On Jan. 10, a protester holding a sign \xe2\x80\x9cI am Charlie\xe2\x80\x9d was arrested in Moscow and later sentenced to eight days in jail. Moscow alone has two million Muslim residents, and according to some estimates, an equal number of Muslim migrant workers. Mr. Putin wants to keep them in his camp, and this requires pragmatism and the utmost delicacy. The brutal war in Chechnya may have ended, but Islamist rebels, some of them professing loyalty to the Islamic State, still roam the Caucasus, and Moscow is fearful that their influence can easily spread northward.'b'Though the Kremlin was quick to express solidarity with France and condemn terrorism in the aftermath of the Paris attack, the pro-government media placed equal blame at the feet of the Charlie Hebdo journalists for their provocative cartoons, and at the Western liberalism that allows such publications.'b'Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s Russia is not a friendly place for irreverent humor. (The doctor is not named in the complaint and has agreed to testify for the prosecutors.) That\xe2\x80\x99s on top of his government salary of $121,000, which alone is more than most Americans make.'b'Mr. Silver is also facing charges of failing to report what could be a substantial amount of income from a small real estate firm. Within two weeks after Mr. Cuomo shut down the commission, Mr. Bharara took control over its files and unfinished investigations. The case against Mr. Silver could be the first of several against Albany lawmakers. Or as Mr. Bharara hinted on Thursday, \xe2\x80\x9cStay tuned.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This dramatic turn of events could be the start of a wholesale cleanup of Albany\xe2\x80\x99s appalling political culture, something voters have wished for and deserved for many years. But it\xe2\x80\x99s only a start.'b'OUR modern criminal justice system is designed to avoid jury trials. Through investigation and considered use of discretion, prosecutors are expected to charge only when there is sufficient evidence to convict. Once charged, defendants are encouraged to plead guilty in part to avoid a \xe2\x80\x9ctrial penalty\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a longer sentence after a trial, often a much longer one. And 95 percent of them do just that. The Supreme Court acknowledged this reality in 2012 when it described our criminal process as \xe2\x80\x9ca system of pleas.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Serial'b',\xe2\x80\x9d the hit podcast about Adnan Syed\xe2\x80\x99s 2000 conviction for strangling his former high school girlfriend, Hae Min Lee, focuses on the question of whether Mr. Syed was unjustly convicted. Found guilty of first-degree murder and kidnapping after a five-week trial and two hours of jury deliberation, Mr. Syed is now serving a sentence of life plus 30 years. If he is innocent, this outcome is indeed a tragedy.'b'But if he is guilty, the result is also troubling. The average sentence for individuals convicted of murder that year in the United States was 19 years. Had Mr. Syed, then 18, plea-bargained in what his prosecutor recently described as a \xe2\x80\x9crun-of-the-mill domestic violence murder,\xe2\x80\x9d he might have been able to earn his freedom by age 40.'b'It is noteworthy that a court is currently considering whether Mr. Syed\xe2\x80\x99s counsel gave him substandard legal assistance when she failed to explore the option of a guilty plea. Mr. Syed claims that he twice asked his lawyer to seek an offer from the prosecutor, but she told him none was forthcoming. The prosecutor states that she made no such request. Mr. Syed\xe2\x80\x99s attorney died in 2004, three years after being disbarred, before she could address this claim.'b'In this case, the injustice may lie not in the conviction, but in the failure to negotiate the charges. The unstructured presentation of the facts in \xe2\x80\x9cSerial\xe2\x80\x9d obscured a strong case for the prosecution. A former classmate who was cross-examined for five days testified that Mr. Syed confessed to the killing, as he enlisted his help in burying the body. On the evening of Ms. Lee\xe2\x80\x99s disappearance, Mr. Syed\xe2\x80\x99s cellphone pinged cell towers near the burial site. A bargaining effort should have been undertaken here.'b'First-degree murder under Maryland law, for a case like Mr. Syed\xe2\x80\x99s, requires that a killing be premeditated or the result of the commission of a felony. The prosecution\xe2\x80\x99s theory was that Mr. Syed strangled Ms. Lee in a 21-minute car-ride after school. Strangulation, however, is not typically associated with premeditation, and the robbery, kidnapping and false imprisonment charges Mr. Syed also faced appear strained. The former classmate\xe2\x80\x99s reliability was compromised, and the cellphone evidence was open to interpretation.'b'In addition, there was the mitigating factor of Mr. Syed\xe2\x80\x99s age at the time of the crime. Seventeen is an age of increased inclination to take risks and limited impulse control. Age, as the juvenile justice scholar Barry Feld notes, also impairs a youth\xe2\x80\x99s competence to make good legal decisions and participate effectively in legal proceedings. Mr. Syed needed some serious adult guidance on how to deal with the fallout of his situation.'b'But there is little that is systematic in our plea-bargaining processes despite the fact that they fuel our criminal justice system. Plea bargaining is usually informal and unrecorded \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes simply fleeting conversations in courtroom corridors. In many jurisdictions, judges are expressly prohibited from participating in it. Attorneys for defendants plea-bargain most cases early and aggressively. But not always, and financial incentives for lawyers may lead them to do otherwise. A study conducted by the behavioral scientist James Anderson and the economist Paul Heaton in The Yale Law Journal revealed disturbing disparities in the outcomes of murder cases in Philadelphia: Public defenders achieved significantly better outcomes with fewer trials than their private court-appointed counterparts, who were paid more if the case went to trial.'b'A New York federal judge, Jed Rakoff, has proposed one reform: plea-bargaining conferences. In sealed proceedings, judges would examine each party\xe2\x80\x99s position and recommend a nonbinding plea bargain. The plan needs to be refined so it allows a defendant to opt out if he publicly acknowledges he understands what he is giving up. The proposal, however, provides a layer of review to protect the innocent from being pressured into pleading guilty, while potentially encouraging fairer plea bargains through the oversight of a neutral party. It creates a record of plea-bargaining efforts, so there can be no uncertainty as to whether an offer was requested or ignored. Finally, it might help guilty people make a more informed choice about how to resolve their cases.'b'In an ideal world, the primacy of the jury trial should be reinstated. Prosecute fewer people, incarcerate less often, remove the trial penalty by repealing mandatory sentencing regimes. Until then, however, we have an obligation to bring transparency and independent review to the plea-bargaining processes that decide, for the most part, who ends up in our prisons, and for how long.'b'As the world contemplates the deflated football scandal in Boston \xe2\x80\x94 'b'ballghazi 'b'\xe2\x80\x94 please allow me one last moment of undiluted sports delirium. When men rated the women, the median score was about 3 and the ratings followed a bell curve \xe2\x80\x94 a few really attractive women and an equal number of women rated as unattractive.'b'But when women rated men, the results were quite different. The median score was between 1 and 2. Only 1 in 6 of the guys was rated as having above average looks. Either the guys who go to places like OkCupid, Tinder and other sites are disproportionately homely, or women have unforgiving eyes.'b'Looks, unsurprisingly, dominate online dating. But I learned some details from \xe2\x80\x9cDataclysm,\xe2\x80\x9d the book by Christian Rudder, who is the co-founder and president of OkCupid.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a gigantic superstar effect. Women who are rated in the top 5 percent of attractiveness get a vast majority of the approaches. The bottom 95 percent get much less. For men, looks barely matter at all unless you are in the top 3 percent or so. The hunks get barraged with approaches.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s better to have a polarizing profile than a bland one. People who generate high levels of disapproval \xe2\x80\x94 because they look like goths or bikers or just weird \xe2\x80\x94 often also generate higher levels of enthusiasm.'b'Racial bias is prevalent. When Asian men are looking at Asian women they rate them as 18 percent more attractive than average. But when they are looking at black women, they rate them as 27 percent less attractive. White and Latino men downgrade black women by nearly the same percentage. White, Latino and Asian women have similar preferences.'b'When people start texting or tweeting to each other, they don\xe2\x80\x99t turn into a bunch of Einsteins. Rudder looked into the most common words and phrases used on Twitter. For men they include: good bro, ps4, my beard, in nba, hoopin and off-season. For women they include: my nails done, mani pedi, retail therapy, and my belly button.'b'People who date online are not shallower or vainer than those who don\xe2\x80\x99t. Research suggests they are broadly representative. It\xe2\x80\x99s just that they\xe2\x80\x99re in a specific mental state. They\xe2\x80\x99re shopping for human beings, commodifying people. They have access to very little information that can help them judge if they will fall in love with this person. They pay ridiculous amounts of attention to things like looks, which have little bearing on whether a relationship will work. OkCupid took down the pictures one day. The people who interacted on this day exchanged contact info at twice the rate as on a regular day.'b'The dating sites have taken the information available online and tried to use it to match up specific individuals. They\xe2\x80\x99ve failed. An exhaustive review of the literature by Eli J. Finkel of Northwestern and others concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cNo compelling evidence supports matching sites\xe2\x80\x99 claims that mathematical algorithms work.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s because what creates a relationship can\xe2\x80\x99t be expressed in data or photographs. Being in love can\xe2\x80\x99t be done by a person in a self-oriented mind-set, asking: Does this choice serve me? Online dating is fascinating because it is more or less the opposite of its object: love.'b'When online daters actually meet, an entirely different mind-set has to kick in. If they\xe2\x80\x99re going to be open to a real relationship, they have to stop asking where this person rates in comparison to others and start asking, can we lower the boundaries between self and self. They have to stop thinking in individual terms and start feeling in rapport terms.'b'Basically, they have to take the enchantment leap. This is when something dry and utilitarian erupts into something passionate, inescapable and devotional. Sometimes a student becomes enraptured by the beauty of math, and becomes a mathematician. Soldiers doing the drudgery of boot camp are gradually bonded into a passionate unit, for which they will risk their lives. Anybody who has started a mere job and found in it a vocation has taken the enchantment leap.'b'In love, of course, the shift starts with vulnerability, not calculation. The people involved move from selfishness to service, from prudent thinking to poetic thinking, from a state of selection to a state of need, from relying on conscious thinking to relying on their own brilliant emotions.'b'When you look at all the people looking for love and vocation today, you realize we live in a culture and an online world that encourages a very different mind-set; in a technical culture in which humanism, religion and the humanities, which are the great instructors of enchantment, are not automatically central to life.'b'I have to guess some cultures are more fertile for enchantment \xe2\x80\x94 that some activities, like novel-reading or music-making, cultivate a skill for it, and that building a capacity for enchantment is, these days, a countercultural act and a practical and fervent need.'b'The United States and Europe have a lot in common. Both are multicultural and democratic; both are immensely wealthy; both possess currencies with global reach. Both, unfortunately, experienced giant housing and credit bubbles between 2000 and 2007, and suffered painful slumps when the bubbles burst.'b'Since then, however, policy on the two sides of the Atlantic has diverged. In one great economy, officials have shown a stern commitment to fiscal and monetary virtue, making strenuous efforts to balance budgets while remaining vigilant against inflation. In the other, not so much.'b'And the difference in attitudes is the main reason the two economies are now on such different paths. Spendthrift, loose-money America is experiencing a solid recovery \xe2\x80\x94 a reality reflected in President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s feisty State of the Union address. Meanwhile, virtuous Europe is sinking ever deeper into deflationary quicksand; everyone hopes that 'b'the new monetary measures announced Thursday'b' will break the downward spiral, but nobody I know really expects them to be enough.'b'On the U.S. economy: No, it\xe2\x80\x99s not morning in America, let alone the kind of prosperity we managed during the Clinton years. Recovery could and should have come much faster, and family incomes remain well below their pre-crisis level. Although you\xe2\x80\x99d never know it from the public discussion, 'b'there\xe2\x80\x99s overwhelming agreement among economists'b' that the Obama stimulus of 2009-10 helped limit the damage from the financial crisis, but it was too small and faded away far too fast. Still, when you compare the performance of the American economy over the past two years with 'b'all those Republican predictions of doom'b', you can see why Mr. Obama is strutting a bit.'b'Europe, on the other hand \xe2\x80\x94 or more precisely the eurozone, the 18 countries sharing a common currency \xe2\x80\x94 'b'did almost everything wrong'b'. On the fiscal side, Europe never did much stimulus, and quickly turned to austerity \xe2\x80\x94 spending cuts and, to a lesser extent, tax increases \xe2\x80\x94 despite high unemployment. On the monetary side, officials fought the imaginary menace of inflation, and took years to acknowledge that the real threat is deflation.'b'Why did they get it so wrong?'b'To some extent, the turn toward austerity reflected institutional weakness: In the United States, federal programs like Social Security, Medicare and food stamps helped support states like Florida with especially severe housing busts, whereas European nations in similar straits, like Spain, were on their own. But European austerity also reflected willful misdiagnosis of the situation. In Europe as in America, the excesses that led to crisis overwhelmingly involved private rather than public debt, with Greece very much an outlier. But officials in Berlin and Brussels chose to ignore the evidence in favor of a narrative that placed all the blame on budget deficits, and simultaneously 'b'rejected the evidence'b' suggesting \xe2\x80\x94 correctly \xe2\x80\x94 that trying to slash deficits in a depressed economy would deepen the depression.'b'Meanwhile, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s central bankers decided to worry about inflation in 2011 and raise interest rates. Even at the time it was obvious that this was foolish \xe2\x80\x94 yes, there had been an uptick in headline inflation, but measures of underlying inflation were too low, not too high.'b'Monetary policy got much better after Mario Draghi became president of the European Central Bank in late 2011. Indeed, Mr. Draghi\xe2\x80\x99s heroic efforts to provide liquidity to nations facing speculative attack almost surely saved the euro from collapse. But it\xe2\x80\x99s not at all clear that he has the tools to fight off the broader deflationary forces set in motion by years of wrongheaded policy. Furthermore, he has to function with one hand tied behind his back, because Germany remains adamantly opposed to anything that might make life easier for debtor nations.'b'The terrible thing is that Europe\xe2\x80\x99s economy was wrecked in the name of responsibility. True, there have been times when being tough meant reducing deficits and resisting the temptation to print money. In a depressed economy, however, a balanced-budget fetish and a hard-money obsession are deeply irresponsible. Not only do they hurt the economy in the short run, they can \xe2\x80\x94 and in Europe, have \xe2\x80\x94 inflict long-run harm, damaging the economy\xe2\x80\x99s potential and driving it into a deflationary trap that\xe2\x80\x99s very hard to escape.'b'Nor was this an innocent mistake. The thing that strikes me about Europe\xe2\x80\x99s archons of austerity, its doyens of deflation, is their self-indulgence. They felt comfortable, emotionally and politically, demanding sacrifice (from other people) at a time when the world needed more spending. They were all too eager to ignore the evidence that they were wrong.'b'And Europe will be paying the price for their self-indulgence for years, perhaps decades, to come.'b'The modern American death penalty is beset with endless complications and contradictions, and over the years no state has embodied the full range of these as consistently as Georgia.'b'Death sentences handed down by Georgia provided the basis for both the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 1972 'b'moratorium'b' on capital punishment and its 'b'lifting'b' of that moratorium four years later. Diplomatic wisdom argues for staying on the good side of such a strategically significant state.'b'In effect, Washington needs to execute a delicate dance: Push back against Pakistan in order to further America\xe2\x80\x99s friendship with India, while taking care not to alienate the Pakistanis.'b'A neat trick? But in recent years, the Obama administration has invoked national security waivers that bypass the certification process. Given an excuse to withdraw from talks, Iran could accelerate its nuclear program, curbed for a year under an interim agreement, and force the United States or Israel to use military action or a cyberattack to keep Tehran from producing nuclear weapons.'b'In a recent Washington Post 'b'op-ed'b' article, the foreign ministers of Britain, France, Germany and the European Union also implored Congress to hold off on new sanctions. According to Secretary of State 'b'John Kerry'b', even Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service, warned Congress that new sanctions would scuttle the talks, saying it would \xe2\x80\x9cbe like throwing a grenade into the process.\xe2\x80\x9d Mossad later tried to paper over any perceived differences with Mr. Netanyahu.'b'Mr. Netanyahu has long defined Iran as Israel\xe2\x80\x99s top threat and made clear his contempt for negotiations. Like his Congressional allies, however, he has never offered a real alternative, except more sanctions (which can\xe2\x80\x99t work if the rest of the world eases up on Iran) or military action. If a deal is finally reached and Congress finds it lacking, tougher sanctions can be imposed then.'b'Domestic politics are also at work. Republicans apparently see value in trying to sabotage any possible success for Mr. Obama, even if it harms American interests.'b'As for Mr. Netanyahu, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see how disrespecting an American president whom even he says has significantly advanced Israel\xe2\x80\x99s security can benefit his country.'b'There is no doubt that Mr. Obama will maintain America\xe2\x80\x99s security commitments to Israel, whatever the tensions over the Iran issue. But this event is bound to further harm a bilateral relationship that has endured a lot of battering over the past six years. The White House has said that, understandably, Mr. Obama will not meet with Mr. Netanyahu when he is in town. Even Mr. Kerry, who recently called almost 50 world leaders in an effort to block the Palestinians\xe2\x80\x99 attempt to join the International Criminal Court, is losing patience with Mr. Netanyahu\xe2\x80\x99s decision to \xe2\x80\x9cplay politics,\xe2\x80\x9d according to his aides. Can Mr. Netanyahu really afford to dismiss such allies?'b'DENVER \xe2\x80\x94 OVER the summer, I moved into a house in rural Nebraska where, for the first time ever, I had full control of the thermostat. It was a drafty 4,000-square-foot palace of cold-to-the touch cinder-blocks that had long stood empty. As fall approached, I started to think about heating. Keeping that whole place at 70 degrees with natural gas, for just one person, seemed like a waste. I wondered: How cold could I let my house get, while remaining comfortable?'b'Home temperatures appear to be slowly rising. The average nighttime bedroom in the United States is around 68 degrees, and the average living room is more than 70, according to a 2011 study on obesity and indoor temperatures. A study published that same year in the journal Building and Environment found that home heating and cooling were responsible for 9 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s energy consumption.'b'Reducing household energy use by lowering the thermostat would be a boon for the environment and our checking accounts. The agency forecasts that American households will pay an average of $621 for natural gas, $943 for electrical heating systems or $1,586 for heating oil this winter.'b'Winter weather arrived in mid-November, and soon the temperature was in the single digits. My house\xe2\x80\x99s thermostat had been preset to 55 degrees. Wearing a T-shirt, sweatshirt, sweatpants and a light coat, I found I was reasonably comfortable when I was under the covers or up and moving. But sitting at my computer, my hands were always half numb.'b'I remembered reading in Darwin\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Voyage of the Beagle\xe2\x80\x9d about a tribe he encountered in Tierra del Fuego called the Yaghan, who wore few clothes and by all reports were comfortable, despite living in a region where the annual mean temperature is 42 degrees. If the Yaghan could do it scantily clothed, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t I do it well clothed? I did the obvious thing, and put on fingerless gloves and a hat. And after just a few days, a colder-than-normal house seemed, well, normal. I decided to go colder.'b'The lowest the thermostat would go was 45 degrees, which I figured was good because I had to make sure the pipes wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t freeze. At first it was fairly unpleasant. I wore two pairs of wool socks, thermal underwear, a thin pair of pants, sweatpants, a wool shirt, a sweatshirt, a light hoodie, a light jacket, a big poofy winter jacket, two winter hats and those fingerless gloves. Yet I was still having trouble typing because of my numb hands. That\xe2\x80\x99s when I pulled out my down sleeping bag, and decided to wear it whenever I was sitting. With the sleeping bag, now that my core had been warmed, my extremities were warming up, too.'b'Life at 45 degrees isn\xe2\x80\x99t for everyone \xe2\x80\x94 I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t recommend it for the sick, the elderly or children. And there are, of course, legitimate hazards to the cold. The National Weather Service reports that there were 66 cold- and winter-related deaths in 2013 in the United States. A more useful measurement, popular in Europe, is \xe2\x80\x9cexcess winter mortality,\xe2\x80\x9d which simply compares deaths during winter to those during the rest of the year. The resulting figures tend to be much higher than the weather service\xe2\x80\x99s: In England and Wales there were an estimated 31,100 such deaths in the 2012-13 winter.'b'Using this measure, paradoxically, warmer countries like Spain and Portugal suffer more cold-related deaths than colder countries, because they aren\xe2\x80\x99t as well versed in the art of keeping warm. The Siberian city of Yakutsk, the coldest city in the world, has an average temperature of minus 16 from October to March, yet experiences no excess winter deaths. Scandinavians, who also have a low excess winter mortality rate, have a common saying: \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no bad weather, only bad clothing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to say that I liked living in a 45-degree house, but eventually I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind it, and it taught me that one\xe2\x80\x99s sense of comfort can be redefined with a bit of grit and resourcefulness. Sitting in my sleeping bag, I began to wonder: If we all set our thermostats to our own \xe2\x80\x9ccomfortable low,\xe2\x80\x9d how many West Virginia mountains could we save? How many fewer wells would need to be fracked? How much less greenhouse gas would we emit?'b'My experiment came to a halt when friends in Lincoln asked if I could watch their house and dogs for a few weeks. Their thermostat was set at 74 degrees, and I thought it would be inappropriate to fiddle with it. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to lie: It was nice to be able to eat a bowl of cereal in my underwear. But part of me genuinely missed my cold, yet comfortable, house.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'We read \xe2\x80\x9c'b'After PTSD, More Trauma'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Sunday Review, Jan. 18), by David J. Morris, a former Marine infantry officer, with concern. The Department of Veterans Affairs has long recognized access to care as a top priority for improving veteran services. Secretary Robert A. McDonald has challenged the V.A. to refocus and re-energize these efforts.'b'An increasingly broad range of effective treatment options are now available to veterans, but we fear that Mr. Morris\xe2\x80\x99s account will make some veterans reluctant to seek help for post-traumatic stress disorder.'b'Since 2006, the V.A. has trained over 6,000 clinicians in two of the most effective treatments for PTSD: prolonged exposure therapy and cognitive processing therapy. Both treatments are strongly recommended in the practice guidelines of the Veterans Affairs and Defense Departments and in other PTSD guidelines around the world.'b'A 2013 study found that over 60 percent of veterans who received prolonged exposure therapy from the V.A. in the national training initiative experienced clinically meaningful improvement. Although feeling worse in therapy can happen, a standard V.A. protocol for prolonged exposure informs patients of this and the option to discontinue.'b'We are glad to hear that Mr. Morris was offered an alternative treatment that helped. The V.A. welcomes criticism but also needs constructive ideas to succeed. The V.A. is actively engaging community partners, academia, advocates, the private sector and, most important, veterans and their families, to improve services. Together, we can fulfill Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s charge \xe2\x80\x9cto care for him who shall have borne the battle and for his widow, and his orphan.\xe2\x80\x9d Information about PTSD can be found at 'b'www.ptsd.va.gov'b'.'b'MARSDEN McGUIRE'b' PAULA SCHNURR'b' Washington, Jan. 23, 2015'b''b''b''b'Dr. McGuire is deputy chief consultant, mental health standards of care, at the V.A. RIGA'b' Houston, Jan. 20, 2015'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I applaud the courage of David J. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Time to Test North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s Intentions'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 15):'b'You are correct that the United States should test North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s intentions regarding its recent offer to engage in discussions about its nuclear weapons development. Currently, they appear to have persuaded our attorney general that the amendment bars him from taking action against Inspire magazine, published on the Internet by Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.'b'The organization is a sworn enemy of the United States, and its web publication is available throughout the land. The online magazine proclaims its goals of providing inspiration and justification to inflict harm on the United States as well as Britain, France and other countries, by killing its citizens, preferably in large numbers. It encourages its readers to engage in attacks.'b'The magazine has given instructions for building car bombs as well as pressure-cooker bombs using material from a kitchen or a hardware store. Those instructions were followed to the letter by the Tsarnaev brothers, who murdered three and sent 264 to hospitals in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing.'b'It also \xe2\x80\x94 in its issue this past Christmas Eve \xe2\x80\x94 shared a new bomb recipe aimed at bringing down civilian airliners. According to Inspire, the new bomb would not be detected by the Transportation Security Administration metal detectors, only potentially by sniffer machines. But even if detected, the bomb probably wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be discovered, the publication says, without probing into orifices that a T.S.A. officer might be reluctant to visit.'b'In Britain, possession of the online magazine is a crime. Is this publication protected by our First Amendment? Not on your life!'b'In 1791, our forebears, anxious lest the new government adopt some of the restrictions that had been imposed by the king, adopted a basic commandment barring the government from making any law \xe2\x80\x9cabridging the freedom of speech.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Does that mean what it says? Obviously not, because we have adopted many laws abridging speech, such as in cases of child porn, perjury, false representation, libel and slander, criminal conspiracy, etc. The list is substantial. When it comes to political speech, how do we distinguish the good speech from the bad? We look to bedrock principles.'b'For example, threats are not protected because they provide no social value. The idea behind the First Amendment, wrote the founders, was that the citizens be free to criticize their government. And over the next several centuries, our courts have developed a great body of law refining and expanding that concept. In the area of national security and politics, there are no wrong ideas, and free speech is indispensable to the disclosure of truth.'b'The most recent and most expansive Supreme Court decision on protected speech in the context of national security was the 'b'Brandenburg case'b' in 1969, which struck down an Ohio law that criminalized advocacy of crime, violence or terrorism as a means of accomplishing political reform. The statute was unconstitutional, the court said, because political speech is protected unless it is \xe2\x80\x9cdirected to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action.\xe2\x80\x9d Because this Ohio statute did not adequately distinguish between abstract advocacy versus true incitement to imminent action, the conviction of Clarence Brandenburg, a Ku Klux Klan leader, was reversed.'b'In looking at the question of what speech is protected and what is not, courts have always looked to context. For example, every Supreme Court decision on this subject recognizes war as an exception to the First Amendment, even though the Constitution says no such thing. The classic example cited by the older cases is recognition of the government\xe2\x80\x99s unfettered right, in time of war, to ban the publication of information revealing the sailing dates of troop transports. Ten years after Brandenburg, a district judge in the United States v. Progressive case enjoined the publication of classified nuclear bomb formulas. The court found that times had changed, war was no longer limited to foot soldiers who travel to battle sites on troop transports, and even though it was not clear that a reader would imminently \xe2\x80\x9cbuild a hydrogen bomb in the basement,\xe2\x80\x9d the scope of the danger overwhelmed the imminence factor.'b'The balancing act was succinctly explained by Robert W. Warren, the district court chief judge who, when referring to Patrick Henry\xe2\x80\x99s famous liberty-or-death choice, 'b'wrote'b', \xe2\x80\x9cin the short run, one cannot enjoy freedom of speech, freedom to worship, freedom of the press unless one first enjoys the freedom to live.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The balancing test must look at what is real. The measurement of imminence changes when we are talking about detonating a nuclear bomb in New York City as opposed to an unlicensed rally blocking the Brooklyn Bridge.'b'The federal government should move decisively to block Inspire on the web. It is criminal incitement that has produced lawless action, and no sentient judge would today say otherwise.'b'It is one thing for Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to excuse the journalist James Risen from revealing a book source, and quite another to permit virulent enemies to recruit, train and support those who would destroy our country. If we sanction this kind of so-called freedom, we risk horrible consequences. The Paris killings are small stuff compared with what would happen if our civilian airline system were crippled. I fear that in response to more terrorism, we would see repression on a terrifying scale.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s exploding appetites have unleashed a wholesale looting of Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s valuable natural resources. Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s tiger population is by most estimates less than 70.'b'The pursuit of the valuable copper deposits in the country, formerly called Burma, has led to violence against Burmese who dare to object to the environmental and human costs. The country needs foreign investment that is respectful of human rights and the environment. It will be up to President Thein Sein to rein in the corruption and crony deals that are stripping away resources and creating political instability.'b'The tragic degradation of thoroughbred racing continues at New York\xe2\x80\x99s Aqueduct Racetrack, where the fatality rate for horses \xe2\x80\x94 'b'7.8 per 1,000 horses'b' \xe2\x80\x94 has reached more than four times the national average as heedless owners put unproven horses at risk for lucrative purses. Twelve horses broke down in competition and had to be put to death in just 22 days in the track\xe2\x80\x99s current winter meet.'b'The alarming rate prompted officials of the New York Racing Association to issue emergency measures this month to crack down on horsemen who indiscriminately run weak and unaccomplished horses in races that can prove lethal.'b'The track has always been more blue-collar than blue-chip as an attraction for bettors and the industry\xe2\x80\x99s lower-rung horses. The booming casino\xe2\x80\x99s gambling revenues have inflated the racetrack\xe2\x80\x99s purses, heightening the lure for owners and trainers to put horses at risk.'b'The new emergency measures cut the weekday card from nine races to eight and mandate a two-week layoff between races to keep horses off a competitive treadmill. His two well-educated daughters cannot find jobs; more than half of Greek youths have no work, and the jobs that do appear are often short-term and lacking in benefits.'b'Such stories of misery are legion after six years of economic crisis \xe2\x80\x94 including stories of suicides, of housewives turning to prostitution. Listening to them, the only surprise in the rise of the left-wing Syriza party, which is expected to come in first in Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s general election, is that it has taken so long for an anti-austerity party to come to the fore.'b'Alexis Tsipras, Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s charismatic 40-year-old leader, has been campaigning under the banner \xe2\x80\x9cHope is on its way.\xe2\x80\x9d He has vowed to undo the austerity program mandated by the troika of international creditors \xe2\x80\x94 the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund \xe2\x80\x94 and at the same time to somehow reduce the country\xe2\x80\x99s debt and remain in the eurozone. Fulfilling these contradictory promises may not be possible, but to a lot of people that\xe2\x80\x99s not the point \xe2\x80\x94 voting for Syriza is another way of saying \xe2\x80\x9cEnough.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The incumbent prime minister, Antonis Samaras, has insisted that the radical left wants to drive Greece out of the euro, and that the only path for Greece is to stay the course of painful reforms and budget cuts that he has led.'b'Recent opinion polls showed Mr. Samaras\xe2\x80\x99s center-right New Democracy party only four to six percentage points behind Syriza. So even if Syriza does come in first, it will probably need a coalition to form a government. Given the variety of parties and passions likely to come out of the elections, the next government may not be around for long.'b'All this makes for a frightening welter of unknowns as voters approach decision time. If Mr. Tsipras goes ahead with his promise to cut taxes and restore social spending without finding new sources of funding, the \xe2\x80\x9ctroika\xe2\x80\x9d bailout could be cut short. Without the bailout, Greece would face the risk of a default on its massive sovereign debt. And failing to meet its debts would raise the possibility of a \xe2\x80\x9cGrexit,\xe2\x80\x9d a Greek exit from the eurozone.'b'Though Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, who has the decisive say in what demands to make of Greece, insists she wants Greece to remain in the eurozone, the possibility of a Greek exit is no longer regarded in Berlin and Brussels as necessarily an unmitigated disaster.'b'For the Greeks, however, it would be, most likely plunging the country into recession, and the large majority of Greeks want the country to remain in the single currency.'b'In any case, Mr. Tsipras has given signals that he may be open to a more sensible course than his radical party platform. Polls show that a strong majority of Greeks, 61 percent, want consensus in talks with the troika, and the optimistic scenario is that his left-wing credentials would give him the credibility to urge more patience.'b'Another question is whether Berlin and Brussels really mean their tough talk about Greece. But there seems to be a growing sentiment among economists in Europe that debt relief is essential to bringing the Greek economy back from the depths. Whether Greeks \xe2\x80\x9cdeserve\xe2\x80\x9d punishing austerity after years of profligacy, as many in northern Europe continue to maintain, is not the right question. (Fast-track procedures have been used to conclude 14 trade agreements since 1974.)'b'You\xe2\x80\x99d need a heart of stone not to be sympathetic to the concerns of the Democrats.
