No matter. It was all just in the air.'b'AS jury selection continues in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the Boston Marathon bombings, so does debate about what would constitute a fair and impartial jury. Questions have been raised about the race, gender, age and religiosity of prospective jurors; about the effect of holding the trial in Boston; and about the legal requirement that the jurors be open to the possibility of sentencing the defendant to death.'b'But recent research of ours suggests that another, largely overlooked factor may also play an important role in the trial: whether the jurors perceive Mr. Tsarnaev as white.'b'No sooner did the F.B.I. release photographs of Mr. Tsarnaev and his older brother, Tamerlan, three days after the bombings, than questions arose about the racial identity of the suspects. (\xe2\x80\x9cAre the Tsarnaev Brothers White?\xe2\x80\x9d ran a headline in Salon.) Although neither brother matched the visual prototype of a white American, both hailed from the Caucasus, the region that gave rise to the term \xe2\x80\x9cCaucasian,\xe2\x80\x9d and both had lived in America for many years.'b'In the aftermath of the bombings, we sought to answer two questions: If white people perceived Dzhokhar Tsarnaev as less white, did that influence their support for treating him harshly? (Tamerlan was dead by this point.) And if people varied in how white they considered Mr. Tsarnaev to be, what psychological propensities, if any, determined whether they perceived him as more like \xe2\x80\x9cus\xe2\x80\x9d or more like \xe2\x80\x9cthem\xe2\x80\x9d? We, along with three of our colleagues, 'b'published our findings last year'b' in the journal Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin.'b'Within hours of the F.B.I.\xe2\x80\x99s release of the suspects\xe2\x80\x99 photographs, we collected responses from 426 white Americans to a broad questionnaire assessing a range of their demographic information as well as aspects of their ideological orientations. Eight days later, we offered these same participants the opportunity to respond to a second questionnaire. Here, we presented them with the original F.B.I. photos, and asked them to tell us how white they thought the suspects looked.'b'We then asked the participants whether they endorsed statements such as \xe2\x80\x9cI hope the perpetrator of the Boston Marathon attacks rots in hell\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIt is O.K. for Tsarnaev not to have been read his Miranda rights before interrogation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cWe shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t rush to judgment in bringing the perpetrator of the Boston Marathon attacks to justice.\xe2\x80\x9d They were also asked to indicate the sentence that they felt Mr. Tsarnaev ought to receive should he be found guilty, with options ranging from \xe2\x80\x9ca maximum of 20 years in prison with the possibility of parole\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cthe death penalty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We found that there was substantial ambiguity about whether the Tsarnaev brothers were white. On a scale from zero (nonwhite) to 100 (white), the participants varied in their perceptions, with ratings running the full gamut from zero to 100. The average rating was around 64.'b'Which individuals were less likely to \xe2\x80\x9cgrant\xe2\x80\x9d the Tsarnaevs whiteness? In our initial questionnaire, we focused on two ideological outlooks that have been well studied by political psychologists: the belief that some groups of people are superior to others (\xe2\x80\x9csocial dominance orientation\xe2\x80\x9d) and the belief in the importance of following traditions and respecting authorities (\xe2\x80\x9cright-wing authoritarianism\xe2\x80\x9d). We found that participants who scored high in either outlook were less likely to perceive the Tsarnaev brothers as looking white, effectively steering the brothers into \xe2\x80\x9coutsider\xe2\x80\x9d territory.'b'We also found that such whiteness perceptions had the potential to play an important role in the outcome of Mr. Tsarnaev\xe2\x80\x99s trial. The lower that individuals rated Mr. Tsarnaev as looking white, the more willing they were to punish him severely. In a case like Mr. Tsarnaev\xe2\x80\x99s, where guilt is widely presumed and where the outcome will most likely fall on one side of the line between life imprisonment and death, this finding seems especially relevant.'b'One implication of our research is the need to expand what factors play a role in determining jury makeup. If your tendency to perceive a defendant as more like \xe2\x80\x9cus\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthem\xe2\x80\x9d is reliably predicted by certain of your ideological beliefs, and if those beliefs can influence factors critical to the impartiality of the legal process, then jury screening questionnaires should measure them.'b'In an increasingly multiracial world, trying racially ambiguous defendants will become only more common. Just as we ask potential jurors questions like \xe2\x80\x9cDo you go to church?\xe2\x80\x9d we need to ask questions like \xe2\x80\x9cIs having a decent respectable appearance still the mark of a lady?\xe2\x80\x9d (one of many questions used to gauge right-wing authoritarianism) and \xe2\x80\x9cIf certain groups of people \xe2\x80\x98stayed in their place,\xe2\x80\x99 would we have fewer problems?\xe2\x80\x9d (social dominance orientation).'b'By using such information, courts can better take into account the broader ideological balance of a potential jury.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 A HISTORIC change of roles is at the heart of the clamor and turmoil over the collapse of oil prices, which have plummeted by 50 percent since September. For decades, Saudi Arabia, backed by the Persian Gulf emirates, was described as the \xe2\x80\x9cswing producer.\xe2\x80\x9d With its immense production capacity, it could raise or lower its output to help the global market adjust to shortages or surpluses.'b'But on Nov. 27, at the OPEC meeting in Vienna, Saudi Arabia effectively resigned from that role and OPEC handed over all responsibility for oil prices to the market, which the Saudi oil minister, Ali Al-Naimi, predicted would \xe2\x80\x9cstabilize itself eventually.\xe2\x80\x9d OPEC\xe2\x80\x99s decision was hardly unanimous. Venezuela and Iran, their economies in deep trouble, lobbied hard for production cutbacks, to no avail. Afterward, Iran accused Saudi Arabia of waging an \xe2\x80\x9coil war\xe2\x80\x9d and being part of a \xe2\x80\x9cplot\xe2\x80\x9d against it.'b'By leaving oil prices to the market, Saudi Arabia and the emirates also passed the responsibility as de facto swing producer to a country that hardly expected it \xe2\x80\x94 the United States. This approach is expected to continue with the accession of the new Saudi king, Salman, following the death on Friday of King Abdullah. And it means that changes in American production will now, along with that of Persian Gulf producers, also have a major influence on global oil prices.'b'America was once, by far, the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest oil producer and exporter, and its swing producer. The Texas Railroad Commission determined \xe2\x80\x9callowable\xe2\x80\x9d levels of production for Texas, the Saudi Arabia of the day. But by 1970, United States oil production had reached its high point of 9.6 million barrels per day and began to decline.'b'The United States began to import more and more oil. By 2008, its own oil production was down almost 50 percent from the high point. Oil prices reached $147 a barrel, and fears that the world\xe2\x80\x99s oil production had peaked and that we were beginning to run out of oil had become pervasive.'b'Quietly, though, an unconventional oil and gas revolution was beginning to pick up speed in the United States. It yoked together two technologies: hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling. The impact was measured first in the rapidly growing production of shale gas, which now makes up about half of total American gas. This \xe2\x80\x9cshale gale\xe2\x80\x9d catapulted the United States ahead of Russia to become the world\xe2\x80\x99s No. 1 gas producer.'b'Then around 2010, the same technologies started to be seriously applied to the search for oil. The results were phenomenal. By the end of 2014, oil production in the United States was 80 percent higher than it had been in 2008. The increase of 4.1 million barrels per day was greater than the output of every single OPEC country but Saudi Arabia.'b'Today, American output is almost back to where it was in 1970. On top of that was a million-barrel-a-day gain since 2008 from the Canadian oil sands. The chimera of \xe2\x80\x9cenergy independence\xe2\x80\x9d began to look more tangible, at least for North America.'b'This revolution also turned out to be a big boost for the American economy, creating jobs, improving the country\xe2\x80\x99s competitive position and drawing in over a $100 billion of new investment. Only rarely has the global oil market seen production increases on this scale this fast. The last time was in the early 1980s, when new supplies from Mexico, the North Sea and Alaska created an oil surplus that led to a price crash.'b'This time, several things postponed a price collapse. One was the growing consumption in the developing world, led by China. Another was turmoil in Libya, South Sudan and other countries that reduced supply. Over a million barrels per day were also taken off the market by sanctions imposed on Iran. Without that big surge of shale oil from the United States, it is highly likely that those sanctions would have failed. Prices would have spiked, countries seeking cheaper oil would have broken ranks \xe2\x80\x94 and Iran might not be at the nuclear negotiating table today.'b'By the middle of last summer, however, circumstances changed. World economic growth was slowing. Europe was on its back. Since 2004, China\xe2\x80\x99s rapidly rising demand for oil had been the defining factor for the global oil market. But China\xe2\x80\x99s economy was slowing, too, and that meant slowing growth in oil demand. At the same time, Libya managed to quadruple its oil output, at least for a time. That was the trigger for the beginning of the price decline.'b'It was assumed that OPEC would step in and cut production to boost the price. Trillions of dollars of investment have been made over the last several years on that premise.'b'But Saudi Arabia and the other gulf countries declined to do so. If they reduced production, they reasoned, they would lose market share permanently. As they saw it, they would be cutting back on their \xe2\x80\x9clow cost oil\xe2\x80\x9d to make room for \xe2\x80\x9chigh cost oil,\xe2\x80\x9d and then would have to make more cuts to accommodate more high cost oil.'b'They were looking at competition not only from American shale oil but also from Canadian oil sands and new supplies from Russia, the Arctic, Brazil, Central Asia, Africa and growing volumes of offshore oil around the world.'b'But, most immediately, they were looking at two neighbors. They did not want to give up markets to Iraq, a country they see as an Iranian satellite, and whose output is increasing. And they certainly did not want to make way for Iran, which they thought might come to a nuclear deal with the United States and its allies, bringing that missing Iranian oil back into the market.'b'The depth of the price fall may be much more than even some of the gulf producers anticipated. Around the world, oil companies are cutting budgets, paring costs, slowing down projects and postponing new ones. Some may end up being canceled.'b'Saudi Arabia is hoping that lower oil prices will stimulate economic growth and demand for oil. In the meantime, with their large holdings of foreign reserves, Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf emirates can afford to wait.'b'That is not true for many of the other oil exporters. Venezuela is highly vulnerable to turmoil and even financial collapse. Russia is coping not only with lower prices for oil, which provides over 40 percent of government revenues, but with Ukraine-related sanctions, and seems headed into a deep recession.'b'Nigeria, the largest economy in Africa and the continent\xe2\x80\x99s most populous nation, is also at risk. The oil sector represents 95 percent of export earnings and 75 percent of government revenues. And its revenues are falling as it needs more money to fight the Boko Haram Islamist insurgency.'b'Over all, the fall in oil prices could mean a $1.5 to $2 trillion transfer from oil-exporting countries to oil-importing countries. Japan will be a big beneficiary. So will China. American consumers will benefit, too, though it will also mean that fewer oil wells will be drilled here, more rigs will be laid up and increasing numbers of workers will be let go.'b'American shale oil has become the decisive new factor in the world oil market in a way that could not have been imagined five years ago. It has proved to be a truly disruptive technology. But will that impact continue in a world of low prices?'b'Oil is now below $50 a barrel, a price too low for a good deal of the new shale oil development to make economic sense. Yet output is likely to continue to rise by another 500,000 barrels per day in the first half of 2015 because of sheer momentum and commitments already made.'b'Come the middle of the year, however, growth will flatten out. Producers will work hard to improve efficiency and lower costs, but in 2016, at these prices, American output could decline. Production elsewhere in the world will also be flattening.'b'But by then, the world economy might be doing better, stimulating oil demand. Prices could start rising again. If the gulf producers have their way, prices will not go back to $100 a barrel. Even at prices well below $100, American shale oil producers will find ways to drive down costs and output will start rising again. And the world\xe2\x80\x99s new swing producer will find itself back in the swing of things.'b'There have been powerful reminders in recent days that the financial system needs more regulatory vigilance, not less. Cuomo to his 'b'graceless defense'b' of a discredited aide \xe2\x80\x94 have revealed his political instincts to be less than impeccable.'b'But the key factor is his worldview. Bloomberg had placed the interests of Wall Street and the wealthy above those of average New Yorkers.'b'The second was what some have 'b'called'b' \xe2\x80\x9cidentity group\xe2\x80\x9d liberalism, which appealed to black and Latino voters as blacks and Latinos, not on the basis of economic interests they shared with whites. The centerpiece of Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s identity-group agenda was his promise to win better treatment for minorities at the hands of the police.'b'The problem for Mr. de Blasio is that only the first approach has widespread appeal. In 'b'a poll'b' Quinnipiac released shortly after his inauguration, almost 70 percent of voters backed the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s proposed tax increase on families making over $500,000. Eighty-three percent were concerned about income inequality (though few listed it as their top concern). But only 48 percent of voters said that Mr. de Blasio would be able to ease the Police Department\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cstop and frisk\xe2\x80\x9d tactics without sacrificing public safety.'b'Once voters focused on the identity portion of Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s agenda, it was inevitable that his numbers would suffer. The only surprise is how quickly that happened. The same post-inauguration poll put Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s approval rating at 53 percent \xe2\x80\x94 20 points below his election-night tally. A substantial number of voters had deserted the mayor only days into his term.'b'In retrospect, Mr. de Blasio might have predicted this fate based on Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s bumpy tenure. Like Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s, the president\xe2\x80\x99s struggles derive from more than just his choice of priorities; a brutal recession, a relentless opposition party, even latent racism all played a role. Still, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s decision to bet his presidency on health care made it all but impossible to build support among whites. Many of them believed (not entirely correctly) that he was spending roughly a trillion dollars to expand health coverage for 'b'other\xc2\xa0 people'b' \xe2\x80\x94 that he was a classic identity-group liberal, in other words. After losing white voters by 'b'12 points'b' in 2008, Mr. Obama lost them by 'b'20 points'b' four years later.'b'Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s choice of crusade was even riskier. If you were to rank issues by their potential to unite whites and minority voters, the most promising would be populist economic issues like 'b'raising taxes on the rich'b'. Somewhere in the middle would be an issue like health care, which has large economic benefits for both whites and nonwhites, even if opponents can portray it as a sop to the latter. At the very bottom would be issues with little economic content, but which different racial groups view in radically different ways.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s no better example of this final category than policing, especially after the deaths of Michael Brown and Eric Garner last summer. In the 'b'latest Quinnipiac poll'b', blacks approve of Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s handling of \xe2\x80\x9crelations between the police and the community\xe2\x80\x9d by a two-to-one ratio; whites\xc2\xa0disapprove by the same ratio. In effect, Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s identity-group liberalism has capped his level of support. Inroads among African-Americans tend to coincide with a decline among whites.'b'Of course, given the country\xe2\x80\x99s changing demography, the same dynamic can raise a politician\xe2\x80\x99s floor of support even while it lowers his or her ceiling, insuring against a steep drop in popularity. President Obama managed to win re-election in 2012 by largely 'b'preserving his margins'b' among blacks and liberals (whose share of the electorate increased), while improving his margins among Hispanics. Even at the low point of Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s confrontation with the police, his approval rating was a hardly catastrophic 47 percent.'b'The lesson of Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s first year isn\xe2\x80\x99t so much that his mayoral strategy was misguided. As with Mr. Obama and health care, there\xe2\x80\x99s no shame in attempting historic reforms en route to a narrow re-election. The real lesson is that Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s brand of liberalism isn\xe2\x80\x99t a basis for Democratic dominance, as his boosters once enthused. Politically, economic populism trumps identity-group appeals.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a lesson the president has learned, building his State of the Union address around the idea of raising taxes on the wealthy to fund child care and college tuition for low- and middle-income families. It\xe2\x80\x99s a safe bet that Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s next campaign will reflect this wisdom, too. In an op-ed article 'b'he wrote'b' just after his party lost the Senate last fall, Mr. de Blasio advised Democrats to run on reducing inequality and reining in corporations. Nowhere on his list of recommendations did the word \xe2\x80\x9cpolice\xe2\x80\x9d appear.'b'EVERY news broadcaster, commentator and writer has proclaimed the massacre of the French satirical cartoonists and editorialists to be a tragedy. And perhaps it was. But then, so we are told, was the death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.'b'Broadcasters and reporters daily proclaim as tragic the fatalities that result when, say, a family car spins out of control on an icy street and crashes. Just as, every spring, drunken high school students die tragically when they drive off the road. It\xe2\x80\x99s a staple of the prom season.'b'The critic George Steiner declared \xe2\x80\x9cThe Death of Tragedy\xe2\x80\x9d in 1961, but tragedy thrives today. Indeed, these days, any event that causes suffering or distress earns tragedy\xe2\x80\x99s mournful title.'b'But if everything that is avoidable, stupid and simply untoward is tragic, then nothing really is \xe2\x80\x94 not if we insist on its description of a specific kind of human sorrow. In devaluing the word, we devalue what it is meant to express. We trivialize what we wish to make truly important.'b'Since the Greeks first coined the word, tragedy has required not only a calamitous event but one that can be judged as meaningful. It has to matter in some greater manner that is, ideally, instructive.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTragedy is, then, a representation of an action that is heroic and complete,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'argued Aristotle in \xe2\x80\x9cPoetics,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' \xe2\x80\x9cand of a certain magnitude.\xe2\x80\x9d It is never trivial.'b'For an event to qualify as tragedy, its telling demands some kind of emotional catharsis, a resolution to the losses it details. This month\xe2\x80\x99s Je Suis Charlie march in Paris qualifies. But more important, to be worthy of its name, tragedy must instruct.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou emerge from tragedy equipped against lies,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote the playwright Howard Baker in 1989. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter the musical, you\xe2\x80\x99re anybody\xe2\x80\x99s fool.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Has the Paris massacre made us more aware, more sensitive to lies?'b'Reports suggest that it has merely made us afraid, angry and militant in our responses. That\xe2\x80\x99s something different.'b'In the old days, tragedy was the exclusive province of the great and powerful. With Marlowe\xe2\x80\x99s Doctor Faustus or Shakespeare\xe2\x80\x99s Hamlet, their tragic flaws, enacted, became the definition of tragedy. It may be angst (Hamlet), or hubris (Faustus), but it\xe2\x80\x99s there and we know, watching, that the ruinous end will be of their own making.'b'When tragedy became a common ill, the tragic flaw went republican. No better example exists than Arthur Miller\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDeath of a Salesman\xe2\x80\x9d and its truly tragic hero, Willy Loman, a salesman with nothing to sell.'b'As audience members, we want to say, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, Willie, don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d but we know that his inevitable suicide will be the result not of his failure but of ours, the fault of a society in which employment is a happenstance that can be withdrawn from even the hardest worker. If tragedy is, as Nietzsche believed, about the terrors of reality, then Miller\xe2\x80\x99s tragedy is about not a flaw of character but of our world.'b'And here is the essence of modern \xe2\x80\x9ctragedies\xe2\x80\x9d like the deaths of Michael Brown, 12-year-old Tamir Rice, who took a toy gun into a Cleveland park, and Trayvon Martin at the hands of the self-appointed neighborhood watchman George Zimmerman. Individually, they are sad, senseless, stupid events. In their deaths alone, there is no catharsis, no relief in the telling, nothing instructive and certainly no insurance against either falsehoods or future, similar events.'b'The tragedy resides in the larger context, the greater issues that each suggests but none completes. Together, they appear as inevitable deaths that result from a series of truly tragic American flaws: a system of justice that does not serve populations in need of protection; law enforcement that allows police officers to be a threat to those they are sworn to protect; and inequalities of education and opportunity that ensure the racial divide will continue.'b'The same is true of the Charlie Hebdo murders. There is something sadly comical about the fact that Islamist extremists targeted not essayists or politicians but cartoonists, the court jesters of modern public debate.'b'The tragedy lies not in the simple fact of their murder but in the decades of military encroachment and colonial expansion that helped to radicalize a religious sect. It lies, too, in our culture\xe2\x80\x99s failure to integrate new members in an ethos that is inclusive and assures a political space for legitimate complaint.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s modern tragedy for you. In that sense, tragedy is everywhere lurking, waiting for the next opportunity to show its power. Our tragedy is this collective, fatal flaw, which insists on demonizing those we disagree with and turning them into mortal enemies. The question is whether we will react tragically, breeding more terror in our responses, or, instructed in its causes, search for resolution.'b'Readers discuss the peril that global warming poses for life on earth, and what can be done.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Is a Climate Disaster Inevitable?'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Sunday Review, Jan. 18):'b'Adam Frank\xe2\x80\x99s perspective as an astrophysicist on the problem of global warming brings the unsettling insight that we may be doomed to pollute ourselves out of existence. McCAFFREY'b' Oakland, Calif., Jan. 17, 2015'b''b''b'The writer is programs and policy director at the National Center for Science Education and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cClimate Smart &amp; Energy Wise.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'LAST week, President Obama signed a memorandum that would allow employees at federal agencies to take up to six weeks of paid parental leave, and he has made it clear that he thinks Congress should extend paid leave to employees in the private sector, too.'b'No one expects the Republicans who control Congress to take him up on his invitation. Any attempts to thicken the social safety net through government spending are philosophically inimical to the 'b'G.O.P.'b' point of view. Yet here\xe2\x80\x99s the irony: In their own offices, Republicans are often very generous with federal money, giving their staffs plenty of compensated time off to care for a child.'b'Last week, I wrote to all 100 Senate offices and asked how they individually handled parental leave. While only 26 replied (not surprising, really; it meant voluntarily laying bare their private policies, always a touchy subject), it\xe2\x80\x99s worth noting that virtually all of the respondents \xe2\x80\x94 15 Democrats, two independents and nine Republicans \xe2\x80\x94 said they provided paid leave of some kind. What this means, practically speaking, is that all of them go above and beyond what the Family and Medical Leave Act requires \xe2\x80\x94 12 weeks of unpaid leave, assuming both employee and employer meet the requirements.'b'The traditional liberal rap on the Republican Party is that its policies are hostile to working women. But that\xe2\x80\x99s clearly not how Republicans conduct themselves as bosses on Capitol Hill.'b'Marco Rubio, the conservative presidential hopeful from Florida, gives his staff as much paid maternity and paternity leave (12 and six weeks, respectively) as Bernie Sanders, who started his career as an \xe2\x80\x9cunabashed socialist\xe2\x80\x9d in Vermont and went on to co-found the Congressional Progressive Caucus. The Republican Mike Enzi, who successfully beat back a primary challenge from Liz Cheney in Wyoming last year, gives six weeks of paid maternity leave, which is identical to the policy of Dianne Feinstein, once the mayor of highly liberal San Francisco. (Barbara Boxer, also from California, offers 12, to both parents.)'b'In offering eight paid weeks of parental leave for both sexes, the Mississippi Republican Thad Cochran goes further than the Missouri Democrat Claire McCaskill, who offers the same for mothers but for dads, three. The Tennessee Republican Lamar Alexander, the chairman of the HELP Committee (Health, Education, Labor and Pensions) gives 12 paid weeks of maternity leave, which is just a tad more than the Delaware Democrat Chris Coons, who offers 10. (Most of these offices also say their employees can supplement their leave with unused sick and vacation days.)'b'In other words, when confronted with the life challenges of their own personnel, these elected officials all believe paid compensation is in order.'b'One might expect this from Democrats, who, as a matter of principle, believe that governments have an obligation to care for their citizenry when the free market fails to do so. But it\xe2\x80\x99s more surprising from Republicans, who generally speaking, do not. The question is, why?'b'I put this question to Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, who offers six weeks of paid parental leave (and an extra two for the mother if there are complications during pregnancy). Her position is that there\xe2\x80\x99s a difference between the government\xe2\x80\x99s requesting that employers do something and requiring that they do it. In her office\xe2\x80\x99s case, she says that yes, she decided to set aside money for paid leave, but \xe2\x80\x9cit means making cuts elsewhere \xe2\x80\x94 cutting the number of people we hire over all, or the travel my staff is able to do.\xe2\x80\x9d When it comes to the private sector, she says, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s up to businesses to make that decision.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And this belief is perfectly respectable as far as it goes. The problem is that we, as a nation, have been running this experiment for decades now, and the verdict is clear: Without government assistance \xe2\x80\x94 or nudging \xe2\x80\x94 most businesses will never feel the obligation to pay for family leave on their own. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, only 11 percent of private-sector workers got paid family leave in 2012. As Mr. Obama noted this summer, \xe2\x80\x9cmany women can\xe2\x80\x99t even get a paid day off to give birth.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ms. Fischer has attempted to provide a bipartisan solution to this problem by co-authoring a bill with Angus King, a Maine Independent who caucuses with Democrats, that would provide tax credits to businesses offering families paid leave. This notion is surely more palatable to the Republican-led Congress than Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s initiative, which involves $2.2 billion in spending. But Ms. Fischer frankly concedes that she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t expect Congress to entertain their bill this session.'b'Yet there\xe2\x80\x99s a solid case to be made that paid family leave is good for business. Three years ago, Rutgers\xe2\x80\x99 Center for Women and Work issued a report showing that women who took paid leave were far more likely to be working for the same employer a year later. It also added that women and men who returned to work after paid leave were far less likely to collect food stamps or public assistance in the year following their child\xe2\x80\x99s birth. As Ms. Fischer herself says, family leave also helps people on her staff \xe2\x80\x9cdo their job well. They\xe2\x80\x99re not preoccupied, they\xe2\x80\x99re not worrying about everything that\xe2\x80\x99s happening at home when they\xe2\x80\x99re at work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S already a clich\xc3\xa9 to point out that the United States is the sole industrialized nation without a paid maternity leave policy. (In case you\xe2\x80\x99re wondering what we have in common with Papua New Guinea, this is it.) According to a Pew study last April, our inability to provide affordable child care as a nation may help explain our declining rates in women\xe2\x80\x99s participation in the work force.'b'Absent state funding and intervention on this matter, it falls to individual families \xe2\x80\x94 small, fragile, closed little loops of two parents (if that) \xe2\x80\x94 to resolve what the state and the private sector do not. It\xe2\x80\x99s utterly exhausting to them. It means a scarcity economy at home, with spouses quarreling about whose career is more important and whose time is more valuable. Someone almost inevitably needs to scale back ambitions or earning power in order to make life work.'b'And that someone, usually, is the mom. Which brings me to this final plea: Even the most enlightened Senate offices \xe2\x80\x94 and private-sector offices \xe2\x80\x94 seem to believe that fathers require fewer weeks of leave than mothers. Mr. Obama himself referred to \xe2\x80\x9cmaternity leave\xe2\x80\x9d in his 'b'State of the Union address'b', not \xe2\x80\x9cparental leave,\xe2\x80\x9d as he had in previous statements. There are hundreds of arguments to make in favor of parity between the sexes when it comes to family leave. (High among them: More engaged dads allow their wives to lean in; more and more gay men are having kids, and shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be subjected to different rules.) But here, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to name a very modest reason: It would make things more tranquil at home. Over and over again in my research, I hear mothers of newborns say, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen my husband comes home from work, he wants to comfort the baby, but he can\xe2\x80\x99t, because the baby is used to me.\xe2\x80\x9d And then the fights begin. Because Mom is tired. Mom wants a break.'b'I doubt mothers would be hearing such things if fathers took equal time off from the get-go \xe2\x80\x94 paid or unpaid. Couples would be dividing child care and the domestic tasks more equitably (at present, mothers do nearly twice as much of both); they would also have two expert hands on deck. Their marriages would be stronger. And they\xe2\x80\x99d have the Republican Congress to thank.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 THE talk up in Boston is all about deflation while the talk down here is all about inflation.'b'Our sleek, techie president, whose battery dies faster than an iPhone\xe2\x80\x99s, was fully charged Tuesday night for the State of the Union.'b'He was so puffed up, with such a bristling sense of self, that it was hard to believe this was the same guy who spent the last year clenched like a fist, beset by ISIS, beheadings and Ebola, shunned by his own party and slammed by the other party in the fall election.'b'The murmur went up from grateful Democrats gathered at the Capitol: \xe2\x80\x9cWow, he\xe2\x80\x99s got a pulse.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Proving once again that he is a different kind of cat, Barack Obama is oddly pumped by his party\xe2\x80\x99s defeat. The loss of his girlfriend, kids and job was a huge blow.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt knocked him to the dirt,\xe2\x80\x9d says his younger brother, Clayton, also a pal of mine. \xe2\x80\x9cIt destroyed his self-esteem.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Kevin\xe2\x80\x99s weight ballooned to 350 pounds, and he developed diabetes and had a couple of heart attacks. He grew marijuana and self-medicated with it, Clayton says, and was arrested for drug offenses.'b'My kids would see Kevin and me together and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe he had run cross country with me, and that he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t 20 years older.'b'Kevin eventually got disability benefits, but he was far behind in child support and was punished by losing his driver\xe2\x80\x99s license \xe2\x80\x94 which made it pretty much impossible to get a job in a rural area. Disability helped Kevin by providing a monthly check that he desperately needed, but it also hurt him because he might have looked harder for a job if he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been getting those checks, Clayton says.'b'Yet it\xe2\x80\x99s absurd to think that people like Kevin are somehow living it up. After child support deductions, he was living on about $180 a month plus food stamps and a small income from selling home-grown pot. He supplemented this by growing a huge vegetable garden and fishing in the Yamhill River.'b'Three years ago, Cindy died of a heart attack at 52. Then doctors told Kevin a few weeks ago that his heart, liver and kidneys were failing, and that he was dying. He had trouble walking. He was in pain.'b'He was also worried about his twin boys. They had trouble in school and with the law, jailed for drug and other offenses. The upward mobility that had seemed so promising a generation ago turned out to be a mirage. Family structure dissolved, and lives become grueling \xe2\x80\x94 and shorter.'b'Kevin wrote a will a few days before he died. He bequeathed his life\xe2\x80\x99s savings of $3,500 to his mom for his funeral expenses. Anything left over is to be divided between his children \xe2\x80\x94 and he begs them not to fight over it. His ashes will be sprinkled on the farm.'b'I have trouble diagnosing just what went wrong in that odyssey from sleek distance runner to his death at 54, but the lack of good jobs was central to it. Sure, Kevin made mistakes, but his dad had opportunities for good jobs that Kevin never had.'b'So, Kevin Green, R.I.P. You were a good man \xe2\x80\x94 hardworking and always on the lookout for someone to help \xe2\x80\x94 yet you were overturned by 'b'riptides of inequality'b'. Those who would judge you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a clue. They could use a dose of your own empathy.'b'IN \xe2\x80\x9cRomeo and Juliet,\xe2\x80\x9d the young Miss Capulet poses one of literature\xe2\x80\x99s most famous questions: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s in a name?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When it comes to a street name, the answer is: a lot.'b'Street names tell stories. They tell us if a neighborhood is expensive or affordable, brand-new or decades old. With street names alone, we can uncover all kinds of insights.'b'This might seem surprising, especially given the relatively random process by which streets get their names. A real-estate developer might come up with a motif that seems relevant to a particular place, or just an arbitrary theme \xe2\x80\x94 Caribbean, equestrian, or United States presidents. Some developers hold competitions among employees and then pick the winning names. The local government usually takes a look at the resulting map, just to make sure the names won\xe2\x80\x99t confuse mail carriers or ambulance drivers. And that\xe2\x80\x99s about it.'b'But if you look at enough data, patterns start to emerge. Even randomness has an order.'b'Turning to the same database we use to estimate and analyze home values, we looked at years of data about sales and listings. We learned three things about the relationship between home values and street names: First, names are better than numbers. Second, lanes are better than streets. Third, unusual names are better than common ones.'b'Imagine that one of us (Spencer) lives on 10th Street and the other (Stan) lives on Elm Street. With only this information, we can guess that Stan\xe2\x80\x99s house is probably worth more than Spencer\xe2\x80\x99s. On average, homes on named streets are 2 percent more valuable than those on numbered streets. (We looked only at single-family homes, condos and co-ops. Large apartment buildings \xe2\x80\x94 especially in New York City \xe2\x80\x94 would skew the data.)'b'For some cities, this named-street premium is higher \xe2\x80\x94 greater than 20 percent on average in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Riverside, Calif., and San Francisco. We found only three cities where named streets don\xe2\x80\x99t have the upper hand. In Atlanta and New York, named and numbered streets are roughly equal. Denver is the sole city where numbered streets are more valuable.'b'Next we looked at street suffixes \xe2\x80\x94 the \xe2\x80\x9croads,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdrives\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cboulevards\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and found that, for instance, homes on \xe2\x80\x9cWashington Street\xe2\x80\x9d are usually different from homes on \xe2\x80\x9cWashington Court.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For one thing, a house on Washington Street is probably older. Different street suffixes were popular at different moments. \xe2\x80\x9cStreets\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cavenues\xe2\x80\x9d were stylish in the 1950s, \xe2\x80\x9cways,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccircles\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccourts\xe2\x80\x9d in the late \xe2\x80\x9980s.'b'Street suffixes also offer clues about the size of their neighborhood. Boulevards and avenues include the most homes on average, while courts and lanes include the fewest.'b'Most significant, suffixes have a lot to say about home prices. Homes on \xe2\x80\x9cstreets\xe2\x80\x9d are almost always among the least valuable. If you\xe2\x80\x99re looking for a higher-value home, you\xe2\x80\x99re much more likely to find it on a \xe2\x80\x9cway\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cplace.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Which brings us to our third rule: You should also look at streets with uncommon names.'b'Nationally, the most common street names tend to have the lowest home values. Look at Main Street. It\xe2\x80\x99s by far the most common street name in America. It\xe2\x80\x99s also the least valuable. Main Street homes are worth, on average, about 4 percent less than America\xe2\x80\x99s median.'b'On the other side of the spectrum are \xe2\x80\x9cLake\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSunset.\xe2\x80\x9d Homes on \xe2\x80\x9cLake\xe2\x80\x9d average 16 percent more than the national median home value, and \xe2\x80\x9cSunset\xe2\x80\x9d houses are a close second.'b'We aren\xe2\x80\x99t recommending that you start a petition to rename your street. Correlation is not causation. Homes on \xe2\x80\x9cLake\xe2\x80\x9d aren\xe2\x80\x99t more valuable because of the name; generally they\xe2\x80\x99re more valuable because the descriptive name reflects a truth about the real estate. In this case, they\xe2\x80\x99re probably next to \xe2\x80\x94 you guessed it \xe2\x80\x94 a lake.'b'And of course, all of these rules reflect broad national trends. There are plenty of exceptions; like politics, all home values, trends and characteristics are local.'b'No matter where you look, however, street names have meaning. They are artifacts from a neighborhood\xe2\x80\x99s genesis, bearing data that we finally can uncover.'b'Just a few years ago, real estate information was guarded in county courthouses and secret databases. Shopping for a home was like being in a dark room. An agent might shine a flashlight on two or three homes \xe2\x80\x94 but all you wanted was to flip the switch and see it all for yourself. Today, real estate information is more transparent and democratized; the connection between street names and home values is only the beginning. Buying, selling, renting, regulating and financing all have been illuminated.'b'ARE you confused by sex? I certainly am.'b'One of the many reasons sex is puzzling is that we lack reliable data. People lie to friends, lovers, doctors, surveys and themselves.'b'Three years ago, when I was a graduate student in economics, I began to write about how new data, particularly Google searches, could give us fresh insights into socially sensitive topics. Since then, many people have asked me to write about sex.'b'I was wary because I wanted to do more research. Now I\xe2\x80\x99m finally ready to report. Call it everything you always wanted to know about sex, but didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the data to ask.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s start with the basics. How much sex are we having? Traditional surveys are no good at answering this question.'b'I analyzed data from the General Social Survey, a classic source. Heterosexual men 18 and over say that they average 63 sex acts per year, using a condom in 23 percent of them. This adds up to more than 1.6 billion heterosexual condom uses per year.'b'Heterosexual women say they average 55 sex acts per year, using a condom in 16 percent of them. This adds up to about 1.1 billion heterosexual condom uses per year.'b'Who is telling the truth, men or women?'b'Neither. According to Nielsen, fewer than 600 million condoms are sold every year.'b'Americans may also be exaggerating how often they have unprotected sex. About 11 percent of women between the ages of 15 and 44 say they are sexually active, not currently pregnant and not using contraception. Even with relatively conservative assumptions about how many times they are having sex, we would expect 10 percent to become pregnant every month. But this would already be more than the total number of pregnancies in the United States (which is one in 113 women of childbearing age).'b'Men who have never been married claim to average 29 condom uses per year. This is more than the total number of condoms sold in the United States to married and single people combined.'b'Married people probably exaggerate how much sex they have, too. On average, married men under 65 tell surveys they have sex once a week. Only 1 percent say they have gone the past year without sex. Married women say there is a little less sex but not much less.'b'Google searches give a far less lively picture of sex during marriage.'b'On Google, the top complaint about a marriage is not having sex. Searches for \xe2\x80\x9csexless marriage\xe2\x80\x9d are three and a half times more common than \xe2\x80\x9cunhappy marriage\xe2\x80\x9d and eight times more common than \xe2\x80\x9cloveless marriage.\xe2\x80\x9d There are 16 times more complaints about a spouse not wanting sex than about a married partner not being willing to talk.'b'Even couples not yet married complain somewhat frequently about lack of sex. Google searches for \xe2\x80\x9csexless relationship\xe2\x80\x9d are second only to searches for \xe2\x80\x9cabusive relationship.\xe2\x80\x9d (Abusive relationships are obviously a very important topic that I will return to in the future.)'b'On Google, there are five and a half times more complaints about an unmarried partner not wanting sex than an unmarried partner refusing to text back. There are more complaints that a boyfriend \xe2\x80\x9cwon\xe2\x80\x99t have sex\xe2\x80\x9d than that a \xe2\x80\x9cgirlfriend\xe2\x80\x9d won\xe2\x80\x99t. Complaints about \xe2\x80\x9chusbands\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwives\xe2\x80\x9d are roughly equal. (One quick point about sexuality. I am assuming that a large majority of searches with \xe2\x80\x9cmy girlfriend\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cmy wife\xe2\x80\x9d are by men. In 'b'a previous article'b', I argued that more men are gay than surveys suggest and that the closet remains a cause of huge amounts of secret suffering. But I also found that about 95 percent of men are heterosexual.) Taken altogether, the data suggest that Americans manage to have sex about 30 times per year \xe2\x80\x94 or once every 12 days.'b'Sex can be quite fun. Why do we have so little of it?'b'Google searches suggest one predominant reason: enormous anxiety, with much of it misplaced.'b'Start with men\xe2\x80\x99s neuroses. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t news that men worry about their genitals, but the degree of this worry is rather profound. From a Google search alone, we cannot know the gender of a user. However, we can often make a pretty good guess for searches about sex and body parts, like \xe2\x80\x9cmy penis ____.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Men Google more questions about their sexual organ than any other body part: more than about their lungs, liver, feet, ears, nose, throat and brain combined.'b'Men make more searches asking how to make their penises bigger than how to tune a guitar, make an omelet or change a tire. Men\xe2\x80\x99s top Googled concern about steroids is whether taking them might make their penis smaller. Men\xe2\x80\x99s top Googled question related to how their body or mind changed as they aged was whether their penis got smaller.'b'Side note: One of the more common questions for Google about a penis is \xe2\x80\x9cHow big is my penis?\xe2\x80\x9d That men turn to Google, rather than a ruler, with this question is, in my opinion, a quintessential expression of our digital era.'b'Do women care about penis size? Rarely, according to Google searches. For every search women make about a partner\xe2\x80\x99s phallus, men make roughly 170 searches about their own.'b'TRUE, on the rare occasions women do express concerns about a partner\xe2\x80\x99s penis, it is frequently about its size, but not necessarily that it is small. More than 40 percent of complaints about a partner\xe2\x80\x99s penis size is that it is too big. \xe2\x80\x9cPain\xe2\x80\x9d is the most Googled word used in searches with the phrase \xe2\x80\x9c___ during sex.\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cBleeding,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpeeing,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccrying\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfarting\xe2\x80\x9d round out the top five.)'b'One percent of searches looking to change one\xe2\x80\x99s penis size are seeking information on how to make it smaller.'b'Another major sexual concern is climaxing prematurely. Men\xe2\x80\x99s second-most-common sex question is how to make their sexual encounters longer.'b'Once again, the insecurities of men do not appear to match the concerns of women. There are roughly the same number of searches asking how to make a boyfriend climax more quickly as climax more slowly. In fact, the most common concern women have related to a boyfriend\xe2\x80\x99s orgasm isn\xe2\x80\x99t about when it happened but why it isn\xe2\x80\x99t happening at all.'b'We do not often talk about male body insecurity. And while it is true that overall interest in personal appearance skews female, it is not as lopsided as stereotypes would suggest. According to my analysis of Google AdWords (also based on anonymous, aggregate web activity), interest in beauty and fitness is 42 percent male; weight loss is 33 percent male; and cosmetic surgery is 39 percent male. Among all searches with \xe2\x80\x9chow to\xe2\x80\x9d related to breasts, about 20 percent ask how to get rid of man breasts.'b'What can this new data teach us about women\xe2\x80\x99s insecurities? Every year, in the United States, there are more than seven million searches looking into breast implants. Official statistics tell us that about 300,000 women go through with it annually.'b'Women also show a great deal of insecurity about their behinds, although many women have recently flip-flopped on what it is they don\xe2\x80\x99t like about them.'b'In 2004, in some parts of the United States, the most common search regarding changing one\xe2\x80\x99s butt was how to make it smaller. The desire to make one\xe2\x80\x99s bottom bigger was overwhelmingly concentrated in areas with large black populations. Beginning in 2010, however, the desire for bigger butts grew in the rest of the United States. This interest has tripled in four years. In 2014, there were more searches asking how to make your butt bigger than smaller in every state. These days, for every five searches looking into breast implants in the United States, there is one looking into butt implants.'b'Does women\xe2\x80\x99s growing preference for a larger behind match men\xe2\x80\x99s preferences? Interestingly, yes. \xe2\x80\x9cBig butt porn\xe2\x80\x9d searches, which also used to be concentrated in black communities, have recently shot up in popularity throughout the United States.'b'What else do men want in a woman\xe2\x80\x99s body? In the no surprise department, men show a preference for large breasts. About 12 percent of nongeneric pornographic searches are looking for big breasts. This is nearly 20 times higher than the search volume for small-breast porn.'b'That said, it is not clear that this means men want women to get breast implants. About 3 percent of big-breast porn searches explicitly say they want to see natural breasts.'b'Google searches about one\xe2\x80\x99s wife and breast implants are evenly split between asking how to persuade her to get implants and perplexity as to why she wants them.'b'Or consider the most common search about a girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s breasts: \xe2\x80\x9cI love my girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s boobs.\xe2\x80\x9d It is not clear what men are hoping to find from Google when making this search.'b'Women, like men, have questions about their genitals. In fact, they have nearly as many questions about their vaginas as men have about their penises. Women\xe2\x80\x99s worries about their vaginas are often health-related. But at least 30 percent of their questions take up other concerns. Women want to know how to shave it, tighten it and make it taste better. A strikingly common concern is how to improve its odor.'b'Women are most frequently concerned that their vaginas smell like fish, followed by vinegar, onions, ammonia, garlic, cheese, body odor, urine, bread, bleach, feces, sweat, metal, feet, garbage and rotten meat.'b'In general, men do not make many Google searches involving a partner\xe2\x80\x99s genitalia. Men make roughly the same number of searches about a girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s vagina as women do about a boyfriend\xe2\x80\x99s penis.'b'When men do search about a partner\xe2\x80\x99s vagina, it is usually to complain about what women worry about most: the odor. Mostly, men are trying to figure out how to tell a woman about a bad odor without hurting her feelings. Sometimes, however, men\xe2\x80\x99s questions about the odor reveal their own insecurities. Men occasionally ask for ways to use the smell to detect cheating \xe2\x80\x94 if it smells like condoms, for example, or another man\xe2\x80\x99s semen.'b'I know I am obsessed with Google searches and other new data sets. I ask myself all the time whether I am taking it too far. Every researcher, no matter how grounded in data, can let his biases get in the way of the truth. This data is all public. Other researchers will undoubtedly add their own interpretations and ask new questions.'b'Dan Ariely, a psychologist at Duke, offers a reason for caution in interpreting this data. While most data sources underestimate sexual thoughts, he suspects that Google may overestimate them.'b'As Professor Ariely put it, \xe2\x80\x9cGoogle is a reflection of what people don\xe2\x80\x99t know and need extra information about.\xe2\x80\x9d If you want to know how to make omelets, you may just ask a relative. You are less likely to ask your relatives about penis enlargement.'b'Another surprising thing about \xe2\x80\x9cbig data\xe2\x80\x9d is how small it often is. Many people expect that any given Google search will be made millions of times. You may look at the accompanying graphic that includes the total monthly search volumes for various phrases and think, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'People do not type everything they think into Google. Google data is a small sample of everybody\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts and concerns. It is suggestive, not definitive.'b'I AM hardly an expert on sex. Professionally, I am neither a psychologist nor a sex therapist.'b'But here\xe2\x80\x99s what I think.'b'Just about every study I have done relying on Google searches made me feel worse about the world. Huge numbers of people are racist and sexist; far too many children suffer from unreported abuse. But after studying the new data on sex, I actually feel better.'b'This data makes me feel less lonely. In my previous studies of Google data, I had found the viciousness that humans often hide. But this time around, I have seen our hidden insecurities. Men and women are united in this insecurity and confusion.'b'Google also gives us legitimate reasons to worry less than we do. Many of our deepest fears about how our sexual partners perceive us are unjustified. Alone, at their computers, with no incentive to lie, partners reveal themselves to be fairly nonsuperficial and forgiving. In fact, we are all so busy judging our own bodies that there is little energy left over to judge other people\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'Maybe if we worried less about sex, we\xe2\x80\x99d have more of it.'b'The country\xe2\x80\x99s economy increased at a slower rate in 2014 than in previous years.'b'PARIS \xe2\x80\x94  The typical trajectory of most French Islamist terrorists follows four steps: alienation from the dominant culture, thanks partly to joblessness and discrimination in blighted neighborhoods; a turn to petty crime, which leads to prison, and then more crime and more prison; religious awakening and radicalization; and an initiatory journey to a Muslim country like Syria, Afghanistan or Yemen to train for jihad.'b'Stints in prison were seminal for Ch\xc3\xa9rif Kouachi, Amedy Coulibaly and other major figures of French jihadism in recent years \xe2\x80\x94 Mohammed Merah, Mehdi Nemmouche, Khaled Kelkal \xe2\x80\x94 as both a rite of passage and a gateway to radicalism.'b'Muslims account for about 7-10 percent of 'b'France'b'\xe2\x80\x99s total population but around half of its prison population of 68,000. Muslims are even more numerous in facilities near large cities, particularly in maisons d\xe2\x80\x99arr\xc3\xaat, which hold prisoners serving shorter sentences.'b'Precise figures are unavailable because la\xc3\xafcit\xc3\xa9, France\xe2\x80\x99s strict form of secularism, prohibits officially asking and collecting data about people\xe2\x80\x99s religious preferences. These estimates are based on research I conducted in French prisons in 2000-3 and again in 2011-3, when I interviewed some 160 inmates and many guards, doctors and social workers in four major facilities, some among the largest in Europe. Fifteen of those inmates had been sentenced for terrorist acts.'b'Many Muslims feel marginalized when they get to prison, due to exclusion and bigotry from the white majority in mainstream society, and their own counterracism. Although in urban prisons they are a majority, they continue to feel victimized and trapped. Very few guards are Muslim, and prison officials, who tend to be hypersecular, have little understanding of Islam, for example confusing fundamentalism with extremism.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook at how a Catholic or a Jew is treated, and look at how we are treated,\xe2\x80\x9d Abdelkarim, a Frenchman of Italian origin in his late 20s who was serving a five-year sentence for armed robbery, told me in 2012. \xe2\x80\x9cThey have their weekly prayers; in this prison we don\xe2\x80\x99t have Friday prayers. Their rabbi can go to all the cells; our Muslim minister cannot. There\xe2\x80\x99s kosher food, but no halal meat. They despise us, and they call that la\xc3\xafcit\xc3\xa9.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In fact, Muslim ministers can visit Muslim inmates in their cells but usually don\xe2\x80\x99t do it for lack of time, and halal meat is increasingly available. But such misperceptions are common, and they only reinforce the appeal of Islam as the religion of choice for the stigmatized and the oppressed. Unlike Christianity, it has an anti-Western and anti-imperialist bend.'b'One young French inmate of Algerian origin told me in 2013, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are a Muslim and ask to participate in the Friday prayers, they take your name down and hand it over to the Renseignements G\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9raux.\xe2\x80\x9d (The Renseignements G\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9raux is the French equivalent of the FBI.) He added: \xe2\x80\x9cIf I try to take my prayer carpet to the courtyard, they prohibit it. If I grow a beard, the guards call me Bin Laden, smiling and mocking me. They hate Islam. But Islam can take revenge!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Adherence to radical Islam is largely the transfer into the spiritual realm of that particular combination of indignation, rancor and wholesale rejection encompassed by the expression, widespread among prisoners, \xe2\x80\x9cavoir la haine\xe2\x80\x9d (to have hate). For some inmates, especially those who were only nominally Muslim and nonpracticing, violent aspirations emerge first, with religiosity \xe2\x80\x94 and often a very approximate understanding of Islam \xe2\x80\x94 grafting itself onto to them later.'b'Abdelkarim, who converted to Islam (and adopted an Arabic name) about a decade before I met him, acted as an informal Salafist chaplain; his prison counted about 1,000 Muslim inmates and just one Muslim minister, an older gentleman from North Africa out of touch with the young prisoners\xe2\x80\x99 concerns. Each time Abdelkarim sang the call to prayer at dawn he would be sent to solitary confinement for a few days; eventually he was transferred to another jail. Nationwide, there is only about one Muslim minister for every 190 inmates, leaving self-proclaimed ulama to proffer their own religious guidance.'b'Radical preaching catches on because it offers young Muslim prisoners a way to escape their predicament and develop a fantasy of omnipotence by declaring death onto their oppressors. During my research in 2000-3, the prisoners idolized Khaled Kelkal, whose network killed eight people in a Paris subway station in 1995 to punish the French government for backing a military coup against an Islamist party in Algeria. A decade later their new icon was Mohammed Merah, who in 2012 shot down seven people, including soldiers and Jewish children, in the name of radical Islam; some inmates even impersonated him. Now the new celebrities will be the Kouachi brothers and Coulibaly.'b'About three months ago, the authorities at Fresnes, a very large prison known for its strict discipline, started experimenting with separating suspected Muslim radicals from the general population, grouping them in special cells. Although it is too early to assess the measure\xe2\x80\x99s effectiveness, the provisional results are mixed.'b'The prisoners\xe2\x80\x99 segregation at Fresnes is incomplete, owing to the shape of the 19th-century building. With rows of cell blocks branching out perpendicularly from a central corridor, the inmates can communicate with each other simply by shouting. The radicalized prisoners now have less influence on other inmates, especially ones who are impressionable or have mental disorders. But they are in closer contact with one another, allowing them to organize and make plans.'b'Prime Minister Manuel Valls announced recently that the quarantine program would be expanded in several prisons around Paris. The proposal needs to be refined. Seasoned jihadists must be separated from untested radicals and the returnees from, say, Syria and Iraq, who may have been traumatized or disappointed by their experience of jihad and still stand a chance of being reintegrated into mainstream society.'b'More must also be done to address the legitimate claims of Muslim inmates. Collective Friday prayers should be allowed in all French prisons, for example. The government announced last week that 60 Muslim ministers would be trained to supplement the 182 or so currently in service. This is a welcome proposal. But at least three times as many ministers are needed, and they must be more uniformly distributed throughout the prisons. Above all, they will need to be coached to better understand and address the concerns of disaffected young Muslim prisoners.'b'Indeed, reform must begin with respect. For if French prisons have become a breeding ground for radicalism, it is partly because they mistreat the Islamic faith itself.'b''b'\n'b'Farhad Khosrokhavar 'b' is a sociologist at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales and the author, most recently, of \xe2\x80\x9cRadicalisation.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94  America and 'b'Iran'b' took a step toward a final nuclear deal on Jan. 18, but they should be making leaps. The negotiators have proposed some creative solutions but major political compromises are sorely needed, and soon.'b'If a framework agreement can\xe2\x80\x99t be reached in March, the talks could become mired in stalemate. Those who oppose any diplomacy between Iran and the West are already seeking to end the process altogether. With time, they will gain further ammunition.'b'Spoilers have been striking from Tehran, Washington and Tel Aviv. Some are trying to limit the ability of President 'b'Barack Obama'b' (or whoever succeeds him) to deliver a reasonable sanctions-relief package to Iran. Others are seeking to corner Iran and force its government into knee-jerk reactions to regional flare-ups. Hard-liners in the United States and Iran see the nuclear negotiations as an opportunity to score points domestically and they are escalating their efforts to scuttle a grand bargain.'b'Although the Obama administration has dedicated itself to multilateral diplomacy with Iran, it has been under constant pressure from Congress. Powerful American legislators, influential lobby groups and the Israeli prime minister have repeatedly called for increased economic pressure on Iran to extract further concessions. Not only does this contradict America\xe2\x80\x99s interest in maintaining the freeze on Iran\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'nuclear program'b', but it also devalues the agreement brokered between Iran and France, Britain, Russia, China, America and Germany.'b'Threats by American lawmakers to impose further sanctions on Iran have already poisoned the spirit of the talks and created doubt among Iranians about whether the United States is able and willing to deliver on its promises. This has provoked hard-liners in Tehran to respond with their own threats that Iran would increase its enrichment capacity should new sanctions pass.'b'During his 'b'State of the Union address'b', President Obama made clear that he would veto any proposals for additional sanctions on Iran. And although officials in Tehran recognize this as a good faith gesture on the part of Mr. Obama, they also remember that a Congressional bill introduced in late 2013 nearly garnered enough support to withstand a similar veto threat. Iranian officials worry that the Obama administration is constitutionally unable to make a durable and ironclad promise of sanctions relief as part of a final deal. With a Republican majority in both chambers of Congress, and House Speaker John Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s invitation to Prime Minister 'b'Benjamin Netanyahu'b' to address Congress for a third time, Iran fears that Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s veto won\xe2\x80\x99t be enough.'b'At the same time, Iran is at risk of losing the West\xe2\x80\x99s trust. There is a danger that Iran will damage its newfound reputation as a good faith interlocutor by retaliating for the presumed Israeli attack that killed Hezbollah operatives and an Iranian general in Syria last Sunday.'b'Iran believes the strike was a premeditated Israeli operation targeting a high-level Iranian official. Influential hardliners in Tehran\xe2\x80\x99s security establishment view it as an act of aggression by 'b'Israel'b' and demand a direct response.'b'But any such retaliation, either overtly by Iran or covertly through Hezbollah, would likely prompt Israel\xe2\x80\x99s European and American allies to halt the nuclear negotiations altogether \xe2\x80\x94 especially if the retaliation involves attacks against civilians.'b'The Iranian government must decide how openly it wishes to involve itself in the inevitable Hezbollah retaliation while ensuring its tactics do not threaten Iran\xe2\x80\x99s long-term strategic objective of securing a nuclear deal. Iran prudently avoided any entanglement in the Gaza conflict over the summer \xe2\x80\x94 and it should continue to keep its distance.'b'If Tehran responds excessively, or if operations are carried out unofficially by Iranian hard-liners, this would escalate the Israeli-Iranian standoff and could derail the nuclear talks completely.'b'March will be an important month for all parties. The results of the Israeli elections could deflate Tel Aviv\xe2\x80\x99s fierce opposition to current negotiations with Iran. For Mr. Netanyahu, blocking any nuclear deal is a personal investment. Some of his political rivals do not necessarily share his fervor on the issue. They view a nuclear deal as less of a threat and place more value on maintaining Israel\xe2\x80\x99s strong alliances with European nations and the United States, all of whom seek a nuclear deal with Iran. If Mr. Netanyahu is defeated by a less hawkish opponent, the Obama administration will have an easier time reassuring Israel about any deal with Iran and there would also be less Israeli pressure on Congress.'b'March is also symbolic for Mr. Rouhani, who is eager to mark the Iranian New Year with a psychological shift on sanctions and engagement with the West. They granted his request but they will not tolerate talks that continue to be extended indefinitely with no tangible sanctions relief in sight.'b'The extension of negotiations has prevented a return to hostile rhetoric between Iran and the West. But tepid progress without any major concessions is a blessing for spoilers, who will use the additional time to sabotage diplomacy.'b'Iran must not allow its short-term ideological pursuits in the region to jeopardize its overarching strategic objective: achieving a comprehensive nuclear deal that brings sanctions relief and provides Iran the option of having a functional relationship with the West.'b'Likewise, the United States must not allow a myopic and obstructionist Congress to derail a deal that is in Washington\xe2\x80\x99s long-term interest and strengthens global security.'b''b'\n'b'Ellie Geranmayeh 'b' is a policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations. After a tense, week-long negotiation between a special committee and the minister of the economy, Emmanuel Macron, the National Assembly will begin debate Monday on whether department stores and shops will be allowed to open more often on what has been a traditional day of rest.'b'During his presidential campaign in 2012, 'b'Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande'b' lambasted the Right for its efforts to transform Sunday into a day like any other, devoted to business and material gain. In 1906, the government grudgingly conceded Sundays as a day of repose, hoping that if workers spent more time at home they would spend less time drinking in cafes. And the recovery now underway, such as it is, is barely visible, offering no prospect of returning to precrisis living standards for the foreseeable future.'b'What went wrong? I fairly often encounter assertions to the effect that Greece didn\xe2\x80\x99t carry through on its promises, that it failed to deliver the promised spending cuts. Nothing could be further from the truth. In reality, Greece imposed savage cuts in public services, wages of government workers and social benefits. Thanks to repeated further waves of austerity, public spending was cut much more than the original program envisaged, and it\xe2\x80\x99s currently about 20 percent lower than it was in 2010.'b'Yet Greek debt troubles are if anything worse than before the program started. One reason is that the economic plunge has reduced revenues: The Greek government is collecting a substantially higher share of G.D.P. in taxes than it used to, but G.D.P. has fallen so quickly that the overall tax take is down. Furthermore, the plunge in G.D.P. has caused a key fiscal indicator, the ratio of debt to G.D.P., to keep rising even though debt growth has slowed and Greece received some modest debt relief in 2012.'b'Why were the original projections so wildly overoptimistic? As I said, because supposedly hardheaded officials were in reality engaged in fantasy economics. Both the European Commission and the European Central Bank decided to believe in the confidence fairy \xe2\x80\x94 that is, to claim that the direct job-destroying effects of spending cuts would be more than made up for by a surge in private-sector optimism. The I.M.F. was more cautious, but it nonetheless grossly underestimated the damage austerity would do.'b'And here\xe2\x80\x99s the thing: If the troika had been truly realistic, it would have acknowledged that it was demanding the impossible. Two years after the Greek program began, the I.M.F. looked for historical examples where Greek-type programs, attempts to pay down debt through austerity without major debt relief or inflation, had been successful. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t find any.'b'So now that Mr. Tsipras has won, and won big, European officials would be well advised to skip the lectures calling on him to act responsibly and to go along with their program. The fact is they have no credibility; the program they imposed on Greece never made sense. It had no chance of working.'b'If anything, the problem with Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s plans may be that they\xe2\x80\x99re not radical enough. Debt relief and an easing of austerity would reduce the economic pain, but it\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful whether they are sufficient to produce a strong recovery. On the other hand, it\xe2\x80\x99s not clear what more any Greek government can do unless it\xe2\x80\x99s prepared to abandon the euro, and the Greek public isn\xe2\x80\x99t ready for that.'b'Still, in calling for a major change, Mr. Tsipras is being far more realistic than officials who want the beatings to continue until morale improves. The rest of Europe should give him a chance to end his country\xe2\x80\x99s nightmare.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'In a Safer Age, U.S. Rethinks Its \xe2\x80\x98Tough on Crime\xe2\x80\x99 System'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news analysis, front page, Jan. 14) doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mention a crucial piece of the public safety puzzle: What constitutes safety?'b'As the article notes, rates of crime have been falling in the United States, and abroad, for decades. The reasons for the drop are complicated, but we do know with certainty that the American policy of mass incarceration has failed to deliver on its public safety promise.'b'We also know that community safety has been undermined by excessive policing and the disproportionate incarceration of minority men. African-American and Latino communities continue to experience higher rates of justice involvement and victimization. For example, African-Americans, Latinos and whites engage in similar levels of drug use \xe2\x80\x94 behavior that is most likely to come to the attention of law enforcement \xe2\x80\x94 but minority communities are incarcerated at much higher levels\xc2\xa0than whites for drug crimes.'b'Both sides of the political aisle have been moving away from tough-on-crime policies because of the growing awareness of the failures and long-term costs of incarceration. The short-term costs of incarcerating a young person can run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, while the long-term costs associated with youth incarceration could cost taxpayers $8 billion to $21 billion a year.'b'To change this picture, we have to do more than just curb costs. We have to change laws, policies and practices that lead to too many people experiencing the prison and justice system, and invest in the success of the communities most affected by crime to advance community safety.'b'JASON ZIEDENBERG'b'\nDirector of Policy and Research'b'\nJustice Policy Institute'b'\nWashington, Jan. 14, 2015'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Why Drugs Cost So Much'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Jan. 15):'b'Peter B. CASTELLANI'b'\nPres. and Chief Exec., Pharmaceutical'b'\nResearch &amp; Manufacturers of America'b'\nWashington, Jan. 15, 2015'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The most effective means of reducing the outrageous prices of the new drugs described in Peter B. Grace has Type 1 diabetes, for which there is no cure. Now 15 years old, she has endured approximately 34,000 blood tests, 5,550 shots and 1,660 medical tubing injections to keep her alive.'b'Previously known as juvenile diabetes, Type 1 diabetes is usually diagnosed in children and young adults. With this form of the disease, the body does not produce its own insulin, the hormone that helps convert food into energy. Only 5 percent of patients have Type 1 diabetes (most have Type 2, in which the body produces insulin, but does not use it properly). Grace\xe2\x80\x99s experience with the disease has been particularly volatile. Her blood glucose levels must be checked and managed constantly; if they get too low, she could die within minutes.'b'Grace\xe2\x80\x99s parents have devoted their lives to keeping their daughter healthy.
