She can create her own \xe2\x80\x9cin group,\xe2\x80\x9d where only kind women are welcome.'b'MAREA WEXLER'b'\nNorthampton, Mass., Jan. 20, 2015'b''b'Nearly a decade ago, Mayor Michael Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s administration 'b'declared'b' \xe2\x80\x9ca new era of solid waste stewardship,\xe2\x80\x9d a veritable trash Enlightenment, when it adopted a plan that would handle New York City\xe2\x80\x99s garbage for the next 20 years. The plan was built on the reasonable and fair idea that each borough needed to take adequate responsibility for its own trash.'b'That era hasn\xe2\x80\x99t quite arrived \xe2\x80\x94 it awaits the completion of one key element, a marine transfer station on the East River in Manhattan, near 91st Street and York Avenue, where trash will be unloaded from trucks onto barges for shipment out of state. Nobody loves a floating dump, but this station has met ferocious opposition from Upper East Side residents alarmed by the prospect of noise, fumes, congestion and traffic accidents. The resistance continues, even though the station is well underway; hard hats and cranes are digging and lifting and are expected to be done by late 2016 or early 2017.'b'The Bloomberg plan was a good one, and still is. Mayor Bill de Blasio deserves credit for sticking with it under pressure. Fairness in this case trumps not-in-my-backyardism. And Yorkville and East Harlem are not doomed.'b'But this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that the worries are incomprehensible or that the plan can\xe2\x80\x99t be improved. The road to the bridge to the station, over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, cuts right through the middle of an athletic center called Asphalt Green, which is used by many schoolchildren. It\xe2\x80\x99s an unsettling juxtaposition \xe2\x80\x94 a continual stream of garbage trucks so close to little children\xe2\x80\x99s swimming lessons and soccer games, and a toddlers\xe2\x80\x99 playground.'b'The city says that it has the situation well in hand: that sidewalks and turn lanes will be carefully designed for maximal safety, and a person will actually be stationed at the corner to direct trucks and keep pedestrians safe.'b'Opponents are not placated. Asphalt Green hired Samuel Schwartz, an engineer and a former city traffic commissioner, to come up with something better, which he did: a plan to shift the access to the station a block north, using a service road of the F.D.R. Drive, so that garbage trucks go around and behind \xe2\x80\x94 instead of through \xe2\x80\x94 Asphalt Green. It\xe2\x80\x99s an intriguing idea that could go a long way toward making parents and children breathe easier. The city\xe2\x80\x99s sanitation commissioner, Kathryn Garcia, says her agency is looking at Mr. Schwartz\xe2\x80\x99s plan, with engineers calculating its costs and feasibility. A decision is expected in a few weeks.'b'The city should seriously consider the benefits of Mr. Schwartz\xe2\x80\x99s idea, for increased safety and for the station\xe2\x80\x99s peaceful coexistence with its unnerved neighbors. Some of those neighbors, though, will probably continue fighting the long war: At a recent meeting on traffic safety at a church a few blocks from Asphalt Green, transfer station opponents heckled Mr. Schwartz, demanding that he abandon his compromise proposal and instead join their fight to sink the transfer station completely.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s an unreasonable demand. What\xe2\x80\x99s reasonable is Mr. Schwartz\xe2\x80\x99s compromise, which has the twin benefits of helping the neighborhood\xe2\x80\x99s children and ensuring the success of Mr. Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s and Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s well-considered plan for all the city\xe2\x80\x99s waste.'b'LAST Thursday, 'b'Sheldon Silver'b', the speaker of the New York Assembly for the past 20 years, was arrested and charged with mail and wire fraud, extortion and receiving bribes. According to Preet Bharara, the federal prosecutor who brought the charges, the once seemingly untouchable Mr. Silver took millions of dollars for legal work he did not do. In exchange, he used his official power to steer business to a law firm that specialized in getting tax breaks for real estate developers, and he directed state funds to a doctor who referred cases to another law firm that paid Mr. Silver fees.'b'Albany is reeling, but fighting the kind of corruption that plagues not only New York State but the whole nation isn\xe2\x80\x99t just about getting cuffs on the right guy. As with the recent conviction of the former Virginia governor Bob McDonnell for receiving improper gifts and loans, a fixation on plain graft misses the more pernicious poison that has entered our system.'b'Corruption exists when institutions and officials charged with serving the public serve their own ends. Under current law, campaign contributions are illegal if there is an explicit quid pro quo, and legal if there isn\xe2\x80\x99t. But legal campaign contributions can be as bad as bribes in creating obligations. The corruption that hides in plain sight is the real threat to our democracy.'b'Think of campaign contributions as the gateway drug to bribes. In our private financing system, candidates are trained to respond to campaign cash and serve donors\xe2\x80\x99 interests. Politicians are expected to spend half their time talking to funders and to keep them happy. Given this context, it\xe2\x80\x99s not hard to see how a bribery charge can feel like a technical argument instead of a moral one.'b'The former 'b'governor of New York David A. Paterson, for example, said that he had trouble understanding where the criminality lay in the allegation'b' that Mr. Silver accepted payments from law firms for referrals, including referrals by a doctor to whom Mr. Silver funneled state health research funds. Mr. Paterson said, \xe2\x80\x9cin the legal profession, people refer business all the time. And theoretically, as a speaker, you could do that as well.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The legal shades into the illegal. The real estate developers represented by the law firm that allegedly shuttled payments to Mr. Silver for fake legal services were also major campaign contributors. One developer mentioned in the charges gave more than $10 million to political campaigns in the past decade, including $200,000 to Mr. Silver and his political action committees.'b'The structure of private campaign finance has essentially pre-corrupted our politicians, so that they can\xe2\x80\x99t even recognize explicit bribery because it feels the same as what they do every day. When you spend a lifetime serving campaign donors, it may seem easy to serve them when they come with an outright bribe, because it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem that different.'b'Mr. Silver retained such tight control over budgets and lawmaking in Albany that his staffers were regarded as more powerful than most elected representatives. As a Democrat who cares about education, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say that I loved seeing Mr. Silver, a great public school advocate, in handcuffs. For others, there\xe2\x80\x99s glee in seeing the perp walk. But one high-profile indictment does not represent the dawn of a new democracy.'b'We should take this moment to pursue fundamental reform. We must reconstitute what it means to run for office and to serve in office. We need to ban outside income for elected officials. Transparency alone is not enough; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t solve the problem of creating outside dependencies. New York lawmakers can\xe2\x80\x99t carry water for two masters when in office.'b'We should reject the private financing of campaigns as the only model. We need to provide enough public funding for campaigns so that anyone with a broad base of support can run for office, and respond effectively to attacks, without becoming dependent on private patrons. Running for office shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a job defined by permanent begging at the feet of the wealthiest donors in the country.'b'Those two reforms would be transformational. We will never eradicate every shady deal, but we can make politics more about serving the public and less like legalized bribery.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s one last thing we should do: ban corporate spending and limit total campaign spending. Last week not only saw Mr. Silver in handcuffs, it also marked the fifth anniversary of the Citizens United ruling, in which the Supreme Court decided that outside corporate spending was in no way corrupting. We will have to revisit that decision, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t need to wait for the court to act.'b'Corruption is about greed and private interests put ahead of the public good. Whether influence is bought through a bribe, outside spending, outside income or campaign contributions, the public suffers in the same way. Until we move past scandals toward structural change, our democracy will suffer, too.'b'On one of the last occasions an Egyptian president visited Addis Ababa, he got no further than the road from the airport: In 1995 the motorcade of President Hosni Mubarak 'b'came under fire'b' from Egyptian jihadists. Mr. Mubarak was saved by 'b'his bulletproof car'b', his driver\xe2\x80\x99s skill and Ethiopian sharpshooters.'b'After that, Ethiopian and Egyptian intelligence officers worked together to root out terrorists in the Horn of Africa, contributing, along with pressure from the United States government, to Osama bin Laden\xe2\x80\x99s expulsion from Sudan in 1996. But that was the limit of their cooperation.'b'Egypt and Ethiopia have otherwise been locked in a low-intensity contest over which nation would dominate the region, undermining each other\xe2\x80\x99s interests in Eritrea, Somalia and South Sudan. A quiet but long-sustained rivalry, it is one of those rarely noticed but important fault lines in international relations that allow other conflicts to rumble on.'b'This week, however, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt is expected to fly to Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia, to attend 'b'a summit of the African Union'b'. He will also meet with Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn of Ethiopia, a rare chance to shift the political landscape in northeastern Africa.'b'The heart of the rivalry hinges on how to share the precious waters of the Nile River. Running low is Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s nightmare, and more than 80 percent of the Nile\xe2\x80\x99s water comes from rain that falls on the Ethiopian highlands and is then carried north by the fast-flowing Blue Nile. (Ethiopia is nicknamed \xe2\x80\x9cAfrica\xe2\x80\x99s water tower.\xe2\x80\x9d) Yet management of the Nile is formally governed by a 1929 treaty between Egypt and colonial Britain, and a 1959 treaty between Egypt and Sudan that awarded most water rights to Egypt, some to Sudan and none explicitly to Ethiopia or the other states upstream. This arrangement is widely considered unfair, especially to Ethiopia, which was never colonized, and on whose behalf Britain could not even claim to have spoken. This legal framework also limits the right of upper riparian states to build dams or irrigation systems even though they were sidelined from helping shape it.'b'Egypt has a history of blocking Ethiopia\xe2\x80\x99s requests for international aid to build dams, at times even threatening military action if it attempted to go ahead. Following the 1978 Camp David accords with Israel, President Anwar Sadat declared, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The only matter that could take Egypt to war again is the Nile water'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d To this day, Egyptian engineers are stationed as far as Lake Victoria, in Uganda, monitoring activities along the river.'b'Ethiopia has continued to reject Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s approach, not least because it is one of the poorest countries in the world and considers economic development to be essential to its survival. In 1999 Ethiopia, along with eight other states, set up the Nile Basin Initiative to develop a cooperative and equitable partnership to manage the river\xe2\x80\x99s resources. (Egypt and Sudan are nominal members but inactive; South Sudan joined in 2012.)'b'So far most concrete actions taken have been about combating erosion along the Nile\xe2\x80\x99s watersheds and encouraging sustainable management of lakes and subsidiary bodies of water.'b'Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, who was in power from 1991 until his death in 2012, also commissioned several huge dam projects. The largest of these is the 'b'Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam'b' on the Blue Nile, a point of national pride whose construction has been financed through the issuance of special bonds.'b'The plan has not gone down well with Egypt. During a meeting chaired by President Mohamed Morsi in June 2013 \xe2\x80\x94 captured on television cameras, apparently without the participants\xe2\x80\x99 knowledge \xe2\x80\x94 Egyptian politicians proposed sabotaging the dam project. (Last April unidentified gunmen attacked a bus near the site of the dam, killing nine people.) But Mr. Sisi knows that Ethiopia will not change course.'b'He also realizes that the dam\xe2\x80\x99s threat to Egypt is more symbolic than material. (His predecessors, including Mr. Morsi, knew that as well, but seemed more interested in entertaining anti-Ethiopian sentiment among Egyptians.) The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam is being built a few miles from Ethiopia\xe2\x80\x99s border with Sudan, in rocky terrain unsuitable for irrigation. The dam will generate electricity, meaning that Ethiopia, like Egypt, wants the water to flow through rather than be stopped. Moreover, the dam is set in a gorge at high altitude: It will store large amounts of water with less surface area in a cooler climate than, say, Lake Nasser in Egypt, reducing evaporation and saving water, which should also benefit Egypt.'b'Given these common interests, Egypt should cooperate with Ethiopia to manage the Nile\xe2\x80\x99s waters. Mr. Sisi made a strong start on this front last year, when the two countries set up a 'b'bilateral commission'b' to examine all aspects of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam. It is now time for Egypt to join the Nile Basin Initiative\xe2\x80\x99s Cooperative Framework Agreement, which was signed in 2010 to \xe2\x80\x9cpromote integrated management, sustainable development, and harmonious utilization\xe2\x80\x9d of the Nile and to protect it \xe2\x80\x9cfor the benefit of present and future generations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Better relations with Ethiopia could also be Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s ticket to mending its difficult relations with other governments in sub-Saharan Africa. Two days after the Egyptian military ousted Mr. Morsi in July 2013, while Gulf states rushed to assist the new government, the African Union suspended Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s membership on grounds that the coup violated its principles. (Egypt has since been reinstated.) And there is little sympathy on the continent for Cairo\xe2\x80\x99s position on the Nile issue, since it appears to be blocking Ethiopia\xe2\x80\x99s development under colonial-era treaties widely seen as exploitative.'b'Mr. Sisi should take advantage of his coming visit to Addis Ababa to finally make progress on joint management of the Nile. That could open the way for Egypt and Ethiopia to find common ground on thornier issues, such as how to handle internal conflicts in Somalia and South Sudan. And that, in turn, could be a step toward greater stability in the region.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 Before a recent interview in Istanbul, I was talking to the journalist about Turkish politics. After about 15 minutes, she looked down and lowered her voice, as though confiding a secret: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is so tiring to be Turkish sometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That mental exhaustion is caused for the most part by politics. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his leading cadres have chosen a divisive strategy, pursuing hostility over compromise and a politics of duality over a culture of coexistence. Even the most trivial or absurd questions can provoke heated debate: \xe2\x80\x9cWould laughing in public endanger a Turkish woman\xe2\x80\x99s modesty?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cShould Turkish Airlines female flight attendants be allowed to wear red lipstick, and if not, which color might be permissible?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cShould patriotic citizens consume ayran (a yogurt drink) instead of raki?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAre all female drivers of red cars voting for the opposition party?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The unbearable fatigue is particularly sharp among liberal intellectuals and women. The liberals do not represent huge numbers of Turks, but they are an important measure against which the Justice and Development Party\xe2\x80\x99s political trajectory can be tracked. When the party first came to power in 2002, liberals supported it. A.K.P., the party\xe2\x80\x99s initials in Turkish, was pro-reform and pro-European Union. It was expected to promote civil liberties, a heartening idea after three military takeovers since 1960, each worse than the previous one. But as the party swerved toward authoritarianism, liberals were cast adrift.'b'At a New Year\xe2\x80\x99s dinner in Istanbul, I listened to my morose liberal friends: \xe2\x80\x9cThere are two ways left for anyone who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sympathize with the A.K.P. today: Either we are going to become foolishly apolitical, or we\xe2\x80\x99ll get to be bitterly political. And if you want to be neither foolish nor bitter, tough luck!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some liberals have gone silent, but some stand in sharp opposition, while others engage in self-criticism. \xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the support for more pluralistic and democratic developments ... where we went wrong. It was failing to see that the A.K.P.\xe2\x80\x99s boundaries would turn out to be so narrow,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote the Turkish author and sociologist Oya Baydar. \xe2\x80\x9cThose who used to say that the A.K.P. was only pretending to be democratic and would eventually replace military despotism with a civilian one ... have been proved right.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today, liberals are viewed with scorn by the anti-A.K.P. camp for being too soft and na\xc3\xafve. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the end, weren\xe2\x80\x99t they, as were some left-wing intellectuals in the 1950s and 1960s in the Soviet Union, the \xe2\x80\x98useful idiots\xe2\x80\x99 of the A.K.P. and Erdogan?\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Ariane Bonzon, a French journalist who covers Turkey and the Middle East.'b'Among Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s nonconservative women \xe2\x80\x94 at least half of the 48 percent who did not vote for Mr. Erdogan in the last election \xe2\x80\x94 there is a growing concern about the A.K.P.\xe2\x80\x99s meddling in their private lives. In the past, sexist statements from male politicians were regarded as spontaneous outbursts. Today, they are seen as part of a systematic and sinister ideological campaign to confine women to traditional gender roles. After the minister of health, Mehmet Muezzinoglu, visited the first baby born in 2015, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cMothers should not put any career other than motherhood at the center of their lives.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The backlash was immediate. Turkish women have heard top government officials weigh in on subjects like abortion, cesarean-section deliveries, contraception and style of dress. \xe2\x80\x9cI am fed up with all these sexist comments, constantly telling us women how to live our lives,\xe2\x80\x9d Ayse Arman wrote in the newspaper Hurriyet. A sense of victimhood plagues society, and there is a constant cycle of retribution that creates new victims.'b'After the horrible shootings in Paris at the magazine Charlie Hebdo, and amid a rise in both Islamopobia and anti-Westernism, Turkey could have stood as a unifying voice, a modern, democratic, pluralistic Muslim country with a strong secularist tradition. Politically, a \xe2\x80\x9cGrexit\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 Greek exit from the euro \xe2\x80\x94 would shatter the assumption that there is no retreat from the euro and further destabilize Europe. An announcement there of an extension of the program for several months would be a good signal that the Europeans have heard the cry of the Greeks and are prepared to be more sensible.'b'When the United States at last abandons the abhorrent practice of capital punishment, the early years of the 21st century will stand out as a peculiar period during which otherwise reasonable people hotly debated how to kill other people while inflicting the least amount of constitutionally acceptable pain.'b'The Supreme Court stepped back into this maelstrom on Friday, when it 'b'agreed to hear'b' Warner v. Gross, a lawsuit brought by four Oklahoma death-row inmates alleging that the state\xe2\x80\x99s lethal-injection drug protocol puts them at risk of significant pain and suffering.'b'In accepting the case, the justices had to change its name. That may sound strange until you consider that while it takes only four justices to accept a case for argument, 'b'it takes five'b' to stay an execution. The case is now named for another inmate, Richard Glossip. (On Monday, the Oklahoma attorney general requested temporary stays of the impending executions of Mr. Glossip and the other two plaintiffs.)'b'Mr. Warner was sentenced to death for raping and murdering an 11-month-old girl named Adrianna Waller in 1997. They 'b'upheld'b' the constitutionality of lethal injection in 2008. But, since then, the battles over the practice have grown more warped. Many drug makers now refuse to supply their products for killing, leaving states to experiment on their inmates with other drugs, often acquired under cover of official secrecy and administered by authorities with no medical training. During a 'b'hearing'b' last month on Oklahoma\xe2\x80\x99s protocol, a state witness who testified that midazolam is effective appeared to rely on the website 'b'drugs.com'b', not scientific studies. It would all be a laughable farce if it didn\xe2\x80\x99t involve killing people.'b'There is disingenuousness on both sides. Many who oppose the death penalty, this page included, are obviously not interested in identifying more \xe2\x80\x9chumane\xe2\x80\x9d methods of execution; the idea itself is a contradiction in terms. Nor are many capital punishment supporters concerned with how much suffering a condemned person might endure in his final moments. In the middle sit the armchair executioners who engage in macabre debates about the relative efficiency of, say, nitrogen gas.'b'It is time to dispense with the pretense of a pain-free death. The act of killing itself is irredeemably brutal and violent. If the men on death row had painlessly killed their victims, that would not make their crimes any more tolerable. When the killing is carried out by a state against its own citizens, it is beneath a people that aspire to call themselves civilized.'b'Last summer, Alex Kozinski, a federal appellate judge in California and a supporter of the death penalty, called out this charade for what it is.'b'Lethal injections, 'b'he wrote'b', are \xe2\x80\x9ca misguided effort to mask the brutality of executions by making them look serene and peaceful.\xe2\x80\x9d But executions \xe2\x80\x9care brutal, savage events, and nothing the state tries to do can mask that reality. The heat causes the liquid to turn into vapor, which the user inhales. Most of these devices also allow the user to control the voltage. 'b'These devices have become increasingly popular'b' as a way to ingest nicotine without smoking.'b'In the study, the Portland State scientists ran the device at both a low voltage and a high voltage. At the low voltage, they did not detect formaldehyde. But at the high voltage, they found some. Formaldehyde is, indeed, a known carcinogen, which also exists, among hundreds of other toxic chemicals and dozens of cancer-causing agents, in combustible cigarettes. The authors concluded that someone who was a heavy user of a vaporizer at the high voltage was five to 15 times more likely to get cancer than a longtime smoker. Or so they seemed to say.'b'There is not much doubt that studies like this have an impact on the public perception of e-cigarettes. Even though cigarettes result in 480,000 American deaths each year \xe2\x80\x94 and even though it is the tobacco, not the nicotine, that kills them \xe2\x80\x94 many in the public health community treat e-cigarettes as every bit as evil. Every dollop of news suggesting that vaping is bad for your health, much of which has been overblown, is irrationally embraced\xc2\xa0 by anti-tobacco activists. One result is that, whereas 84 percent of current smokers thought e-cigarettes were safer than ordinary cigarettes in 2010, that 'b'number had dropped to 65 percent by 2013'b'.'b'Worse, close to a third of the people who had abandoned e-cigarettes and returned to smoking did so because they were worried about the health effects of vaping, according to a study published last year in the journal Nicotine &amp; Tobacco Research.'b'The Portland State study fits right into this dynamic. It is, on the one hand, factually true that vaping at an extremely high voltage will cause formaldehyde-releasing agents to develop.'b'But this conclusion is highly misleading. People don\xe2\x80\x99t vape at a high voltage because it causes a horrible taste \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9ca burning taste that occurs from overheating the liquid,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Konstantinos Farsalinos, a Greek scientist and vaping expert, in an email to me. Farsalinos has done human studies of vaping and discovered that above a certain voltage \xe2\x80\x94 lower than the high voltage test on the Portland State study \xe2\x80\x94 people simply couldn\xe2\x80\x99t inhale; the taste was unbearable.'b'Indeed, the study actually conveys good news. When used at normal voltage, vaping does not produce formaldehyde! \xe2\x80\x9cRather than scaring people about the dangers of vaping and alarming them to the \xe2\x80\x98fact\xe2\x80\x99 that vaping raises their cancer risk above that of smoking, we should instead be regulating the voltage and temperature conditions of electronic cigarettes so that the problem of formaldehyde contamination is completely avoided,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Michael Siegel, a professor of public health at Boston University, 'b'on his blog'b'. But given the way the Portland State authors characterized their research, it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that headline writers took away a different message.'b'When I spoke to David Peyton, one of the study\xe2\x80\x99s authors, he insisted that the study had been mischaracterized. All it was meant to do, he said, was compare the levels of formaldehyde in e-cigarettes versus cigarettes. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is exceedingly frustrating to me that we are being associated with saying that e-cigarettes are more dangerous than cigarettes,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is a fact not in evidence.\xe2\x80\x9d Well, maybe.'b'When I read him the tweet from the New England Journal of Medicine \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cAuthors project higher cancer risk than smoking\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 he sounded horrified. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t see the tweet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI regret that. That is not my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a lot we don\xe2\x80\x99t yet know about e-cigarettes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peyton toward the end of our conversation. He is right about that; e-cigarettes are still so new that they need to be studied carefully. And he and his co-authors are planning further studies. Perhaps the next time, they will produce something that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t serve mainly as a scare tactic to keep smokers away from e-cigarettes.'b'The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge covers only a small part of Alaska. Smaller still is the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow, 1.5 million-acre strip flanking the Beaufort Sea. The plain is an ecological and biological wonder, the hunting grounds for Alaskan natives and home to caribou, polar bears, all manner of marine life and countless bird species. It may also contain one of the biggest unexploited oil fields in America.'b'For all these reasons, the plain has been the subject of a bitter tug of war between politicians and oil companies that covet its commercial resources, on one side, and conservationists who think that opening it would be a calamity \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthe equivalent,\xe2\x80\x9d the former secretary of the interior Bruce Babbitt 'b'once said'b', \xe2\x80\x9cof offering Yellowstone National Park for geothermal drilling, or calling for bids to construct hydropower dams in the Grand Canyon.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama has now come down emphatically on the side of conservation. At the recommendation of Sally Jewell, his secretary of the interior, and John Podesta, his senior counselor, Mr. Obama 'b'proposed on Sunday'b' to set aside more than 12 million acres of the refuge as permanent wilderness, including the 1.5 million acres of the coastal plain. Wilderness designation is the highest level of protection the government can confer on public land. It would bar commercial development of any kind, including, crucially, oil-and-gas exploration.'b'The proposal is the latest instance of the president\xe2\x80\x99s use of his executive authority, which he has deployed in an effort to circumvent a hostile Congress on issues like immigration and climate change. While Congress must put the final stamp of approval on any wilderness proposal, under law the areas so designated by a president will receive full wilderness protections until Congress acts. Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s action also stirred echoes of former President Bill Clinton, who used his last two years in office to protect millions of acres of land from commercial exploitation.'b'From the perspective of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s energy needs, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s timing was just right. Estimates of the oil under the coastal plain have varied wildly over the years, but while extracting the oil never seemed worth the devastation it would cause, it seems less so now that major new oil deposits have been discovered in the lower 48 states and consumption is dwindling along with America\xe2\x80\x99s reliance on imports.'b'Other measures to protect the Arctic are likely to emerge in the days ahead. A new five-year leasing plan in the works at the Interior Department reportedly includes restrictions on new oil leases in the Arctic Ocean, where existing leases owned by Shell and other companies are already controversial. The Obama administration is also considering whether to further limit oil-and-gas production in the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska, half of which was placed off limits to drilling by Ken Salazar, a former interior secretary, shortly before he left office in 2013.'b'None of this, obviously, pleases Senator Lisa Murkowski and many other Alaskans, who have been complaining of federal land grabs for decades. \xe2\x80\x9cA stunning attack on our sovereignty,\xe2\x80\x9d is the way Ms. Murkowski put it, echoing her father, a former Alaska senator and governor, Frank Murkowski, who worked tirelessly to open up the refuge for drilling. That his daughter has been no more successful is cause for cheer.'b'The big debate during the 20th century was about the relationship between the market and the state. Both those institutions are now tarnished. The market is prone to devastating crashes and seems to be producing widening inequality. Government is gridlocked, sclerotic or captured by special interests. Government is an ever more rigid and ineffective tool to address market failures.'b'So over the past generation many of the most talented people on earth have tried to transform capitalism itself, to use the market to solve social problems. These are people with opposable minds: part profit-oriented and part purpose-oriented. They\xe2\x80\x99ve created organizations that look a little like a business, a little like a social-service provider, and a little like a charity \xe2\x80\x94 or some mixture of the three.'b'Hippie companies like Ben &amp; Jerry\xe2\x80\x99s ice cream led the first wave in this sector, but now you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a burgeoning array of social-capitalist tools to address problems \xe2\x80\x94 ranging from B Corporations like Warby Parker (which gives free glasses to the poor) to social impact bonds. (For example, a private investor raises money to finance a program to reduce recidivism. If the program works and the government saves money because there are fewer prisoners to house, then the government pays back the investor, with a profit.)'b'Impact investing is probably the most promising of these tools. Impact investing is not socially responsible investing. Socially responsible investing means avoiding certain companies, like tobacco growers. Impact investors seek out companies that are intentionally designed both to make a profit and provide a measurable and accountable social good. Impact funds are frequently willing to accept lower financial returns for the sake of doing good \xe2\x80\x94 say a 7 percent annual return compared with an 11 percent return. But some impact investors are seeking to deliver market-rate returns.'b'Brian Trelstad of Bridges Ventures, has looked at companies in early autism intervention, paid for by Medicaid, that can improve long-term educational outcomes while reducing spending on special education; affordable after-school enrichment programs that bring extra education services to charter school students; and energy efficiency companies that serve people in public housing, which saves long term heating costs.'b'When impact funds came on the scene, seven or so years ago, there was the usual overhyping. A 2010 report by the Rockefeller Foundation and JPMorgan projected that impact investing could see new capital inflows of up to $1 trillion by 2020. That\xe2\x80\x99s looking unlikely given that right now roughly something like only $40 billion has been invested through these funds.'b'There are more roadblocks than anticipated. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to find a reliable way to measure the social impact of these dual-purpose companies. Impact investors have also had trouble finding scalable deals to invest in. It costs as much to do due diligence on a $250 million deal as on a $25 million deal, so many firms would rather skip the small stuff.'b'The hype created skepticism and a backlash. But impact investing is now entering the mainstream. An older generation used their (rigorous) business mind in one setting and then their (often sloppy) charity mind in another. Today more people want to blend these minds. Typically a big client, or a young heir, will go to his or her investments adviser and say, \xe2\x80\x9cI want some socially useful investments in my portfolio.\xe2\x80\x9d If the adviser has nothing on offer, the client leaves the firm.'b'New impact funds are being born. In a low-interest-rate era, they can offer comparable returns. The Obama administration has been aggressively supportive. Social stock exchanges are being founded. The big players like Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse are now in the field.'b'I recently sat in a beautiful New York meeting room with a nicely and formally dressed banker, Andy Sieg, as he discussed the impact fund he\xe2\x80\x99s helping to create at Merrill Lynch. He said his associates, especially his young associates, were extremely eager to work on the project. People are eager to have this kind of impact.'b'Impact investing is not going to replace government or be a panacea, but it\xe2\x80\x99s one of a number of new tools to address social problems. If you want to leave a mark on the world but are unsure of how to do it, I\xe2\x80\x99d say take a look. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a high-net-worth individual (a rich person), ask your adviser to get you involved. If you\xe2\x80\x99re young and searching, get some finance and operational skills and then find a way to get involved in a socially useful investment proposition. If you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a business mind, there are huge opportunities to build the infrastructure (creating measuring systems, connecting investors with deals).'b'Someday government will get unstuck, with new programs to address this new era. But there\xe2\x80\x99s no prospect of that happening soon. Right now social capitalism is a more creative and dynamic place to spend a life.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Redefining Mental Illness'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by T. M. Luhrmann (Op-Ed, Jan. 18):'b'While many experiences \xe2\x80\x94 such as hearing voices \xe2\x80\x94 can occur without illness, a psychiatric diagnosis is more than a single symptom. The clustering of many symptoms together when combined with persistent distress and functional impairment is required for any consideration of a mental disorder.'b'Such approaches have been central to clinical medicine for centuries and are a precursor to the scientific understanding of the causes and mechanisms of disease, not an end in themselves.'b'Ms. Luhrmann notes approvingly that the National Institute of Mental Health, in beginning a program called Research Domain Criteria, determined that existing psychiatric diagnoses \xe2\x80\x9cwere neither particularly useful nor accurate for understanding the brain, and would no longer be used to guide research.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'However, she does not mention a 'b'joint statement'b' by the institute\xe2\x80\x99s director, Dr. Tom Insel, and the former president of the American Psychiatric Association, Dr. Jeffrey Lieberman, which explained: \xe2\x80\x9cAll medical disciplines advance through research progress in characterizing diseases and disorders. DSM-5 and RDoC [Research Domain Criteria] represent complementary, not competing, frameworks for this goal.\xe2\x80\x9d Precisely.'b'Psychiatric disorders are among the most common and disabling of medical conditions. Because they affect those functions that are most uniquely human, we owe both the best science and respectful listening to our patients.'b'PAUL SUMMERGRAD'b'\nBoston, Jan. 21, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is president of the American Psychiatric Association and chairman of the psychiatry department at Tufts University School of Medicine and Tufts Medical Center.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Support Our Students'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by David Brooks (column, Jan. 20):'b'There is a human capital component to President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s plan to make community colleges free: return on investment. The $60 billion that would be spent over a decade is an investment in our civic future. Our return for that financial commitment should be service to the country, which could include work as a teacher, nurse, engineer, firefighter or police officer.'b'A national policy to offer free community college tuition is a crucial investment in and commitment to our social contract. But let\xe2\x80\x99s be clear about the cost. The tuition isn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d; our citizens cover the cost of \xe2\x80\x9cfree.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I propose a simple plan: When students agree to accept the tuition (and complete their education), that contract confirms their two-year participation in a national service corps.'b'America prospers because we invest in people, ideas, infrastructure, research, design, education and health care. This is the fabric of the social contract that each generation knows: Invest early, often and with compassion, and watch your returns build the future.'b'MICHAEL G. SIEVERS'b'\nPortland, Ore., Jan. 21, 2015'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe important task is to help students graduate,\xe2\x80\x9d David Brooks says, noting that community college dropout rates now hover somewhere between 66 and 80 percent. Setting graduation as the ultimate goal, however, may be a mistake when technology is changing education and work.'b'Diplomas based on college-mandated credits are becoming anachronistic as online courses become better and more pervasive. Suppose, for example, an aspiring graphic designer wants a course in designing for a new mobile device, and it is offered online by M.I.T. Should she wait until her community college offers it so it will count toward a degree, or pay a modest fee to take an online course that offers her a verified certificate for passing a test?'b'The certificate or badge approach is more responsive to changes in the job market \xe2\x80\x94 unlike the process for curriculum change in most colleges. Moreover, a degree earned in her early 20s will no longer suffice for our young student. She has to embrace lifelong learning to stay competitive in a world where workplace change is ubiquitous.'b'Nor does the college degree reflect learning on the job, where she is likely to acquire the \xe2\x80\x9csoft\xe2\x80\x9d skills that are so important in a career but often go unnoticed in a degree-based college. Learning is the metric \xe2\x80\x94 not college degrees.'b'ARNOLD PACKER'b'\nBaltimore, Jan. 20, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a former assistant labor secretary in the Carter administration and former chief economist of the Senate Budget Committee. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'David Brooks is correct in his critique of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s idea to make community college free. His recommendations to focus on a student\xe2\x80\x99s living expenses, mentoring relationships and the \xe2\x80\x9cremedial education mess\xe2\x80\x9d rather than tuition, which is likely to benefit those for whom community college is already affordable, are on target.'b'For most students who require remediation and financial support to attend community college, graduation rates are abysmal, with about 80 percent likely to drop out.'b'Our small community college in western New Jersey has found a better way: We are working with prospective students while they are enrolled in their local high schools, with the focus on tutoring and mentoring rather than remedial courses in college, which are costly and don\xe2\x80\x99t contribute to the necessary credits for graduation.'b'PETER SCHMIDT'b'\nPhillipsburg, N.J., Jan. 20, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is board chairman of Warren County Community College.'b''b'Left-wing party Syriza has promised to renegotiate Greece\xe2\x80\x99s debt.'b'CAIRO \xe2\x80\x94  It took one session on Jan. 10 for a court in the Nile Delta province of Beheira to sentence Karim al-Banna, a 21-year-old student, to three years in prison for saying on Facebook that he was an atheist. The student\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer complained that he was denied the right even to present a defense, but an equally chilling aspect of Mr. Banna\xe2\x80\x99s case is that his father testified against him.'b'Also telling is that Mr. Banna was originally arrested, in November, when he went to the police to complain that his neighbors were harassing him. This was after his name had appeared in a local newspaper on a list of known atheists. Instead of protecting him, the police accused him of insulting Islam.'b'Such tag teams of family, media and state are not uncommon in cases against atheists. Because atheism itself is not illegal in Egypt, charges are laid under laws against blasphemy or contempt for religion. In 2012, a 27-year-old blogger, Alber Saber, received a three-year sentence on charges of blasphemy for creating a web page called \xe2\x80\x9cEgyptian Atheists.\xe2\x80\x9d In 2013, the writer and human rights activist Karam Saber (no relation) was convicted of defaming religion in his short story collection \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Is God?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Similar charges have been used for political purposes against Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s Christian minority. In 2013, a Coptic Christian lawyer, Roman Murad Saad, was sentenced in absentia for \xe2\x80\x9cridiculing\xe2\x80\x9d the Quran. From 2011 to 2013, Egyptian courts convicted 27 of 42 defendants on charges of contempt for religion.'b'It is no surprise that Mr. Banna\xe2\x80\x99s conviction occurred on the watch of Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army general who led the ouster of Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood to become president. Regardless of which way the seesaw of power in Egypt tips \xe2\x80\x94 toward the Islamists or toward the military \xe2\x80\x94 it is always a heterosexual, conservative Muslim man who heads the moral hierarchy. The further from that identity you are, the more vulnerable you are.'b'If anything, Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s nominally secular ruler is more Catholic than the pope, to borrow a metaphor from another religion. Assuming the role of defender of public morality is a deliberate reminder that the Islamists do not hold the copyright on piety. This is not new: The regime of the ousted President Hosni Mubarak often vaunted its religiosity to outdo its Islamists rivals.'b'Nowhere is this morality power play exercised more vehemently than in curbing perceived religious and sex crimes. Hence Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s witch hunt against gay men. Rights activists say that 2014 was the worst year in a decade for gay people in Egypt, with at least 150 men arrested or put on trial. Same-sex relationships are not illegal, but gay men are targeted under \xe2\x80\x9cdebauchery\xe2\x80\x9d laws.'b'Last month, 26 men were arrested in a televised police raid on a public bathhouse in Cairo. The men should never have been arrested, but the surprise was that they were all acquitted on Jan. 12. Understandably upset at their loved ones\xe2\x80\x99 ordeal, the families of the acquitted men chanted \xe2\x80\x9cHere are the real men!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 ever-keen to reassert their relatives\xe2\x80\x99 identity as heterosexual, conservative Muslims.'b'After the outcry that followed the men\xe2\x80\x99s humiliation, the court\xe2\x80\x99s ruling perhaps reflects a tacit acknowledgment of prosecutorial overreach. But why all this hullabaloo over already marginal groups like atheists and gay people?'b'Dar al-Ifta, the institute for the study of Islamic law that is responsible for issuing religious edicts, was deservedly derided after it published a report in October saying that Egypt had the highest number of atheists in the Middle East: exactly 866\xe2\x80\x94 hardly a plausible number in a nation of 87 million. Yet the pro-government media and religious officials are waging a \xe2\x80\x9cwar on atheism.\xe2\x80\x9d Atheists are described alternately as threats to national security or as carriers of a dangerously contagious virus.'b'In this atmosphere, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to gauge people\xe2\x80\x99s candid views on religion. For those who don\xe2\x80\x99t genuflect to the official order, a \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t ask, don\xe2\x80\x99t tell\xe2\x80\x9d policy in Egypt long provided cover. But to admit atheism is to invite not just arrest but a threat to one\xe2\x80\x99s life.'b'In a speech this month honoring the Prophet Muhammad\xe2\x80\x99s birthday, Mr. Sisi called on Muslim leaders in Egypt to start a \xe2\x80\x9creligious revolution\xe2\x80\x9d to counter the jihadist message of the Islamic State. He also sent his foreign minister to the solidarity march after the attacks in Paris at the office of the magazine Charlie Hebdo and a kosher supermarket.'b'The contradiction in Mr. Sisi\xe2\x80\x99s aim of keeping the heterosexual, conservative Muslim man at the top of Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s moral hierarchy is glaring. You can\xe2\x80\x99t trump the Islamists in their piety and lead a campaign against minorities like atheists and gay men even as you condemn extremist violence and show solidarity for free speech and free thinking.'b'This week we mark the fourth anniversary of the 2011 revolution. Although it has not delivered the political freedoms it called for, it did begin an unraveling of authority that has left Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s self-appointed moral guardians disconcerted and scrambling. Armed with social media, more people are insisting on asking and telling \xe2\x80\x94 about personal belief and sexual identity. A reckoning is long overdue in a country where religion and morality have so often been bent to suit the political expedients of its rulers.'b'Despite the clampdown, atheists are openly challenging such hypocrisy. Social media has allowed those who \xe2\x80\x9cdeviate\xe2\x80\x9d from the authoritarian template to find one another and express themselves in ways that the regime, its men of religion and its media otherwise deny them. A religious revolution has begun, but not on Mr. Sisi\xe2\x80\x99s or the clerics\xe2\x80\x99 terms. We all stand to gain if fathers no longer testify against sons, and families no longer feel the need to prove their loved ones are \xe2\x80\x9creal men.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\n'b'Mona Eltahawy 'b' is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cHeadscarves and Hymens: Why the Middle East Needs a Sexual Revolution.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'NAPLES, Italy \xe2\x80\x94  \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah,\xe2\x80\x9d which recounts the exploits of the fictional Savastanos crime family, is Italy\xe2\x80\x99s all-time most popular TV series. And it is starting to go global: Twelve of the first episodes have already been sold for broadcast in 50 countries. \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d will tell world viewers a great story. But what will it tell them about Italy itself?'b'The Savastanos are part of the Camorra, Naples\xe2\x80\x99s version of the Mafia. The boss, Pietro, is married to Imma; their son is Gennaro, better known as Genny. Ciro is their go-to hit man, and Salvatore Conte is their rival. These meticulous, over-the-top killers manage to square a love of music with violence, drug dealing, exotic interior d\xc3\xa9cor,  devotion to the saints and a passion  for firearms.'b'The setting is the outskirts of Naples, a tangle of overpasses, badly lit parking lots and outsize concrete housing projects, including the infamous Le Vele. Occasionally, as contrast, a picture-postcard Mediterranean appears in the background, the view tourists see on their way to the Amalfi Coast.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah,\xe2\x80\x9d based on the best-selling book of the same name by the journalist Roberto Saviano, takes its title from the sinful city in the Bible; handily, it also rhymes with Camorra. The Italy that \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d portrays is squalid, brutal and comes as a surprise to some. \xe2\x80\x9cFor those of us who romanticize Italy, \xe2\x80\x98Gomorrah\xe2\x80\x99 is a fizzing antidote,\xe2\x80\x9d according to London\xe2\x80\x99s Daily Telegraph.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not the first time that Italian-style criminality has inspired spectacular artistic results. From \xe2\x80\x9cThe Godfather\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Hustle,\xe2\x80\x9d filmmakers have long worked with Mafia-centered plots. Television came along later, but has shown equal enthusiasm. Six seasons and 86 episodes, running from 1999 to 2007, made \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sopranos\xe2\x80\x9d an enviable success. That chronicle of an Italian-American family exemplified the mix of dishonesty and sympathy, love and cruelty, that allegedly runs through Italian organized crime, and it quickly won over millions of international viewers.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d is more realistic. The criminals aren\xe2\x80\x99t glorified; there are no lovable monsters like Tony Soprano.  Its story lines are fictional, but they draw on current events. With stunning camerawork, fast-paced tempos and well-written dialogue that rolls out in accurately rendered Neapolitan Italian, it is proof, if proof were needed, that Italians can turn out first-rate television. Before shooting \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah,\xe2\x80\x9d the director Stefano Sollima had made the popular Rome-based  TV series \xe2\x80\x9cRomanzo Criminale\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cCriminal Novel\xe2\x80\x9d). Before that, Mr. Sollima worked as a cameraman for global news networks like CNN, NBC and CBS, sometimes in  war zones.'b'In short, Italy has created a popular, realistic, beautifully rendered TV series \xe2\x80\x94 which is what has so many people worried. The international success of \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d could turn into bad publicity for Naples and Italy, just as the young government of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi is trying so hard to restore confidence among foreigners. Italy has worked hard to move beyond the national stereotype of the unprincipled, untrustworthy wheeler-dealer toting a pistol in one hand and a plate of spaghetti (or, in \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah,\xe2\x80\x9d a fried fish) in the other. The very realism that critics and viewers love could easily backfire, reinforcing the idea that something is rotten in the state of Italy.'b'Similar charges were leveled at \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sopranos,\xe2\x80\x9d which is set in New Jersey. The Italian-American community took umbrage, claiming the series fostered the worst clich\xc3\xa9s to the point of being defamatory. The National Italian American Foundation and Mario Cuomo, the former governor of New York, protested. The cast members were kept away from Columbus Day parades. In 2001, a PublicMind poll reported that viewers who watched \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sopranos\xe2\x80\x9d tended to regard Italian-Americans and New Jersey negatively.'b'Will \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d do the same for the city and people of Naples?'b'Many of my compatriots are wringing their hands over this question. But I think their concerns are, fortunately, misplaced, precisely because of the show\xe2\x80\x99s realism. The Savastanos are not going to be the new Sopranos. Characters in \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d compel \xe2\x80\x94 as they do in any good TV series \xe2\x80\x94 but they don\xe2\x80\x99t charm. Empathy is absent. \xe2\x80\x9cGomorrah\xe2\x80\x9d hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got goodies and baddies; just baddies and worsies. The Naples in which the criminals operate is also shown to have the second-largest passenger port in the world, Italy\xe2\x80\x99s fourth-largest urban economy and Europe\xe2\x80\x99s largest historic center, a Unesco World Heritage site. Nonprofits and small businesses can become exempt \xe2\x80\x94 ludicrous exceptions, since even a spokesperson for the New York State Restaurant Association 'b'called the cost of replacement packaging \xe2\x80\x9cnominal\xe2\x80\x9d'b' \xe2\x80\x94 and foam peanuts can still be used in packing originating elsewhere. And while that sounds like a lot'b', it\xe2\x80\x99s less than 1 percent'b' of what the city picks up curbside. Nor does the ban address rigid polystyrene like that used in CD cases, which accounts for another 30,000 tons of junk.'b'So if the ban were totally successful, it would reduce the amount of polystyrene in landfills by less than 50 percent, and the amount of overall curbside collection by less than half of a percent. Not exactly a revolution in waste reduction. (There are other reasons to ban polystyrene, which is a suspected carcinogen.)'b'But to see the ban in context generates hope. In addition to forcing both industry and consumers to seek alternatives, the ban\xe2\x80\x99s importance lies in the ability of the city to get it enacted, an effort that began with the Bloomberg administration and was completed by Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'Of course, \xe2\x80\x9cBig Plastic,\xe2\x80\x9d or whatever you want to call it \xe2\x80\x94 in this instance represented by the industry leader Dart Container Corporation and the trade group American Chemistry Council \xe2\x80\x94 fought hard against the measure, even successfully stalling it for a year in an attempt to demonstrate that the foam could be recycled. The city remained unconvinced, and the ban will take effect July 1, though it won\xe2\x80\x99t be enforced until next year.'b'Combine the surge in these bans with the probably more important and increasingly popular bans of \xe2\x80\x94 or taxes on \xe2\x80\x94 one-time-use plastic shopping bags, and you start to see a pattern: municipalities and sometimes even states are asserting themselves against the \xe2\x80\x9cright\xe2\x80\x9d of industry to sell whatever it wants, and more of the public is willing to have government alter its behavior when the reasons are sound. (The just-passed soda tax in Berkeley fits into this pattern.) That combination is leading to victories for the environmental and public health movements, and it\xe2\x80\x99s changing people\xe2\x80\x99s behavior.'b'Plastic shopping bags are a visible and intractable nuisance as well as a long-term danger to health \xe2\x80\x94 the slowly degrading plastic leaches toxins into the environment for centuries \xe2\x80\x94 and a well-publicized threat to wildlife; 95 percent of the seabirds examined in one North Sea study had plastic in their stomachs. In clogging storm drains, they\xe2\x80\x99ve even been found to increase the danger of flooding. (You might read, or re-read, the 11-year-old 'b'Ian Frazier piece'b' in The New Yorker about snagging bags out of trees, which comes to mind whenever I see a bag stranded and waving from a limb or some barbed wire, or simply floating through the air like a balloon.) The collection of plastic bags costs taxpayers a bundle, roughly $25 million annually in California alone.'b'A statewide ban on plastic bags is on hold in that state, where, according to the environmental group Californians Against Waste, 400 of them are used per second. But they\xe2\x80\x99re still banned in over 130 jurisdictions, containing a third of California\xe2\x80\x99s population. They\xe2\x80\x99re also banned in 'b'dozens of other communities nationwide'b'. (Not New York City, though; a shame.) Perhaps more impressive is the global activity against plastic bags: in 2002, Ireland instituted a 15-euro cent tax per bag (it\xe2\x80\x99s now 22 euro cents), which helped reduce usage by 95 percent while raising money for recycling and waste reduction initiatives. Seeing this success, several European countries followed suit; Italy banned non-biodegradable plastic bags entirely, joining Rwanda, China, South Africa and other countries that have gotten rid of ultra-thin bags and begun charging customers for thicker plastic versions.'b'The California measure was to go into effect this July, but the American Progressive Bag Alliance, whose chief called the ban \xe2\x80\x9ca terrible piece of job-killing legislation\xe2\x80\x9d (even though a significant portion of the bags are produced in other states), appears to have forced a referendum. This 16-month delay will allow manufacturers to sell around 9 billion extra bags, 'b'worth as much as $145 million'b'. That\xe2\x80\x99s down from its pre-ban peak but still a staggering number when you consider almost all of them are used only once.'b'But the trends are clear: noxious, petroleum-based containers that 'b'do not lend themselves to recycling'b' and are easily replaced are on the way out, if not via national legislation or the Environmental Protection Agency then through local and state laws.'b'There is, however, another issue here, and that is changing culture. Plastic bags could, of course, be re-used, at least a little bit. Almost no one does that, because they\xe2\x80\x99re not especially sturdy, they\xe2\x80\x99re uncomfortable to carry and because we\xe2\x80\x99ve been trained to think of them as disposable.'b'But in a world that is continually being reminded that resources and landfill are limited, curbing products that waste both makes sense, not only for its direct effect but for its cultural changes. I saw this myself in the course of the last month, during which I\xe2\x80\x99ve been mostly in Berkeley.'b'Generally, I would call myself a modestly law-abiding recycler, or a half-hearted begrudging one, anyway. But in my first few trips to the supermarket in Berkeley I felt not exactly ashamed but out of step: nearly everyone was carrying their own bags into the store. And there I was, paying 10 cents for a paper bag.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a price I can afford to ignore, but within a week, I\xe2\x80\x99d joined the crowd. The reasons, I think, range from wanting to be part of the community to recognizing that it just isn\xe2\x80\x99t that onerous to walk down the street with an empty canvas bag. (It\xe2\x80\x99s even easier if the bag is in your car.)'b'Within another week, I was bringing once-used fruit-and-vegetable plastic bags back to the market to use again; I mean, why not? Which almost leads me to suggest that we start carrying re-usable containers for take-out food, as some people have begun to do for coffee. Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s less convenient. But convenience isn\xe2\x80\x99t everything.'b'Political hostility in the United States is more and more becoming personal hostility. New findings suggest that the sources of dispute in contemporary life go far beyond ideological differences or mere polarization. They have become elemental, almost tribal, tapping into in-group loyalty and out-group enmity.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHostile feelings for the opposing party are ingrained or automatic in voters\xe2\x80\x99 minds,\xe2\x80\x9d Shanto Iyengar, a political scientist at Stanford, and Sean Westwood, a post-doctoral researcher at Princeton, wrote in a July 2014 paper \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Fear and Loathing Across Party Lines'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Partisans now discriminate against their adversaries \xe2\x80\x9cto a degree that exceeds discrimination based on race.\xe2\x80\x9d The authors find that this discrimination pervades decision making of all kinds, from hiring to marriage choices.'b'In a 'b'separate 2012 study'b', \xe2\x80\x9cAffect, Not Ideology,\xe2\x80\x9d Iyengar and two other colleagues used a polling method known as a \xe2\x80\x9cthermometer rating\xe2\x80\x9d to measure how Democrats and Republicans feel about each other. The temperature scale goes from 1 to 100. One means the respondent feels cold toward the group; 100 implies that the respondent has warm feelings. Iyengar and his colleagues found in 2008 that Democrat and Republican ratings of the opposition party had dropped to just below 32 degrees. In comparison, Protestants gave Catholics a 66 rating, Democrats gave \xe2\x80\x9cbig business\xe2\x80\x9d a 51, and Republicans rated \xe2\x80\x9cpeople on welfare\xe2\x80\x9d at 50.'b'One of the most striking findings of Iyengar\xe2\x80\x99s 2012 paper is the dramatic increase in the percentages of members of both parties who would be upset if their children married someone in the opposition party (shown in figure 1).'b'From 1960 to 2010, the percentage of Democrats and Republicans who said that members of their own party were more intelligent than those in the opposition party grew from 6 percent to 48 percent; the percentage describing members of the opposition party as \xe2\x80\x9cselfish\xe2\x80\x9d rose from 21 percent to 47 percent.'b'Iyengar and Westwood contend that the conflict between Democrats and Republicans is based more on deeply rooted \xe2\x80\x9cin group\xe2\x80\x9d versus \xe2\x80\x9cout group\xe2\x80\x9d sensibilities than on ideology.'b'In an email exchange, Iyengar speculated on a number of reasons for the increase in polarization:'b'The result, according to Iyengar, is that \xe2\x80\x9csince inter-personal contact across the party divide is infrequent, it is easier for people to buy into the caricatures and stereotypes of the out party and its supporters.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Iyengar\xe2\x80\x99s findings are backed up by a 2014 'b'Pew Research Center study'b' that revealed that \xe2\x80\x9cthe level of antipathy that members of each party feel toward the opposing party has surged over the past two decades.\xe2\x80\x9d Fully 36 percent of Republicans and 27 percent of Democrats believe the opposition party\xe2\x80\x99s policies \xe2\x80\x9care so misguided that they threaten the nation\xe2\x80\x99s well-being,\xe2\x80\x9d Pew found.'b'More recently, a group of four scholars working with Jonathan Haidt, a professor at New York University\xe2\x80\x99s Stern School of Business, and Thomas Talhelm, a doctoral candidate in social psychology at the University of Virginia, have developed a new line of inquiry into the causes and nature of polarization. Their paper, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Liberals Think More Analytically Than Conservatives'b',\xe2\x80\x9d was published online in December. It argues that'b'The answer, according to Talhelm, Haidt and their colleagues: \xe2\x80\x9cliberals and conservatives in the same country think as if they were from different cultures.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These researchers argue that liberals share a propensity for analytic thinking and have'b'Analytic thinking, in this view, \xe2\x80\x9cemphasizes slicing up the world and analyzing objects individually, divorced from context \xe2\x80\x94 much like scientific analysis requires thinkers to separate complex phenomena into separate parts.\xe2\x80\x9d Talhelm elaborated in a phone conversation: The analytic thinking typical of liberals is \xe2\x80\x9cmore conscious, more focused on the rules of logic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Conversely, these researchers define holistic thinking \xe2\x80\x93 which they consider more typical of conservatives \xe2\x80\x94 as \xe2\x80\x9cseeing scenes as a whole and seeing people as a product of situations.\xe2\x80\x9d Talhelm described this style of thought as \xe2\x80\x9cmore automatic, caught up in emotions, and in some ways less adherent to the rules of logic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Talhelm wrote me in an email that \xe2\x80\x9canalytic thinkers tend to do better in engineering, and they hold more patents for inventions. But holistic/intuitive thinkers tend to do better in more social fields, such as early childhood education and marketing.\xe2\x80\x9d One study in the 1960s, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfound that analytic thinkers were more likely to have long hair (for men) and short skirts (women).\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In their 2014 paper, Talhelm and his co-authors'b'Conservatives, in this analysis, are more dedicated to their communities and to the idea of community than liberals. Conservatism, they write,'b'Talhelm and his colleagues suggest a different interpretation for the words \xe2\x80\x9cindividualism,\xe2\x80\x9d which traditionally is associated with conservatism, and \xe2\x80\x9ccollectivism,\xe2\x80\x9d which is often linked to liberalism:'b'Liberal individualism focuses on the self and personal fulfillment. As Talhelm put it:'b'Looking at the issue of partisan conflict in historical terms, Keith T. Poole, a political scientist at the University of Georgia, explained via email that polarization was very high before the Civil War, and again in the 1880s and 1890s \xe2\x80\x9cat the height of industrial capitalism\xe2\x80\x9d when the parties split over \xe2\x80\x9cgold vs. silver, taxes, tariffs, labor organization and inflation.\xe2\x80\x9d Starting in the 1960s, when race came to the forefront, Poole wrote, other issues involving nothing to do with economics \xe2\x80\x94 gun control, gay rights, sexual issues \xe2\x80\x94 began to be drawn into the \xe2\x80\x9cliberal\xe2\x80\x9d vs. \xe2\x80\x9cconservative\xe2\x80\x9d dimension. Now almost every issue from foreign policy to taxes to lifestyle issues has been drawn into the left vs. right alignment.'b'The work of Iyengar, Talhelm and Haidt adds a new layer to the study of polarization. In seminal work, scholars like Nolan McCarty, Jacob Hacker and Paul Pierson, political scientists at Princeton, Yale and Berkeley, respectively, have stressed the key role of external factors in deepening our political schism, including inequality, the nationalization of politics, immigration and the fast approaching moment when whites will no longer be in the majority.'b'David Leege, political scientist emeritus at Notre Dame, provided further insight into the economic forces exacerbating polarization:'b'Iyengar, Talhelm and Haidt do not reject the importance of these external factors. But they do argue that the depth of our polarization reflects ingrained personal, cognitive and psychosocial traits \xe2\x80\x94 traits that are, in Iyengar\xe2\x80\x99s word, \xe2\x80\x9cprimal.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is not an easy problem for politicians to solve. 'b'Republican'b' and 'b'Democratic'b' leaders are struggling to moderate their parties\xe2\x80\x99 most extreme ideological positioning. But if polarization reflects primal aspects of the human condition, particularly when we are under stress, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t going anywhere. However much they might want to pitch themselves toward the center, politicians will feel the need to tap into the energy, not to mention the primary votes, that ideological purity provides. It is this contradiction between purity and pragmatism that will shape the political landscape for the foreseeable future.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Iranian Ayatollah Beseeches Western Youth on Islam'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 23) quotes Ayatollah Ali Khamenei advising Western youths to study the \xe2\x80\x9cteachings of the Prophet of Islam and his humane, ethical doctrines\xe2\x80\x9d in dealing with problems facing young people today.'b'The ayatollah appears to have conveniently forgotten his personal role and that of his entire regime in the treatment of the American hostages in the hostage crisis of 1979-81.'b'BRUCE LAINGEN'b'\nBethesda, Md., Jan. 23, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer was charg\xc3\xa9 d\xe2\x80\x99affaires at the United States Embassy in Tehran during the hostage crisis. 'b''b'I\xe2\x80\x99m not someone who believes that poverty can ever truly be ended \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m one of those \xe2\x80\x9cthe poor will always be with you\xe2\x80\x9d types \xe2\x80\x94 but I do believe that the ranks of the poor can and must be shrunk and that the effects of poverty can and must be ameliorated.'b'And there is one area above all others where we should feel a moral obligation to reduce poverty as much as possible and to soften its bite: poverty among children.'b'People may disagree about the choices parents make \xe2\x80\x94 including premarital sex and out-of-wedlock births. People may disagree about access to methods of family planning \xe2\x80\x94 including contraception and abortion. People may disagree about the size and role of government \xe2\x80\x94 including the role of safety-net programs.'b'But surely we can all agree that no child, once born, should suffer through poverty. Surely we can all agree that working to end child poverty \xe2\x80\x94 or at least severely reduce it \xe2\x80\x94 is a moral obligation of a civilized society.'b'And yet, 14.7 million children in this country are poor, and 6.5 million of them are extremely poor (living below half the poverty line).'b'Today, the 'b'Children\xe2\x80\x99s Defense Fund'b' is releasing a report entitled \xe2\x80\x9cEnding Child Poverty Now\xe2\x80\x9d that calls this country\xe2\x80\x99s rate of child poverty \xe2\x80\x9ca moral disgrace.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the report points out:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAmerica\xe2\x80\x99s poor children did not ask to be born; did not choose their parents, country, state, neighborhood, race, color, or faith. In fact if they had been born in 33 other Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries they would be less likely to be poor. Among these 35 countries, America ranks 34th in relative child poverty \xe2\x80\x94 ahead only of Romania, whose economy is 99 percent smaller than ours.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It points out many of the corrosive cruelties of childhood poverty: worse health and educational outcomes, impaired cognitive development and the effects of \xe2\x80\x9ctoxic stress\xe2\x80\x9d on brain functions. It also points out the \xe2\x80\x9cintergenerational transmission\xe2\x80\x9d properties of poverty:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn one study, people who experienced poverty at any point during childhood were more than three times as likely to be poor at age 30 as those who were never poor as children. The longer a child was poor, the greater the risk of adult poverty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But the report is more than just an excoriation of the hollowness of our professed American values and our ethical quandary. It also serves as an economic manifesto, making the point that allowing child poverty to remain at these unconscionable levels costs \xe2\x80\x9cfar more than eliminating it would,\xe2\x80\x9d calculating that an immediate 60 percent reduction in child poverty would cost $77.2 billion a year, or just 2 percent of our national budget.'b'For context, the report puts it this way:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvery year we keep 14.7 million children in poverty costs our nation $500 billion \xe2\x80\x94 six times more than the $77 billion investment we propose to reduce child poverty by 60 percent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The report cites the M.I.T. Nobel laureate economist and 2014 Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient Dr. Robert Solow, who wrote in his foreword to a 1994 C.D.F. report, \xe2\x80\x9cWasting America\xe2\x80\x99s Future\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cAs an economist I believe that good things are worth paying for; and that even if curing children\xe2\x80\x99s poverty were expensive, it would be hard to think of a better use in the world for money.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To pay for the effort, the report calls for some of the same things the president called for in his State of the Union speech last week, like closing tax loopholes and eliminating tax breaks for the wealthy. But it also called for a reduction in the military budget. This is an echo, in a way, of the concerns Martin Luther King had about military spending sapping money from efforts to help the poor, which he laid out in his not-nearly-cited-enough 1967 anti-Vietnam speech at the Riverside Church:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI knew that America would never invest the necessary funds or energies in rehabilitation of its poor so long as adventures like Vietnam continued to draw men and skills and money like some demonic destructive suction tube. So I was increasingly compelled to see the war as an enemy of the poor and to attack it as such.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What would we get for our $77 billion, anyway? Things like the creation of subsidized jobs, an increase in the earned income tax credit, a raise of the minimum wage, an expansion of child care subsidies and housing subsidies, and an increase in SNAP benefits.'b'The report holds up Britain, which took some of the same steps as a case study of how such an approach can work because they \xe2\x80\x9cmanaged to reduce child poverty by more than half over 10 years, and reductions persisted during the Great Recession.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We can do this too, if we just stop seeing helping these children as an us-versus-them struggle between makers and takers, if we stop getting so hung up on prudishness about sex and traditional views of what constitutes a family, if we stem our impulse to punish children for their mothers giving birth before marriage.'b'By the way, Britain\xe2\x80\x99s out-of-wedlock birthrate is even higher than ours.'b'When we think of Silicon Valley, we tend to imagine a world of extreme wealth and limitless opportunity. What we forget are the populations that have been displaced or neglected by the recent tech boom. Rising property prices in the area have created unsustainable living costs, especially for the poor. At the same time, Silicon Valley lacks 'b'sufficient affordable housing'b' and homeless shelters.'b'This Op-Doc video shows scenes from an overnight public bus that has become popular with the region\xe2\x80\x99s homeless. (According to'b' a report last year'b' from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, 75 percent of the more than 7,500 homeless people in the Silicon Valley area are not in shelters, the highest rate among the nation\xe2\x80\x99s major cities.)'b'Line 22 is a bus route that runs 24 hours in Silicon Valley, shuttling between San Jose and Palo Alto. The homeless pay the fare to ride the bus at night along its hour-and-a-half route, getting off at each end, and often riding several times back and forth. The practice has gone on for years, and the bus is known colloquially as \xe2\x80\x9cHotel 22.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I heard about this phenomenon while living in Palo Alto as a student at Stanford University. It was such a contrast to my image of Silicon Valley that I decided to ride the bus myself. What I saw seemed like a microcosm of the challenges confronting this dispossessed population. And despite mostly keeping to themselves, the sleepers sometimes came into direct conflict with late-night commuters who also ride the bus at those hours.'b'I filmed over the course of a week and edited the footage to represent a composite night on the bus. I hope this film is a window into this nation\xe2\x80\x99s inequities that can so easily go unseen.'b''b'This video is part of a series produced by independent filmmakers who have received support from the nonprofit Sundance Institute.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Prominent North Korean Defector Recants Parts of His Story of Captivity'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 18) overstates the importance of the prison-camp survivor Shin Dong-hyuk\xe2\x80\x99s testimony before the United Nations Commission of Inquiry.'b'Set up to investigate crimes against humanity in North Korea, and headed by an Australian judge, Michael Kirby, the commission heard a total of more than 300 witnesses, experts, survivors and perpetrators in public and confidential sessions.'b'Rather than allow North Korea to use the inaccuracies recently discovered in Mr. Shin\xe2\x80\x99s testimony to undermine the commission\xe2\x80\x99s conclusions and recommendations, let us instead call upon Pyongyang to open the prison camps so that the international community can see for itself what countless victims have reported about them.'b'ROBERTA COHEN'b'\nCARL GERSHMAN'b'\nWashington, Jan. 18, 2015'b''b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writers are, respectively, co-chairwoman of the Committee for Human Rights in North Korea and president of the National Endowment for Democracy.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Representing South Gate, the Los Angeles suburb featured in \xe2\x80\x9c'b'How Mexicans Became Americans'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Sam Quinones (Sunday Review, Jan. 18), I have witnessed its significant transformation.
