It has nothing to do with either \xe2\x80\x9cidentity politics\xe2\x80\x9d or liberalism. It has to do with constitutional rights.'b'The objection to how the police were using stop-and-frisk was that they were conducting unconstitutional searches, violating Supreme Court decisions and targeting victims based on skin color unrelated to reasonable suspicions of crime or possession of a gun. Such searches are illegal, and a federal court so found after an extensive trial.'b'This decision, and Mayor de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s support of it, were greeted with more applause among blacks and Latinos because they were the chief victims of the illegal police practices.'b'Any mayor, liberal or conservative, has an obligation to uphold the law. This should not be seen as a matter of identity politics.'b'IRA GLASSER'b'\nNew York, Jan. 25, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer was executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union from 1978 to 2001.'b''b'Having failed to repeal the Affordable Care Act outright, congressional Republicans are moving ahead with plans to dismantle it piece by piece.'b'Earlier this month, the 'b'House passed a bill'b' that would undermine the so-called employer mandate, which requires certain employers to provide insurance or pay a penalty. In all, 240 Republicans and 12 Democrats voted for the bill while 172 Democrats voted against it. In the Senate, two Democrats recently joined dozens of Republicans to sponsor 'b'a similar measure'b'.'b'Like other attempts to weaken health care reform, the bill, named the Save American Workers Act, is based on false premises and offers false promises. But its bipartisan patina makes it a threat, as do the catchy if misleading assertions of its supporters to win public support.'b'At issue is the threshold at which the employer mandate kicks in. The law requires employers with 50 or more employees to provide insurance to those who work more than 30 hours a week, or pay a penalty of $2,000 to $3,000 per worker. Most of the roughly 230,000 companies with 50 or more workers already provide health insurance, while about 11,500 of such companies do not.'b'The House bill, however, would encourage many companies that provide insurance to stop doing so. It would require coverage (or a penalty) only for employees who work at least 40 hours a week, on the ground that 40 hours is the standard in employment law for a full-time worker. That is true but misses the point of the health care law, which sets a 30-hour threshold to ensure the broadest possible coverage without unduly burdening companies or taxpayers. The law is not intended to address employment-law standards. Turning the issue into an argument over the definition of \xe2\x80\x9cfull time\xe2\x80\x9d is specious.'b'Republicans have also argued that a higher, 40-hour-a-week threshold would protect employees from having their hours cut by employers seeking to evade the coverage requirement. That\xe2\x80\x99s backward. A higher threshold would put more workers, not fewer, at risk of shortened workweeks. With a 30-hour threshold, the employees in danger of cutbacks are those who work around 30 to 34 hours a week, about 7 percent of the work force. With a 40-hour threshold, the employees in danger of cutbacks are those who work 40 hours or more a week, nearly half of the work force.'b'One thing Republicans don\xe2\x80\x99t say is that raising the hourly threshold 'b'would worsen the deficit'b' as more employees turn to publicly subsidized exchanges to find insurance.'b'President Obama has vowed to veto legislative attempts to weaken or undo the health reform law. But that could prove difficult if the measure were attached to other important legislation. The attacks on health reform are senseless, but the danger that they could weaken reform is real.'b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Holding the Democratic Convention in Brooklyn? Young people enticed by the fantasy that they can play and learn at a high level will continue to suffer the consequences.'b'SANA, Yemen \xe2\x80\x94 When I moved here in 2010, not a single gunman could be seen on the streets. Anti-gun laws were strictly enforced by the police, and violence was almost unknown.'b'Nowadays, I escort my wife to the supermarket armed with an automatic assault rifle and a 9-millimeter pistol. The number of spare magazines I carry depends on the gravity of the ever-escalating insecurity that plagues my city.'b'Last week, 'b'the government collapsed'b'. President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi resigned, as did his prime minister and the rest of the cabinet. The Houthis, a group of Shiite militants from the north who fought a bloody series of wars with the central government for over a decade, now effectively control the capital. Their flags fly on street corners, and armed militias operate checkpoints through the city.'b'While the takeover was shocking to foreign officials, for those of us here it was less surprising. After anti-government protests in 2011, Ali Abdullah Saleh, then the president, came under pressure from the United Nations and agreed to step down. Elections were held and Mr. Saleh\xe2\x80\x99s vice president, Mr. Hadi, the only candidate on the ballot, was elected president. Diplomats lauded this \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Yemen'b' model\xe2\x80\x9d of nonviolent political transition, and hailed it as an ideal process for other troubled Arab Spring states.'b'But in the eyes of its mother a monkey is a beautiful gazelle, a Yemeni proverb goes.'b'As the political transition meandered along, violence became dreadfully routine. The Yemeni state disintegrated in slow motion. The transition process, led by the United Nations envoy Jamal Benomar, was ill conceived, badly managed and, as the political vacuum in Sana attests, bound for failure.'b'Yemen\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'oil industry'b' has been almost shut down. Foreign investors, some of whom I have advised over the years, are pulling out. The Red Sea crude oil export pipeline has been blown up repeatedly by tribesmen from oil-rich Marib Province, irate that their demands for local development have been ignored by Mr. Hadi. Similar unresolved demands have provoked tribes in Hadhramaut to take control of oil fields. The kidnappings of foreigners and Yemenis for profit spiked tremendously. Symptomatic of the general lawlessness, over 100 officials have been assassinated, in what may be a result of conflicts between factions of the armed forces.'b'And worst of all, northern Yemen fell into a widespread state of war between the Houthis and the Yemeni military.'b'Throughout a six-month Houthi onslaught last year, Mr. Hadi refused to send army reinforcements to fight the Houthi militia in the north. Instead, he set up a series of mediation committees to try to arrange cease-fires as well as involve the Houthis in the political process.'b'This approach made sense to Mr. Hadi and the United Nations \xe2\x80\x94 they wanted to avoid outright civil war, and thought diplomacy would work.'b'But Yemen moves to a different rhythm. In our country\xe2\x80\x99s culture of tribalism, a party to a conflict must engage in the ritual of violence, if only for the sake of saving face, and leave it to third parties to negotiate. Mr. Hadi\xe2\x80\x99s repeated failure to punish Houthi aggression and his tepid calls for peace were read as weakness.'b'And so each cease-fire deal was broken by the Houthi militia with impunity: Within six months, the Yemeni state had lost control of huge amounts of their military hardware, as well as four northern provinces, to the Houthis.'b'Army leadership resented Mr. Hadi for his refusal to punish the Houthis, despite the deaths of hundreds of soldiers. That\xe2\x80\x99s why, in September, it was hardly a surprise when the Houthi militia entered Sana and established control. Military units refused to fight the Houthi advance, while others, perhaps sympathetic to the Houthi cause, were quietly supportive. The capital fell as Yemen\xe2\x80\x99s army gave Mr. Hadi a taste of his own policy of appeasement.'b'Mr. Hadi\xe2\x80\x99s government attempted a few more diplomatic contortions. Mr. Benomar arranged an 'b'agreement with the Houthis'b' but this was unrealistic. Violent clashes in the city, including one devastating suicide bombing that left over 35 dead, have been widely attributed to Al Qaeda\xe2\x80\x99s local branch, which has also been rallying against the Houthis.'b'Since Mr. Hadi and the government resigned last week, the Houthis have tightened their control, placing Mr. Hadi and other ministers 'b'under house arrest'b'. Government officials in Hadhramaut, Shabwah, Marib, Aden and other provinces are no longer taking orders from Sana. It seems Mr. Hadi\xe2\x80\x99s resignation has caught the Houthis by surprise; even they didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect it to be this easy to seize power. We wait again as the United Nations envoy mounts frantic bids to arrange a new political agreement.'b'Meanwhile, no one is in charge in the capital. Supermarket parking lots are filled with heavily armed guards, and customers walk the aisles with guns slung over their shoulders. Most taxi drivers in Sana have a pistol tucked under their seat.'b'Ultimately, Mr. Hadi\xe2\x80\x99s government collapsed through a series of grievous omissions: inaction in the face of powerful militias, unwillingness to impose law and security all over the country, and a failure to improve the lives of ordinary Yemenis. Mr. Hadi and the United Nations were not able to create the change that Yemenis took to the streets for in 2011.'b'The Yemen model has been replaced by the Houthi model, with its simple adage: Violence pays.'b''b' 'b''b'Haykal Bafana'b', 'b' a lawyer, is the managing director of Bafana Advisory, a firm that guides companies on investment in Yemen. 'b''b'BUENOS AIRES \xe2\x80\x94  On Jan. 14, a prosecutor named Alberto Nisman accused Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s president, Cristina Fern\xc3\xa1ndez de Kirchner, and her foreign minister, H\xc3\xa9ctor Timerman, of covering up Iran\xe2\x80\x99s alleged role in a 1994 terrorist attack.'b'Mr. Nisman was found dead four days later, just hours before he was scheduled to present his findings to Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s Congress. Newspaper headlines around the world suggest that the government is somehow responsible for one of these tragedies or both. I don\xe2\x80\x99t buy it.'b'Before he was found with a bullet in his head, Mr. Nisman had spent almost a decade investigating the worst terrorist attack in Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s history \xe2\x80\x94 the bombing of the Jewish community center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people in July 1994. His death shocked the country and deflected attention from his 290-page accusatory affidavit. The opposition saw the congressional hearing as a weapon against the government; the ruling party, meanwhile, was preparing to poke holes in the affidavit.'b'The media is now leaking fragments of 5,000 hours of intelligence wiretaps, in which neither the president nor the foreign minister make an appearance. Also, rumors abound about whether Mr. Nisman was murdered or killed himself.'b'Mrs. Kirchner has flip-flopped between assuming it was a suicide and, later, suggesting it was not. It is an election year and although she cannot run for another term, her vacillating has not helped her party.'b'Speculation aside, it is important to question the accuracy of the charges made in the affidavit itself, which points a finger at Iran. The document, which has been published online in Spanish, is self-contradictory.'b'First, it accuses Mr. Timerman \xe2\x80\x94 a Jew who was once the victim of the anti-Semitic dictatorship that kidnapped and tortured his father \xe2\x80\x94 of seeking to revoke the Interpol Red Notices, or arrest warrants, against the accused Iranians. Then it cites a wiretap, in which an alleged Iranian agent denounces Mr. Timerman with anti-Semitic epithets for not revoking the red notices.'b'Mr. Nisman was rebuked for this claim by a man he had praised \xe2\x80\x94 the former secretary general of Interpol, Ronald K. Noble. The affidavit repeats 96 times that Mrs. Kirchner and Mr. Timerman tried to get the Interpol warrants against the accused Iranians revoked. But Mr. Noble, who oversaw the warrants, denies this and says Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s leaders consistently did the opposite.'b'In an interview on Jan. 18, Mr. Noble declared: \xe2\x80\x9cNisman\xe2\x80\x99s claims are false.\xe2\x80\x9d The same day, Mr. Nisman was found dead.'b'It is strange that an experienced prosecutor like Mr. Nisman would prepare such a weak document if his goal was to level serious accusations against the president and foreign minister. Of the 290 pages, only two mentioned possible violations of the law, and there was no reference at all to legal doctrine or jurisprudence. Consequently, many people believe that the document wasn\xe2\x80\x99t written by a lawyer and that Mr. Nisman was misled and used.'b'The key to the story is not likely to be found in the present government, but rather in former president Carlos Menem\xe2\x80\x99s administration. Mr. Menem is of Syrian descent, and before Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s 1989 presidential election, he met in Damascus with the Syrian leader, Hafez al-Assad, who had backed him financially. Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s participation in Operation Desert Storm against Syria\xe2\x80\x99s ally, Iraq, in 1991, spoiled this romance. Then, in 1992, the Israeli embassy in Argentina was attacked and in 1994 the Jewish community center was bombed.'b'Secret documents that were declassified in 2003 revealed that Israel\xe2\x80\x99s prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, sent a personal envoy to Argentina just hours after the 1994 attack to agree on a common interpretation of events to present to the press. At the time, Mr. Rabin was facing political pressure at home from opponents of the Oslo peace talks with the Palestinians, which were for the first time occurring with Syrian approval.'b'After his meeting with Mr. Menem, Mr. Rabin\xe2\x80\x99s envoy accused Iran of the attack. The same week, a spokesman from the State Department in Washington went further and excluded Syria from the list of suspects.'b'Mr. Menem also found it politically convenient to look away from Syria, and he did all he could to prevent the Syrian angle from being investigated, due to his previous  relationship with the Assad government and his unfulfilled promises to Syria of diplomatic support and cooperation on nuclear and missile technology.'b'Today, Mr. Menem is on trial alongside some of his cabinet members from that era, as well as a judge and two prosecutors accused of obstructing justice and covering up evidence about the 1994 attack.'b'My organization, the Center for Legal and Social Studies, represents a group of the victims of the attack. In 2005, N\xc3\xa9stor C. Kirchner, Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s president at the time, recognized the state\xe2\x80\x99s responsibility for failing to prevent the bombing or solve the crime.'b'A settlement was agreed upon in which the government promised to modify Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s intelligence law to prevent interference with the judiciary. It took almost a decade before Mr. Kirchner\xe2\x80\x99s widow, now leading the country, began to fulfill that commitment.'b'Last December, Mrs. Kirchner finally appeared to act on her late husband\xe2\x80\x99s promise by ousting the Intelligence Service\xe2\x80\x99s top brass in an overdue attempt to clean house. Mr. Nisman\xe2\x80\x99s death could have been blowback; many believe that the ousted intelligence operations chief, Antonio Stiuso, fed Mr. Nisman the affidavit and might have been involved in his death.'b'According to the affidavit, the Memorandum of Understanding that Argentina and Iran signed in January 2013 facilitated a cover-up, the secret goal of which was to enable Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s purchase of Iranian oil \xe2\x80\x94 something highly unlikely because of the high sulfur content of Iranian oil, six times the amount allowed by Argentine refineries. But the memorandum\xe2\x80\x99s actual purpose was to allow a judge to interrogate the accused Iranians and to set up an International Truth Commission, composed of prestigious jurists from other countries.'b'Signing a memorandum with the  na\xc3\xafve illusion that it might one day bring the accused before a tribunal, as with Libya and the 1988 Lockerbie bombing case, does not constitute a crime. Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s government doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know who is guilty, but it wants to permit the judiciary to find out.'b'Mr. Nisman\xe2\x80\x99s death and the ongoing uncertainly about the 1994 attack have exposed the flaws in Argentina\xe2\x80\x99s justice system and its promiscuous relationship with the intelligence establishment.'b'The promised reforms cannot be postponed any longer. Argentina needs more transparency, more oversight of intelligence services and the severing of inappropriate ties between spies, judges and prosecutors.'b'Mrs. Kirchner announced the dissolution of the Intelligence Secretariat and the creation of a federal intelligence agency earlier this week. That is only the first step toward finding justice for the victims of the 1994 attack and Mr. Nisman\xe2\x80\x99s family.'b''b'\n'b'Horacio Verbitsky,'b' a journalist and author, is president of the Center for Legal and Social Studies and a member of the board of Human Rights Watch Americas.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Leaders Defend Shutdown for a Blizzard That Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 28):'b'When public transportation was suspended because of the coming snowstorm, was any care taken for the hundreds of workers who remained at their posts? And high praise to those in charge for thinking of the welfare of the citizenry above all else.'b'SAM GOODYEAR'b'\nBinghamton, N.Y., Jan. 28, 2015'b''b'There is no point in second-guessing the decisions that were made from Sunday to Monday involving the New York City megablizzard that never arrived, including the one to shut down the city subways \xe2\x80\x94 the 'b'first time in 110 years'b' that the system stopped because of a snow forecast.'b'But, in the cold, clear light of Wednesday, it is fair to ask a question:'b'Why is it that the main story shifts to subplots involving perceived power plays and simmering resentments and miscommunication between Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio? This time, it was the strange revelation that, on Monday afternoon, when Mr. Cuomo made the call to shut the subways down, the mayor of New York found out only a few minutes before the rest of the public did.'b'Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s people say they had no intention to freeze out the mayor \xe2\x80\x94 that it was just a crazy day, the forecast since the night before had been for dangerous winds and deep snowdrifts, and that almost as soon as the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Thomas Prendergast, made the shutdown recommendation to Mr. Cuomo, on Monday at 4:15 p.m., City Hall learned about it, on a 4:30 conference call. He only wished he\xe2\x80\x99d been told sooner.'b'Beyond that, it seems Mr. Cuomo never picked up the phone, if only for the courtesy: \xe2\x80\x9cHey, Bill, heads-up, we need to shut the subways down. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Not that the mayor had any real authority over the matter. Contrary to what a lot of people think, the governor runs the subways, which are part of the M.T.A., a creature of New York State government.'b'But the mayor is responsible for his city \xe2\x80\x94 and held to be so by all of his constituents. And the city has a right to wonder why its leaders were not involved, even as interested bystanders, in discussions whose outcomes affect the lives of hundreds of thousands of people.'b'In a region of many neighboring and overlapping jurisdictions, when emergencies ignore political borderlines, the public can only benefit when leaders speak to \xe2\x80\x94 and with \xe2\x80\x94 one another. Remember the time last year when Mr. Cuomo and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey together declared a 'b'mandatory quarantine'b' for returning Ebola health care workers? That decision was tightly coordinated; Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Christie spoke like brothers-in-arms. But they also infuriated New York City health officials, who had not been informed, and had no chance to block or weigh in on the policy, except after the fact to call it foolish, which it was.'b'No one will ever say that Mr. Cuomo is anything but a take-charge executive in a crisis. The commander in chief of the Empire State is not one to snooze through an emergency or delegate hard jobs to underlings.'b'But at moments like this \xe2\x80\x94 as with the Ebola overreaction, and Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s alpha-male tussling with Mr. de Blasio over issues like prekindergarten \xe2\x80\x94 we all have a right to ask why the governor and the mayor always have to seem as if they are in a contest for who is the most powerful person in the room.'b'In 'b'my last column'b', I wrote about a high school buddy, Kevin Green, a warm and helpful man who floundered in a tough job market, hurt his back and died at the age of 54. The column was a call for empathy for those who are struggling, but, predictably, scolds complained that Kevin\xe2\x80\x99s problems were of his own making.'b'Grrrr.'b'So what do we know about empathy and how to nurture it?'b'First, it seems hard-wired. 'b'Even laboratory rats'b' will sometimes free a trapped companion before munching on a food treat.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cProbably the biggest empathy generator is cuteness: paedomorphic features such as large eyes, a large head, and a small lower face,\xe2\x80\x9d Steven Pinker, the Harvard psychologist, tells me. \xe2\x80\x9cProfessional empathy entrepreneurs have long known this, of course, which is why so many charities feature photos of children and why so many conservation organizations feature pandas. Prettier children are more likely to be adopted, and baby-faced defendants get lighter sentences.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Not much we can do about looks \xe2\x80\x94 although criminal defense lawyers try, by having scruffy clients shave and dress up before appearing in court.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s also some research suggesting that wealth may impede empathy. 'b'One study by psychologists at the University of California at Berkeley'b' finds that drivers of luxury cars are more likely to cut off other motorists and ignore pedestrians at a crosswalk. Likewise, 'b'heart rates of wealthier research subjects'b' are less affected when they watch a video of children with cancer.'b'Granted, skepticism is reasonable any time (mostly liberal) academics reach conclusions that portray the wealthy in a poor light. But these experiments also find a measure of backing in the real world. For example, among Democratic politicians, personal wealth is a predictor of supporting legislation that would increase inequality, 'b'according to a journal article last year'b' by Michael W. Kraus and Bennett Callaghan.'b'Likewise, the wealthiest 20 percent of Americans give significantly less to charity as a fraction of income (1.4 percent) than the poorest 20 percent do (3.5 percent), according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.'b'That may be partly because affluence insulates us from need, so that disadvantage becomes theoretical and remote rather than a person in front of us. Wealthy people who live in economically diverse areas 'b'are more generous'b' than those who live in exclusively wealthy areas.'b'Wealth may also turn us inward. Some experiments manipulated research subjects to think of money \xe2\x80\x94 such as by having them gaze at a pile of Monopoly money and imagine great wealth \xe2\x80\x94 and found that when a person then \xe2\x80\x9caccidentally\xe2\x80\x9d spilled pencils nearby, 'b'those thinking of great wealth were less helpful'b' than those imagining tight budgets and picked up fewer pencils from the floor.'b'So how do we increase empathy?'b'Dacher Keltner, who runs 'b'the Greater Good Science Center'b' at the University of California at Berkeley, says that having people think about suffering activates the vagus nerve, which is linked to compassion. He also cites evidence that uplifting stories about sacrifice boost empathy, as do various kinds of contemplation \xe2\x80\x94 prayer, meditation, yoga.'b'Keltner says that going out into nature also appears to encourage greater compassion. Feelings of awe, such as those generated by incredible images from space, seem to do the same thing, he says.'b'Professor Pinker, 'b'in his superb book'b' \xe2\x80\x9cThe Better Angels of Our Nature,\xe2\x80\x9d explores whether the spread of affordable fiction and journalism beginning in the 18th century expanded empathy by making it easier for people to imagine themselves in the shoes of others. 'b'Researchers have found that reading literary fiction'b' by the likes of Don DeLillo or Alice Munro \xe2\x80\x94 but not beach fiction or nonfiction \xe2\x80\x94 can promote empathy.'b'I used to be cynical about student service projects, partly because they seemed so often to be about dressing up a college application, and trips so often involve countries with great beaches. (Everyone wants to help Costa Rica!) Then there was The Washington Post\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'report about the Mexican church that was painted six times'b' over the course of a summer by successive waves of visitors.'b'Yet I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to believe that service trips do open eyes and remind students of their good fortune. In short, they build empathy.'b'So let\xe2\x80\x99s escape the insulation of our comfort zones. Let\xe2\x80\x99s encourage student service projects and travel to distant countries and to needy areas nearby. Whatever the impact on others, volunteering may at least help the volunteer. Let\xe2\x80\x99s teach Dickens and DeLillo in schools, along with literature that humanizes minority groups and builds understanding.'b'Above all, let\xe2\x80\x99s remember that compassion and rationality are not effete markers of weakness, but signs of civilization.'b'TOO often the debate over how to restart Europe\xe2\x80\x99s economy veers into the conveniently crisp alternatives of stimulus versus austerity. Should the pressure to reduce government deficits be relaxed? Should central bank actions to lower interest rates have come sooner and been more aggressive?'b'That simplistic debate has returned to the forefront, with the European Central Bank\xe2\x80\x99s plunge into purchasing the sovereign debt of its member nations and Greece\xe2\x80\x99s resounding vote at the ballot box against spending cuts.'b'But the focus on macroeconomic policy underappreciates the critical importance of smaller structural problems that collectively amount to a bigger challenge for Europe.'b'Archaic restrictions on hiring and firing workers, flawed energy policies and kilometers of red tape that can make even starting a business difficult \xe2\x80\x94 just to name a few \xe2\x80\x94 have combined to damage the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s ability to compete in increasingly global markets.'b'Among major countries, France and Italy have these problems most acutely, with wages continuing to rise even as the efficiency of workers has stagnated.'b'In France, President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande arrived in office in 2012 atop a leftist wave and responded with policies that ranged from lowering the retirement age to 60 to raising corporate and value-added taxes.'b'His policies have even managed to get French businessmen into the street, shouting \xe2\x80\x9cenough is enough\xe2\x80\x9d into megaphones \xe2\x80\x94 an expression of their frustration with the layers of regulations, such as a new requirement that all part-time jobs be at least 24 hours per week. Unpopular and under pressure from the European Union, Mr. Hollande has tacked modestly toward the center.'b'Meanwhile, Italy\xe2\x80\x99s youthful new prime minister, Matteo Renzi, arrived determined to reverse three years of recession by overhauling problems such as rigid labor laws and a grindingly slow judicial system.'b'After months of battling, he recently made progress on a bank reform bill and secured initial passage of his jobs act. That occasioned demonstrations and strikes across the country by workers who feared that it would succeed in dismantling Italy\xe2\x80\x99s 2,700 pages of labor market regulations, which effectively institutionalized inefficiency by making it exceptionally difficult to fire workers.'b'Even generally sensible Germany has veered wildly off course in its energy policy. In the wake of the 2011 nuclear disaster at Fukushima in Japan, the country, which derived about a quarter of its energy from low-cost nuclear power, has begun shutting down its reactors. That came on top of a requirement that utilities purchase specified amounts of clean power at prices far higher than electricity from conventional sources.'b'A result is weakened competitiveness for Germany\xe2\x80\x99s much-vaunted industrial sector and suggestions by businessmen that new facilities requiring large amounts of power may be located in more hospitable countries.'b'More positively, Spain, while still plagued by an unemployment rate of 23.7 percent, has managed to implement labor and tax reforms, helping the country to begin adding jobs again amid renewed economic growth.'b'With all the problems facing Europe, the recent European Central Bank decision to buy bonds amounts to reaching into a medicine cabinet when the patient needs open-heart surgery.'b'For one thing, high interest rates are hardly Europe\xe2\x80\x99s problem. France can borrow at 0.6 percent for 10 years, and even Spain and debt-laden Italy can borrow at around 1.5 percent.'b'And despite robust European Central Bank financing programs, loan demand from the private sector remains weak. Since 2008, business investment has dropped about 15 percent.'b'Many explanations are offered for why the eurozone is lagging. Some say it\xe2\x80\x99s lack of immigration. Sure, the United States has benefited enormously from the diversity and productivity of newcomers. But with 11.5 percent unemployment, the eurozone wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to need more workers.'b'Income inequality? Unlike the United States, where inequality has soared, on the Continent, the gap between the haves and the have-nots, although large, has widened only modestly.'b'To be sure, in the appropriate context, more public spending and investment and commendable efforts to avoid deflation, like those of the European Central Bank, would be well advised.'b'But under the present circumstances, such steps risk distracting the Continent even further from addressing its most serious challenges.'b'Europe needs to become more competitive in global markets. That can be achieved only by a variety of policy changes, such as keeping top tax rates at sensible levels and regulatory reforms that would give companies more freedom to manage their businesses as they see fit, including, when necessary, closing plants and reducing head counts. 'b''b'Many Republicans have no fondness for net neutrality \xe2\x80\x94 the idea that cable and phone companies should treat all information equally as it travels over their broadband Internet networks. So it comes as no surprise that some of them are trying to throw a wrench into the Federal Communications Commission\xe2\x80\x99s plan to adopt strong Internet rules.'b'Republicans and large telecommunications companies are natural allies in opposing government regulations. Now, two Republican lawmakers, Senator John Thune of South Dakota and Representative Fred Upton of Michigan, have 'b'proposed a bill'b' that they claim would achieve neutrality on the Internet without the kind of regulation the F.C.C. is expected to approve next month. But the legislation has such large loopholes that powerful cable and phone companies like Comcast and Verizon would feel almost no effect.'b'Mr. Thune and Mr. Upton say'b' their bill 'b' would forbid the cable and phone companies from giving preference to traffic from certain businesses, like Amazon and Google, that are willing to pay more for faster delivery, which would hurt smaller companies. The legislation would also prohibit such companies from blocking or slowing downloads from certain sites.'b'Those are excellent goals, but there is a giant caveat in the bill: Companies would be allowed to offer \xe2\x80\x9cspecialized services\xe2\x80\x9d that would not be subject to any of those rules. Conceivably, almost anything could be called a \xe2\x80\x9cspecialized service,\xe2\x80\x9d which is really just linguistic sleight of hand.'b'The bill would also prohibit the F.C.C. from classifying broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, something the commission has been 'b'moving closer to'b' in recent months. Courts have ruled that the commission now has limited authority to regulate broadband, but the telecommunications designation \xe2\x80\x94 which already applies to home phone lines and cellphone service \xe2\x80\x94 would give the commission the authority it needs to prohibit companies from engaging in unfair and unreasonable business practices. The chairman of the F.C.C., Tom Wheeler, 'b'recently suggested'b' that the agency would vote on Feb. 26 to reclassify broadband.'b'The good news is that even if Republicans in Congress, who receive 'b'big donations'b' from telecommunications companies, can push through Mr. Thune\xe2\x80\x99s and Mr. Upton\xe2\x80\x99s legislation, President Obama would almost surely veto it. 'b'In November'b', the president 'b'called on'b' the F.C.C. to reclassify broadband. But Republicans could try to get the proposal through by attaching it to unrelated bills the president would find difficult to veto. Democrats in Congress and President Obama should be ready to defend the F.C.C.'b'ROCHESTER, Minn. \xe2\x80\x94 PRESIDENT OBAMA\xe2\x80\x99S new budget is expected to include hundreds of millions of dollars for so-called precision medicine. The initiative, which he introduced last week in his State of the Union address, has bipartisan support and is a bright spot in the otherwise tight funding environment for medical research. Unfortunately, precision medicine is unlikely to make most of us healthier.'b'The basic idea behind it is that we each have genetic variants that put us at increased or decreased risk of getting various diseases, or that make us more or less responsive to specific treatments. If we can read someone\xe2\x80\x99s genetic code, then we should be able to provide him or her with more effective therapeutic and preventive strategies.'b'But for most common diseases, hundreds of genetic risk variants with small effects have been identified, and it is hard to develop a clear picture of who is really at risk for what. This was actually one of the major and unexpected findings of the Human Genome Project. In the 1990s and early 2000s, it was thought that a few genetic variants would be found to account for a lot of disease risk. But for widespread diseases like diabetes, heart disease and most cancers, no clear genetic story has emerged for a vast majority of cases.'b'Age, sex, body weight and a few simple blood tests are much better predictors of Type 2 diabetes, for example, than a genetic score based on how many snippets of \xe2\x80\x9crisky\xe2\x80\x9d DNA you have. And the advice for those at risk to exercise more and eat more healthfully remains the same.'b'When higher-risk genetic variants are found, their predictive power is frequently dependent on environment, culture and behavior. The main genetic variant associated with obesity, for instance, is associated with obesity only in people born after the early 1940s \xe2\x80\x94 most likely because of the low-physical-activity, high-calorie world that emerged after World War II.'b'A second unexpected finding of the Human Genome Project was the problem of \xe2\x80\x9cmissing heritability.\xe2\x80\x9d While the statistics suggest that there is a genetic explanation for common conditions and diseases running in families or populations, it turns out that the information on genetic variants doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explain that increased risk.'b'Several high-profile attempts to use genetic variants to target patients with commonly used drug therapies have also failed in clinical trials. Perhaps the most notable example is the anticoagulant warfarin, which is used by millions of patients to prevent blood clots and strokes. Researchers have found that genetic information on how patients metabolize drugs does not improve on the standard way of adjusting the dose up or down, based on factors like age, weight and blood test results.'b'For relatively rare diseases like cystic fibrosis, exciting new drugs have been developed using genetic information, but they have not been able to fix defective genes via gene therapy, as originally hoped. There have also been positive reports about precision therapies for specific genetic defects in cancer, but it\xe2\x80\x99s difficult to design clinical trials to test this strategy in a large number of patients. Many tumors are also notorious for their ability to mutate and ultimately circumvent the best therapies.'b'The push toward precision medicine could also lead to unintended consequences based on how humans respond to perceptions of risk. There is evidence that if people believe they are less at risk for a given disease, they feel excessively protected and their behavior gets worse, putting them at increased risk. Likewise, those who feel they are at greater risk, even if the increased risk is small, might become fatalistic, making their behavior worse as well. Then there are the worriers, who might embark on a course of excessive tests and biopsies \xe2\x80\x9cjust in case.\xe2\x80\x9d In a medical system already marked by the overuse of diagnostic tests and procedures, this could lead to even more wasteful spending.'b'We have been down this road before. The idea behind the \xe2\x80\x9cwar on cancer\xe2\x80\x9d was that a deep understanding of the basic biology of cancer would let us develop targeted therapies and cure the disease. Unfortunately, although we know far more today than we did 40-plus years ago, the statistics on cancer deaths have remained incredibly stubborn. The one bright spot has been tobacco control \xe2\x80\x94 again highlighting the dominant role of culture, environment and behavior versus biological destiny in what ails most of us.'b'Given the general omert\xc3\xa0 about researchers\xe2\x80\x99 criticizing funding initiatives, you probably won\xe2\x80\x99t hear too many objections from the research community about President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s plan for precision medicine. But I am deeply skeptical. Like most \xe2\x80\x9cmoonshot\xe2\x80\x9d medical research initiatives, precision medicine is likely to fall short of expectations. Medical problems and their underlying biology are not linear engineering exercises, and solving them is more than a matter of vision, money and will.'b'We would be better off directing more resources to understanding what it takes to solve messy problems about how humans behave as individuals and in groups. Ultimately, we almost certainly have more control over how much we exercise, eat, drink and smoke than we do over our genomes.'b'SANTA BARBARA, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 Every Cuban knows the \xe2\x80\x9cwet foot, dry foot\xe2\x80\x9d drill: Risk fleeing to the United States and get caught at sea, and you will be sent back to the island; but if you wangle just one toe onto dry land, you\xe2\x80\x99re home free. Indeed, for almost a half century, Cubans have been the most privileged immigrants in the United States.'b'The repeal of this Cold War relic of immigration policy is long overdue. But for Cubans, it was a record year. About 30,000 took to the Florida Straits or arrived via Mexico (the preferred route for those who can afford the flight). Unlike the Mexicans, Guatemalans, Salvadorans and Haitians \xe2\x80\x94 most of whom received the heave-ho \xe2\x80\x94 each Cuban was welcome.'b'Word, and worry, has spread that the two pieces of legislation that make up the Cuban Privilege might not be around much longer. Since Dec. 17, when President Obama re-established relations with Cuba, the waters between the two countries have been swarming with migrants.'b'Last month, 481 Cubans were intercepted or rescued from jury-rigged rafts and boats \xe2\x80\x94 a 117 percent increase from the previous year, according to the Coast Guard. Many are not so lucky. Some migrants try five or 10 times before they successfully cross the 90 miles of water. How many have not made it? Thousands for sure over the last 50 years \xe2\x80\x94 making the Florida Straits one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest aquatic graveyards.'b"Cuban authorities have demanded an end to the Cuban Adjustment Act, claiming the policy causes a brain drain. (Of course, they never acknowledge why more than a million Cubans have risked their lives to escape.) The vote in Miami last week had different motivations: Commissioner Bruno Barreiro, whose family members were beneficiaries of the act, argued that the Castro brothers have long exploited the law to ship out dissidents and to infiltrate spies into the exile community. And El Exilio Historico (the old guard) complains that the new arrivals are economic migrants, not political refugees fleeing communism \xe2\x80\x94 the law\xe2\x80\x99s raison d'\xc3\xaatre."b'While all this is true, there are more compelling reasons to end the Cuban Privilege. One of them is fairness. Are Cubans seeking a better way of life really more deserving than, say, refugees fleeing death squads or drug cartels?'b'Another is its enabling of a veritable crime syndicate: According to a 'b'recent series in The Sun Sentinel'b', a small cadre of Cubans specializing in Medicare and insurance fraud have bilked American taxpayers and businesses out of more than $2 billion since 1994. Even when caught and prosecuted (many, if not most, flee back to Cuba before capture), they cannot be deported, because Cuba refuses to accept them.'b'It is not at all clear if these two relics of immigration policy will be scotched; the State Department has said they are not on the table. Much depends on the Hispanics in Congress, whose colleagues expect them to take the lead. But the three serving in the Senate happen to be, yup, Cuban-American: Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz and Robert Menendez.'b'None have especially strong bona fides among most Latinos. Indeed, being second-generation white Cuban exiles puts them at odds with the overwhelming majority of Latinos in the United States, who are of mixed race or indigenous descent. Ted Cruz, who is not fluent in Spanish, has been called as Hispanic \xe2\x80\x9cas Tom Cruise.\xe2\x80\x9d In 2012, 'b'an anti-Rubio commercial'b' on Spanish-language TV ended with the tag \xe2\x80\x9cNo Somos Rubios\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a pun meaning both \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not Rubios\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not blonds\xe2\x80\x9d (or whites).'b'But if Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz are serious about their White House ambitions, they will need the votes of Latinos. That means they need to see to it that fairness dictates immigration reform. And that means the end of the Cuban Adjustment Act and \xe2\x80\x9cwet foot, dry foot.\xe2\x80\x9d So three Cuban-Americans \xe2\x80\x94 members of a group that enjoys an unprecedented, coveted status \xe2\x80\x94 could well decide the fate of millions of their less fortunate Hispanic brethren. Now that\xe2\x80\x99s rich. Only in America.'b'AS we were reminded last summer when thousands of unaccompanied children showed up on our southwestern border, the security and prosperity of Central America are inextricably linked with our own.'b'The economies of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras remain bogged down as the rest of the Americas surge forward. Inadequate education, institutional corruption, rampant crime and a lack of investment are holding these countries back. Six million young Central Americans are to enter the labor force in the next decade. If opportunity isn\xe2\x80\x99t there for them, the entire Western Hemisphere will feel the consequences.'b'Confronting these challenges requires nothing less than systemic change, which we in the United States have a direct interest in helping to bring about. Toward that end, on Monday, President Obama will request from Congress $1 billion to help Central America\xe2\x80\x99s leaders make the difficult reforms and investments required to address the region\xe2\x80\x99s interlocking security, governance and economic challenges. That is almost three times what we generally have provided to Central America.'b'Last summer, as our countries worked together to stem the dangerous surge in migration, the leaders of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras asked for additional assistance to change the climate of endemic violence and poverty that has held them back. In June, I made it clear to these leaders that the United States was ready to support them \xe2\x80\x94 provided they took ownership of the problem. Mr. Obama drove home this point when the leaders visited Washington in July.'b'And they responded. Honduras signed an agreement with Transparency International to combat corruption. Guatemala has removed senior officials suspected of corruption and aiding human trafficking. El Salvador passed a law providing new protections for investors. Working with the Inter-American Development Bank, these three countries forged a joint plan for economic and political reforms, an alliance for prosperity.'b'These leaders acknowledge that an enormous effort is required. We have agreed to intensify our work together in three areas.'b'First, security makes everything else possible. We can help stabilize neighborhoods through community-based policing, and eradicate transnational criminal networks that have turned Central America into a hotbed for drug smuggling, human trafficking and financial crime. Some communities in Guatemala and El Salvador are already seeing the benefit of United States-sponsored programs on community policing, specialized police training and youth centers similar to Boys and Girls Clubs in the United States. As I learned in crafting the 1994 United States crime bill, these programs can reduce crime.'b'Second, good governance begets the jobs and investment that Central America needs. Today, court systems, government contracting and tax collection are not widely perceived as transparent and fair. These countries have among the lowest effective tax rates in the hemisphere. To attract the investments required for real and lasting progress, they must collect and manage revenues effectively and transparently.'b'Third, there is not enough government money, even with assistance from the United States and the international community, to address the scale of the economic need. Central American economies can grow only by attracting international investment and making a more compelling case to their citizens to invest at home. That requires clear rules and regulations; protections for investors; courts that can be trusted to adjudicate disputes fairly; serious efforts to root out corruption; protections for intellectual property; and transparency to ensure that international assistance is spent accountably and effectively.'b'We are ready to work with international financial institutions and the private sector to help these countries train their young people, make it easier to start a business, and ensure that local enterprises get the most out of existing free trade agreements with the United States.'b'The challenges ahead are formidable. But if the political will exists, there is no reason Central America cannot become the next great success story of the Western Hemisphere.'b'The region has seen this sort of transformation before. In 1999, we initiated Plan Colombia to combat drug trafficking, grinding poverty and institutional corruption \xe2\x80\x94 combined with a vicious insurgency \xe2\x80\x94 that threatened to turn Colombia into a failed state. Fifteen years later, Colombia is a nation transformed. As one of the architects of Plan Colombia in the United States Senate, I saw that the key ingredient was political will on the ground. Colombia benefited from leaders who had the courage to make significant changes regarding security, governance and human rights. Elites agreed to pay higher taxes. The Colombian government cleaned up its courts, vetted its police force and reformed its rules of commerce to open up its economy. The United States invested $9 billion over the course of Plan Colombia, with $700 million the first year. But our figures show that Colombia outspent us four to one.'b'The cost of investing now in a secure and prosperous Central America is modest compared with the costs of letting violence and poverty fester.'b'Mr. Obama has asked me to lead this new effort. For the first time, we can envision and work toward having the Americas be overwhelmingly middle class, democratic and secure.'b'That is why we are asking Congress to work with us. Together, we can help Central America become an embodiment of the Western Hemisphere\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable rise \xe2\x80\x94 not an exception to it.'b'A couple of years after America\xe2\x80\x99s attempted invasion of Cuba in 1961, the disastrous intervention known as the Bay of Pigs, an envoy President John F. Kennedy secretly dispatched to Havana posed an odd question to the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know how porcupines make love?\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'James Donovan asked'b', to make a point about how hard it would be to establish a trustful relationship between Washington and Havana. \xe2\x80\x9cVery carefully.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More than a half century later, as American and Cuban officials 'b'faced each other last week'b' for historic talks to begin normalizing relations, it was evident that trust remains in short supply. But this first step in the present d\xc3\xa9tente bodes well for a process that will require patience and deft managing of expectations in both countries.'b'Having been indoctrinated for decades to view the American government with suspicion and resentment, Cubans across the island were mesmerized by a week that was as remarkable for some of the things that happened as it was for those that did not.'b'A vivacious senior Cuban diplomat, 'b'Josefina Vidal'b', substantively answered questions about the thaw from international and Cuban journalists during a televised news conference, a rare sight in a country where official statements are typically oblique and issued in writing. Remarks to the press by 'b'Roberta Jacobson'b', the United States assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, were also televised and 'b'covered by Cuba\xe2\x80\x99s state media'b' without the usual condemnatory tone reserved for American policy.'b'The two women agreed to disagree on a lot, including what role Washington could play to promote greater freedoms in the authoritarian nation. But breaking with a tradition of charged rhetoric on both sides, Ms. Vidal and Ms. Jacobson treated each other civilly.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDespite the profound differences between the two countries, the exchanges unfolded in a respectful and professional manner,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Vidal said.'b'Ms. Jacobson held a high-profile meeting with dissidents; the Cuban government did not stop it or publicly condemn it. She also visited the home of a prominent blogger, 'b'Yoani S\xc3\xa1nchez'b', where she gave an interview to the independent news site Ms. S\xc3\xa1nchez runs from her living room. \xe2\x80\x9cAs journalists, we\xe2\x80\x99re witnessing historic days, in which information is a winner,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. S\xc3\xa1nchez tweeted.'b'Jos\xc3\xa9 Daniel Ferrer, a leading dissident, said he has reassessed his early concern that normalization of relations would embolden the Cuban government and hurt the cause of 'b'those who have been pressing for democratic reforms'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cThe road is going to be very long and hard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Ferrer, the head of the Patriotic Union of Cuba, who met with Ms. Jacobson and other senior diplomats during her visit. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I think that if we are able to work smartly and give it our best, we can advance a lot under these new parameters.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Glued to the news, Cuban entrepreneurs were abuzz about the opportunities the new relationship could bring. Some Cuban journalists, meanwhile, suggested that it might be time for more media outlets to operate independent of state control.'b'What was arguably most striking about the momentous week in Havana was that neither of the Castro brothers was seen or heard from. But this week, Fidel Castro broke his silence about the new era with the United States, making a brief mention of the talks at the end of a lengthy letter published Monday by the Communist Party newspaper, Granma.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t trust American policies,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Castro wrote, adding that he nonetheless supported negotiations about the countries\xe2\x80\x99 differences through diplomacy. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will always defend cooperation and friendship with all nations on earth, among them our political adversaries.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Ra\xc3\xbal Castro, meanwhile, said in a speech on Wednesday that the road to normalization will be long, as he listed a lengthy set of grievances, including the American naval base in Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay and the sanctions against the island.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe were able to advance in this recent negotiation because we treated each other with respect, as equals,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'With plenty of people in both countries skeptical about the merits of a thaw, Cuban and American officials will need to be pragmatic and patient as they begin to untangle a toxic relationship laden with five decades of acrimony, resentment and mistrust. Given the enthusiasm and expectation the new era has sparked among ordinary Cubans and Americans alike, allowing the d\xc3\xa9tente to collapse would be a loss for both sides.'b'In seeking to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece, congressional Republicans have placed a high priority on 'b'repealing a tax on medical devices'b' that would raise some $29 billion over the next 10 years to help ensure that health reform will not increase the deficit. Repealing the tax is a terrible idea that has been given a veneer of respectability by support from liberal Democrats in states with large concentrations of device manufacturers. They include Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken of Minnesota and Representative Ron Kind of Wisconsin, among others. President Obama ought to veto any bill that eliminates the tax.'b'The health reform law imposes a modest 2.3 percent tax on sales of medical devices, to be paid by the manufacturers or importers. It applies to such products as X-ray machines, M.R.I. scanners, pacemakers and artificial hip and knee joints but not to eyeglasses, contact lenses and hearing aids. The $29 billion to be raised from the device industry is less than the amounts to be raised from insurers and drug companies, all of which will benefit from increased business under the act and should pay their fair shares of the cost. If the lost revenues from a repeal of the device tax are offset by reduced spending on other health care programs, as they might well be, many patients could suffer medical or financial harm.'b'Trade groups say the tax has already caused a big loss of jobs, has reduced spending on research and will lead to a total loss of 195,000 jobs among manufacturers and suppliers and in the general economy over the next five years. They also say the tax will stifle innovation, drive up health care costs and provide an incentive for manufacturers to locate facilities overseas.'b'Independent analysts believe the industry\xe2\x80\x99s dire forecasts are malarkey. The Congressional Research Service estimated that the tax would have \xe2\x80\x9crelatively modest\xe2\x80\x9d effects on jobs, research and company profits and a \xe2\x80\x9cnegligible\xe2\x80\x9d effect on the price of health care. Some jobs would be lost, but they account for a tiny fraction of 1 percent of the industry\xe2\x80\x99s work force. The C.R.S. said the tax should not affect decisions on where to locate production facilities because domestically produced devices and imported devices are subject to the same tax.'b'Some parts of the industry are thriving. In Warsaw, Ind., which bills itself as the \xe2\x80\x9cOrthopedic Capital of the World,\xe2\x80\x9d demand for artificial hips and knees and other orthopedic devices appears to be growing and companies are scrambling to hire more people.'b'Bills to repeal the tax were introduced in both chambers of Congress this month. Apart from its immediate harm, repealing the tax could trigger a rush by other health care interests to repeal the taxes and fees that apply to them, thereby increasing budget deficits or requiring painful cuts in health care programs.'b''b'To the Editor'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c 'b'\xe2\x80\x9916 Koch Budget Is $889 Million'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 27):'b'So this is the democracy we\xe2\x80\x99re trying to promote in other countries, a democracy where the legislators do not represent their constituents who voted them in, but the highest bidder.'b'I never voted for the Koch brothers to represent me.'b'DONNA MACHINA'b'\nOakton, Va., Jan. 27, 2015'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'There is a huge, unintended consequence waiting to be addressed: the intimidation factor.'b'The infusion of almost a billion dollars into an election cycle is far more of a concern than even the nine wise justices could predict.'b'ADAM STOLER'b'\nBronx, Jan. 27, 2015'b''b'The Veterans Affairs Department is going to provide housing for disabled homeless veterans on the vast property it owns in Los Angeles. On Wednesday, it 'b'announced'b' an agreement with plaintiffs in a lawsuit \xe2\x80\x9cthat restores the West Los Angeles V.A. campus to serving veterans in need,\xe2\x80\x9d by housing them there, and by ending the practice of leasing parts of the 387-acre property to outside parties in deals \xe2\x80\x9cthat do not meet the goal of serving veterans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Which raises two obvious questions: Isn\xe2\x80\x99t serving veterans the main \xe2\x80\x94 the only \xe2\x80\x94 purpose of the V.A.? Why did it have to be sued to do its job?'b'To which there is one obvious answer: Somewhere along the way, the department lost sight of its mission. The interests of wounded, destitute veterans came into conflict with those of people in Los Angeles who have power and money. The land went to corporate leaseholders, to other, apparently more urgent, commercial and civic needs \xe2\x80\x94 to baseball diamonds, theater stages, hotel laundries, rental car and bus storage, even oil wells and a dog park.'b'The homeless, meanwhile, went to sidewalks and highway underpasses.'b'This was the way it had been for many years. Los Angeles has long had the largest population of homeless veterans in the country, and also one of the country\xe2\x80\x99s largest V.A. medical centers. But nowhere on that property was there any permanent housing to help veterans leave the streets for good. That this deplorable situation was tolerated for so long reflects the failure of the area\xe2\x80\x99s elected officials. Its powerful congressional delegation and V.A. officials proclaimed their support for the veterans but never managed to do right by them.'b'Much credit goes to Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert McDonald, barely six months on the job, for recognizing that the Los Angeles debacle could and should be remedied quickly. He listened to the plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 lawyer Ron Olson and to Bobby Shriver, the former mayor of Santa Monica, who has pressed this issue for years, and embraced the once radical-sounding idea that the sickest and most troubled veterans need \xe2\x80\x9chousing first\xe2\x80\x9d to receive services they deserve but cannot get without a roof and a bed.'b'Credit Mr. McDonald, too, for agreeing to appoint a \xe2\x80\x9chomeless czar\xe2\x80\x9d to report directly to him, so this urgent mission does not get swallowed by the agency\xe2\x80\x99s dead-end bureaucracy. The ambitious agreement commits the V.A. to having, by mid-February, an \xe2\x80\x9caction plan\xe2\x80\x9d on ending homelessness in Los Angeles, and to completing, by October, a new master plan for the site.'b'Mr. McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s predecessor committed the V.A. to an ambitious plan to end veterans\xe2\x80\x99 homelessness by the end of this year. That won\xe2\x80\x99t happen unless the V.A. solves Los Angeles. Mr. McDonald has just given his department a swift kick in the right direction.'b'In the middle of 2013, the United States began supporting moderate rebels in Syria. We gave them just enough support to betray them.'b'As 'b'Adam Entous reported in The Wall Street Journal earlier this week'b', we promised the fighters support but then never had the will to follow through. The C.I.A. gave the rebels just 5 percent to 20 percent of the arms they requested. One trusted commander asked for more than a thousand rifles and received fewer than 36. One commander got the equivalent of 16 bullets a month per fighter. The rebels captured dozens of tanks, but the C.I.A. wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t provide cash for fuel or shells so the tanks just sat there.'b'The rebels asked the C.I.A. for ammunition to take advantage of temporary opportunities, but the C.I.A. sometimes took two weeks to decide. The U.S. gave the rebels money to pay their troops, but they only gave them $100 to $150 for each fighter per month. The Islamic State paid its fighters twice that.'b'The C.I.A. was terrified that the arms it supplied would fall into enemy hands so it maintained paralyzingly tight controls on sophisticated weaponry. Trusted commanders had to film their use of anti-tank missiles. They had to hand over spent missile launchers at a spot along the border to qualify for resupply.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe walk around Syria with a huge American flag planted on our backs, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t have enough AK-47s in our hands to protect ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d one fighter told American lawmakers.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you give us hope if you were not going to do anything about it?\xe2\x80\x9d another asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe thought going with the Americans was going with the big guns,\xe2\x80\x9d another leader declared at a meeting. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a losing bet.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The whole Wall Street Journal report gives the impression that the Islamic State not only has more resolve than the U.S. and its intelligence agencies, it has faster and more competent leadership.'b'The betrayal of the rebels in 2013 and 2014 is only a small betrayal, compared with the betrayal of values that might be unintentionally happening now. It appears as though the U.S. is backing off in its opposition to Bashar al-Assad, the mass murderer whose barbaric regime is a prime cause of instability in that part of the world. In our effort to stop the Islamic State, in the hopes of smoothing the Iranian nuclear talks, we may have entered a de facto alliance with Assad.'b'Now, Syria is obviously a viper\xe2\x80\x99s pit in a region where the choices normally range from the appalling to the horrendous. But there are ways to approach problems in this region, and there are ways not to.'b'The way not to approach the Middle East is as a chessboard on which the grandmasters of American foreign policy can impose their designs. This is the sort of overconfident thinking that leads policy makers to squander moral authority by vowing to destroy Assad one month and then effectively buttressing him the next. This is the sort of overconfident thinking that leads to too-clever calibration of our support for the moderate rebels \xe2\x80\x94 giving them enough support to give the illusion of doing something real, while not actually giving enough to do any good.'b'The Middle East is not a chessboard we have the power to manipulate. It is a generational drama in which we can only play our role. It is a drama over ideas, a contest between the forces of jihadism and the forces of pluralism. We can\xe2\x80\x99t know how this drama will play out, and we can\xe2\x80\x99t direct it. We can only promote pluralism \xe2\x80\x94 steadily, consistently, simply.'b'Sticking to our values means maintaining a simple posture of support for people who share them and a simple posture of opposition to those who oppose them. It means offering at least some reliable financial support to moderate fighters and activists even when their prospects look dim. It means avoiding cynical alliances, at least as much as possible. It means using bombing campaigns to try to prevent mass slaughter.'b'If we do that then we will fortify people we don\xe2\x80\x99t know in ways we can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine. Over the long term, we\xe2\x80\x99ll make the Middle East slightly more fertile for moderation, which is the only influence we realistically have. Ideas drive history.'b'Right now there is bipartisan inconsistency over the effectiveness of government. Republicans think government is a bumbling tool at home but a magnificent instrument abroad. Democrats think government is a magnificent instrument at home but a bumbling tool abroad. In reality, government is best when it chooses the steady simple thing over the complex clever thing. When you don\xe2\x80\x99t know the future and can\xe2\x80\x99t control events, bet on people. Support the good, oppose the bad.'b'Realist half-commitments that undermine our allies and too-clever games that buttress our foes will only backfire \xe2\x80\x94 and lead to betrayals that make us feel ashamed.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'More Fall Out as Middle Class Shrinks Further'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Business Day, Jan. 26): \xe2\x80\x9cMiddle class\xe2\x80\x9d has become a meaningless political term covering everyone who is not on food stamps and does not enjoy big capital gains. Like a sociological magician, I can make the middle class grow, shrink or disappear just by the way I choose to define it.'b'What is clear and incontestable is the growing inequality in this country over the last three decades. In a 180-degree reversal of the pattern in the decades after World War II, the gains of economic growth flow largely to the people at the top.'b'DENNIS GILBERT'b'\nClinton, N.Y., Jan. 26, 2015'b''b''b'The writer, a professor of sociology at Hamilton College, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe American Class Structure in an Age of Growing Inequality.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'The babies came one after the other in my family, six in eight years\xe2\x80\x99 time, then a miscarriage, a seventh, and finally a dire medical warning: An eighth child might leave the rest without the young woman who had brought us into this world. My mother went to her general practitioner first, then the Roman Catholic bishop. The doctor said stop. The cleric said shame if you do.'b'In our neighborhood, we were the small family, at least among the Irish and Italians. A few doors down, there were 12 kids in one house, 14 in another. We could almost field a full baseball team. But the Flynns, they could put an entire football lineup on a snowy field at Thanksgiving, with reserves.'b'My mother agonized over what to do. She was devout, though starting to read progressive Catholic magazines like Commonweal, which published the essays of Hannah Arendt and the poetry of W.H. Auden. We loved Robert F. Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s family: 11 kids, and 'b'Ethel looks great'b'. Bobby himself was the seventh of nine. Of course, they had money, so it looked glamorous.'b'If only Pope Francis had been around then. His words from the papal plane returning from the Philippines earlier this month \xe2\x80\x94 that good Catholic parents did not have to \xe2\x80\x9cbe like rabbits\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 would have landed like angel dust on the shoulders of my ever-pregnant mom. Just before his breeding advice, the pope told a story about a mother in remarkably similar circumstances as my own.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI met a woman some months ago in a parish who was pregnant with her eighth child, who had seven C-sections,\xe2\x80\x9d said Francis. \xe2\x80\x9cBut does she want to leave the seven as orphans? This is to tempt God.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As a father of two children, I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine having seven. Growing up, nobody in our neighborhood had a big house. Kids were stuffed into tiny rooms, racked and stacked on bunk beds, crammed into a windowless space next to the boiler. My dad put in a little room in the basement next to where he brewed beer in 55-gallon plastic barrels. The non-Catholics, and even some of the Catholics from tonier parts of town, made fun of us \xe2\x80\x94 'b'don\xe2\x80\x99t those people know how to control themselves?'b''b'But beyond the strain to a house, adding another child, in our case, was a life and death matter. As Francis said, the question was whether to tempt God.'b'Church teaching, then and now, was against all \xe2\x80\x9cartificial\xe2\x80\x9d forms of birth control. As loyal Catholics, my parents practiced the \xe2\x80\x9crhythm method,\xe2\x80\x9d and you can see how well that worked out. Even an operation that was vital to the life of the mother was frowned upon, if that would make it impossible for her to get pregnant again. If she did what doctors insisted she do, she would be a bad Catholic. The bishop left my mother in tears. Hadn\xe2\x80\x99t she done her share?'b'She decided to ignore the admonition from on high. She had the operation, in her mid-30s, and the baby train came to halt. She never lost her faith. But she did come to a conclusion, shared by an overwhelming majority of American Catholics, that men in clerical authority have no business telling women what to do with their bodies. For that matter, neither do politicians.'b'Today, some people with big families have taken offense at the pope\xe2\x80\x99s comments. Rick Santorum, a Catholic father of seven with a persistently medieval worldview, questioned what the pope was trying to accomplish. The National Catholic Register quoted a woman with nine siblings, who said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are left to wonder whose side Pope Francis is on.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s on the side of reason \xe2\x80\x94 well, halfway there. The pope later clarified his remarks, saying his stance did not mark a fundamental shift from the church\xe2\x80\x99s position. If only. Opposition to birth control and condoms in places like the Philippines poses serious public health risks, tempting God again.'b'The pope\xe2\x80\x99s rabbit remark did not bother me, as one of seven children, in the least. What bothers me is church dogma that disrespects people who are forced to go through what my mother went through.'b'Religions are at their best when they deal with the theological realm or big global issues. Religions are at their worst when they muddle in sex, and question whom you can love. Many interpretations of Islam, regarding women, are an abomination. Mormons, until about an hour ago, had long made gays feel immoral and inferior \xe2\x80\x94 this from a religion where the founders were men who had 50 wives. Strict Catholic doctrine about sex, still on the books, could not be preached by Pope Francis with a straight face.'b'The People\xe2\x80\x99s Pope is the most popular man on the planet. He\xe2\x80\x99s been on the cover of Rolling Stone, and was named Time Magazine\xe2\x80\x99s Person of the Year in 2013. His words matter far beyond the flight of doves in St. Peter\xe2\x80\x99s Square. His off-the-cuff remarks continue to display a vigorous Jesuit mind at work, trying to resolve reason and faith, but above all \xe2\x80\x94 showing humanity.'b'As it turned out, my mother didn\xe2\x80\x99t need a scowling bishop to make up her mind. She had a mind of her own, and used it. Because of that, she lived to a ripe old age.'b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Sorority Anti-Rape Idea: Drinking on Own Turf'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 20):'b'Young women at college don\xe2\x80\x99t realize the tremendous power they possess.
