Resettlement programs, if properly researched and established, offer the greatest potential for countries to absorb refugees, not just by sharing the costs of refugee crises, but by harnessing the great resources that refugees have to offer.'b'GALYA BENARIEH RUFFER'b'\nEvanston, Ill., Jan. 28, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is the director of the Center for Forced Migration Studies at the Buffett Center, Northwestern University.'b''b'In the five years (!) that have passed since the euro crisis began, clear thinking has been in notably short supply. But that fuzziness must now end. Recent events in Greece pose a fundamental challenge for Europe: Can it get past the myths and the moralizing, and deal with reality in a way that respects the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s core values? If not, the whole European project \xe2\x80\x94 the attempt to build peace and democracy through shared prosperity \xe2\x80\x94 will suffer a terrible, perhaps mortal blow.'b'First, about those myths: Many people seem to believe that the loans Athens has received since the crisis broke have been subsidizing Greek spending.'b'The truth, however, is that 'b'the great bulk of the money lent to Greece'b' has been used simply to pay interest and principal on debt. In fact, for the past two years, more than all of the money going to Greece has been recycled in this way: the Greek government is taking in more revenue than it spends on things other than interest, and handing the extra funds over to its creditors.'b'Or to oversimplify things a bit, you can think of European policy as involving a bailout, not of Greece, but of creditor-country banks, with the Greek government simply acting as the middleman \xe2\x80\x94 and with the Greek public, which has seen a catastrophic fall in living standards, required to make further sacrifices so that it, too, can contribute funds to that bailout.'b'One way to think about the demands of the newly elected Greek government is that it wants a reduction in the size of that contribution. Nobody is talking about Greece spending more than it takes in; all that might be on the table would be spending less on interest and more on things like health care and aid to the destitute. 'b'And doing so would have the side effect'b' of greatly reducing Greece\xe2\x80\x99s 25 percent rate of unemployment.'b'But doesn\xe2\x80\x99t Greece have an obligation to pay the debts its own government chose to run up? That\xe2\x80\x99s where the moralizing comes in.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s true that Greece (or more precisely the center-right government that ruled the nation from 2004-9) voluntarily borrowed vast sums. It\xe2\x80\x99s also true, however, that banks in Germany and elsewhere voluntarily lent Greece all that money. We would ordinarily expect both sides of that misjudgment to pay a price. But the private lenders have been largely bailed out ('b'despite a \xe2\x80\x9chaircut\xe2\x80\x9d on their claims in 2012'b'). Meanwhile, Greece is expected to keep on paying.'b'Now, the truth is that nobody believes that Greece can fully repay. So why not recognize that reality and reduce the payments to a level that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t impose endless suffering? Is the goal to make Greece an example for other borrowers? If so, how is that consistent with the values of what is supposed to be an association of sovereign, democratic nations?'b'The question of values becomes even starker once we consider why Greece\xe2\x80\x99s creditors still have power. If it were just a matter of government finance, Greece could simply declare bankruptcy; it would be cut off from new loans, but it would also stop paying off existing debts, and its cash flow would actually improve.'b'The problem for Greece, however, is the fragility of its banks, which currently (like banks throughout the euro area) have access to credit from the European Central Bank. Cut off that credit, and the Greek banking system would probably melt down amid huge bank runs. As long as it stays on the euro, then, Greece needs the good will of the central bank, which may, in turn, depend on the attitude of Germany and other creditor nations.'b'But think about how that plays into debt negotiations. Is Germany really prepared, in effect, to say to a fellow European democracy, \xe2\x80\x9cPay up or we\xe2\x80\x99ll destroy your banking system?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And think about what happens if the new Greek government \xe2\x80\x94 which was, after all, elected on a promise to end austerity \xe2\x80\x94 refuses to give in? That way, all too easily, lies a forced exit of Greece from the euro, with potentially disastrous economic and political consequences for Europe as a whole.'b'Objectively, resolving this situation shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be hard. Although nobody knows it, Greece has actually made great progress in regaining competitiveness; wages and costs have fallen dramatically, so that, at this point, austerity is the main thing holding the economy back. So what\xe2\x80\x99s needed is simple: Let Greece run smaller but still positive surpluses, which would relieve Greek suffering, and let the new government claim success, defusing the anti-democratic forces waiting in the wings. Meanwhile, the cost to creditor-nation taxpayers \xe2\x80\x94 who were never going to get the full value of the debt \xe2\x80\x94 would be minimal.'b'Doing the right thing would, however, require that other Europeans, Germans in particular, abandon self-serving myths and stop substituting moralizing for analysis.'b'Can they do it? We\xe2\x80\x99ll soon see.'b'PRESIDENT OBAMA\xe2\x80\x99s domestic agenda, which he announced in his State of the Union address this month, has a lot to like: health care, maternity leave, affordable college. But there was one thing he got wrong. As part of his promise to educate American children for an increasingly competitive world, he vowed to \xe2\x80\x9cprotect a free and open Internet\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cextend its reach to every classroom and every community.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More technology in the classroom has long been a policy-making panacea. But mounting evidence shows that showering students, especially those from struggling families, with networked devices will not shrink the class divide in education. If anything, it will widen it.'b'In the early 2000s, the Duke University economists Jacob Vigdor and Helen Ladd tracked the academic progress of nearly one million disadvantaged middle-school students against the dates they were given networked computers. The researchers assessed the students\xe2\x80\x99 math and reading skills annually for five years, and recorded how they spent their time. The news was not good.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStudents who gain access to a home computer between the 5th and 8th grades tend to witness a persistent decline in reading and math scores,\xe2\x80\x9d the economists 'b'wrote'b', adding that license to surf the Internet was also linked to lower grades in younger children.'b'In fact, the students\xe2\x80\x99 academic scores dropped and remained depressed for as long as the researchers kept tabs on them. What\xe2\x80\x99s worse, the weaker students (boys, African-Americans) were more adversely affected than the rest. When their computers arrived, their reading scores fell off a cliff.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t know why this is, but we can speculate. With no adults to supervise them, many kids used their networked devices not for schoolwork, but to play games, troll social media and download entertainment. (And why not? Given their druthers, most adults would do the same.)'b'The problem is the differential impact on children from poor families. Babies born to low-income parents spend at least 40 percent of their waking hours in front of a screen \xe2\x80\x94 more than twice the time spent by middle-class babies. They also get far less cuddling and bantering over family meals than do more privileged children. The give-and-take of these interactions is what predicts robust vocabularies and school success. Apps and videos don\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'If children who spend more time with electronic devices are also more likely to be out of sync with their peers\xe2\x80\x99 behavior and learning by the fourth grade, why would adding more viewing and clicking to their school days be considered a good idea?'b'An unquestioned belief in the power of gadgetry has already led to educational snafus. Beginning in 2006, the nonprofit One Laptop Per Child project envisioned a digital utopia in which all students over 6 years old, worldwide, would own their own laptops. Impoverished children would thus have the power to go online and educate themselves \xe2\x80\x94 no school or teacher required. With laptops for poor children initially priced at $400, donations poured in.'b'But the program didn\xe2\x80\x99t live up to the ballyhoo. For one thing, the machines were buggy and often broke down. And when they did work, the impoverished students who received free laptops spent more time on games and chat rooms and less time on their homework than before, 'b'according to'b' the education researchers Mark Warschauer and Morgan Ames. It\xe2\x80\x99s drive-by education \xe2\x80\x94 adults distribute the laptops and then walk away.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s true that there is often an initial uptick in students\xe2\x80\x99 engagement with their studies \xe2\x80\x94 interactive apps can be fun. But the novelty wears off after a few months, said Larry Cuban, an emeritus education professor at Stanford.'b'Technology does have a role in education. But as Randy Yerrick, a professor of education at the University at Buffalo, told me, it is worth the investment only when it\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly suited to the task, in science simulations, for example, or to teach students with learning disabilities.'b'And, of course, technology can work only when it is deployed as a tool by a terrific, highly trained teacher. As extensive research shows, just one year with a gifted teacher in middle school makes it far less likely that a student will get pregnant in high school, and much more likely that she will go to college, earn a decent salary, live in a good neighborhood and save for retirement. To the extent that such a teacher can benefit from classroom technology, he or she should get it. But only when such teachers are effectively trained to apply a specific application to teaching a particular topic to a particular set of students \xe2\x80\x94 only then does classroom technology really work.'b'Even then, we still have no proof that the newly acquired, tech-centric skills that students learn in the classroom transfer to novel problems that they need to solve in other areas. While we\xe2\x80\x99re waiting to find out, the public money spent on wiring up classrooms should be matched by training and mentorship programs for teachers, so that a free and open Internet, reached through constantly evolving, beautifully packaged and compelling electronic tools, helps \xe2\x80\x94 not hampers \xe2\x80\x94 the progress of children who need help the most.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Charles M. Blow\xe2\x80\x99s Jan. 28 online column, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Reducing Our Obscene Level of Child Poverty'b',\xe2\x80\x9d cuts to the heart of the matter: Far too many children live in poverty in this country, and the consequences are not just economic.'b'Poverty squelches children\xe2\x80\x99s chances of meeting their most basic needs of sound nutrition, nurturing relationships and safe environments.'b'Food insecurity, malnutrition and chronic hunger are components of the complex effects of poverty on a child\xe2\x80\x99s nutrition. As Mr. Blow alludes to, the inability of caregivers to provide food for themselves or their children constitutes a \xe2\x80\x9ctoxic stress\xe2\x80\x9d in families, contributing to depression, anxiety and other emotional hardships.'b'There is a substantial body of literature linking early childhood malnutrition and adult disease, including diabetes and cardiovascular disease.'b'In addition to food insecurity, poor families may have difficulty maintaining adequate housing, heat and utilities. In this way, children also suffer the effects of poverty through the stress that economic hardship exerts on their families.'b'For pediatricians, childhood poverty is a health issue requiring the same course of prevention, early detection, diagnosis and treatment as any other ailment. Children who live in poverty have increased rates of asthma, obesity, dental caries, injuries, mental health diagnosis, H.I.V. infections and tobacco exposure.'b'Eradicating poverty and its enduring effects on child health will require meaningful partnerships, strong investments and sustained commitments by our elected leaders. Pediatricians will continue to speak up for children, from our clinics to the halls of the Capitol, until we achieve real progress on ensuring the foundations of health for every child in this country.'b'SANDRA G. HASSINK'b'\nPresident'b'\nAmerican Academy of Pediatrics'b'\nWilmington, Del., Jan. 28, 2015'b''b''b''b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Where\xe2\x80\x99s the Empathy?'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (column, Jan. 25):'b'The soul-searing commentary by Nicholas Kristof shines an appropriately harsh light on rich America\xe2\x80\x99s view of our \xe2\x80\x9chave not\xe2\x80\x9d brothers and sisters in our morally decaying land.'b'Mr. Kristof\xe2\x80\x99s compassionate sketch of Kevin Green, his boyhood friend who fell on hard times, suffered bad breaks and died an untimely death at 54, is appropriately critical of our country\xe2\x80\x99s wealthy, and their view: I have mine; if you don\xe2\x80\x99t have yours, it\xe2\x80\x99s your fault, and not my problem.'b'Am I in the minority, or does it seem that every day, more of us are becoming social Darwinists, quick to ignore or, worse, blame our brothers and sisters in need?'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t even those who might have made bad choices, and are now drowning, deserve a lifeline of compassion from those of us more blessed?'b'Whether atheist, agnostic or fervent follower (of whatever faith) who worships a deity, one is compelled to ask: By what accident am I in this lucky spot, and how can I sleep at night as I consider the dust of what was once a man? 'b''b'In the past few weeks, as the radical leftist party Syriza barreled toward victory in 'b'Greece'b'\xe2\x80\x99s early national elections, it became a symbol both inside and outside the country: Everyone seemed to see what they wanted in the formerly marginal party that promised to reject the international bailout agreement that has kept Greece on life support for nearly five years.'b'For a growing number of Greeks, exhausted and desperate after six years of recession and insecurity, Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s anti-austerity platform was seen as a promise of salvation and an effort to reclaim the country\xe2\x80\x99s sovereignty; others saw the impending clash with Greece\xe2\x80\x99s European Union partners as a deadly threat to an economy that was just beginning to show signs of growth.'b'Many foreign observers, on the left and the right, saw Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s rise as a rebellion against austerity and the economic and political orthodoxy of the European Union, a revolt that could spread to other debtor nations. European Union governments, which had lent Greece money (along with the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund), worried that their taxpayers would foot the bill for Greece\xe2\x80\x99s voters and that this would inspire populist revolts in other countries.'b'In the first days after the Jan. 25 election, Syriza remains a chimera, an unpredictable hybrid. The party is a coalition of several factions and viewpoints, with cabinet members ranging from garrulous, cosmopolitan academics to former Communist trade-unionists with limited experience of the outside world. Adding to the puzzle is the fact that the party leader, Alexis Tsipras, the new prime minister, formed a coalition with a small, extreme right-wing party \xe2\x80\x94 Independent Greeks \xe2\x80\x94 in order to hold a majority in the 300-member Parliament. This decision puzzled local supporters as well as foreign analysts. The two parties have in common their virulent opposition to the bailout agreement, and this was one more way for Mr. Tsipras to show that his pre-election rhetoric was no bluff.'b'The government is clearly heading for a clash with Greece\xe2\x80\x99s partners. It is pushing for a large reduction of debt and the annulment of various structural reforms carried out (halfheartedly) by previous governments. In their first comments, new ministers have announced cuts in the privatization program and the recall of public sector employees who were laid off \xe2\x80\x94 canceling measures demanded by creditors. Several European leaders have reminded Athens that Greece is committed to the bailout agreement and that Europe cannot write off loans their taxpayers provided. Greece\xe2\x80\x99s financing expires in February, unless bailout monitors from the troika (the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund) complete an inspection suspended in November.'b'Syriza declares that it does not recognize the troika and will deal only with European decision-making bodies. Mr. Tsipras stresses that he wants Greece to remain in the eurozone. But with Greece shut out of capital markets, and with its partners not about to give in to Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s demands, it is difficult to see how the economy will function if funds run out.'b'The showdown over the bailout is extremely dangerous, and obscures many serious issues that need to be dealt with in Greece and in the European Union as a whole.'b'Greece is the first European Union country in which a party from the political fringes has ridden a wave of popular anger against economic hardship to provide a direct challenge to policy makers in European capitals. The program of loans in return for austerity and reform has not gone according to plan and needs fixing. In turn, Greece must make a huge effort to create a  viable economy that will not need further bailouts.'b'Syriza, not being part of the political mainstream that governed Greece over the past four decades, is in a unique position to cut down on the corruption, tax evasion and inequality that plague Greece. But at the same time, the party also shares a dominant mind-set that holds back progress, such as devotion to a huge state and an economy and education system in which politics play a destructive role. Syriza represents the potential for change as well as the danger of rolling back reforms of the past few years.'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cmarriage\xe2\x80\x9d with the Independent Greeks, whose 13 Parliament members are now added to Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s 149, reveals another aspect of Greece\xe2\x80\x99s politics. The smaller party represents the opposite of Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s liberal social platform, which includes expanded rights for immigrants, recognition of 'b'same-sex marriage'b', separation of church and state, and protection of  human rights.'b'Apart from their rejection of the bailout agreement \xe2\x80\x94 the Independent Greeks\xe2\x80\x99 leader, Panos Kammenos, is even more vocal than Mr. Tsipras in his attacks on Germany \xe2\x80\x94 the two party leaders have something else in common: Mr. Tsipras, who is 40, and Mr. Kammenos, who is 49, both cut their political teeth during years that Greece experienced unprecedented growth, stability and prosperity.'b'As a student activist for the Communist Party, Mr. Tsipras learned that the way to get things done was by confronting authority while making maximal demands; Mr. Kammenos, the son of a wealthy businessman, entered the cocoon of mainstream politics early and was deeply embedded in the establishment, serving in a previous conservative government before forming his own party. So Syriza has chosen a coalition partner that will not temper the government\xe2\x80\x99s stand against its European Union partners but will probably try to outdo the leftists on rhetoric and actions.'b'The confrontation with Greece\xe2\x80\x99s creditors can be seen as a clash between populism and dogma: on one side, a government that gained power by exploiting anger and despair; on the other, the creditor countries and organizations that insist on austerity even in the face of evidence that it is destroying a country and its people.'b'But it also raises the issue of democracy, and how the rights of one nation can clash with the rights of others. If the democratically elected Greek government reneges on the country\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to repay its debt, this will be at the expense of taxpayers in partner countries. If the European Union pushes Greece hard for further austerity to get back the loans, this may crush the will of Greek voters. And if the European Union leaves Greece in its proud isolation, where its economy will most likely collapse, will all Greeks be forced to pay for the mistakes of a government elected by 36 percent of them (along with the less than 5 percent who voted for its partner)?'b'Political developments in Greece now demand a serious discussion on the relationship among Europe\xe2\x80\x99s peoples, and on the need for reform to spring from hope, not punishment.'b''b'\n'b'Nikos Konstandaras 'b'is the managing editor and a columnist at the newspaper Kathimerini. 'b''b'ABOARD THE POLAR PIONEER, off the Antarctic Peninsula \xe2\x80\x94 I never intended to go to Antarctica and I intended never to read \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick.\xe2\x80\x9d There is a significant distinction between these two positions. It had simply not crossed my mind that Antarctica could be a tourist destination, until I was offered a writing commission to go there. But \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d was a book that was always waiting to be read, and it was an active assertion of will to decide no, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. I made that decision after someone I don\xe2\x80\x99t now remember described it as an interminable novel with tortured descriptions of harpoons and ropes and men with crazy obsessions. I can\xe2\x80\x99t fully explain the doggedness of that position, which I don\xe2\x80\x99t extend to any other so-called great book, but I became even more intractable about it after my friends Karin and Elizabeth, the two people whose literary tastes I most trust, also pressed me to read the book.'b'But when a week before I set off, another friend suggested \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d should accompany me on the 10-day voyage from Ushuaia, Argentina, to as-far-as-the-ice-would-allow-it along the Antarctic Peninsula and back to Puerto Williams, Chile, it immediately felt inevitable. I would read the book I had planned never to read in the place where I had never planned to go. There\xe2\x80\x99s no arguing with the universe when it throws symmetry your way.'b'I started to read it two days into the voyage, when our ship, the Polar Pioneer, a Russian icebreaker carrying 52 tourists, had crossed the choppy Drake Passage and was nearing the South Shetland Islands. I opened to the first page of the book and wrote in its bottom margin, \xe2\x80\x9cDec 8: Sailing to Antarctica on the Polar Pioneer. First whale (humpback) sighted at 2.20 p.m.\xe2\x80\x9d I never annotate novels; it seems odd to think anything I might write in the margins could add to rather than detract from what is printed on the page. But from the start, the echoes between what I was reading and what I was seeing around me seemed to ask for me to take note, quite literally.'b'And so very quickly (in fact, by page 20, as my annotations tell me) my favorite reading spot became a high chair on the bridge, where I could look up from the \xe2\x80\x9cice and icebergs all astern\xe2\x80\x9d on the page to see the very sight before me. \xe2\x80\x9cThrough icy water \xe2\x80\x94 we feel the ship scrape against small icebergs,\xe2\x80\x9d I wrote as the Polar Pioneer progressed through the Lemaire Channel with snow-covered cliffs on both sides and snow petrels swooping about. At the top of the next page I read Melville\xe2\x80\x99s phrase \xe2\x80\x9cbrace the ship against the icy concussions of those battering seas\xe2\x80\x9d and at the bottom is my handwriting again: \xe2\x80\x9cAlmost constant shuddering through the ship now that it is impossible to skirt the icebergs.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sometimes the annotations were marks of difference rather than similarity between the Pequod of \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d and the Polar Pioneer of my voyage. \xe2\x80\x9cSupreme lord and dictator\xe2\x80\x9d is how Melville describes Captain Ahab. Beside that sentence I wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd here I sit, on the bridge, behind Captain Yuri of very tolerant countenance.\xe2\x80\x9d I should say that \xe2\x80\x9cvery tolerant countenance\xe2\x80\x9d is not in my everyday speech. But by this point the book was working its way into me \xe2\x80\x94 as was the surrounding landscape. As I read on and traveled on, the superficial annotations marking echoes and variations became increasingly sparse: In iceberg country, the bulk of experience lies beneath the surface.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d and Antarctica have this in common: At the very start you stand amazed, believing you\xe2\x80\x99ve experienced \xe2\x80\x9cthe great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open,\xe2\x80\x9d and it is only when you are further in that you look back upon that beginning (of book, of voyage along the continent) and are startled by how ordinary it seems compared with where you now are. The day I started to read the book was also our first landing via inflatable Zodiac crafts, in which we skimmed along the calm water toward the Aitcho Islands of the South Shetlands and visited our first penguin colony. How feverishly we all reached for our cameras and took pictures of the first, lone penguin that walked past our party; how we gasped in amazement at the first Weddell seal moving across the snow like a slug.'b'We knew nothing then of what was yet to come: the sculpture parks of icebergs; the elephant seal pups that would lie on our legs and consent to being stroked; the hissing, jabbing, pecking battles between skuas and penguins for penguin eggs on the verge of hatching; the sailing into the caldera of an active volcano; the whale pods swimming alongside the ship, raising their flukes above the surface ever so often \xe2\x80\x94 a sight that Melville described as \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps the grandest sight to be seen in all animated nature.\xe2\x80\x9d All these sights were still unimagined when, back on the bridge after Aitcho Island, I was reading the encounter of Ishmael with Queequeg the Cannibal, not recognizing that as wonderful as it was, it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly prepare me for the complete break with all convention, all recognized form, that Melville would embark on once he had his readers on the Pequod.'b'Why do people persist in claiming that \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d is about Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s obsession with the white whale? Certainly it is a book about obsession, but it is Melville who is obsessed, with the need to capture the visible in a net of words. What else explains all those chapters about kinds of whales, parts of whales, stages of reducing a dead whale to salable components, not to mention the details of every last rivet on a whaling ship? Or, as Andrew Delbanco more elegantly puts it in his introduction to the Penguin Classics edition, \xe2\x80\x9cit furnishes one dazzling solution after another to the persistent literary problem of conveying to an innocent reader the palpable reality of an unfamiliar world.\xe2\x80\x9d Until Antarctica, I had never stepped foot anywhere that struck me so forcefully as an \xe2\x80\x9cunfamiliar world\xe2\x80\x9d in a purely physical sense. From Sugarloaf Mountain in Rio de Janeiro to the Buddhist stupas of Taxila, everything I have ever seen has been an amplified version of something I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen or read about before.'b'Antarctica is a different matter. \xe2\x80\x9cHow will you ever describe this to people who haven\xe2\x80\x99t been here?\xe2\x80\x9d the other tourists asked me, over and over. The line announced itself as a challenge the first time I heard it, and everywhere I went I tried to translate the images around me into descriptive sentences, particularly the icebergs, so varied in shape and texture and even color (those blues!). It felt from the start that I would fail; the camera on my smartphone would convey more than I ever could.'b'But as I burrowed more deeply into Melville, I knew my failure had nothing to do with the power of word versus photograph and everything to do with the power of Melville\xe2\x80\x99s sentences versus mine. One Antarctic afternoon, near the British base of Port Lockroy, I trudged knee-deep in snow toward what appeared to be sun-bleached oars someone had jammed vertically into the packed whiteness. They were whale vertebrae, from a partially buried skeleton. A few of us dug around to reveal more of them, part of the skull and a lower jaw. The size muddled our comprehension: We spent a long time identifying the bone that was the mandible, even though its position near the unmistakable skull should have made it obvious. How could a jawbone be that size?'b'When I took off my wet gloves, my hands were warm with sun and exertion. I snapped some photographs. Considered if I could come up with anything better than \xe2\x80\x9csun-bleached oars\xe2\x80\x9d to describe the vertebrae; couldn\xe2\x80\x99t. Tried to construct an image of a whale from the bones against which I rested my fingertips; couldn\xe2\x80\x99t again. A few days later I read the chapter \xe2\x80\x9cMeasurement of the Whale\xe2\x80\x99s Skeleton.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cHow vain and foolish ... for timid untravelled man to try to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over his dead attenuated skeleton. ... Only in the heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings of his angry flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the fully invested whale be truly and livingly found out.\xe2\x80\x9d The rhythm of the language, its use of rhyme and assonance, the miracle of compression within that expansive sentence! You journey into Melville as though he were a new continent, unlike any you\xe2\x80\x99ve encountered before.'b'Of course, I was wrong to think Melville\xe2\x80\x99s sole obsession was with capturing the visible. It was my own preoccupation with the \xe2\x80\x9chow would you describe this?\xe2\x80\x9d question that I was reading into his work, which goes so far beyond the visible world. By the end of the voyage I realized that describing icebergs couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really begin to convey how it felt that day, our last before we sailed away from the Antarctic Peninsula, when we spent hours on Zodiacs, warming our hands against the sun-soaked flanks of the crafts gliding along a sea so still that every iceberg was almost indistinguishable from its reflection. The next day I jotted down one of my last annotations, just over halfway through the novel: \xe2\x80\x9cFinal landing, on Elephant Island. Returning to the ship I noticed only one iceberg to be seen. We have sailed away from them; the sea has lost much of its magic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Because then the annotations almost entirely disappear, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how many pages of \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d I had left when we disembarked the Polar Pioneer at Puerto Williams. A little over 50 is probably about right. I switched on my phone, which had served the sole function of camera for the last 10 days, and the first text message I saw, sent more than 24 hours earlier, was from a BBC producer asking me if I might come on a news show to talk about \xe2\x80\x9cthe tragedy in Peshawar.\xe2\x80\x9d It fell to my sister, who still lives in Pakistan, where we both grew up, to explain what that meant: the massacre of schoolchildren by the Taliban. When I next picked up \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick,\xe2\x80\x9d that evening, all I could see in it was Ahab, the fanatic, infecting his crew with his vengeful, suicidal madness. In what world of enchantment had I been sailing that allowed me to read \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d without seeing a reflection of the blood-soaked world in which we live?'b'The West African 'b'Ebola'b' outbreak first hit Sierra Leone in May 2014, followed by an explosion of cases in the capital Freetown in the autumn. The epidemic now counts more than 10,500 cases across Sierra Leone, with signs that the spread is slowing.'b'The early days of the crisis were characterized by a sense of immense fear, anxiety and alarm, regionally and globally. In Sierra Leone, a three-day, countrywide, military-led lockdown in September fed the fear in West Africa and beyond. Many flights originating in unaffected African countries were restricted. African students were prevented from attending some American schools, and there were countless reports of discrimination against Africans across the globe. Pictures of health workers in full protective suits became a ubiquitous symbol of the panic.'b'Misleading reports, speculation and poor projections from international agencies, government ministries and the media about the Ebola outbreak exacerbated the problem. The fear that was spread by the dramatic reports that accentuated the negative, undermined confidence, made it harder to encourage people to seek care, and misdirected attention away from Sierra Leone\xe2\x80\x99s urban areas, where data suggest the economic effects of Ebola have been concentrated.'b'Valid, credible and timely data is essential during a global crisis. Without reliable data, efforts to assist affected people and to rebuild damaged communities can be misdirected and inefficient.'b'An early example of how data were presented misleadingly was the 'b'World Health Organization'b'\xe2\x80\x99s choice to report from April through August that the death rate from Ebola was \xe2\x80\x9cup to 90 percent,\xe2\x80\x9d when the actual death rate of this outbreak from confirmed cases, even in the early days in March 2014 in Guinea, was about 70 percent \xe2\x80\x94 still hardly reassuring, but better than almost-certain death. Warning people of likely death is not a good way to encourage them to seek care.'b'Both the W.H.O. and the 'b'Centers for Disease Control and Prevention'b' misjudged how the disease would evolve. Initially slow to appreciate the severity of the outbreak, the W.H.O. and the C.D.C. subsequently overestimated likely cases. The C.D.C. projected that up to 1.4 million people in Liberia and Sierra Leone could be infected by January 2015. (As of Jan. 27, 19,140 cases have been reported across the two countries.)'b'Inaccurate and implausible claims about the economic impact further reduced the public\xe2\x80\x99s confidence, which had its own economic consequences.'b'For example, in August, a senior Sierra Leonean government official was reported as saying his country\xe2\x80\x99s Gross Domestic Product had fallen by 30 percent, a figure that was implausible considering the crisis was only a few months old and that even during Sierra Leone\xe2\x80\x99s devastating civil war real G.D.P. fell only by an average of 5 percent a year.'b'In October, the World Bank estimated that the costs associated with Ebola for West Africa as a whole may be as high as $32.6 billion, an estimate that was revised down this month to be at most $6 billion. When the public anticipates bad times, they cut back on discretionary purchases and save more, compounding the effects of the shock.'b'Meanwhile, the local and international press was full of reports of skyrocketing 'b'food prices'b', while surveys undertaken by the International Growth Center and Innovations for Poverty Action of markets across Sierra Leone (conducted monthly from August through December 2014) showed food prices in line with previous years.'b'One problem with doomsday scenarios is that when reliable data is finally released \xe2\x80\x94 as they were this month \xe2\x80\x94 the real figures can seem small and insignificant relative to earlier predictions.'b'They are not. In Sierra Leone, the urban areas in particular have been badly hit. The percentage of household heads \xe2\x80\x9cnot working in the previous week\xe2\x80\x9d rose from 25 percent in July/August to 33 percent in November. This reduction in employment is taking place in one of the poorest countries in the world with few formal safety nets. Just over a quarter of household heads work in non-farm household enterprises in which revenues are down by 40 percent over this period, and the six-month failure rate of these businesses tripled.'b'The informal economy is particularly vulnerable to the fear that is stoked by bad data. When the future is uncertain people cut back on small luxuries like purchasing snacks on the street or having their hair done, yet these discretionary purchases are the mainstay of the non-farm enterprise sector. This sector has also been hit badly by government restrictions on transportation, markets, bars and restaurants.'b'Why were projections so bad? Partly because it is hard to collect good data in a crisis. But also, we believe, because dramatic headlines make for a better story. Agencies face asymmetric incentives: They are likely to face more criticism for underestimating rather than overestimating the impact of an emergency. As they scramble to raise funding for a crisis in a world grown weary of alarm calls, the temptation is to focus on the upper range of plausible estimates.'b'But collectively focusing on worst-case scenarios can make people fatalistic, damaging efforts to prevent the disease from spreading. It also has a negative effect on the economy and makes it harder for those seeking to raise money for future crises. Independent data sources and assessments are vital to our understanding of and response to the crisis.'b'There is real suffering in Sierra Leone today and a lot the international community can do, but we need to be clear- sighted and levelheaded about the problems if we are to help effectively.'b'A drone crashed 'b'into the White House lawn'b' early Monday.'b'A secretive group met behind closed doors in New York this week. What they decided may lead to higher drug prices for you and hundreds of millions around the world.'b'Representatives from the United States and 11 other Pacific Rim countries convened to decide the future of their trade relations in the so-called Trans-Pacific Partnership (T.P.P.). Powerful companies appear to have been given influence over the proceedings, even as full access is withheld from many government officials from the partnership countries.'b'Among the topics negotiators have considered are some of the most contentious T.P.P. provisions \xe2\x80\x94 those relating to intellectual property rights. And we\xe2\x80\x99re not talking just about music downloads and pirated DVDs. These rules could help big pharmaceutical companies maintain or increase their monopoly profits on brand-name drugs.'b'The secrecy of the T.P.P. negotiations makes them maddeningly opaque and hard to discuss. But we can get a pretty good idea of what\xe2\x80\x99s happening, based on documents obtained by WikiLeaks from past meetings (they began in 2010), what we know of American influence in other trade agreements, and what others and myself have gleaned from talking to negotiators.'b'Trade agreements are negotiated by the office of the United States Trade Representative, supposedly on behalf of the American people. Historically, though, the trade representative\xe2\x80\x99s office has aligned itself with corporate interests. If big pharmaceutical companies hold sway \xe2\x80\x94 as the leaked documents indicate they do \xe2\x80\x94 the T.P.P. could block cheaper generic drugs from the market. Big Pharma\xe2\x80\x99s profits would rise, at the expense of the health of patients and the budgets of consumers and governments.'b'There are two ways the office of the trade representative can use the T.P.P. to maintain or raise drug prices and profits.'b'The first is to restrict competition from generics. It\xe2\x80\x99s axiomatic that more competition means lower prices. When companies have to fight for customers, they end up cutting their prices. When a patent expires, any company can enter the market with a generic version of a drug. The differences in prices between brand-name and generic drugs are mind- and budget-blowing. Just the availability of generics drives prices down: In generics-friendly India, for example, Gilead Sciences, which makes an effective hepatitis-C drug, recently announced that it would sell the drug for a little more than 1 percent of the $84,000 it charges here.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why, since the United States opened up its domestic market to  generics in 1984, they have grown from 19 percent of prescriptions to 86 percent, by some accounts saving the United States government, consumers and employers more than $100 billion a year. Drug companies stand to gain handsomely if the T.P.P. limits the sale of generics.'b'The second strategy is to undermine government regulation of drug prices. More competition is not the only way to keep down the prices of essential goods and services. Governments can also directly restrain prices through law, or effectively restrain them by denying reimbursement to patients for \xe2\x80\x9coverpriced\xe2\x80\x9d drugs \xe2\x80\x94 thus encouraging companies to bring down their prices to approved levels. These regulatory approaches are especially important in markets where competition is limited, as it is in the drug market. If the United States Trade Representative gets its way, the T.P.P. will limit the ability of partner countries to restrict prices. And the pharmaceutical companies surely hope the \xe2\x80\x9cstandard\xe2\x80\x9d they help set in this agreement will become global \xe2\x80\x94 for example, by becoming the starting point for United States negotiations with the European Union over the same issues.'b'Americans might shrug at the prospect of soaring drug prices around the world. After all, the United States already allows drug companies to charge what they want. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean we might not want to change things someday. Here again, the T.P.P. has us cornered: Trade agreements, and in particular individual provisions within them, are typically far more difficult to alter or repeal than  domestic laws.'b'We can\xe2\x80\x99t be sure which of these features have made it through this week\xe2\x80\x99s negotiations. What\xe2\x80\x99s clear is that the overall thrust of the intellectual property section of the T.P.P. is for less competition and higher drug prices. The effects will go beyond the 12 T.P.P. countries. Barriers to generics in the Pacific will put pressure on producers of such drugs in other countries, like  India, as well.'b'Of course, pharmaceutical companies claim they need to charge high prices to fund their research and development. This just isn\xe2\x80\x99t so. For one thing, drug companies spend more on marketing and advertising than on new ideas. Overly restrictive intellectual property rights actually slow new discoveries, by making it more difficult for scientists to build on the research of others and by choking off the exchange of ideas that is critical to innovation. As it is, most of the important innovations come out of our universities and research centers, like the National Institutes of Health, funded by government and foundations.'b'The efforts to raise drug prices in the T.P.P. take us in the wrong direction. The whole world may come to pay a price in the form of worse health and unnecessary deaths.'b''b'\n'b'Joseph E. Income should be documented in detail, including the amounts and the names of clients for legislators who are lawyers.'b''b'Campaign Finance'b''b'The charges against Mr. Silver make it scandalously clear how easy it is to buy influence in Albany. FLATOW'b' West Orange, N.J., Jan. 29, 2015'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Judges, With Hat in Hand'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 19) hit the core issue of why modest rules governing fund-raising for judicial elections are essential to preserve an independent and respected judiciary.'b'In recent years, the need for such rules has grown, as millions of dollars of laundered money flows into state supreme court elections from corporate treasuries, secretly passed through political committees and parties, hiding their identification.'b'The issue now before the United States Supreme Court is whether a judicial candidate can directly solicit funds in violation of state law. But urgently needed is disclosure of who is giving the money so that judges can be successfully petitioned to recuse themselves if a contributor has a case before the court, as Caperton v. A. T. Massey Coal (U.S. Supreme Court, 2009) requires.'b'An example is Justice Lloyd A. Karmeier of Illinois, who refused to recuse himself in a $10 billion Philip Morris case even though he got substantial support and dark money from Philip Morris\xe2\x80\x99s parent company, Altria, in two elections. We need additional requirements, not fewer, to assure the public\xe2\x80\x99s faith in our judiciary.'b'JOAN CLAYBROOK'b'\nWashington, Jan. 21, 2015'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is president emeritus of Public Citizen.'b''b'Mitt Romney is out! And we hardly had time to adjust to the idea that he was in.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve decided it is best to give other leaders in the party the opportunity to become our next nominee,\xe2\x80\x9d Romney said in one of the least private conference calls in the history of communication.'b'Well, that was certainly gracious. (This week on \xe2\x80\x9cAmazing America,\xe2\x80\x9d Sarah Palin visited Ted Nugent on his ranch in Texas. Celebrities just aren\xe2\x80\x99t what they used to be.)'b'So many candidates, but, sadly, very few good pet stories. The future holds no chances to point out that Romney once drove to Canada with the family Irish setter strapped to the roof of the station wagon. And the other animal options are pretty slim. Mike Huckabee used to fry squirrels in a popcorn popper, but that was back in college. Jeb Bush says he\xe2\x80\x99s very fond of manatees, though I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe he keeps one in his home.'b'Ted Cruz recently tweeted a picture of himself posing with what looked like a rug made from a dead, and endangered, tiger. Rand Paul confided to Vogue that he hates squirrels. Maybe we can get a squirrel theme going here.'b'But about Romney\xe2\x80\x99s dropout announcement. It was great, in the sense that within a few short minutes he managed to remind the world of everything that was terrible about Mitt Romney, Presidential Candidate.'b'Nobody was really expecting to have a Mitt conversation this year. 'b'He had famously told The Times\xe2\x80\x99s Ashley Parker'b' that his response to any thought of another presidential run was: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no, no. No, no, no, no, no. Romancing his old donors, reassembling his team, visiting the Republican National Committee. This week, he was at Mississippi State, tearing into Hillary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s foreign policy record and unveiling his new message about fighting income inequality. On Thursday, he was twittering a response to a jibe by the president. (\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Obama, wonder why my concern about poverty? The record number of poor in your term, and your record of failure to remedy.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'And then, on Friday, he dropped out of the race with a conference call to his supporters in which he insisted that he could win the nomination and bragged about polls that showed he was practically the only person in the race. (\xe2\x80\x9cOne poll out just today shows me gaining support and leading the next closest contender by nearly 2 to 1.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'Plus, Romney said, \xe2\x80\x9cI would have the best chance of beating the eventual Democratic nominee. ...\xe2\x80\x9d At this point, it seemed that he was going to have to announce that he had just discovered he only had six months to live. There was no other possible reason he could be depriving his party of all that presidential power.'b'But, no, Romney said he was making an abrupt U-turn because there might be somebody out there who was even more stupendous and he did not want to get in the way of said candidate\xe2\x80\x99s emergence.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s our Mitt. The man who dropped out of the race for the Republican nomination in 2008 not because he lost too many primaries, but because \xe2\x80\x9cI simply cannot let my campaign be a part of aiding a surrender to terror.\xe2\x80\x9d (That would be the Democratic Party.)'b'Romney has mutated a lot in the time we\xe2\x80\x99ve known him, but the one clear, shining quality that never wavers is his complete inability to make a strong, clear statement. This is the guy who tackled the critical issue of illegal immigration by promoting the concept of \xe2\x80\x9cself-deportation.\xe2\x80\x9d The man who, when confronted with the dog-on-the-roof saga, claimed that Seamus the setter \xe2\x80\x9clikes fresh air.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And, on Friday, Romney concluded his most recent change of course by predicting that people would ask him if he could ever possibly change his mind. The answer, he said, was: \xe2\x80\x9cThat seems unlikely.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Truly, if you follow up an eleven-no refusal to run with a sudden leap into the fray that does not even survive the month of January, the least you could do is tell your supporters this is absolutely the end of the line.'b'For all his faults, there are a lot of candidates in the Republican scrimmage who would make far worse presidents than Mitt Romney. Still, it\xe2\x80\x99s sort of a relief to see him go.'b'Although I will miss that dog story.'b'Under the guise of improving security, the Chinese government is clamping down on technology companies and further limiting the access its citizens have to information that is not sanitized by the Communist Party. These moves will hurt the Chinese economy and create a major rift between China and the rest of the world.'b'The government of President Xi Jinping has taken a series of steps recently that have unnerved businesses, human rights organizations and governments around the world. This week, for example, American and other foreign business groups 'b'sent a letter'b' to Mr. Xi protesting new policies that require companies that sell computer equipment to Chinese banks to turn over their source code to the government and to create ways for security officials to monitor and control those devices. Industry executives expect similar policies to be enacted for other sectors of the Chinese economy, making it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, for foreign technology vendors to sell their products to Chinese customers.'b'Chinese officials have also proposed a 'b'law'b', purportedly to fight terrorism, that would require technology companies to provide the government with the means to monitor all communications over their systems in China, including those that are encrypted. And in recent weeks, the authorities have made it nearly impossible for Internet users to employ 'b'virtual private networks'b' that allow people to evade the government filters and restrictions collectively known as the Great Firewall. Dissidents, researchers, businesses and professionals have long used V.P.N.s to access information beyond China\xe2\x80\x99s borders, and the government previously seemed to tolerate the practice.'b'With these new moves, Chinese leaders are trying to increase government control over communications in order to suppress dissent. And they are trying to promote Chinese technology businesses at the expense of foreign companies. That is not entirely surprising. Mr. Xi has previously made clear that he considers the free flow of information on the Internet a 'b'threat'b' to the Communist Party. And he'b' has said 'b'that he considers domestic control over technology a matter of \xe2\x80\x9cnational economic security, defense security and other aspects of security.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But this push for greater control could cost China dearly. The country\xe2\x80\x99s businesses and professionals say it has become increasingly difficult for them to communicate with customers and suppliers abroad or to obtain scientific data and research from the rest of the world. Executives at Chinese banks are reportedly worried that they will have to rely on substandard domestic computer equipment that could make their systems more vulnerable to hacking by criminals, foreign rivals and others.'b'Foreign businesses and governments are rightly saying these new policies amount to protectionism. The changes also seem to make a joke of China\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to abide by global trading rules established by the World Trade Organization and of its stated desire to deepen trade and investment ties with the United States and other countries. Officials from China and the United States are negotiating a 'b'bilateral investment treaty'b' that is supposed to make it easier for companies from each country to do business in the other nation. American officials should use those talks to put China on notice that its latest security policies are wrongheaded and unacceptable.'b'Mr. Xi cannot expect the United States or any other country to engage in negotiations to liberalize trade and investment with his country while his government is actively making it impossible for foreign businesses to survive there.'b'New York City\xe2\x80\x99s correction commissioner did the right thing this month when he 'b'fired a captain and five guards'b' who tied up and savagely beat an inmate at the Rikers Island jail complex in the spring of 2012. But the fact that it took nearly three years to dismiss the officers reveals \xe2\x80\x94 again \xe2\x80\x94 a disciplinary process badly in need of repair. It also underscores the need for the full-scale reforms that the Justice Department is seeking in federal court.'b'The case dates to April 2012, when the guards and the captain hogtied a mentally ill man named Robert Hinton and carried him by his arms and legs into a solitary confinement cell. He emerged with a fractured vertebra and a broken nose, his eyes swollen shut and blood streaming from his mouth. If ever there was a case that demanded swift resolution, this was it. But the department\xe2\x80\x99s internal investigations often move slowly, thanks to the immense power of the correction officers\xe2\x80\x99 union, which essentially runs the jail system.'b'The process is so drawn out that officers awaiting disciplinary action in one case can be implicated in another. Eight months after the Hinton case, the captain who has now been fired is said to have joined other officers in handcuffing two inmates to a gurney, wheeling them into an examination room beyond the view of security cameras and beating them savagely while horrified members of the medical staff pleaded with them to stop.'b'In the past, officers charged with brutality typically received suspensions, then returned to work. But in an unusual ruling last fall, an administrative law judge said that the miscarriage of justice in the 2012 case was so egregious that the six men involved should be fired. Unlike previous commissioners who sometimes dragged their feet, the current commissioner, Joseph Ponte, accepted that recommendation. Even so, the officers are free to appeal to the Civil Service Commission.'b'Mr. Ponte\xe2\x80\x99s prompt action is no doubt related to a 'b'pending federal class-action lawsuit'b', joined by the Justice Department last month, that charges the Correction Department with failing to discipline officers engaged in abuse. Any settlement of that suit must require the city to strengthen and streamline a clearly inadequate disciplinary system.'b''b''b"Editors' Note:"b''b''b''b'Joe Nocera\xe2\x80\x99s column on Saturday, about the arrest of the longtime New York State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, was premised on several factual errors.'b''b''b'The column misidentified the person who in 2008 placed Arthur Luxenberg, a lawyer who represents people exposed to asbestos, on a panel that recommends judicial appointments. It was Mr. Silver, not Jonathan Lippman, chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.'b''b''b'The column also suggested that Mr. Luxenberg\xe2\x80\x99s role on that panel resulted in the appointment of a judge, Sherry Klein Heitler, to lead New York City\xe2\x80\x99s dedicated asbestos court. In fact, the panel had no involvement in that appointment.'b''b''b'Finally, the column implied that Mr. Silver rewarded the judiciary with a pay increase. While Mr. Silver\xe2\x80\x99s appointee to a state commission on judicial pay did cast a deciding vote in 2011 for a pay raise, as the column noted, the appointee actually voted against an even greater pay increase favored by some members of the commission.'b''b''b'_____________'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe scandal isn\xe2\x80\x99t what\xe2\x80\x99s illegal,\xe2\x80\x9d goes one of Michael Kinsley\xe2\x80\x99s best-known sayings. \xe2\x80\x9cThe scandal is what\xe2\x80\x99s legal.\xe2\x80\x9d I offer you l\xe2\x80\x99affaire Sheldon Silver as a case in point.'b'Silver, who for two decades was the all-powerful speaker of the New York Assembly, was indicted last Thursday for 'b'a variety of alleged illegal actions'b'. Chief among them was his failure to list outside income on his financial disclosure forms, and his steering $500,000 from a state slush fund he controlled to a doctor who specialized in mesothelioma \xe2\x80\x94 a rare, deadly cancer \xe2\x80\x94 in return for client referrals. Silver says he\xe2\x80\x99ll be vindicated, but Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney who indicted him, has won the cooperation of a number of key participants, including said doctor, whose name is 'b'Robert Taub'b'. We\xe2\x80\x99ll return to him in a minute.'b'Despite the rather obvious potential for conflict of interest, it\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly legal for a New York legislator to earn outside income. Few took fuller advantage of this than Silver, who for more than a decade was paid millions of dollars by two law firms. One of them was Weitz &amp; Luxenberg, a big-time New York plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 firm that specializes in bringing lawsuits on behalf of people with mesothelioma, which results primarily from exposure to asbestos.'b'Though Silver is a lawyer, he knew nothing about asbestos litigation \xe2\x80\x94 nor did he ever do any actual lawyering for the firm. So what did he do? The firm now says it brought him on \xe2\x80\x94 at a base salary of $120,000 a year \xe2\x80\x94 purely to lend it prestige. But in truth, Silver did much more than that. As speaker of the Assembly he could ensure that the legislature did nothing to 'b'clip the wings of the plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 bar,'b' like setting a cap on damages.'b'He could also solicit client referrals, for which he would receive a piece of the action. This is where Taub comes in. Many doctors who specialize in mesothelioma have a pretty explicit tit-for-tat: They refer patients to firms that help fund their research. 'b'A legal bribe,'b' you might call it. Before Taub and Silver began doing business, the doctor asked for funding from Weitz &amp; Luxenberg. The firm said no. So instead, Silver instructed the Department of Health to make two $250,000 grants to fund Taub\xe2\x80\x99s research. (In a statement, Weitz &amp; Luxenberg said it had no knowledge of Silver\xe2\x80\x99s quid pro quo.)'b'When the grant money ran out, Taub began referring most of his patients to Simmons Hanly Conroy, a big asbestos firm in Illinois. But he still made the occasional referral to Weitz &amp; Luxenberg to curry favor with Silver. In return, Silver got Taub\xe2\x80\x99s son a job, and directed $25,000 in state funds to his wife\xe2\x80\x99s charity. Perfectly legal.'b'There is one other thing Silver could do for Weitz &amp; Luxenberg. He could help make sure that the New York judiciary would look favorably on asbestos cases. The chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, Jonathan Lippman, is a childhood friend of Silver\xe2\x80\x99s. And, in 2008, Lippman placed Silver\xe2\x80\x99s good friend Arthur Luxenberg \xe2\x80\x94 yes, the same Luxenberg who was paying Silver $120,000, plus referral fees \xe2\x80\x94 on a committee that recommends judicial appointments. Six months later, a judge named Sherry Klein Heitler was assigned to lead New York City\xe2\x80\x99s dedicated asbestos court.'b'Defense lawyers say that since then, the asbestos court has become the plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 bar\xe2\x80\x99s best friend. Prior to Heitler\xe2\x80\x99s appointment, the court had deferred punitive damages claims indefinitely for the sensible reason that since companies stopped making asbestos products decades earlier there was no behavior to correct. But after Weitz &amp; Luxenberg requested that this deferral be lifted, Heitler brought punitive damages back. Mesothelioma cases that had very little in common were consolidated, which pressured defendant companies to settle and, when they didn\xe2\x80\x99t, could lead to huge jury awards. 'b'According to a 2013 report by the American Tort Reform Association,'b' the average jury award for an asbestos claim in New York City since 2007 is $21.7 million. That is \xe2\x80\x9croughly seven times the $3.1 million average award in courts throughout the rest of New York State.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And no firm has had more success than Weitz &amp; Luxenberg. According to the economic consulting firm Bates White, it handles some 53 percent of the city\xe2\x80\x99s mesothelioma filings. The court itself acknowledged Weitz &amp; Luxenberg cases take precedence over others. It has also won the most money. In July 2013, it won $190 million for five plaintiffs, the most awarded in a New York City asbestos case.'b'Weitz &amp; Luxenberg insists that the judiciary treats everyone fairly, and that it reaps the biggest awards because it does the best job. That may be so. But it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t hurt that Silver also played an important role in setting judicial pay, and that in 2011 his commission appointee 'b'cast the deciding vote'b' in getting the state judges a 27 percent raise.'b'Which, of course, is perfectly legal.'
